  005027440012F8CC8825650700143DC6; Wed,  3 Sep 97 01:45:43 
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: "nathan.b.beckord" <nathan.b.beckord@ArthurAndersen.com>
Date:  2 Sep 97 22:36:17 
Subject: Una Mas Burning Man Chronicle (looong)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Exec Summary:another Burning Man survived, with all limbs and 86% of my brain 
cells intact.  Not too shabby.



Long Version: (caveat-- this is a long-assed essay) Wednesday began at 8:30 am 
running around doing errands, stopping at toys r us, circuit city, goodwill, 
home depot, trader joes, and several friends' houses for 'other' supplies.  
Picked up the rental van, and finally got on the road 12 hours later.  Reno at 
midnight, where the trip was partially paid for by generous quarter video 
poker. Last meal of cheap casino steak and lobster at 2am, then final shower 
the next morning. 

We got to the site shortly after noon, and helped setup the camp, which was 
called Windy City, as we built a big windmill and had some homemade landsailers 
and such.  Met our really cool neighbors, at Yukon __'s Antarctic freeze zone 
(they had a wading pool filled with this weird gelatin-like stuff), then headed 
to Bianca's smut shack for some cheap thrills and dayglo nail polish. 

Friday was spent checking out all the fab camps, the Man, and relaxing in 
beanbags while watching folx stroll along the playa. At night, we rode around 
on bicycles intoxicated, as it really doesn't hurt much to fall down and crash 
on the Playa.  A high point was finding the field of  small speakers mounted on 
3-ft high posts, each one playing a different sound, such as doors creaking, 
race cars, chain saws, birds chirping, etc.  As you walked around, the sounds 
faded into one another, very surreal sensory experience with stars overhead and 
the desert stretched out in front.  Then hit the Black Light camp for some 
boogying, decent happy hardcore and techno classics.  

Saturday someone in our group came up with the idea to change the theme of our 
camp to the Shave and Shot camp (wasn't much wind anyhow).  Our lovely Liz  
(who incidentally is pictured in tuesday's Chronicle article on Bman) performed 
approximately 30 nude head shaves and mohawks, as well as numerous chest, back, 
leg, kootch, and pube trims (sorry, couldn't thnk of a polite way to phrase it 
;->)  By the end, we had a couple pounds of hair in a pile on the ground, which 
made for scented burning later on.  

After a martini hour at sunset,  I through on the furr shorts and velour shirt 
and went with my neighbor for her confession and paddling at the Temple of 
Atonement-- I guess she'd had 'impure thoughts' earlier that day.  We then 
checked out the Ishtar opera, which was a little less intense than last year's 
(remember?  "fire at night, Devil's delight!"), and that damn tower wouln't 
burn down.  But still an interesting performance, with all the fire twirlers on 
stilts, etc.  Then we checked out some goa and then the techno camp near the 
NubChai decorated school bus, then some mellowness at Biancas, while a 
neghboring camp with loud speakers played the soundtrack to the Wizard of Oz. 

Sunday, the big day.  More shaving to salsa music, art car tourings, ice 
sculpture licking, etc.  The sun set and there was a palpable, powerful 
electric energy in the air as people psyched up for the Burn. With a change of 
clothes into silver pants silver shirt, silver glasses, candy rings, much 
glitter, and a silver prism tophat with pink flamingo on top, then a gulp and 
swallow, my mood for the evening was appropriately set. We set off to witness 
the spectacle. Fire twirlers swirled, then a guy set himself completely on fire 
and ran around under then Man.  The Man caught fire, the purple and green neon 
lights popped, fireworks shot out of his head and mid torso, then he fell.  
Chaos erupted as everyone began dancing around the fallen effigy, chanting scre
aming and cheering.  This eventually gave way to several intense drum circles 
centered around burning piles of hay bales.  I immediately got seperated from 
my crew, which was both good and weird.  Hours later, I needed to chill out, so 
I headed out into the desert a ways and looked back.  Quite a site, with fires 
blazing all over the playa, fireworks and flares going off, and people in their 
wildest costumes running and jumping around in a pagan-like bliss. 

Finally, I headed back into camp, and saw some crazy circus, Juicy Danger or 
something.  The guy carved up an apple held in his assistant's mouth with a 
chain saw, then juggled an egg, bowling ball, and the (still-running) chain 
saw.  Then he balanced a running lawn mower on his chin while audience members 
tossed in soggy heads of lettuce.  Vegetarian cowboy with a whip show, and 
female all-star wrestling were other shows.  After the show, I somehow ended up 
following along with the mobile death-machine flamethrower, looking for things 
to burn down.  They tied a big balloon up 30 feet in the air, cranked the 
muzzle, and fired off a stream of glowing flame that blew up the balloon, Then, 
it headed out to the Goa camp, cranked up the muzzle again, and for several 
tense minutes, the fire-dripping barrel was pointed straight at the DJ (Gil? ) 
I don't know how he continued playing with that thing staring him straght in 
the face, dripping fire,  but eventually the machine backed up and left.  I 
stayed, and danced a bit, then went over to watch as a four-story structure 
surrounding a huge metal skeleton-man burned down around him.  Someone was 
yanking on a rope attached to the metal-man's unit, trying to pull him down. 
Out of the blue another guy came running, and body-checked the yanker off his 
feet to the ground. Weird.  

I headed back into town, danced at the Black light camp, then wandered into a 
parachute tent with a flashing green light and good music.  A girl in 
pippi-longstocking garb was dancing, then suddenly started doing these wild 
body-contortions, rolls and spider-jumps. A few djembe drummers wandered in, as 
did a saxaphonist, and they all jammed along as the dj  played wicked music 
that sounded like someone laughing maniacally.

After the groove slowed, I headed back out to the Goa camp to finish off the 
night.   The Goa camp was a sight to see-- a two story pyramid structure, with 
4 massive stacks of speakers draped with psychedelic tapestries and illuminated 
with blacklights..  The DJ (I guess it was Goa Gil, although I didn't know at 
the time) led the group from above with hard fast goa, as crazy psychedelic 
videos played non-stop behind him.  I moved out to dance around one of the 
fires, while facing the stage.  I turned around to see purple light rising from 
mountains, which faded slowly into pinks and reds.  At this point, I headed 
back to my camp to wake my conspirators.  We left at 7, and made it back to SF 
around 1, filthy, sweaty (those silver vinyl pants and shirt allow NO moisture 
out  ;P ) burned and bedraggled, but all told I'd do it again in a heartbeat.  


----'s:
-more gawkers this year
-too many yahoos with still and video cameras running around just watchin
-fucking police helicopters flying around camp all the time
-constantly breathing dust

+++'s: 
+ incredible desert sunsets
+fireworks 
+fire
+excellent music coming from all over, all the time 
+unique freedom to do what you want
+ultimate collection of artists, musicians, weirdos, and freaks ever assembled

Burn baby Burn, 
Nathan

>> Date: Tue Sep 02 14:16:27 PDT 1997
>> From: macadio6@rocketmail.com
>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org 
>> Subject: BUZZ-N- (Rewindview)(Longish)

>> Hey Kids..
>> 
>> Well Saturday was a blast the long awaited Megga Buzz happened. It 
was
>> kewl Me and my trusty side kick Vertigo got off to a late start we
>> were running on Raver time. I wanted to get to the party kind of 
early
>> but I did not set my alarm and was like sleeping till 12:00 am. Could
>> it be cause I stayed up all night and most of the day on Friday for
>> the @spire party? Hmm... Ne-Wayz so me and Verts head out Making pit
>> stops on our way we make it to the party and are gretted by heat as 
we
>> walk in the door. it was hot and there were plenty of Folks walking
>> around some smilling some laughing some looking confused. the place
>> was set up nice I like lasers and visual thingies. The DJ's that I 
did
>> get to hear were throwind down. I got to hear Simon I have not heard
>> him in like a year or two and he was working the decks with some
>> progressive house. DRC was laying down some fierce Tekno traXX She
>> looked cute too like princess lia with a hair cut real short. She had
>> on the black suit that they wore in return of the Jedi. I and Vertigo
>> had a real good time we were a little nervous cause we did not get to
>> practice that much due to prior engagments so most of it was just off
>> the head. We got a lot of positive reinforcment from Friends and some
>> people that I had never met before. I Thank all you that came out to
>> support us. I would Like to Thank Vlad as well for giving me the
>> chance to display my talents to the masses. 
>> 
>> 
>> Highlights:
>> 
>> all the young beautiful ladies giving me smooches while I was 
playing.
>> 
>> The big laser that spelled out "Macadio & Vertigo" I always wanted to
>> see my name in lights or in this case Lasers.
>> 
>> The guy that grabbed my Ankle as I walked by and said that we
>> "floored" him it looked like he was having a good timEE 
>> 
>> The cute girl that asked my Name and looked very interested, but I 
was
>> to shy or was it to busy spinning?
>> 
>> Getting to play a good set with my Boy Vertigo!!! You go boy you know
>> your Ruff...

>> I love all of you Thanks for the Postive Energy!!!

>Everyone,
>
>I didn't get much time to see too many DJs ( I'll make sure to
>give support next time) so I'll cut to the record chase.
>
>There are certain instances in life when the energy becomes
>one and things just begin to happen. the Energy given by the
>folks in the crowd (you know who you are) trancended the music
>to spiritual levels. This is what Love does. there was Great
>love in that room, and I thank everyone. 
>
>Macadio...Thanks for leading me with your experience, patience
>and will. You truly led the set with Domination. 
>
>Oh...BTW.. I had my first proposal by some mysterious woman
>while we spun. I had to turn her down. You guys and the music
>are the most important thing in this scene. With the vibe you
>brought, it was multiplied. I've never felt it like this before.
>Sooo....Let's Make More!
>
>					VERTIGO

>Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

>
>ok guys... here's the scoop, but before I begin, I want to appologize 
to
>macadio, dan (micron), carlos (pistachio), terrac, todd manley, jeff 'n
>ari, and anyone who wasn't able to have a good time.
>
>quick summary:
> location had a cop sitting in front of it. =(
> cop leaves. =)
> we set-up. =I
> party's going strong! =)
> genny craps out! =(
> genny get's going! =)
> I get sick. =(
> genny's outta gas! =(
> genny get's fed! =)
> all in all the party people had a great time! =)
>
>lesson learned! get a damn good generator!
>
>ok.... the story. it all started with a precision plan and a lot of
>faith. the plan was to get it all going by 11pm, but it didn't get 
going
>till 1am. now the reasons this all happened. the day of the party I 
went
>to get the genny, but my friends credit card was declined, and because
>of that, we barely got a generator. They gave us a real shitty one
>because we didn't have any kind of deposit. We all meet up at the map
>point to discuss the plan and go over how the setup was going to 
happen.
>Now if it all went smoothly we would of been setup way sooner than 1am,
>but things weren't so smooth. People helping out kinda took some of the
>plan as a joke and were in disbeliefe at some of the things we had to 
do
>to get this party rolling. So I kinda worked around those ideas and 
just
>winged it. (I will NEVER do that again). We head down to the location 
to
>set-up, and uh oh..... po po sitting there. At first we thought someone
>tipped off the police about the location, but we hoped to gawd that he
>was just checking for speeders. As we scrambled a plan for back-up
>locations, we positioned someone near the location with a cell phone to
>watch the cop. 30 mins later we get a call saying that the cop was
>leaving, but it kinda looked like he might come back. I pause to think
>for a sec, and say, "fuck it! I have a good feeling about this, let's
>use the location!" so  I send two trucks down to unload and tell them 
to
>call me when they've unloaded so that the second two could come unload.
>I never get the call.... so the second load heads over to see what
>happened. We don't see the first group anywhere! I run down to the
>actual spot we were going to use and don't see anyone. I run all the 
way
>back  to find them back at the top! I had no idea where they were or
>came from, and didn't have time to ask. We jump on the setup and get
>moving. I had no idea that the trek to the spot would be so bad with
>equipment. (thank  you guys that helped out!) they finally get going 
and
>set up, and I take off to check the ticket take, check point, and map
>point to make sure everything was going ok. Everything was going great.
>Sound starts thumping, people started dancing, and everything was going
>great. Then the genny started giving us major problems. It also was
>about to run out of gas. So I take off to go get gas and by the time I
>got back to the top of the hill, I could barely function anymore. I had
>only gotten 15 hours of sleep durring the week (w/o drugs), and just
>over did it that night with all the stress, running up and down the 
hill
>5 times, and not drinking any water. I drove to the map point and had
>the kids there go get the gas and take it back. From that point on I
>don't know what happened with the party. I had no other choice to try
>and recooperate, so that I could help with clean up in the morning. 
What
>I heard was that the vast majority of the party peoples there had a
>really good time and even when the music went out, they were still
>having fun talking and meeting people. Regardless of that, I am sorry
>for all the problems experienced. I, myself, am really upset with what
>happened. I don't want you guys to have to make the best of it to have 
a
>good time, I want it to be where you have no choice but to have a good
>time!
>
>                                                                my
>sincere appologies,
>
>just jer - @spire
>
>Thanks to all who came out and supported us and the scene once again,
>all of you kids were great! Thanx to all who helped out in any way, big
>or small. Thanks to all the dj's who spun out. And special thanx to 
Jeff
>and Ari, without them, we almost didn't have the heart thumpin' bass,
>thanx guys!
>
>once again... I'm sorry!
>
>?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?
>?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?
>?   ps. I promise you guys, the indoor! =) the indoor! =) just wait
>'till the indoor! =)  ?
>?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?
>?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?    ?
>

Hey, did anybody see the Burning Man segment on the 10 o'clock news on
Channel 2.  I did.  It was pretty cool.  They didn't make out to look
like it was for extreme freaks and weirdos.  Instead they gave a fairly
unbaised look at the activities that were happening n'Stuff.  It was
pretty damn trippy looking.  I mean I'm a pretty fucking weird kid and
all (you have to know me personally to understand) but I still have to
say that that party looks hella ODD.  It's cool though because it's that
kind of eccentricism that keeps our generation (not that other
generations aren't involved) vibrant.  We (in terms of general society)
should praise this kind of eccentrism and encourage it more often instead
of trying to repress it.

I don't know, just my random thoughts on the beauty of being strange.

Bye for now.

dErEk

There will be a rally to protest the logging of the Headwaters Forest on
September 14 in Carlotta (Humboldt County)

Some of the people from the Community organization here will be chartering
a bus (probably a Green Tortoise bus, which are lots of fun to ride in, and
have sleeping facilities..!) to go up there on the 13th..  It will be a lot
of fun, a chance to participate in a very good cause.. and pretty
inexpensive... (probably around $20-30 person..for two days..) The area is
gorgeous.. (along the Avenue of the Giants)  Contact the organizers at
(415) 487-6327 (voicemail) if you are interested..

 When redwoods are cut, it's a tragedy for the whole human race, since some
of these trees are over 2000 years old..

Log the profiteers, not the trees!

Date: Wed, 03 Sep 1997 01:10:01 +0000
From: "Kenneth Sol (Wish)" <mel_h@pacbell.net>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.02E-PBME (Macintosh; U; PPC)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: A Sad Goodbye
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,

	Well, it's finally happening...After a year and a half, over 70 
consecutive Wednesday night parties, and over 50 different dj's from 
all around, we are throwing our last Wish Wednesday, next Wednesday 
September 10th.  

	Unfortunately, this is not by choice...We have lost our space to a 
much bigger entity from outside of the bay area, who have a lot more 
money to spend on full page ads in magazines, and promote to all the 
people we never needed to because our family grew on word of mouth 
only.  Not only that, but we just found out ourselves this last 
weekend from other sources, so we're really in shock too. 
	
	It was never easy throwing a small, intimate 18 and over weekly in 
San Francisco, but because of all of you who had supported us, we 
found the love and energy we needed to keep it going.  But, these next 
two weeks are going to be our hardest yet...

	Tonight, Wednesday September 3rd, MARS & Mystr-E of Frequency 8 will 
be playing for the last time at Wish.  We really hope that all of our 
family can make it out to party with us and enjoy their amazing trance 
sound.

	Next week, we are working on putting together something we hope will 
be a very special evening for all of who can make it.  We have made a 
lot of good friends in the dance community over the last year and a 
half, and most will be able to make it out to help celebrate our 
transition to something new.

	Is this the last you'll be seeing of Wish?  Well, it's hard to say 
right now.  It's time to take a quick break and rethink what we really 
want to happen for Wish in the future...We are already talking about 
what we can do to get all of us back together again, so who knows...

	So, please come down to Wish at Big Heart City, (836 Mission St, SF) 
one last time, and play in the black lights with us...we'll be seeing 
you soon.

	Much love, and respect...

The Wish Crew  :-)

Has anybody read the new XLR8R cover story on graffiti?  Does anyone
realize how destructive this article is to our scene?  This is one of
the most thoughtless forms of industry sabatage that I have ever scene. 
Maybee im over-reacting, but its just that genecide makes me nervous.

I encourage everyone to read the artice and send your opinions to
XLR8R.  The attatched is the leter that I sent them.  Please read, and
give me your feedback.  

Keep it real...

Vlad.



Dear Editorial Staff at XLR8R:

	Firstly, I would like to say that the following comments are private,
and are NOT to be published publicly in your magazine.   The last time I
E-Mailed my comment to you they were published in your letters section
after being edited. DO NOT DO THIS AGAIN!

	I would like to thank you on your wonderful Cover story on Graffiti. 
You and your magazine have once again shown that you have no clue as to
whats happening in the scene.   Myself, as well as every other Rave
promoter have put hundreds of hours of work into trying to minimize the
impact of Tagging and Stickering as well as all other destructive
vandalism at the parties, raves and clubs in the Bay Area.   And just as
our efforts start to pay off, and tagging at events is down, your
Informative (not) Magazine comes out with an entire cover story
dedicated to glorifying and encouraging this disrespectful form of
negative egotistical vandalism.   
	Over the last 6 months, the amount of tagging has been reduced, and has
become less and less visible.  Nor has tagging ever been directly
associated with raving.  But your magazine (which is directly associated
with raving) has made a direct connection between tagging and raving,
and will encourage more tagging at raves.   
If you think I am over-reacting than you should see the damage after the
party that we just had, Megga-Buzz-Mania, on this Labor Day, We had more
tagging than weve seen at our last 4 parties combined.  We had tagging
on the speakers, generator, walls, bathroom, floor, banners and every
where else.   I contribute this increase directly to your magazine.  It
came out only ONE week before our event.  Thank you for encouraging
negative behavior at a time when positive role modeling is so important
to help the misguided youth in our society find something to identify
with.  
Graffiti is an art-form.  But your article did not Do it any justice AT
ALL!  Instead you brought it down to a lower level by assimilating it
with tagging. which has no artistic value whatsoever.   You made it
sound like it was "all-good", and fun.  Well in this scene it isnt. 
But then again, what do you really know about this scene.
	Your magazine has done a grave injustice to our scene, and the effects
of your article will be felt for a long time, by all promoters in this
industry.  Venues and equipment will be tagged, and owners of facilities
will not want their locations used for rave events, and promoters will
have to charge higher admission to cover the excessive security,
cleaning, painting and damage expenses with every event.  Nobody wins,
especially the Ravers.  Thank you for being so considerate to the
promoters that place ads in your magazine to advertise their events. 
Im sure that they really appreciate all the extra money you will cost
them.  Maybe in the future, your magazine would consider glorifying
Gang-Rape, excessive drug use, or unsafe sex I am sure those would make
excellent cover stories to follow your trend of encouraging
communication and glorifying negative psychotic behavior in our
society.  Keep up the Positive work. NOT!

Vlad
Feel Good Entertainment

From: Lee Fogel <lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: BM rave review
Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.90.970903144833.7469A-100000@pbssi>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

There was some concern this year about the Burning Man organizers copping
an ant-rave attitude.  Sound systems were to be limited to a wimpy 300W.
After much negotiations, our camp (Temporary Astonishment Zone) was given
official permission to bring in a moderately sized system (a combo of
Rob Rayle's and Ran D. Dream's equipment.)  One thing we did to help
control the noise was to haul out an 8 foot wall made of bales of hay to
buffer the sound system from the campsites.  This cost us an extra $600,
but if it means that medium-sized sound systems will be tolerated at 
future BMs, then it was well worth it.

There were a quite a few other smaller systems scattered around, and of 
course there was the "community dance" quitely advertised for the main 
BM stage further out on the Playa for Sunday night.  

For me, this resulted in four consecutive nights of great raving.  
Thursday nite, the TAZ system featured Rob Rayle spinning CDs along with
some tasteful keyboard work for an enthusiastic little crowd.  I wandered
back and forth between Rob's Goa set and another site that featured 
house music.  Of course, you have to be an idiot to go to Burning Man
just to rave, but as long as you decide not to sleep much there was
plenty of time for everything.

Unlike last year, everything was pretty close together so you could 
wander on foot, returning at will to a choice of small intimate
rave sites.  I think there were a lot of converts; one camp had a nice 
party going with an enthusiastic bunch of raver-hicks all wearing cowboy 
hats, jumping up&down, whooping it up.

Wandering around all the campsites, I was struck by how much good music
there was.  Prodominantly techno/house/dub/ambient.  If it wasn't for the 
fact that this was Burning Man I would have concluded that all the music  
I love had become totally mainstream.  Of course there was also some 
rock, hip hop, punk, and noise distortion.  I also heard pop music mixed 
with video game sound effects, and a smattering of retro dylan/Greatful 
Dead/etc.  It was fun to hear all the campsite systems overlaying each
other into a thick musical collage.

On Friday, Rob, Niels, myself and Troy finally got our Drum Machine Circle
going.  What a blast!  Sounded like a mess most of the time, but there
were some fairly decent moments.  After the sun set, the TAZ system again
pumped out rave sounds with Niels started off with some acid house.  Keep
practicing Niels! :)  Later it was Tom doing the Goa thing with Rob 
supplying some occassional keyboards and sound effects.  They drew a great 
crowd of about 100 that was totally into it.  We had a really nice setup;
Ran D. had brought a bunch of excellent lighting effects.  We also had a 
ton of blinking Xmas lights, black lights, a strobe, and a projection
screen with slides, and some nice banners.

Saturday night's music began with Ran D. (Dionysis Dreams) doing an
ambient set, which led into a really cool middle eastern dance thing that
drew an interesting bunch of dancers.  Sometime later I was about to go
to sleep, but somehow ended back at the sound system where Rob Rayle was
DJing naked, with everyone going nuts.  I blinked my eyes a couple of
times when it looked like he was actually playing keyboards with his
penis - talk about wanking on your instrument!  But it was just
one of my many BM hallucinations.  Later Tom took over and went on
into the morning, I don't quite remember when I passed out.

Sunday, after the burn, was, according to the published schedule, a 
"community dance".  From what I was told by a BM promoter, the local 
Sheriff's dept had explicitly demanded that there be no "raves", so 
instead we had an official full on killer "community dance".  Whatever! 
As reported, Goa Gil kicked our asses with 6 hour set, preceeded by a 
semi-live CCC set with Adam Om.  I didn't think I would have the energy 
to dance for more than an hour, but the vibe was so thick and the music 
so intense that I managed to dance for 5 or 6.  It was an incredible 
group of freaks, freaking out, dancing, trancing by the stage and around
the fires in the middle of the desert.  Even Goa Gil himself stepped back 
at one point and danced during his set.  Never saw him do that before.

I think this BM was a great success for integrating raving with the event,
without turning BM into a giant rave.  Despite the focus of this report,
I did do a lot more than raving, really getting to experience the best
of many worlds for an absolutely crazy and wonderful time!

Lee
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.org
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

	Hey, are any of you out there into making dance oriented music yourselves?
 If so, I'd like to start a band.  I play the MC-303, which is one of the
ultimate drum machines/acid groover emitters.  But I also play the pc, but
I kind of think it's cheating as far as a performance art, but I do use it
as a sampler.

	I can take it all the way up to jungle (although I specialize in electro)
but the high tempo doesn't give it much time to think (which limits the
amount of sound I can put out on the other tracks) so I need some
accompaniment.  And to make a jungle beat significantly interesting (ie:
tricky) I usually use all 8 tracks just on drums.

	Totally into the live thing too.  Improvise.

	Basically I just wanna jam.

ps - Oh yeah, I can read/write sheet music, know all about keys, etc, and I
also sing kind of like Shabba Ranks (not words, just beats).

> so, just what is the average age of sfravers?

I don't know. I've been out several times to more massive related events
(Jauggernaut, Spundaes, etc.) and it seems to me that if I had to guess it's
probably around 20 to 23 median age.
There are times though when I start feeling a little old tho...


> maybe i have a better chance of fittin' in?  well?

I hope so considering I'm 28 and don't think of myself as out-moded. In fact,
I'd like to think that I'm one of those people that provides a sense of
history and "institutionalized" memory for the rave scene. Being a former DJ
and being sucked in back about '91 (LA - Beej, Sean Perry, shit like that -
Happy Wednesdays, etc.) I feel like I can have that long view where there may
be none. Anyway, that's just MHO.

my philosophy on what a breakbeat is:

the bass is the man
the snare is the woman

they bounce back and forth:

boom - bip
boom boom - bip

how they dance depends on their relationship, how they feel about
eachother, sexual prowess, etc..

the cymbals and hi-hats are drugs they add that extra sparkle (this I'm not
so sure about yet... I think they might be something deeper... any
guesses?)

From: drek1@juno.com (Derek J Fieldsoe)

Actually, you're not.  When these constellations were first observed 2000
years ago, then everything we know about astrology would be correct. 
However, when the earth revolves around the sun and rotates, it also
wobbles like a top would if you spun it.  Because of this wobbling, we,
2000 years later, see the same constellations as the Greeks or whoever
did except that they are now in different locations in the sky.  So this
whole time while you thought the constellation Scorpious was behind the
sun on the date of your birth, the actual constellation behind the sun
was really Libra. 

Therefore you are truly and scientifically proven to be Libra.  Sorry if
that pisses you off or I'm glad to please you if  you feel better about
this.

See you later alligator.

dErEk

That's cool.  I'm not telling you have to believe it but you should keep
in mind that this new chart was proven by careful scientific observations
over the past 50 years.  This shit is fo' sho' correct.  I'm merely an
unbiased source of information.  :o)

But you know, in the end, it's probably best to just let life go by and
not to try and get an idea of how it's going to be.  Just live.  Sort of
like water flowing past your feet in a stream.  That water will make
contact with you but will just keep on going on without spending time
dwelling on you.  That's what one's rationale should be like; IMHO. 
Don't mind my Zen/Buddhist stuff.  Just do whatever feels right.

dErEk

On Wed, 3 Sep 1997, Jon Beck wrote:

> my philosophy on what a breakbeat is:
> 
> the bass is the man
> the snare is the woman
> 
> they bounce back and forth:
> 
> boom - bip
> boom boom - bip
> 
> how they dance depends on their relationship, how they feel about
> eachother, sexual prowess, etc..
> 
> the cymbals and hi-hats are drugs they add that extra sparkle (this I'm not
> so sure about yet... I think they might be something deeper... any
> guesses?)
>

Some thoughts to ponder:


 There's so much comedy on television. Does that cause comedy in the
streets.
    

 I think animal testing is a terrible idea; they get all nervous and give
the wrong    answers.


. The hypothalamus is one of the most important parts of the brain,
involved in    many kinds of motivation, among other functions. The
hypothalamus controls the    "Four F's":
      1.  fighting;
      2. fleeing;
      3. feeding; and
      4. mating.

. What is a committee? A group of the unwilling, picked from the unfit,
     to do the unnecessary.

. Slogan of 105.9, the classic rock radio station in Chicago: "Of all
    the radio stations in Chicago...we're one of them."

. With every passing hour our solar system comes forty-three thousand
    miles closer to globular cluster M13 in the constellation Hercules,
and
still                           there are some misfits who continue to
insist that there is no such thing as            progress.
 
. Madness takes its toll. Please have exact change.

. Applying computer technology is simply finding the right wrench to
pound
in the    correct screw.


 Karate is a form of martial arts in which people who have had years and
years     of training can, using only their hands and feet, make some of
the worst movies         in the history of the world. -- Dave Barry

 
 A great many people think they are thinking when they are merely
rearranging     
    their prejudices. -- William James


 We should be careful to get out of an experience only the wisdom that
is in it -         
     and stop there; lest we be like the cat that sits down on a hot
stove-lid. She                   will never sit down on a hot stove-lid
again -- and that is well; but also she           will never sit down on
a
cold one anymore. -- Mark Twain


. When cryptography is outlawed, bayl bhgynjf jvyy unir cevinpl.

 Lazlo's Chinese Relativity Axiom: No matter how great your triumphs or
how             tragic your defeats -- approximately one billion Chinese
couldn't care less.

straps.-- Emo     Phillips

when           you make it again. -- F. P. Jones

the      experience of others, are also remarkable for their apparent
disinclination to           do so. -- Douglas Adams, _Last Chance to See_

woman in             the audience stood up and said, "Yes, but is it the
God of the Catholics or the      God of the Protestants in whom you don't
believe?" -- Quentin Crisp

nations,      separating the imaginary rights of one from the imaginary
rights of another.
     -- Ambrose Bierce, The Devil's Dictionary

tired of being      told that ordinary, decent people are fed up in this
country with being sick and      tired. I'm certainly not! But I'm sick
and
tired of being told that I am! -- Monty           Python

Ashleigh     Brilliant

Actually, there is no laraves mailing list, but there is a Southern
California list which is pretty much dominated by LA:
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/socal/list_info/
Check out the above URl for info.  If you like to drive a bit, you can come
visit us down here in San Diego where we do have our own SD-Raves list :)
Actually, there are a lot, lots and lots, of events in LA and I hear that
it's pretty friendly up there too.  Good Luck!

Binge and Plur,

Aleaxander
www.carbonated.com

years and that really motivated me to get into partying again...

DEFINATELY!!... I had planned to see them last time they were here but I
lost my ID (had to be 21) and I found it a week later.. so I guess I
wasn't meant to go?? So me and Rubilicious are going on the 9th...

Talk about 6th degress of seperation.... a few gals from Chicago were
staying at my apartment for a while... and they had a friend they used to
live with athta was going to school/working in Paris who KNEW the guys and
had hung out with them the night before I talked to him on the phone...
crazy....   

if you don't know what 6 degress of seperation is... it's the fact/theory
that we all know eachother (everyone in the world) by 6 people or less...
for example:

guess how many people it takes to associate byroni with Marilyn Monroe???
2...  I used to live in an apartment that was rented by Joe Dimaccio's niece (who I met).. and Joe
Dimaccio was married to Marilyn Monroe.... tRiPPy ShTUff mAN...

Subject: NRR: (But kinda) My trip to New Mexico and meeting Donald Glaude
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.95.970904102950.28656E-100000@ccnet3>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Hola mi familia...

I'm back from New Mexico.... and I have a few more stripes on my world
travellor belt.

The place is totally hot, super clean, has BEEEEEEAUTIFUL fluffy clouds
like we've never seen (I love clouds), beautiful people, taco bells that
you can actually eat (they make the food so much better then they do
here), generally nice people, totally chill...

the 4 days spent there was really theraputic (sp?) and made me realize
just how much I need to relocate and have new experiences, make new
friends, and change my environment. I'm going to fly to some other cities
in the not so distant future and probably move in about a year or so. 

On Saturday night I went to a club called UN (Underground Nation) and got
a chance to see Donald Glaude spin in a tiny wittle club (which was cool).
He spun some really hard housy/funk stuff which isn't my favorite, but the
way he was mixing made it very enjoyable.. this guy has so much soul and
so much energy... he got this club rocking... he kept yelling "Feel
it!!".. :) I was right in front grooving my butt off. When he was finished
(2 hour set) me and my friend DENISE from New Mexico introduced ourselves
to this big Teddy Bear... he's such a cool guy and was totally down...

There were other things about this trip which were nice that I can't post
about... but lets just say that the grass is greener (and cheaper) on the
other side of the fence!!! ;) [Right DEREK?!?!?!?] Sorry Brian.

Ding, Ding, Shuffle, Shuffle, zaaaaap!

Byroni... .. .    
(The Space Cowboy)

I love Daft Punk and wouldn't miss this show for the world man. Those
Frech dudes are about my age and their music is the soundtrack of my life
at the moment...  They have so much talent (in my opinion) and I love
their CD....   I remember hearing Revolution 909 at Love Affair... I was
grooving (I was alone at this party by the way) and this sista' came up to
me and told me that I danced hella good.. so we started grooving hard core
(it's in the blood.. the groove, the funk, the soul!!)  and Revolution 909
came on... and I will always remember this moment at Love Affair when I
hear this song....     Her name is Andrea and she joined the Navy and was
back from boot camp when I met her at Love Affair.. she moved to Maine and
we're still pen pals.. cool, eh?

Byroni

ps. I love Disco... :) I would give anything for someone to throw a
100% disco house party... I can see it now.... maybe I should organize
it... I could call it "Saturday Night Fever 2000" DJ Bloom mixes these
tracks so well... definately see him at Life Force if you're interested in
GOOOOOOOOOOOOOD discoy house....   da boys gotz skillzzz.... homey! ;)

From: Justin McDonald <jmcdonald@wired.com>
Subject: Re: breakbeat philosophy
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

the low, rumbling sound that starts slow (in the background) and pushes
forward ... loudly and sounds like it might overtake the melody is the
world.  It's beaten back by hi-hats, and cymbals, which I see more as
randomness, but could be drugs.

but constant through this is the melody (cycle) of the man and woman ...
boom/bip.



>my philosophy on what a breakbeat is:
>
>the bass is the man
>the snare is the woman
>
>they bounce back and forth:
>
>boom - bip
>boom boom - bip
>
>how they dance depends on their relationship, how they feel about
>eachother, sexual prowess, etc..
>
>the cymbals and hi-hats are drugs they add that extra sparkle (this I'm not
>so sure about yet... I think they might be something deeper... any
>guesses?)

Hello...

Just wanted to let those of you who can receive 90.7fm on your radios that
I am doing a semi-regular weekly show on Fridays from noon-3pm on KALX in
Berkeley.  I play all sorts of different styles, focusing on techno but
branching into lands of ambient, dub, drum and bass, noise, jazz,
avant-garde classical, obscure soundtracks and the like...  KALX can be
recieved in many parts of SF (but definitely NOT in the Haight).  Tune in
if you can!

Fridays 12-3pm with Seth
KALX 90.7fm Berkeley

See ya,
Seth

..............
.....DJ Sutekh
.....Belief Systems................................
.... http://www.belief-systems.com .................
.... http://www.nodeone.com/static .......................
.....*send email for info on mixtapes.................................
.....Set.Seth.Setekh.Setesh.Seti.Sutekh.Setech.Sutech...............

Heh...   =]:....
 I could teach breakdancing I think..

Anyways..  I don't know.. Just follow the predictable four steps. And try
to repeat any hits that were cool for you, every fourth step. So like, if
you do something cool on the 2nd step..Do the same thing on the next 2nd
step. Makes it look like, you knew the songs was going to make that sound
on the first 2nd step. Try not to repeat the exact same feeling more than
8times. And remember.. Don't like be shy. Your reputation depends on it!  
Oh..


I am not making much sence..

>>Byroni wrote:

ps. I love Disco... :) I would give anything for someone to throw a
100% disco house party... I can see it now.... maybe I should organize
it... I could call it "Saturday Night Fever 2000" DJ Bloom mixes these
tracks so well... definately see him at Life Force if you're interested in
GOOOOOOOOOOOOOD discoy house....   da boys gotz skillzzz.... homey! ;)<<<<
 

I love disco too!  I know alot of ppl on the list hate it, and I can see why 
they might feel that way.  If my only exposure to it was at Grooveline at DNA 
with 500 drunk sweaty ppl up from  SJ (no offense) who don't even dress up or 
know the songs, or at some cheesy college fraternity "disco night",  I'd hate 
it too.  I remember my parents taking Disco lessons in the gym at the local 
high school.  Yes, by that time it had been polluted beyond repair.  Ah, but 
the early years.....big-assed bell bottoms, collars, medallions, 
afros....thumping beat and high-hat....quaaludes and coke....THOSE years were 
pure, beautiful and true.  

Picture this: an UNDERGROUND disco party, decorated with authentic attention to 
detail, where you HAVE to dress up to get in, and that played more obscure, 
less-overplayed disco tunes, would be DA BOMB! I would love to help with 
something like this!  

bump-tiss bump-tiss bump-tiss,
Nathan

Well its re-introduction time for me & sfraves as im back in 
town....just to re-cap.....

I'm Rob from London, England & im on a sort of working vacation in the 
US & have been scooting around since July 2nd doing some DJing (trance, 
drum & bass, chill-out) & pushing our new record label in London (home), 
Seraphim Records to the good ravers of this fair country......and its 
has been a totally wonderful time of meeting good people & going to good 
places......i liked SF so much ive extended my stay for a couple of 
weeks to come back & play! So here's some things to ponder on.....

Out
........so far ive pencilled in the CCC/Halicinogen thing on Sat.....Ken 
Ishii/Ultra Hope Monday...& Big Top (Oakland) w/end after 
next.......further recommendations appreciated...& meetings with sound 
minded people.....and also recoms. for good record shops, cafes, places 
to hang out etc....wot do i do in this lumpy city?

Take advantage!
Any parties (beach/house/street/club/whatever)....u need sounds....you 
got em....ive been treated so well in this country that i think its time 
to give some back so i am quite happy to play almost anywhere @ 
anytime....all i ever need is something to play on (Techs  and/or CDs) 
and willing feet & ears (anything else to keep a DJ happy is @ your 
discretion!)....sounds available are Trance, Jungle/D&B or chill-out 
(for those after party sessions!)....including some dub plates of some 
stuff from the label in London........you'll like!

Help!
My friend, is looking to rent someplace as she's just moved in from 
Wisconsin....she teaches, promotes parties & does good art......can 
anyone help?

So come back to me.....if only to say hi.....i leave town on 
15th....give me your best shot

Love & Thanks to all

Rob (invisible cola)

PS Can we not mention a recent MAJOR news story concerning a certain UK 
celebrity.....its not that i dont have any sympathy (i do) its just that 
its getting a bit much now......i keep getting asked the same stuff over 
& over

hi beautiful people,

some dj from australia looking for a weekend freeloading in SF, in 
exchange for (it seems) turntablist exhibition.  this is from 
alt.music.makers.dj, and i'm just forwarding it.  i neither know the 
poster nor the dj himself, but i just have this warm spot for fellow djs 
(even "purported to be dj"s, especially a bohemian kind), so i'm forwarding 
it to y'all - who knows?  maybe one of yous can use a visiting jock.

like i said, don't know the guy/gal, and *I VOUCH FOR NOTHING*.  apologies to
those who find this post inappropriate.

b-

with you at 'the otherside'.  we had to take off early. )

From: NO_JUNK_EMAIL@thankyou.com (Michael R. Erb)
Newsgroups: alt.music.makers.dj
Subject: San Francisco - DJ needs a room 9/13/97
Date: Wed, 03 Sep 1997 19:03:36 -0400
Organization: Michael 'E' Mobile Sound

Hi,

I've got a visiting DJ from Austrailia, staying with me right now. He'll be
flying to San Francisco September 13, 1997 and needs a pick-up from the
airport and a room (or couch) to stay in for the night. 

He is a professional magician, and in return for the favor, he will perform
close-up table magic at a wedding reception (during cocktail hour and/or
during meal) or other appropriate event on Saturday, 9/13/97. He has
performed at numerous functions for me and is an EXCELLENT
entertainer...funny, and very accomplished.

All he needs is a pick up from the airport and a piece of floor to sleep on
for the night...then a ride back to the airport Sunday evening.

If you can help, please email me at: trikstar@hotmail.com

Michael Erb

Heya - just doing a belated readback nearabouts 8/22 -- didn't find any
messages reviewing/commenting/revibing the F8 party almost two weeks ago...

... had an amazing time myself, D.J. Mystere (sp?) waxed me stratosphereic.
Anyone else?

Had my own lonesome beautiful after hours party -- driving back to the
city, bopped up the hill on the right into the golden gate rec. area right
above the bridge, walked to the corner spot overlooking san fran and the
rising sun wrapped in a mexican blanket (me, not the sun). Beautiful
sunrise with fog below, dense clouds above, and a narrow slit of sky
through which the sun rose all of a sudden blinding and exquisite.

Was actually kinda surprised no other city-bound ravers dropped into that
spot...

Anyhow, on F8 - great party they threw, bummer about the enormous lines to
the two toilets but if you hummed a tune and thought about something bad
you'd done in the past week, you could turn it into a sort of pennance for
wrongdoing, purification ritual. Or something.

-c
http://www.sirius.com/~canton/music/music.html

dieselboy sound mediocre (that's just my word for last sunday I guess)...

But, guess what?  He lives in Philadelphia now - kinda cool, actually, cuz
it means it's easier for him to get to New York...

One good thing about New York - our jungle scene can kick your jungle
scene's ass...  (Sorry, that was a knock-off of a Letterman joke (I think)
that got around New York and became it's unofficial motto - one most New
Yorkers tended to adapt to quicker than the real one (I don't even know
what the real one is, actually)...  It was, ""Our City can kick YOUR city's
ass."  

We probably could - y'all are too nice out there.  ;-)  hehehe,  j/k.

Hey guys - this is one of my favorite people - he's really funny, and i
thought you'd enjoy reading this uh, review, sorta...  fyi, ultraworld is
the big ole huge party promoter in baltimore (the one i was talking about a
while back)...

>>Date: Thu, 04 Sep 1997 11:58:30 -0400
>>From: Christopher Green <green@counsel.com>
>>Organization: Counsel Connect
>>To: ne-raves@world.std.com, nyc-raves@hyperreal.org
>>Subject: fun things reviewed
>>
>>so on saturday we went to a deathcore outlaw in a squathouse down in
>>alphabet city.  talk about not ultraworld.  it was in an abandoned
>>apartment with holes in the floor and like one light above the dj. 
>>collin strange was doing a fucked live pa when we walked in.  the room
>>was at capacity with about 30 people inside.  after collin finished some
>>guy came on with an absolutely gory record around 270bpms and proceeded
>>to "mix" through an hour's worth of the same.  you ever seen a deathcore
>>mosh pit inside a room 8 feet wide?  wait, let me guess.  no.  well me
>>neither.  and i've never felt so on the verge of a violent death at a
>>party in my life.  after two hours of temporary insanity i walked home,
>>put on some enya, asked god to forgive me and went to bed.
>>
>>yesterday night when i came to, i found myself with a free pass to the
>>daft punk/sneaker pimps/aphex twin cmj show at the roseland (cheers
>>tye).  some group called fluke was on when we got there.  pretty cool
>>techno/industrial hybrid a la prodigy but fronted by a female loudmouth
>>instead of keith.  we feigned interest in this for nearly 5 minutes
>>before bee-lining it to the back for the open bar, flashing our cmj
>>badges at just about anything that crossed our path including ferns and
>>mirrored columns in an attempt to seem halfway important when in fact
>>the only thing important about us was that we had badges and wanted to
>>drink a lot.  scanning the crowd of influential music industry types,
>>bill werde and i set our night's goals in mind.  his was to drink to the
>>point of disgracing the badge around his neck, whereas i wanted to
>>become so drunk that i sincerely believed that _i_ was daft punk.  the
>>passes worked a charm and we had our drinks coming at us in pairs for
>>the next hour or so with no end in sight, until the bartender, clearly
>>impressed with how much we could sit there and drink and shout at each
>>other, finally decided to charge us for a drink and we in turn decided
>>to go back out front.  daft punk had just come on at this point, and it
>>was damn clear from the very first filtered sample that these guys were
>>going to impress.  they had the crowd rocking hard as they went through
>>well-tweaked remixes of all their hits, from musique to da funk to
>>rollin and scratchin, finally finishing with around the world.  by that
>>point the alcohol and previous nights of sleeplessness were starting to
>>take their toll on my head, and as much as i wanted to hear what aphex
>>twin was up to i made the responsible decision to hit the road and get
>>the hell to bed.  (ed. note: recent reports by bill indicate that aphex
>>twin's PA was pretty "inaccessible" as far as live performances go but
>>it's anyone's guess what that means)
>>
>>
>>green
>>
>>
>

If any of you were curious, as close as I can tell, the calendar web 
page is getting about 2000 views per week, and this email goes out 
to about 1500 people...  The web traffic has gone up dramatically over
the last year, while the email list size has been pretty stable.

Next week's calendar will be out on Wednesday 'cuz I'm going out of town
on Thursday.  Please send any updates by Wednesday afternoon...


                             THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

Precedence: bulk



OK, I started reading your letter, Mr. Vlad, and I have a few things to
say.

First of all, let me make it clear that I did not *finish* reading your
post/letter.

Second of all, I am not going to get on some supersoapbox trip and rail
against those who would be railing against the wind-up-toys graf 'artists'
who litter their surroundings and their names with whacked styles and
thoughtless marker use.

HOWEVER, did you ever stop to think that there are ways around the
mindlessness?   For me, grafitti when taken back to the writing your name
in cement level, demonstrates a sort of childish need to leave a trace of
oneself.  Could that need not be fufilled by making some big sheets or
butcher paper or scrap plywood and sheet rock available for public use?
As a sort of free and open and public wall in the outside sector of your
massive?

What if you put the work/finagling in to make the spot's owners let some
wall in/outside their space be bombed over the course of a whole party by
a local writer with piecing skills?

What if you accentuated the positive somehow?  Did you see the grafitti
left over at the Maritime on Sunday last?  The legacy of the hiphop
festival passed down to the ravers?  The big pieces of plywood that had
wonderful and spacey pieces on them, featuring little chipchop shreds of
wisdom and uplifting statements otherwise.....like the stuff on rave
fliers, only written towards the hiphop side.

I would hope that some people who identify with that article would
understand what I'm saying.  For me, that article described a part of my
life that I will always cherish, a sort of light hearted "I don't give a
FUUUUUUUUCH" and juvenile, but altogether artistic and politically active
time in my maturation process.

With a little effort I'm sure you could minimize further the effects of
the whacked, while perhaps even borrowing a bit of positive culture from
another scene.

That is all I am trying to say.

PAX,
DUH,
MAX

594159415941594EVA.

An interesting thing about "Generation X":
Genreation X includes, mostly, the folks born between 1969 and 1975.  
This period is the period of the lowest number of live births in the 
United States in at least 50 years.
just an interesting anecdote.
You can throw that out the next time you're at some hoighty-toit cocktail 
party and everyone will think you're cool.
:D

i read this out of this little miniature book on scorpios.

"Scorpio is linked to "the underground" in astrological tradition:  
mining, investigation, secret societies (whether legal or not), the 
occult- ..."


"Because of your matchless self-control, you are slow to anger; but 
when you explode, the world around had better take shelter fast."

and this part will make you think:

"The Scorpioin is also connected to the reporoductive organs and to 
spiritual cycles of death and rebirth.  Tremendous potential force 
lies locked in your coiled intensity, which can be used to accomplish 
the miraculous in life.  HOW you choose to unleash this preternatural 
power is another question: you can create, or destroy, with equal 
facility."

 I could teach breakdancing I think..

Anyways..  I don't know.. Just follow the predictable four steps. And try
to repeat any hits that were cool for you, every fourth step. So like, if
you do something cool on the 2nd step..Do the same thing on the next 2nd
step. Makes it look like, you knew the songs was going to make that sound
on the first 2nd step. Try not to repeat the exact same feeling more than
8times. And remember.. Don't like be shy. Your reputation depends on it!

Hello SF ravers!!  
Sorry for the interruption.  We've been subscribed to this list before under
(Lunatune@aol.com), and have met many of you at parties in previous months.
 We have been having a string of bad luck with dishonest people.  Being new
to the bay area, and not living directly in San Francisco, it is hard to meet
friends in the honest rave scene.  We are looking for honest ravers for that
special connection.  There is a wide variety of favors we need, and will
return the favors accordingly.  We try not to be too hypocritical...we
ourselves are honest.  {=^)  We know there is someone out there that has
honest friends with honest connections.  Anyone willing to help us?  Thank
you so much for your time and sorry again for the interruption.

I know I talk a lot of trash about Sacramento . . . but early in the summer 
there was a party that went off here called _Xanadu_.  It was a pure disco 
party, and although you didn't have to dress up you got in half price if you 
did.  I heard it went OFF.  I wish I would have went . . .  there was supposed 
to be a second installment in August, but hey, didn't happen, probably not 
gonna happen anytime soon.

But yeah, we had a pure disco party here in Sac, there was a good turnout and 
a phat vibe.  If it could happen in Sac it could happen in SF, righ righ?  So 
who's the promoter who'd be willing to do it?

  If you like disco and you like to dance, consider these places:
  The Metronome's Block Party  Ballroom in SF (right off 17th and De Haro)
regularly has "Hustle Night!" This month it's on Friday, Sept, 12, and
includes hustle lessons with Raul Ante. Call 252-9000 for info. The cost
is only about $10 (lesson and dance) and you get to wander back and forth
into the Metronome (1/2 block away) and the Block Party and no extra
cost.
  The Starlite Ballroom in Sunnyvale has regular hustle nights every
Saturday night. Cost is $7, and includes a lesson if you want it. I've
seen some spectacularly good hustle dancing there some nights. Call
408-745-7827 for more info.

Max,
    I totally understand where you are coming from, and I am the last person
to ever want to deter anybody's vision of creativity...  However.... Tagging
is more destructive than it is creative.  Im not talking about Graffiti  I
think that Graffiti is a very expressive form of Urban culture.  But It wasn't
Graffiti the the XLR8R article was encouraging... It was Tagging.   And
Tagging (IMO) is the act of unrestrained destructive vandalism.   We have
tried things like putting up a tagging wall , or dedicating a wall for tagging
only at our events in the past.  And hat has happened, is that everything but
the designated area got tagged.  Tagging is spontaneous and tags do not want
to be controlled, or told "Ok you can tag here, but here only"  It manipulates
them and makes them feel like they are selling out if they put their marks on
the permitted surface.  Its the rebellious nature of tagging that they want to
express, Not the mark or the tag, but the ACT of tagging and getting away with
it.  You can't control or regulate that.
    In the big picture... Raving is about a community coming together and
dropping prejudices, and animosities, and feeling like one under a unifying
energy of the music and the vibe.  Tagging is about ME... Unique, Stand alone,
egotistical, arrogant, and destructive behavior which does not conform with
community beliefs.  This is why it is incompatible with raving.  No one tags
messages on the walls that say "Love" or "Smile" or anything that can in
anyway contribute to the community... They Tag THEIR OWN NAMES, or the names
of their Tag Crews on the walls, floors, Sound and lighting equiptment, rental
equiptment, bathrooms, and anything elese they feel like.   They just want to
do it and get away with it, regardless of the damage that it does to the
community.... That's not a Rave attitude.  Its the same mindset as someone who
comes to a party and sells bunk and gets out as soon as possible before
anybody notices the damage.  There is no defense for those people either.
    Tagging is a cancer to the rave scene.  It taxes raves in the same way
that shoplifting raises the prices of retail products.  The article in the
XLR8R has glorified and encouraged Tagging, and brought down the art form of
graffiti all in one swoop.  Its a shame that that a magazine that is supposed
to be down for the scene can be so short sighted.

Keep it real

Vlad


Max McCauley wrote:

> OK, I started reading your letter, Mr. Vlad, and I have a few things to
> say.
>
> First of all, let me make it clear that I did not *finish* reading your
> post/letter.
>
> Second of all, I am not going to get on some supersoapbox trip and rail
> against those who would be railing against the wind-up-toys graf 'artists'
> who litter their surroundings and their names with whacked styles and
> thoughtless marker use.
>
> HOWEVER, did you ever stop to think that there are ways around the
> mindlessness?   For me, grafitti when taken back to the writing your name
> in cement level, demonstrates a sort of childish need to leave a trace of
> oneself.  Could that need not be fufilled by making some big sheets or
> butcher paper or scrap plywood and sheet rock available for public use?
> As a sort of free and open and public wall in the outside sector of your
> massive?
>
> What if you put the work/finagling in to make the spot's owners let some
> wall in/outside their space be bombed over the course of a whole party by
> a local writer with piecing skills?
>
> What if you accentuated the positive somehow?  Did you see the grafitti
> left over at the Maritime on Sunday last?  The legacy of the hiphop
> festival passed down to the ravers?  The big pieces of plywood that had
> wonderful and spacey pieces on them, featuring little chipchop shreds of
> wisdom and uplifting statements otherwise.....like the stuff on rave
> fliers, only written towards the hiphop side.
>
> I would hope that some people who identify with that article would
> understand what I'm saying.  For me, that article described a part of my
> life that I will always cherish, a sort of light hearted "I don't give a
> FUUUUUUUUCH" and juvenile, but altogether artistic and politically active
> time in my maturation process.
>
> With a little effort I'm sure you could minimize further the effects of
> the whacked, while perhaps even borrowing a bit of positive culture from
> another scene.
>
> That is all I am trying to say.
>
> PAX,
> DUH,
> MAX
>
> 594159415941594EVA.

Island Views E-Zine
No. 7
Edited by Bruce Eisner
*************
To visit our site, tune your favorite web browser to http://www.island.org
To contribute any ideas, resources or volunteer help: contact island@scruznet.com
+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
    IN THIS ISSUE

+- Island Founder Bruce Eisner to Lecture at Whole Life Expo, Saturday September 6
+- Island Web Team Formed
+- Island Potluck Friday September 26th
+-  Psychedelic Island Views Published 
feature interviews with Owsley Stanley and Terence McKenna PLUS an excerpt from 
TIKHAL by Alexander Shulgin
+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
Bruce Eisner, author of Ecstasy: The MDMA Story 
and founder of Island Foundation
will speak and participate on a panel discussion on the 
Whole Life Expo this Saturday, 
September 6th. The lecture will be Underground Dance Culture:
A Safe Place for the Healing and Transformation
of Today's Youth? The panel will start at 3PM and 
will feature moderator Jane Piper of the 
Next School Collective. Also on the panel will be rave promoter
Martin O'Brien, writer Andrew Ransley
and editor of the electronic culture magazine XLR8R, 
and Jennifer Stone of the Consortium of Collective
Consciousness. Toward an Ecstatic Culture is the title of Eisner's talk. 
He will discuss the emerging psychedelic
cyberculture of the new millennium and how we can co-create an 
ecstatic society. Bruce will
begin speaking at 5 PM. 
Information on the expo can be found by calling 800 551 EXPO or 
at http://www.wholelife.com.
+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
The first Santa Cruz Island Group Potluck will be 
held on September 26 at 6:30 PM in
Santa Cruz. For directions and information, 
e-mail island@scruznet.com. There is no
agenda for this event, it will be pure networking -- a good time 
is guaranteed for all!
+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
A new team of volunteers has taken charge at Island Web. 
Coleman Todd Fluhr <cfluhr@brother.win.net> is a superb web graphic artist who is
working on a new visual interface for Island Web.
Robert Truesdale <admin@cstreet.com> has volunteered to work the 
Marketplace catalog on an ongoing basis. 
"Richard Gay (Programming)" <rgay@nando.com> will be the new Web Master
and coordinate development on the site. 
These people are added to our previous team members:
Steve Harris <terrapin@oro.net> Outgoing Web Master who is working on upgrading
the Links Database which he originally instituted when Web Master.
Mike Markowski <markowsk@ren.eecis.udel.edu> who does the Island Village
and Huxley's Vision.
We hope to add a couple of other names within a couple of days. 
This team will take our four year old site help Island Web take
a quantum jump to a higher level! Thank you all. 
+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
Psychedelic Island Views No.2 is now available. The new issue can
be previewed or purchased at http://www.island.org/ISLANDVIEWS/piv3.html
This all-new issue dedicated to Terence McKenna features:.
+ An Exclusive Interview Owsley "Bear  Stanley" Alchemist, Part 1 by Bruce
Eisner This covers how the famous LSD chemist first turned on, how he first made
LSD, met Kesey and the Pranksters and began working as soundman for the Grateful
Dead
+ Psychedelic Culture: An Interview of Terence McKenna by Bruce Eisner
+ An excerpt from Alexander T. Shulgin and Ann Shulgin's new took TIHKAL  --
titled "Galileo"
+ The Electronic Acid Test  by Douglas Rushkoff
+ On the Digital Be-In by Mark Katzman
+ Human Be-In (Excerpt from Novel Shadow Dancer) by James Fadiman
+  Elizabeth Gips Changes Column by Elizabeth Gips
+ Meta-Doctors on Duty (poem) by Doctor Jabir 'abd al-Khaliq AKA Nick Herbert
+ Last Word by Peter Stafford
+ Plus Island Marketplace and much much more. 
You can get details on how to the new issue e now by going to
http://www.island.org/ISLANDVIEWS/piv3.html which is part of Island Web.
Island Web and Psychedelic Island Views are both produced by Island Foundation,
a non-profit organization of individuals dedicated to the creation of a
psychedelic culture as inspired by Aldous Huxley's novel Island.

Has anybody read the new XLR8R cover story on graffiti?  Does anyone
realize how destructive this article is to our scene?  This is one of
the most thoughtless forms of industry sabatage that I have ever scene.
Maybee im over-reacting, but its just that genecide makes me nervous.

I encourage everyone to read the artice and send your opinions to
XLR8R.  The attatched is the leter that I sent them.  Please read, and
give me your feedback.

Keep it real...

Vlad.



Dear Editorial Staff at XLR8R:

        Firstly, I would like to say that the following comments are
private,
and are NOT to be published publicly in your magazine.   The last time I

E-Mailed my comment to you they were published in your letters section
after being edited. DO NOT DO THIS AGAIN!

        I would like to thank you on your wonderful Cover story on
Graffiti.
You and your magazine have once again shown that you have no clue as to
whats happening in the scene.   Myself, as well as every other Rave
promoter have put hundreds of hours of work into trying to minimize the
impact of Tagging and Stickering as well as all other destructive
vandalism at the parties, raves and clubs in the Bay Area.   And just as

our efforts start to pay off, and tagging at events is down, your
Informative (not) Magazine comes out with an entire cover story
dedicated to glorifying and encouraging this disrespectful form of
negative egotistical vandalism.
        Over the last 6 months, the amount of tagging has been reduced,
and has
become less and less visible.  Nor has tagging ever been directly
associated with raving.  But your magazine (which is directly associated

with raving) has made a direct connection between tagging and raving,
and will encourage more tagging at raves.
If you think I am over-reacting than you should see the damage after the

party that we just had, Megga-Buzz-Mania, on this Labor Day, We had more

tagging than weve seen at our last 4 parties combined.  We had tagging
on the speakers, generator, walls, bathroom, floor, banners and every
where else.   I contribute this increase directly to your magazine.  It
came out only ONE week before our event.  Thank you for encouraging
negative behavior at a time when positive role modeling is so important
to help the misguided youth in our society find something to identify
with.
Graffiti is an art-form.  But your article did not Do it any justice AT
ALL!  Instead you brought it down to a lower level by assimilating it
with tagging. which has no artistic value whatsoever.   You made it
sound like it was "all-good", and fun.  Well in this scene it isnt.
But then again, what do you really know about this scene.
        Your magazine has done a grave injustice to our scene, and the
effects
of your article will be felt for a long time, by all promoters in this
industry.  Venues and equipment will be tagged, and owners of facilities

will not want their locations used for rave events, and promoters will
have to charge higher admission to cover the excessive security,
cleaning, painting and damage expenses with every event.  Nobody wins,
especially the Ravers.  Thank you for being so considerate to the
promoters that place ads in your magazine to advertise their events.
Im sure that they really appreciate all the extra money you will cost
them.  Maybe in the future, your magazine would consider glorifying
Gang-Rape, excessive drug use, or unsafe sex I am sure those would make

excellent cover stories to follow your trend of encouraging
communication and glorifying negative psychotic behavior in our
society.  Keep up the Positive work. NOT!

Vlad
Feel Good Entertainment

Five years ago, when I was 20, I was living in Japan and met this very cool
23 year old girl from Oregon who was working at an English school in Tokyo
for the year between finishing college and going of to law school.  I met
her through a friend of my hostfamily that was in her class, and so I sort
of had this blind date with her.  Anyway, so we met up and decided to just
slum it at a beer drinking restaurant nearby where we immediately started
talking about our lives in general; a sort of low key philosophical
conversation that pretty quickly leads to an understanding of each others
political views.  Both of us were the children of hippies that where trying
to balance the ideals of our parents within more realistic modern
contraints (at least that's the way we saw it).  So, our conversation
started to move towards the problems and pitfalls of modern life, of trying
to be true to yourself, find meaning it what you do, and yet still be
successful.  At some point she told me I should check out a book by Douglas
Coupland called Generation X.  I had already fallen in love with her, so I
bought the book fairly soon after.
I loved and hated that book.  I loved it because it was very well written
(it's not a masterpiece of literature, but I don't think it was written to
be anyway) and described the lives of a bunch of people who were struggling
with a lot of the same problems I was.  I hated the book because it
described me in a lot of ways when I never thought that there was any way
to describe me.  I wasn't supposed to fit in any sort of framework!  It was
the first book that I ever really saw myself in and it sorta scared me.
Anyway, over the next couple of years I started hearing the term Gen X
being used to desribe a group of people and at first I thought that was
pretty cool, because the people in the book were very cool, very noble, and
very interesting.  However, it soon became clear that the term was being
used to dismiss a generation, to describe in non too flattering terms a lot
of people who were just struggling to deal with the mixed up ideas of the
generations past.  Generation X was a book about people trying to deal with
modern philosophy and idealism in a very post modern or post-post modern
era; where you are no longer able to identify yourself with one group or
philosophy, but find yourself mixing it all up (a funny and obvious example
of this is Modonna!  The Material Girl, Virgin who is definately not a
Virgin, the religious girl in Like a Prayer; if you see one of her videos,
just notice all the different images she is using to define herself and
remember how much you may have liked her in elementary or jr. high school).
 The characters in the book were all living together and sort of taking
some time off to try and figure things out - I guess find themselves in
their own ways outside of commercialism but with the realistic
understanding that they wouldn't be able to really escape it.  On top of
that, the book didn't really try to supply any answers, just seemed to
present some of the problems in clearer terms.  The fact that it was so
missinterpreted really tended to bug me after awhile.
So I guess that's my two cents about Gen X.  It's a fairly good story that
is very different from the generic term that was borrowed from it and used
to describe the generation after the one in the book.  Sorta makes me
giggle at the irony :)

Binge and Plur!

Aleaxander


http://www.coupland.com/
http://www.olywa.net/jonny/genx.html
http://www.imv.aau.dk/~bogus/

I think I'll be spending my birthday at that play nice thingy, so don't
hesitate to stop by and pat me on the head.  I should be in a very
good mood 8) and spinning some tweaked experimental / ambient / triphop /
bluntbeats at some point in the chill/d&b o'matic room.

Last year, I had one of the best birthdays ever dancing my ass off to Juan
Atkins in a small basement with about 150 people tops at some puny Space
Children party at a bar/hotel basement. That party was, well, amazing
(see... and all it took was one (1) eye frying laser, one (1) tictac, and
a DJ who is really scary on three decks and plays the best minimal Detroit
around). Little hot, but I didn't mind.  Vibe kinda blew (too many people
were there to see "THE Juan Atkins", father of detroit, godfather of
techno, blah blah blah... damn hype), but I wasn't dancing to the vibe,
and the friends who took me were great (Neil/Todd/Jay woohoo! and Wayne
and Marci and Moonpup too).

Met these hyperactive bald British guys who were some of the funnest
people to party with... so I guess we got a little good vibe area going,
but there were just so many people standing there with their arms crossed,
watching the labels, checking the skills.  Get a life or dance or 
something... sheesh...

Peace,
AndyW

Thought this might be of interest to any of you budding composers.  This
is a competition of "electroacoustic music" with a prize of $2000.  Now I
there is TONS of talent on this list!  And wouldn't it we wonderful if an
sfraver won?  I think so.

the complete info:  www.algonet.se/~icem/seaa.html

core.  How does a claustraphobe cope?  I need room to boogie and hop
around.  I feel the music, my body wants to move!  Umm, sorry did I step
on your toe, oops didn't mean to elbo your boob, (err this guy smells),
well, hello there bebe lets go upstairs and find a comfy couch and git
away.

Do they ever turn people away due to maximum occupancy?  btw, does anyone
know what maxocc is for 1015?  Well, the music will keep me going there.
