Dori <luvnlyfe@freshmilk.com> wrote


another plug for dieselboy - get it, he's good...  REALLY good - his
earlier stuff is kinda pussy "intelligent" jungle sometimes, (that wimpy
shit yuppies listen to to came "underground" music status while they 
smoke
and drink cocktails in all black) but his new stuff is amazing... and 
his
mixes can be unreal.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Well there's nothing like some dull-headed insulting comment to get a 
respose........ill assume by "intelligent" (idiot terminology) Dori 
means the LTJ Bukem/Goldie/PFM/Omni Trio/whatever-type 
stuff............so "Jungle" is only about hoover bass & mash-up 
sounds...no room for some variety, melodics, rolling drums & a little 
space in the music for you eh, so stuff anyone ("shit yuppies") who 
likes it...........where to start...

Ive lived in London for the past 8 years & have heard Drum & Bass evolve 
from Ragga-ed up breakbeat hardcore thru to the myriad of styles we get 
today.......and as a DJ i enjoy playing all types.

Ive found over in the US "Jungle" tends to mean the more mash-up 
styles.....as the scene has developed in a diff way over here there 
hasn't really been the Logical Progression ('scuse the pun) of styles so 
maybe junglists do actually see the more mellow stuff as shit 
yuppie...Jungle Lite if you like.....try & get a sense of the whole Drum 
& Bass scene (maybe hear some GOOD d&B DJs who can play the more mellow 
stuff & still move a crowd)....you're doing yourself a disservice by 
blithely dissing this stuff....

One minor point to ponder on...ive noticed the word Jungle used a lot 
more over this side of the water (as opposed to Drum & Bass)...the term 
actually comes from the totally offensive & racist phrase "jungle 
bunny"....now the  J & D&B terms are pretty interchangable now & no-one 
cares/knows of the origins...so does it matter? PJ & Smiley (Shut Up & 
Dance), two of the original pioneers, preferred the term "Ragga House" 
and used to get really offended by the term "Jungle"....but then whos 
heard of Ragga House?

Keep on having fun WHOEVER you are

Love

Rob xxx (invisible cola)

        groovi-music@netcom.com
Subject: Tip on Nuking Noise in the Studio (was Re: recording? )
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 05 Sep 97 02:05:35 +1200."
             <l03102800b035146834a3@[209.76.100.55]> 
Date: Fri, 05 Sep 97 18:13:45 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

> my only complaint is
> the MC-303 is reasonably noisy..(ses me who will still use the MT-32 for
> certain things)...would others concur here?...or am I hearing
> things?...BTW..I'm recording via a decent Mackie desk etc...

One technique that has proven very successful is to use a "balanced
active transformer" to isolate the grounds between noisy digital synth
and/or computer eqpt and the mixer (which must have balanced inputs). I
actually used this to isolate a *very* noisy analog output on a
computer I have (SGI Indy) which was injecting horrible noise into my
mixer even with the fader controlling it's input all the way off. This
should also work well on other noisy synths, or people using noisy
computer audio boards (e.g. soundblaster, etc) but will work only if
you use a balanced audio input on your mixer (typically an XLR jack, or
a TRS 1/4" phono jack)...

The idea is that you take the unbalanced line output from some noisy
device, and use a "active transformer" (aka a balanced amplifier
buffer) to create a balanced audio signal to go into your mixer (it
needs to be active because the signal level for balanced audio is much
greater, and the impedance is much lower than crap "consumer grad"
unbalanced audio). 

The important thing is that you do *NOT* connect the ground from the
output of the "active transformer" to the shield/ground input on the
balanced input of your mixer. the shield on the cable inputting the
signal to the mixer input *is* connected to ground on the mixer, but on
the output of the balanced txformer, just connect the hot (+) and cold
(-) wires:

<Noisy    >		  { 1/2 of  }                |
<digital  >--UNB SIGNAL->-{+ RDL   +}->---BALANCED---|+ Balanced input on mixer
<synth or >--GND------+->-{- STA-1 -}->---SIGNAL-----|- 
<computer >	      |->-{G	   G}->/ /---GND-----|Gnd
			  {	    }		     |

What happens here is any ground noise from your errant synth/computer
is decoupled from the rest of your audio chain... although it is still
present on the balanced audio lines (the + and - signals in the diagram
above), the common-mode noise rejection of the balanced input of your
mixer will essentially drop the noise level by 50-100dB (depending on
the quality of your balanced inputs) rendering all the digital noise
and other crap completely inaudible.

After talking to some pros, I found a small "stick on" module  that
does exactly what is needed for this task -- from an Amterdam (*)
company called  Radio Design Labs (STA-1 plus PS-24 power supply)
approx $75.00 for STA-1 and $13.00 for PS-24 from www.fullcompass.com
mailorder (no tax).

See http://www.rdlnet.com for more info on the STA-1 and all sorts of
other really cool little audio modules made by RDL. (Not related, just
a happy customer of their stuff -- sounds great, simple, performs
wonderfully, very compact, decent prices).

PS: It's completely pathetic that very little music gear uses balanced
audio.... once you go balanced, you'll curse every piece of unbalanced
gear you have because it all sounds like crap (noisy, prone to
interference). Plus, w/ balanced audio lines, you can easily run very
long audio lines, traditional unbalanced line level signals can't
really be run for more than 10 feet (3 meters approx) before you start
getting interference... and what with everybody having computers, cell
phones, portable phones, etc -- there's tons of interference available
to screw up your audio signal.

PPS: I just rewired most of my studio for balanced audio. when i get
some more money, i'll get a new mixer w/ balanced audio ins on every
line and put STA-1's on the outputs of all my synths. Right now, the
only piece of music-making gear i have that has balanced outs is my Emu
EIIIxp sampler.

*: what is it about the Netherlands that makes them *rule* on audio...
TC Electronics, Radio Design Labs, Synteco, Phillips, etc. How does one
go about applying for citizenship? :-)

 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==>>                    Niels Mayer (mayer@netcom.com)                   <<==

hey sweets - re: your comment as to "having fun whoever I am" - well, I'm
dori and what I say here is pretty indicative of who i am - cuz unlike a
lotta people, i'm the same online and off...

I had a slight feeling that that "pussy jungle" comment might piss a lot of
west coasters off - from what I've heard from east coast (pahdon me, DRUM &
BASS - over here in nyc we laugh at people who say that, cuz again, it's
that whole black clad vodka-swilling yuppie crowd and music industry goofus
crowd that uses that term, they tag it on with "electronica: - tell me THAT
phrase doesn't make you barf and I WILL laugh) anyway, from what i've heard
about the west coast scene, y'all are kinda into that - whereas in new
york, we like to get slapped in the face with the hard jump up base
lines...  Perhaps it's the different vibes of the cities - but, yeah, I was
sorta waiting for someone to take offense to that, and yeah, you're right,
i was referring to the Bukem/Goldie SHITE (a term most brits I know still
love, hehehe) - you know, it's good for sitting in the park or whatever,
but don't get that shit near me in a club or a party, hear me?  Cuz it
makes me sit down.

As for the use of the term "intelligent" - yeah, you guessed it - more than
likely, I as well included this word in quotes, because I think it's
ridiculous as well - as I said before, it's a term given to the wimpy
jungle beats by people who can't handle anything more...

as far as room for "some variety, melodics, rolling drums & a little 
>space in the music for you eh, so stuff anyone ("shit yuppies") who 
>likes it...........where to start..."

start with Aphrodite - he keeps it hard enough (although he gets a little
wimpy periodically as well) and those bass lines rolling enough to keep me
interested in his experimentation while my butt gets movin' to the beats.  

Ya know, the reason I like the word "jungle" probably has a lot to do with
where I LIVE - people in new york take their jungle SERIOUSLY and hell,
this city is known for being called the "koncrete jungle" ya know...  (We
even get a cheesy monday night jungle thang called the same, headed by
Shitslinger and TC Islept, absolutely the WORST MC known to man)...

Dori
*hard-ass New York bitch*

>Dori <luvnlyfe@freshmilk.com> wrote

>another plug for dieselboy - get it, he's good...  REALLY good - his

>shit yuppies listen to to came "underground" music status while they 
>smoke
>and drink cocktails in all black) but his new stuff is amazing... and 
>his
>mixes can be unreal.
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>Well there's nothing like some dull-headed insulting comment to get a 
>respose........ill assume by "intelligent" (idiot terminology) Dori 
>means the LTJ Bukem/Goldie/PFM/Omni Trio/whatever-type 
>stuff............so "Jungle" is only about hoover bass & mash-up 
>sounds...no room for some variety, melodics, rolling drums & a little 
>space in the music for you eh, so stuff anyone ("shit yuppies") who 
>likes it...........where to start...
>
>Ive lived in London for the past 8 years & have heard Drum & Bass evolve 
>from Ragga-ed up breakbeat hardcore thru to the myriad of styles we get 
>today.......and as a DJ i enjoy playing all types.
>
>Ive found over in the US "Jungle" tends to mean the more mash-up 
>styles.....as the scene has developed in a diff way over here there 
>hasn't really been the Logical Progression ('scuse the pun) of styles so 
>maybe junglists do actually see the more mellow stuff as shit 
>yuppie...Jungle Lite if you like.....try & get a sense of the whole Drum 
>& Bass scene (maybe hear some GOOD d&B DJs who can play the more mellow 
>stuff & still move a crowd)....you're doing yourself a disservice by 
>blithely dissing this stuff....
>
>One minor point to ponder on...ive noticed the word Jungle used a lot 
>more over this side of the water (as opposed to Drum & Bass)...the term 
>actually comes from the totally offensive & racist phrase "jungle 
>bunny"....now the  J & D&B terms are pretty interchangable now & no-one 
>cares/knows of the origins...so does it matter? PJ & Smiley (Shut Up & 
>Dance), two of the original pioneers, preferred the term "Ragga House" 
>and used to get really offended by the term "Jungle"....but then whos 
>heard of Ragga House?
>
>Keep on having fun WHOEVER you are

Hehehe.. not to get flamed or anything... but I went to register for a dance
class the other day, and there were two girls ahead of me in line.  One of
them was facing me and had on a baby tee of some sort, with a cartoon
character on it.  Beneath the cartoon, two words were written.  The cartoon's
name or something.  I half-glanced at it, and the words I saw surprised me.
 "(Cartoon's First name) Raves"  Thinking I must be going crazy and be overly
obsessed with partying, I toook a second look.  Sure enough, the shirt said
something like "Carlos Raves" and it had this cartoon animal (plattipus or
penquin or something) wearing big jeans, a pacifier necklace and a visor.
 Immediately excited and somewhat ready to question this girl if she even
knew what a rave was I asked her where she bought the shirt,.  I was greeted
with a strange glance and a "Oh I don't know.. It was either JC penny's or
Macy's"  AHHH!! The frustration!! How can they be marketing this to people
who don't even know what a rave is??!?!?!  WE need to covet these T-shirts
while they are still in stock!  Quick!  hurry!  RUn to your local mall and
buy them out!
    my second gripe for the day is when I was sitting in Math class
conversing with a nice girl across the aisle about some of the parties we've
been too.  Suddenly the football jock head sitting in front of me blurts out,
"RAves are Fucking Stupid!"  I asked him which ones he'd been too and he
said,"None.. I wouldn't go to one of those things!! BUt I saw one on T.V. and
they're stupid!"  WHat can you do?
My $0.50 for the day...

        hugs n'Stuff,
           'trice the tekno diva             <<<RAVEON>>>>

      P.S.  i'm going out to Mr. Zip Up's Free Party in the Park tomorrow if
anyone's gonna be there.  I need to shop on telegraph, and if there's a free
party going on, hey, why not???  LOOK for me!!

>XLR8R has glorified and encouraged Tagging, and brought down the art form of
>graffiti all in one swoop.  Its a shame that that a magazine that is supposed
>to be down for the scene can be so short sighted.
>

Funny thing!

I never remember anyone tagging at any of the parties I've put on. Maybe
it's the crowd you're pullin' there buddy. In a humorous twist, that crowd
you promote to and their direct actions will eventually act as a natural
governor on how many more parties you'll get to put on, and where. :-)

Awful, isn't it?

:-)

At 10:01 PM 9/5/97, Dori wrote:
>hey sweets - re: your comment as to "having fun whoever I am" - well, I'm
>dori and what I say here is pretty indicative of who i am - cuz unlike a
>lotta people, i'm the same online and off...

hmmm.. i've always thought that i could be more myself online... it's hard
(and it can't be that way only for me) not to put on some sort of mask when
you're out and about. (i, for one, used to (hmmmm, about 12 years ago?) put
on the east coast bitch-don't fuck with me-attitude when i was out - clubs,
at night on the street, sometimes during the day as well!) and of course i
now put on a mask when dealing with work-related things. i put up masks for
many reasons, but online (more often than not) i don't find it necessary.

eeeek - do you think 6 years out of the state could have changed me??? :o

>I had a slight feeling that that "pussy jungle" comment might piss a lot of
>west coasters off - from what I've heard from east coast (pahdon me, DRUM &
>BASS - over here in nyc we laugh at people who say that, cuz again, it's
>that whole black clad vodka-swilling yuppie crowd and music industry goofus
>crowd that uses that term, they tag it on with "electronica: - tell me THAT
>phrase doesn't make you barf and I WILL laugh)

wow. i'm feeling really...naively peaceful???? what ever happened to the
unity? is it only _within_ geographical locations? i *thought* not,... you
know, my first introduction to this (and here's a word i really don't care
for - but for lack of a better one) "scene" was by a group composed of -
well, okay, east coast ppl (great lakes, nyc...), but also by a bunch of
spanish guys, brits, and indian guys. god. i fell in love with the stories
of parties in europe and goa. the *unity*. then bam! the shit hits toronto!
:) anyway, i'm babblng, but the point is that so much more than the music
for me was the unity. the way the group went on a trip together. the
farther away from the party you came from, i thought, the more interesting
i found you. like a family. (okay, on e :) i guess that's why i like sf -
so many ppl from all over the place! and *seemingly* peaceful. for the most
part. (my favorite city is toronto, for precisely that reason.)

anyway, from what i've heard
>about the west coast scene, y'all are kinda into that - whereas in new
>york, we like to get slapped in the face with the hard jump up base
>lines...  Perhaps it's the different vibes of the cities - but, yeah, I was
>sorta waiting for someone to take offense to that, and yeah, you're right,
>i was referring to the Bukem/Goldie SHITE (a term most brits I know still
>love, hehehe) - you know, it's good for sitting in the park or whatever,
>but don't get that shit near me in a club or a party, hear me?  Cuz it
>makes me sit down.

we all have different tastes in music. *so*????

>As for the use of the term "intelligent" - yeah, you guessed it - more than
>likely, I as well included this word in quotes, because I think it's
>ridiculous as well - as I said before, it's a term given to the wimpy
>jungle beats by people who can't handle anything more...

oh. i've really liked what i've heard. maybe not to dance to, but to hang
and listen to...sure.

>Ya know, the reason I like the word "jungle" probably has a lot to do with
>where I LIVE - people in new york take their jungle SERIOUSLY and hell,
>this city is known for being called the "koncrete jungle" ya know...

oh yeah? well, my dad's better than your dad! :P

shit! look at the time! gotta run...

cheers - e. :)

References: <Pine.PTX.3.95.970904205428.2238B-100000@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU> <v03102809b0367c5a8b6d@[204.179.130.139]>

Wayne wrote:

> At 10:15 AM -0700 9/5/97, "Rave On Ecstacy, promotes to taggers" wrote:
>
> >    Tagging is a cancer to the rave scene.  It taxes raves in the same way
> >that shoplifting raises the prices of retail products.  The article in the
> >XLR8R has glorified and encouraged Tagging, and brought down the art form of
> >graffiti all in one swoop.  Its a shame that that a magazine that is supposed
> >to be down for the scene can be so short sighted.
> >
>
> Funny thing!
>
> I never remember anyone tagging at any of the parties I've put on. Maybe
> it's the crowd you're pullin' there buddy. In a humorous twist, that crowd
> you promote to and their direct actions will eventually act as a natural
> governor on how many more parties you'll get to put on, and where. :-)
>
> Awful, isn't it?

    Any rave crowd is a diverse poulation, no matter what party.  But that doesn't
have anything to do with it.  It has nothing to do with My parties.  The problem
is the XLR8R article of making tagging sound like "It belongs, and is part off"
the rave scene.  All forms of Rave Media effect the overall direction of the rave
scene.  XLR8R is one of the largest forms of media in the rave scene.  Their
magazine has a voice, and a presence, and does shape perception of what people
think raving is.  If you think that this will only effect my parties, well then
your not seeing the big picture.    After 7 years in this industry, I have a good
grasp of what's happening.  There will be an increase in the amount of tagging at
raves.  With the increase in tagging, will be an increase in other forms of urban
street activities that were never a part of this scene.  Things go hand - in
-hand.  As the scene is expanding and more people are looking for information on
it, the responsibility of any entity that cares about the scene would be to
promote it on a positive level, so that those new to it start of with the right
impression.  Do you think that the XLR8R issue on Graffiti is the type of image
that you would like someone to see as a first impression of this scene?  This
article is not going to make candy ravers turn in their pacifiers for markers, BUT
it has the potential to encourage new ravers to purchase markers instead of
candy... do you follow my drift?
    This is a very sensitive time, much of what people perceive the rave scene to
be comes form printed media.  Anyone that does not have a lot of experience to
this scene, that reads this issue of XLR8R might get the wrong idea of what raving
is all about.  And that influence and encouragement will increase the amount of
tagging at parties... Not just My parties... But every Party!
    So in a way you are right, Tagging will be a governor to raving, and may
eventually bring down the entire scene.   Now every rave promoter has to work
harder to make sure that this does not happen.   And We have  XLR8R to thank for
that.

Keep It Real

Vlad

Mime-Version: 1.0

People, before it gets any further, can I just say anything I refer to as
far as east coast vs. west coast - IT'S A JOKE...  Don't take it too
seriously, I'm just playing around...  I think that whole thing is
bullshit, because they're total opposites anyways, and there are a lot of
beautiful things about both - and if you can't see that, you're just
extending the battle...  

Matter of fact, I just sent some guy back to Berkeley raving about how nice
New Yorkers are - why?  Cuz it was raining and I shared my umbrella with
him and talked his ear off the whole way...  Hope I didn't create any false
realities for him, hehehe...  JUST KIDDING!  Kewl thing, he's got email.

So anyway, yeah, I don't wanna start any ridiculous played out east coast
vs. west coast threads, because i think they're ridiculous, and i think
that if you can't find something to like a LOT on either side, you need to
open your eyes - and if you can ONLY see the "bitch don't fuck with me"
attitude of a New Yorker, try to see it as, "Hey I'm a bad ass and so are
you." Cuz when the "bitch don't fuck with me" attitude is a positive thing,
what you get is a lotta confidence and a lot of innovation that doesn't
come from anywhere else.  It's definitely a New York thing and that's not bad.

As for the wimpy jungle, I didn't want anyone to take offense to that - our
scenes are OBVIOUSLY very different - so what?  I'm not saying I don't sit
at HOME and listen to "wimpy" jungle - but i most certainly can't dance to
it.  But, you know what they say "Live in New York, but leave before it
hardens you.  Live in California, and leave before it softens you."  Those
of you who live in the city probably see the bottom levels of humanity a
LOT - here, you see it all the time pretty much no matter WHERE you are
(with the exception of the Upper East Side where people really DO believe
the death of Versace was comparable to the death of Mother Teresa) and
yeah, it hardens you a bit...  So maybe I'll come to California, show ya
how we do it New York style, and you guys can soften me up a bit.  I still
refuse to dance to wimpy jungle or call it drum'n'bass but that may just be
because we don't publish WIRED on this coast, hehehe...  I'm more than
willing to sit around and puff to it tho...

As for what parties are all about, you can put labels like peace & unity on
it if you want to but i think that there's so much more to it than that
that it's impossible to do such a thing.  Lucky for you guys tho, you can
go to an event and EXPECT that that sort of thing will be around.

And finally, for the person who made the comment about their dad being
cooler, I'm not taking you seriously, so please don't take me seriously
either - but my dad is uh "hella" cool (sorry, couldn't help myself) -
found him on the internet last year (no joke) and we've only known each
other since last september - but I'm just like him, so somehow I seriously
doubt your dad is cooler.  ;-)

At any rate, I can't stress enough how much to NOT take me seriously - and
I'm coming out there so hopefully I can meet some of you really interesting
people and have a good time.

Mwaaah,

dori

inanna wrote:
> 
> To the people who are offended by MY opinion,(get it folks, its an
> opinion,)
> 
> You tell ME what Mother Theresa did for the people of Calcutta- for
> anyone, for that matter.
> 
> Quit being a lemming and worshiping the people that the media tell you
> to worship!
> 
> Think before you worship,
> Diana

and Ran D. Dreams wrote

> Hey kidz. Take it the fuck offline. We don't give a shit about your 
> relations. This is SFraves not SFfamilies/whatever.

I don't know if you two are aware of this, but part of this list is to promote
and discuss things rave related which goes beyond the topics themselves. It
should also be respected by you two to handle your opinions more fairly and,
perhaps, in a more subtle manner.
How does it help to refer to Mother Theresa as:

"Fuck Mother Theresa"

or 

"We don't give a shit about your relations"

Granted, these topics may not belong here in this list, but certainly the way
you handle your thoughts and how convey those to other people on this list is
definitely something to consider. I, for one, thought that being part of the
rave scene has in part an obligation to tapping into those things that we see
as positive things and applying them to the real world: Respect, openness,
maturity, happiness, dialog, and RESPECT (I have to say it again, it feels like).
To handle yourselves in the manner above is ignorant, non-caring, and
certainly brings the list down. We, as a rave culture (should we all believe
there is one), are only as good as we treat ourselves, those around us, and
those that we do not agree with. If you have to strongly state a position
about some humanist that others may care about, post some supporting thoughts,
and (gasp!) make an effort to tie into the rave/music scene. I'm sure we would
all be appreciative of being educated. If we must tell someone that the topic
is inappropriate for the list, try to send a seperate private message or at
least a publicly posted one with some *tact* that helps the list rather than
degrades it.
Anyway, I know the above topics are non-rave-related specifically, but it
makes me angry when *we* treat each other so callously. Being part of
something greater than the *average* means some amount of work is needed and
even things like posting to a mailing list filled w/ like minded individuals
should be handled with some respect.
Otherwise it makes us and our interests/beliefs a joke. 

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

From: SmileGirl <juliemae@goldrush.com>

X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.01 [en] (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: those goofy dancers <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: GOODBYE SFRaves & some thoughts on the scene...
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

       Well, I've realized that I have to take a break for a while.  My
life has become too overwhelming, and raving and being a part of this
list is too much of an interference/distraction to keep my problems at
bay.  It seems as if my life is lived full of extremes.  I've had some
of the most incredibly good things happen to me (i.e. getting into
U.C.Berkeley, etc.), but it seems like every bit of good is tempered
with 2 or 3 things equally incredible, but bad (getting beat up by ex,
etc.).  Drama follows me around like a magnet, and I am fighting a
losing battle.  I am dealing with extreme depression, friends and family
who think I'm an addict (I think they're wrong, but self-doubt is
creeping in), an asshole ex who keeps toying with my heart and won't pay
me back for all the money he owes me (among his debts to me, the $115 I
had to spend on a new graphing calculator for my Calculus class after he
lost my old one, and the $203 that he told me he'd pay me back for if I
got a pager (the sight of which is a constant sickening reminder that
I'm broke because of it), since he'd been hounding me to get one so he
could get ahold of me), the possibility of school being permanently
damaged, supposed "friends" who won't pay me back, not being able to put
gas in my car for the commute to school each day, and now a tide of
bills that, although relatively small in dollar amount, will affect me
quite adversely when not paid (i.e. phone, credit card, parking
ticket).  I'm actually not very much in debt money-wise and I have the
money to pay for it coming to me, but it's not coming to me until the
end of this month, and unfortunately, that's after I've suffered all the
penalties from not paying the bills now.  And the penalties are way
severe.  Money doesn't do you any good if you get it too late for the
payments.  No, I can't ask my family for the money.  They have made it
clear to us kids that we are NOT, under any circumstances, to ask them
for money for anything.  And I don't know anyone who can help me with
this, so I'm stuck.
        I have to leave this list and take a break from the scene for
several reasons.  If I stay on this list, all my woes will come shining
through in each post I make, and spending my time and energy reading the
flood of posts is not the best way to tackle my ever-present problem.  I
have too much pride to come out and ask for help (this being the closest
thing I can manage) and I'm at a loss for knowing anyone who could help
me, and the longer I go without help, the more prone I'll be to whine
about all the shit, and I don't want to do that to the list.  I gained
the nick SmileGirl and I don't want that to change by my making more
depressing posts, so until I can smile again, I feel it is my
responsibility to not be on the list.
        I've never felt more alone in my life, and raving has not helped
me at all.  If anything, it's left me feeling more alone, since when
I've had really rough days/nights, it's been hard to find anyone who
really wanted to deal with me. And I've tried to go out of my way to
help other people with money, love, friendship, an ear to listen, good
advice, etc., but when I've needed things from people, I haven't found
anyone willing, most of the time.  I'm getting bitter and losing faith
in people, and that's not like me.  I don't like feeling this way.  I'd
rather go back to believing that everyone is genuine and true.  I'd
rather go back to feeling I can count on people and rely on them.  It
was so much nicer being able to trust.
      People seem to only be my friend as far as the next party.  People
only call me in regards to parties.  If we are all a community filled
with love, friendship, and unity, how come, for the most part, our
friendships don't extend past raving-related activities?  I love all of
you genuinely.  I have a pure heart, and people don't realize that when
I tell people they can call me for ANYTHING, I really mean it.  But here
I am, regarded as quite popular by many and knowing a huge amount of
people in the scene... yet, when I'm crying because my parents are
jerks, etc., or when I'm jumping for joy because something incredibly
wonderful just happened, I don't have anyone I feel I can call to tell
them about it, good or bad.  I don't think I should feel that way when I
appear to have so many friends, but it's true.
      Everyone in this scene talks as if they'll be friends forever.  I,
normally an optimist with regards to this, have been in the scene since
1992, and I can only name 1 or 2 people from a few years back that still
keep in touch with me.  Reality sings a different tune with regards to
these oh-so-important friendships and bonds that we make in the scene.
I think the main reason for this is that many of this scene's
participants have not made much of an effort to forge friendships based
on anything but raving and its related activities.  If you want to truly
be my friend, be my friend.  God knows I need real friends right now.
But please, please, PLEASE, be my friend in more ways than just being a
party pal.  Go with me to a comedy club one night, go hiking with me up
in the meadows of the Sierras, or just simply spend a day with me at the
beach (when there isn't a party taking place at the beach).  It doesn't
matter, just do something with me other than raving.  Call me to tell me
about the promotion you got at work, or the A you got on your Psych
exam, or to tell me about the date from hell you just went on.  No
matter what it is, it's important to me, good or bad, because I care
about you, a real  person, not just a raver I know.  There is more to
life than raving, and I started to lose sight of that.  I'll always be a
raver.  You can still call me for that.  You can still count on me to be
in attendance at future parties (after I get out of this slump, that
is).  But please show me that PLUR extends past the parties we go to,
and this list.  Please be true and real.  I need to be able to count on
something for a change.  I love all of you.  Sorry I used up so much
bandwidth with my depressed mood.  Goodbye for a while...
                                     Love,
                                          Julie Mae
P.S.  I am unsubscribing right after I send this, so any responses to
this need to be forwarded to me personally.  You can still reach me at
this e-mail address.  I can't pay the bill though, so in about a week,
you may have to address e-mail to me at SmileGrl1@aol.com if the mail
daemon returns mail sent to this address.  I can also be reached at
(209) 984-3918, and when that's busy, you can call (209) 984-5151.  My
pager/voice mail is (415) 790-1759.

Oh my gawd!  

  So much vibe, so little time!!! It's days like this that make me feel
all warm inside; knowing, that I live in San Francisco.  Okay, I went to
People's park at around 2:15 and ran into TeknoDiva and Michael (DJ
Ulrich?).  The music was phat and the people were kewl.  I caught the
beginning of DJ Ghost's set and was as happy as a flubbertye could be.
But I had to move on to meet with friends and go to the Tsunami preview at
Golden Gate park.  We caught the last thirty minutes of the last set of DJ
Simon...Woo hoo!  The chills and the Thrills and all the happy people made
me insane like a sugar high :)  Anyone out there who doesn't know where to
go tonite...GO TO TSUNAMI!!!  I am still sweating like hothouse hony.
It's a shame that I missed Tuyashi (SP?) Suzuki's set (my friend Claire
keeps on insisting he's the bomb; she first heard him at Berlin's Love
Parade--today is his West Coast premiere...show him what we're all
about!).  Okay, okay, my ride for Friends & Family is two hours late, so
I'm heading back out to People's Park for a warm-up.  I sometimes get the
feeling I'm chasing my tail...hmm, naaaw.  I love it here, I love it here,
I love it here!


Okay, CHill y'all.

M&m
...all this and sober too :)

OK, WHere shall I begin?  I headed out around 11:30  to B.A.R.T. with My
friend Greg.  After a nice long ride and losing Greg's wallet, we winded up
in berkely.  Walked a ways to Telegraph, and met some ravers on the way there
(MAN! They can spot us coming... and I wasn't even candied out!)
Arrived at People's Park after milling our way down Telegraph.  It seemed
bigger than I remembered, because I had been questioning if it was a big
enough park to hold everyone.  NOt many people there, but it was only noon.
 Seanie Boy was messing around on the turn tables, while everyone sort of sat
and enjoyed the music.  Only a few people dancing. 
More and more people showed up, overall, there was a fairly large crowd.
 Lotsa happy people.  Greg seemed to enjoy himself.  I hung out with Ulrich
for a good while! HI HI HI!! And Met Kathleen (I hope I got that right) from
SFR.  UM.. DJ Ghost's set was dissapointing.  WAY Clubby, played out,
oldskool.  I don't know.. I was in the mood for something else.  He threw a
really good party, though.  There's just sumthin about the Ghostribe sound I
don't like.  MAD PROPS to JOEY!! The second he came on everyone ran to the
tables!  
Seanie Boy's kids were there... and let me tell you-- they get mean and Dirty
with their super-soakers.  Sure cooled me off, though.  Is it true the little
boy got to spin durring his daddy's set?? wish I could have caught that.  I
never heard Jeno go on and I didn't see him.. was he there?  I don't know.
 Moshe's set, very clean.  Everyone else I kind of space on.
Hello to Jeremy(I finally met you!) Nik, Neptune, The Oakley Family, Sam,
M&M, Just Jer, Slim,Thomas the Glitterboy (nextime, nextime)  All the people
I danced with and the other's who's name escaped my mind.
THe down point of the day was when I couldn't see the oncoming four-person
mosh pit because of the glare on my sunglasses, and found myself sprawled on
the ground  under pounding feet.  Oh well, everything else was wonderful.
 OH! and hi to Vlad... you are just EVERYWHERE,,, aren't you??
I heard Moontribe is spinning there next Sunday.. anyone want to go???

       hugs N'stuff,
        'trice the tekno diva                  <<<<RAVEON>>>>

"the world is our vinyl... let's spin it."

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 4.71.1008.3
X-MimeOle: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE Engine V4.71.1008.3
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

 Hey there,


         Well, it's been some time since I talked to a friend who is a
lawyer, but drugs charges and penalties are broken up in two different ways;
        first, what the drug is. Some drugs get charges that come with
higher penalties (ie. dust, pcp, heroin). So the type of drug carried does
effect the time in jail/charges.

       Second, then the weight comes in to effect, which sucks. Now with
weed or coke they do not include the weight of what it is carried in,
plastic bags. With acid, they generally include the weight of the paper or
other substance that it is in. And, as you would guess the more weight, the
worse the charge. The reality is you may only have 10,000 micrograms of
acid, which is a fare amount, but with the paper included, makes it seem
like allot more.

Peace, Luv, & Hugs
Rebel D Monteer
terrapin@lords.com
http://www.psnw.com/~terrapin

Okay, I guess it's time for me to spill my guts a little bit, too...

Your mail touched me in a way, because well, I don't know exactly, but
because you were in a situation and you are trying to deal with it.  As
I've posted before, I recently moved out here, and had to break a 1.5 year
long live-in relationship to do so.  My ex didn't want to come out here,
partly because of money reasons, so I had offered to help/support her as
much as I could, even to the point of helping her pay for school if she 
decided to go back, and she basically didn't even recognize that I wanted
to help her out...which kinda hurt.  And, she has a bad habit of NOT
dealing with money problems...she ignores them, in the hopes that they'll
go away...until the bill collectors come knocking on the door, or the IRS
starts garnishing her paycheck, or whatever.

And here you are, with money problems, and it sounds to me like you're
actually TRYING to deal with them, but timing has fucked you over, because
you won't get paid until AFTER your bills are due.  So I think, I've got a
pretty good job, and I'm sure that there are other peeps here that do too,
so if 5 of us throw together $20 each, that's $100 for ya right there, and
it might make your world a bit easier.  I TOTALLY didn't think you were
trolling for handouts.

I'll toss $20 in the mail for ya tomorrow.  Hope it helps some.  Glad you
got your kids set, too...that's really cool.

My ex woulda ran out and bought a new pair of shoes..it's why she still
owes me rent.  :P

Two lovers interested in spiritualism and reincarnation vowed
that if either died, the other one remaining  would try to contact
the partner in the other world exactly 30 days after their dying.
As luck would have it, a few weeks later the young man died
in a car wreck.  True to her word, his sweetheart tried to
contact him in the spirit world exactly 30 days later.

At the seance, she called out, "John, dear John; this is Martha.
Do you hear me?"

A ghostly voice answered her, "Yes Martha, this is John; I can
hear you."

Martha tearfully asked, "Oh John, what is it like where you are?"

"It's beautiful.  There are azure skies, a soft breeze, sunshine
most of the time."

"Well what do you do all day," asked Martha.

"Well Martha, we get up before sunrise, eat some good
breakfast, and there's nothing but sex until noon.  After lunch,
we nap until two and then have more sex until about five.  After
dinner, we go at it again until we fall asleep about 11pm."

Martha was somewhat taken aback.  "Is that what heaven
really is like?"

"Heaven? I'm not in heaven Martha."

"Well then where are you?"

"I'm a jack rabbit in Arizona."

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

That shit is just too funny because that was something the way my week
went. First of all I would like to say that this years Freshmen are itty
bitty! On the first day of school I was walking down minding my own
buisness when some freshmen (trendy ass girl) stops me and saids "Oh my
god, do you go to raves and stuff??" I said "What's a rave?"
She said "It's like this big party in where everybody does a whole lot
of drugs." I said "Hmmm, nope don't go to those."
She goes "You don't know what a rave is? Cause you look like someone who
goes to raves!" I said "I don't know what a rave is, bye" She goes "Bye"

Then like the third day or so I am watching some Freshmen breakers bust
some moves (but they can't) to some crappy rap coming out of their boom
box. So I ask them if I can put in my tape and I put my tape in and they
go "Oh is that Techno music?" I say "It's Cyber Trance" cause that's
what it was. They say "Do you go to raves?" I said "Why do you ask" They
said "Cause they play this trippy music at those things and that sounds
like it." Then on top of that they asked me to rave for them. Like I can
represent the whole scene. So after a while i just left.

Pretty smiliar weeks hu Patrice?

Love,
Paul*E*Wog

I had an amazing time at Tsunami.  I just let go and let that goa trance
strike that primal chord.  The vibe was great.  The crowd was on the whole
more mature than many of the raves I've been to, and everyone was having a
great time dancing.  There weren't any people standing in front of the dj
with their arms crossed at this party, no siree!  The flourescent murals
of butterflies, and cybermandalas were gorgeous.  Upstairs, the dj played
some slower trance stuff with breakbeats.  everyone was getting funky,
down and dirty, all under a hippy mood umbrella.

I really fed off the energy of these guys wearing black vests with
a single patch on the back.  Do they signify an order of
brotherhood, or are they little storage vests?  At any rate these guys
were spreading love, peace of mind, and shaking their bums.  And then
there was all the trippy flouro patterns, and flouro crochet pants, trippy
ass visual clothing.  

Great party.  hope I get to read some reviews of FnF.

regards,
logos

Doreen wrote:
> 
> YEAH!!!!  finallly somebdy posted EXACTLY what i was thinking when i
> read that post from a representive of Feel Good Entertainment.  many
> MANY people who i have met in the scene are not liking where it's
> going lately, and perhaps due to production companies making PROFIT
> off throwing parties!
> all i'm gonnna say is if throwing parties is your meal ticket, then
> get the hell out this 'industry' cuz your losing sight of what it's
> all about.
> 
> -doreen.

I completely disagree.  If you really feel that way, don't spend your
money on the FGE events!  (Hopefully you won't do that.)  If you sit
down and think about it, putting together a rave or any good event/party
for that matter is a HUGE undertaking. (have you ever tried it????) It
has to be done by those that have a good amount of time to deal with all
the elements.  I don't think he meant anything by "industry" other than
the fact that his money goes to an organization that dedicates it's time
to putting on other great parties and events.  He has been in this scene
creating, for the most part, fabulous large events that we enjoy....he
obviously isn't making so much money that he's moved to Jamaica, sipping
rum & cokes and forgetting where he came from.... They even put out
great mailings and a newsletter.  I enjoy the big (licensed) parties as
well as the smaller UG's and I do remember just a few days ago, there
was a post giving out to some of the UG promoters for some difficulties
people had with one of their parties. (I also enjoy a party to start
within a few hours of the posted time...not up to 5 or 6 hours later!!)
You should take your frustrations out on the City for busting all the
UG's.  There are different issues surrounding all the events but just
remember that there is a lot of pressure on the promoters who are
running things..... I believe making a bit of money is part of the
appeal, but just as long as it's not the main issue,which I don't
believe it is, I don't think it's fair to put down ANYONE who takes that
much time to make it possible for you to have a good time. 

And that's all folks.....
:-) Melissa

actually kinda new to me.  It could be because it was at the Troc.  That

this stuff was INTENSE.  Oh yeah, and the decorations were fucking BOMB.

with my mind the most was the one of that body that looked electrocuted
all surrounded by those eye balls and shit.  Good thing I wasn't fryin'.

was going to be CHILL room.  There was for a short bit but it turned into
more dance type stuff.  Oh well.  It was still awesome.  Oh yeah, and it
was by the loudest party I've ever danced at.  My ears and shit were
still ringin' the next morning.  Shoulda worn ear-plugs.

  I think people have lost sight of the fact that a party is supposed to be
you and your friends, and their friends.  You can't really socialize at a
3,000 person party the same way because you spend 90% of the time wandering
around the place.   It's like a step above socializing on the street
outside your house.  Face it though, we're addicted to partying, we're not
going to stop.  
 
   I'm going to say we gotta go private.  We have enough friends with phone
number books of their friends, no fliers needed.

why I love the list, where we can organize parties right here sitting on
your booty, and don't have to worry about all the shit we have to worry

From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: I'm going I'm going
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9709080747.A2564-0100000@netcom9>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



So it's like 7.30 AM and I really don't want to get off my UncleNoah ass 
and go to work but oh well, looks like I'm going anyway, but not until I 
write to you kids a little. :)

I went to a party this weekend in San Bernardino called 'Computer 
Controlled'.  Now, I've been to SB for parties before nad I've always had 
a fairly rotten time.  I've been rather dissappointed in the SoCal ascene 
in genereal lately.  I miss the closeness and that really friendly vibe 
that I love so much in the Bay area and it just hasn't seemed to exists 
down here.  I find myself just walking around a party for like a couple 
of hours and then realize that there's really nothing interesting going 
on and then I go home.

This was not the case at Computer Controlled at all!  The venue had a 
bunch of really cool lighting effects (including a couple of nice 
lasers), a bunch of speakers that made my vision all blurry from the bass 
vibrations when I stuck my head in them, and a bunch of really friendly 
folks from the SoCal-Raves list.  The music was acid/Detroity-techno for 
the most part and there was none of the b/s that I usually encounter at 
SoCal parties like fights, people trying to be "hard", or a myriad of 
other bad vibe bullshit.

I wound up sitting in the chill area outside for a good part of the 
evening with a really cool woman who was on her first E and a whole bunch 
of other SCR list folks.  OH! and the other thing was most of the SoCal 
list folks had on laminates!!  Everyone was running up to each other and 
meeting and hugging and smiling n'stuff.  There were big group hugs on 
the dancefloor (sometimes we'd grab non-list people and they would get 
kind of upset at first but then succumb to the love!

So it looks like laminates have made it to SoCal, a greater sensee of 
community among people from the internet list is growing...  it looks 
like  the only thing that's missing now is E-kisses :D


I miss you SF folks a lot!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I hope you're all having a nice 
day and that you're being careful out there and everything.  I'm sure 
I'll see you all soon :)

The individual confusing you had reference to sidereal or eastern
>astrology which is based on calculating the horoscope based on fixed
>stars.  The tropical or western horoscope is based on an annual
>beginning at the moment of the spring equinox (0 Aries).  You were born
>with the Sun in Scorpio.
>--
>Michael McClain
>Flower Mound, Texas

don't worry, i didn't spend my money at the FGE event, nor will i.  
not everybody 'enjoys' this large and somewhat dangerous events.  
i went to the planet new year make-up party, which i must point out 
WASN'T a fge party, but a massive none the less, and i watched two 
girls get in a cat fight and i got pushed back against the wall.  
ouch!  that was 1 in 4 fights that i personally witnessed.  so i stayed 
outside mostly.  
but to me, that's just not fun.  it's not fun to be a part of, to 
watch, or to even be 10 feet near.  and you don't need to be sailing 
on the love boat sipping rum and cokes to be making a profit.  find 
another meal ticket is all i'm saying.  
no, i have yet to throw a party, but someday i probably will.  and i 
sure as hell won't charge 20 bucks a head at the door with tight ass 
security patting people down.   
ok, i'm going to end this before i really start pissing people off.  
sorry, i didn't mean to offend anyone if i did.  just my two bits.
take care
have a good rest of the day
-doreen.

so let me get this straight....you are slamming <being judgemental and
rude> to this person b/c he doesn't know anything about "your" music or
scene....

> trance, whatever.  then this dork who works with me constantly asks 'IS
> THIS RAVE MUSIC??"  i go "no, it's jungle".  i wouldn't mind
> asnwering his questions to the best of my ability, but he needs to
> phrase them in a non-dorkish way.  people are just uncultured i
> guess.  :-)
>
> -doreen.

imho....this statement is rather hypocritical. you are calling someone a
dork and uncultured and judging them based on their knowledge(or lack
thereof) of music and culture that you are into....give me a break....this
person is technically correct anyway... if you were to define "rave" music
as a genre...would you _exclude_ jungle or D&B from that list of types of
electronic danc music played by DJs at underground parties? I think not.

Its rather sad that a cool, hip "raver" like yourself could be so
judgemental, closed-minded, and unaccepting of someone who does not meet
your standards. And then for you to take the time out to post about what a
dork the person is......to SFR.......thinking that 400 other ppl will agree
that this person is uncultured and a dork cause he thinks jungle is "rave"
music....jeez. Think before you speak/type.....please.  You are the one who
needs to be cultured and gain an education, not the "dork".

fubari

(this didn't work the first time, so i guess i'l try try again)

after some choice emails regarding my weekend at burning man got
strangely redirected towards my work environment, i've come to
recognize the wisdom behind all these silly email names.  thus i am
reborn before you :

                         $$$Messiah Wannabe$$$
                       <messiahw@rocketmail.com>

thats right, if you're tired of christianity, muslim-ism, hinduism,
buddism, new age and manson, but are too lazy to come up with you're
own spiel, i'm your man.  my tithes are quite reasonable, and i would
NEVER EVER tell you that sex is bad...

right.  regarding the nosy questions floating around on friday when i
first tried to post this:  i'm 29, and my sign is cancer (though i've
always considered myself more of a virus)

so anyway, i was at the end up on sunday morning.  oddly enough, i was
completely sober - my roommate invited me just as i was getting out of
the shower, and i thought, what the hell...  well the thing was, i got
there, and well, i just started feeling, uhhh, strange.  out of place.
i mean, my eyes were all clear, my pupils were their normal size, i
felt like everybody was looking at them.  i put on some sunglasses,
but it didn't help, the lenses were black not green, a dead giveaway. 
anyway, i was getting a little nervous, so i started talking to
people, to see if i could, like, trick them into thinking i was fucked
up - you know, asking about where the after party was, "so what are
you on", etc etc, but after just a few moments, i'd start making jokes
or remembering their names or just generally sounding coherent, and
suddenly i was sure THEY ALL KNEW.  i would of just left but i was
more scared of the cops than anyone there.  i mean, as wierd as it was
it still felt like a safe place to be straight...

oh, better late than never, he's my suggestions for activities at the
foamE party:

1. a meditation course in the middle of the bubble morrass...

2. a foam sculpture contest...

3. slip 'n' slide or other suburban lawn games...

4.  a special room where x'ed out soapy ravers can snog, and maybe
check out each other's techniques...

hmmm, i think burning man has forever changed my idea of what raves
could be like....

 - messiah wannabe

ok ok ok
i really don't think i explained my story very well when i posted it 
to the list.  first of all, i have no problem explaining what kind of 
music is what (music of the scene that is) but this particular 
individual whom i work with will ask me "hey doreen, is this your 
RAVE music?" like every 10 minutes or so even when something like 
Beck is playing.  he basically asking to get a rise out of me.  which 
sort of worked.  no, i didn't lose my cool and say "you are dork cuz 
you know nothing about jungle"  seriously, i wasn't a bitch about 
it.  but it bothered me because i felt like he keeps asking just to 
poke fun at me and naturally, i took sort of offense to it. 
that is all.  i just don't feel comfortable playing my music at work 
anymore because of this.  basically, if i felt he was SREIOUSLY 
interested in learning what kind of music is what or whatever he 
wants to know about it, i would be more than glad to tell him.  but i 
don't to those who ask me in such a condesdcending manner.  
yes, jungle is played at raves.
no, he is not confused as to what jungle is because he doesn't give a 
fuck anyway, basically.
so, in the future, i will try to explain my story with as much 
details as possible.  geez, what a response i got!!
-doreen.  ;-)  

"don't shoot!!"

Wake up time! Hello!

Look, you are (probably) living in the most consumer orientated state in 
the most consumer orientated country on the planet. The fact that this 
scene is so much fun is going to attract the commercial element, cos 
they can sell this fun onto lotsa others....and make money.

The best way of sticking up for the true (non-comercial) scene is to 
keep it going....the underground will always be there as long as people 
are ready to inovate & keep things moving.

Surely by the time the commercial elements have started preying on some 
scene, the real scene will be moving on somewhere better?

I prefer to ignore the commercial scene-stealers (why give them any time 
whatsoever?) & get my kicks where i know the real fun is going to 
happen..........just keep your ear to the (under)ground

invisible cola

I was riding home from friends and family and passed someone
that i had seen at a party. We sorta smiled at each other
with a half uncertain look of " you kinda look familiar"
And since we were both zooming down the highway at 
*censored* miles per hour we couldn't speak to each other.

I thought that it would be nice if we had some kind of hand
gesture...kind of like the peace symbol of the 60's
Have you ever been on your way to a rave and come
up on a car of what looks like it might be a bunch
of ravers going to the same place as you ...

I was thinking of the v that robin williams used to make
in mork and mindy when he said nanu nanu or was it
spock with :live long and prosper....

what do you think? can we start a rave hand signal?

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

		foolish fish

nanu nanu to all

Precedence: bulk


As many of you have seen, I occasionally actually get ahead of my work and
start some hella long and boring SFRaves message... it's this little
fiction I came up with in my head.  No politicans were harmed in the
writing of this story.

IF CHELSEA WAS A RAVER...

Excerpts from an interview of a proud new addition to the Stanford
student body...

Interviewer:	So, Chelsea, how have things been for you as far as
outside activities go?  Met any boys?

Chelsea:	Yep.  I like boys.  They are, after all, just under 50% of
the population.  The male vote is important, and although I'm not actively
pursuing a career in politics, it's good not to sever any ties.  But
honestly, some of my best friends are guys.

Interviewer:	Well, What I meant was, any possible love interests on the
horizon?

Chelsea:	Well, I am seeing this girl in my PreColumbian American
History class... she always wears her hair in these pigtails and wears
these hella worked pants that she buys used and then flares out with the
cutest little patches that she sews in herself... plus she's got a fine
little face and a pierced hood.

Interviewer:	Alright... well, er... so what have you been doing other
than that?

Chelsea:	What do you mean?

Interviewer:	Seen any good movies lately?

Chelsea:	No, movies kinda suck lately, except for the music.
Soundtracks have been getting better lately.  I listen to the
Trainspotting soundtrack all the time, and I'm stoked about some of the
stuff from the new batman flick.

Interviewer:	Oh, you mean the recent outbreak of movies featuring
Techno music in their soundtracks?

Chelsea:	Well... I don't really like Techno all that much, I'm a
little more into the edgier jungle... ya know, hard techstep, hardstep...
even some jumpup when I'm feeling freaky.

Interviewer:	My my... have you gone to any good ... er... jungle
concerts lately?

Chelsea:	Concerts? What egg did you hatch from?  I mean, I've seen
a couple live PA's... but no concerts.  I don't want to sit there with
Budweiser presents this, Miller presents that... it's all so old.

Interviewer:	Live P.A's?

Chelsea:	Yeah.  You know, when an artist performs live at a rave as
opposed to spinning.

Interviewer:	Rave?  Are you saying you go to raves?

Chelsea:	sometimes... could I get some water?

Interviewer:	So, at these raves... what do you do?

Chelsea:	Meet people, dance.  What do you think we do there?

Interviewer:	Oh.. I mean, there's just a lot of press about drugs and
craziness.

Chelsea:	No, no... It's about the music and the community.  Yep,
the people and the DJs and the general overall vibe.

Interviewer:	So do you have any favorites performers?  I'd assume
there's a couple DJs you like more than others...

Chelsea:	Um... I dunno.  I really LOVE Thad... I think he spins as
HAK now... and Science floats my boat, and he's so cute!  ReAch rocks
too.  But I don't just like jungle... I've been really into deep house
lately too.  Sounds really good... well... kinda around 5am.  I just like
DJs that get a fat groove on without getting stale.

Interviewer:	5am!?  So these are the genuine article these raves.  Like
the kind in England back in the late eighties, early nineties.  Hmmm...
Say, have you ever tried ecstacy?

Chelsea:	Um... I tasted it, but I never swallowed.

Interviewer:	So, any plans to get more involved in the scene here, or
is this just an opportunity to unwind from some of your grueling Stanford
cirriculum?

Chelsea:	Yeah, but not around here.  I mean, I love the people, but
the scene needs help in other places.

Interviewer:	Like where?  Seattle?  LA?

Chelsea:	No, Washington DC... I know this PHAT location.

Peace,
AndyW

Precedence: bulk


Um... just keep playing the music.  I have reprogrammed at least 3 of my
coworkers.

One of them is this old guy with no hair that came out to see us at Slow
Roasted once, and you know what?

He came up to me after my set, and said "Damn... it's so neat how you just
kinda control the feel of the room with the music, while at the same time
playing music in response to the feel of the room... and that continous
music where the beat never stops... how long have they been doing that
for?"

It was a very pleasant surprise.  He wasn't a hippy... actually a little
too old to be a hippy (more of a beat really).

Don't make adversaries, take a couple deep breaths and educate.  I mean,
it doesn't do anything for anybody to hear that they are square, or don't
understand.  Just be patient, or ignore them.  They're obviously saying
something because you've given them enough information about yourself and
your weekend whereabouts to get them confident about their comments and
what the effect on you will be.

Don't let the bastards get you down.

Dr. Andy Joyce Brothers.
Psychiatric Aid for the Raving Community

p.s.	Does anybody else here think LoveLine is the biggest piece of shit
ever?  I grew up in LA, and was tortured for years, only to have it go
national after I finally leave.  Yuck.  Ew.  Phooey.

yeah, how about the american sign language symbol for the letter "e",
when I am driving my funky painted van down the highway, when I was
coming to and from the BBQ and Beats campout, I got 3 peace signs, one
wave, and one thumbs up, one honk, and one dude yelled out of his
cadillac asking if we had any "grass".  There is definitely a raver
comradery but I think the bulk of these folks were just cool people not
necessarily ravers.

Hi Foolish Fish I did not get to say goodbye to you after FnF!  But I

there?"  I heard your voice say, "yeah, probably sleeping"  I was konked
out, sort of.  So, sorry I didn't say goodbye!!!  WHOT A GREAT PARTY!

Good comeback Dori! 

Still think u need to get to listen to a decent DJ who can move u no 
matter how hard or soft its gets tho. One thing that ive noticed about 
the US (& had backed up by a lot of people) is that too many local 
"name" DJs are shite at keeping the flow going....they can do all the 
mixing & tricks but can't really keep it together on the floor.

Oh yeah, just to clear up....im not from the West Coast, im from London 
(im visiting, DJing, doing record co stuff & generally having 
fun).....so i dont have to get involved with all this west coast vs east 
coast slanging.....London towers over both musically so we can look down 
on your colonial bickerings & smile benevolently (HUMOUR ALERT....feel 
free to comment but dont get too heated!)

As for all that noisy jungle stuff....yeah i like but ive had it going 
for the past 8 years so something different is good....i don't know how 
long you've been into it but come back to me after 8 years & tell me if 
yer still jumping-up!


"Electronica"....you're dead right....which fuck-up came up with THAT!

i did all the NYC jungle bit when i first came over in July....lotsa fun 
but it was a bit like stepping back in time a few years....Konkrete 
Jungle (with Aphrodite funnily enuff), Jungle Nation, one of Dara's 
warehouse parties (with some soppy house following Dara's set....what 
the ?!?).....KJ was fun if a little cheesy like u say....i had a great 
time in the Smelly Apple...can't wait to get back

Following on from some of the East vs West comebacks, my own feeling so 
far is that NYC is one of the friendlier places ive been to....it was a 
great place to start my trip ......SF is a great place too but i sort of 
get the impression that people are a bit to cool here to be toooo 
friendly....altho the rave scene does't really follow that....
Having said that i have met some really good people & did get to the 
best party ive been to in the US (see my Tsunami posting).....

Well ill be back in NYC on the 16th & i think i may be playing there @ 
some point.....and be off to some parties too....then back to London & 
some rest (fat chance!)

Keep hard-assed bitchin' Dori,

see u in the Jungle

invisible cola

hey sweets - re: your comment as to "having fun whoever I am" - well, 
I'm
dori and what I say here is pretty indicative of who i am - cuz unlike a
lotta people, i'm the same online and off...

I had a slight feeling that that "pussy jungle" comment might piss a lot 
of
west coasters off - from what I've heard from east coast (pahdon me, 
DRUM &
BASS - over here in nyc we laugh at people who say that, cuz again, it's
that whole black clad vodka-swilling yuppie crowd and music industry 
goofus
crowd that uses that term, they tag it on with "electronica: - tell me 
THAT
phrase doesn't make you barf and I WILL laugh) anyway, from what i've 
heard
about the west coast scene, y'all are kinda into that - whereas in new
york, we like to get slapped in the face with the hard jump up base
lines...  Perhaps it's the different vibes of the cities - but, yeah, I 
was
sorta waiting for someone to take offense to that, and yeah, you're 
right,
i was referring to the Bukem/Goldie SHITE (a term most brits I know 
still
love, hehehe) - you know, it's good for sitting in the park or whatever,
but don't get that shit near me in a club or a party, hear me?  Cuz it
makes me sit down.

As for the use of the term "intelligent" - yeah, you guessed it - more 
than
likely, I as well included this word in quotes, because I think it's
ridiculous as well - as I said before, it's a term given to the wimpy
jungle beats by people who can't handle anything more...

as far as room for "some variety, melodics, rolling drums & a little 
>space in the music for you eh, so stuff anyone ("shit yuppies") who 
>likes it...........where to start..."

start with Aphrodite - he keeps it hard enough (although he gets a 
little
wimpy periodically as well) and those bass lines rolling enough to keep 
me
interested in his experimentation while my butt gets movin' to the 
beats.  

Ya know, the reason I like the word "jungle" probably has a lot to do 
with
where I LIVE - people in new york take their jungle SERIOUSLY and hell,
this city is known for being called the "koncrete jungle" ya know...  
(We
even get a cheesy monday night jungle thang called the same, headed by
Shitslinger and TC Islept, absolutely the WORST MC known to man)...

Dori
*hard-ass New York bitch*

> "Electronica"....you're dead right....which fuck-up came up with THAT!

Just a note-

I think it's funny that people have problems with the catch-phrase
"electronica"...

3 years ago, friends of mine had an electronic-music college radio show
at CMU in Pittsburgh called 'electronica', and there's a music-makers
email discussion list also called 'electronica' that's been going strong
for just as long...both were started by Tom Butcher from Hyperreal.

I've been calling electronic music 'electronica' longer than the media...

:)

Now this was a goooooooooooooood party.....had nearly all the essential 
ingriedients...top DJs (Tsuyoshi Suzuki is one of the best....its just a 
shame he's taken this long to get over here....make sure he comes 
back!), excellent crowd of people (young & old, freaky & straight(ish)) 
giving such a good vibe, well decorated venue, relaxed management (where 
were they?!)......good fun.

I chatted to a good few people & nearly all reckoned that this was the 
best party they'd been to in the Bay....and it was the best ive been to 
in the 2 months ive been in the country.....it could have been a party 
back home in London, it was THAT good!

By the way, it was mainly Trance going down, NOT Goa Trance....lets drop 
the "G" word purleese..............

So total respect to the CCC crew & all who made it such a good 
night....and to anyone who didn't make it, look out for more CCC parties 
cos they obviously know wot they're doing!

invisible cola

On Mon, 8 Sep 1997, invisible cola wrote:

> the US (& had backed up by a lot of people) is that too many local 
> "name" DJs are shite at keeping the flow going....they can do all the

-->	Ummm, I dunno about that.  I am never disappointed by Ethan or
Dutch (from what I remember of Dutch) or Garth--I would have added Dan,
but I wasn't too impressed by his Nikita performance last Friday *Hi
Glitterboy :) *.  I tend to think there is too much "Geridge" (aka
Garage; which was never clearly explained to me--probably just Breakbeats)
in the London scene.

 
> Oh yeah, just to clear up....im not from the West Coast, im from London 
> (im visiting, DJing, doing record co stuff & generally having 
> fun).....so i dont have to get involved with all this west coast vs east 
> coast slanging.....London towers over both musically so we can look down 
> on your colonial bickerings & smile benevolently (HUMOUR ALERT....feel 
> free to comment but dont get too heated!)
> 
-->	Err, I don't agree with that either.  Maybe the scene in London
has more offerings, but the music isn't necessarily better.  I went to the
parties at The Fridge and The Gardening Club and The 'Shaft and the
whatnots all over town (the worst has been @ The MInistry), but wasn't too
impressed.  If the music happened to be good, the people were too cold,
but that's how it is with the blokes an' birds in London, period.


> As for all that noisy jungle stuff....yeah i like but ive had it going 
> for the past 8 years so something different is good....i don't know how 
> long you've been into it but come back to me after 8 years & tell me if 
> yer still jumping-up!

-->  	Ditto! I was at Logical Progression one night (not a pure jungle
venue, I know) with a good DJ/MC combo, but it still left me cold.  I
dunno, D&B, Breakbeat and Jungle don't do nothin' for me; but I _am_ able
to appreciate (and occassionaly dance to ;) ) a good set.


	Maybe it's different at the raves, but I didn't find any in three
months of searching.  I think the UG in London is dead and buried,
everything's just advertised in the Time-out.


:)
M&m

> >
> >Ive found over in the US "Jungle" tends to mean the more mash-up 
> >styles.....as the scene has developed in a diff way over here there 
> >hasn't really been the Logical Progression ('scuse the pun) of styles 
> so 
> >maybe junglists do actually see the more mellow stuff as shit 
> >yuppie...Jungle Lite if you like.....try & get a sense of the whole 
> Drum 
> >& Bass scene (maybe hear some GOOD d&B DJs who can play the more mellow 
> >stuff & still move a crowd)....you're doing yourself a disservice by 
> >blithely dissing this stuff....
> >
> >One minor point to ponder on...ive noticed the word Jungle used a lot 
> >more over this side of the water (as opposed to Drum & Bass)...the term 
> >actually comes from the totally offensive & racist phrase "jungle 
> >bunny"....now the  J & D&B terms are pretty interchangable now & no-one 
> >cares/knows of the origins...so does it matter? PJ & Smiley (Shut Up & 
> >Dance), two of the original pioneers, preferred the term "Ragga House" 
> >and used to get really offended by the term "Jungle"....but then whos 
> >heard of Ragga House?

my take is that the phrase "electronica" came from a Kraftwerk song, a
VERY long time ago, I had no idea it came from the media.  I forget
which song-- "musique nonstop" I think says "musica electronica"  Since
this song is engrained in most of our heads the catch phrase
"electronica" may have stuck.  It means electronic in (Italian?) 

What if people said "music that is created using drum machines and
keyboards"  and then elaborated...I think it would be funny.

Techno- same as above and then I really don't know.  Everybody has a
different opinion because it is used to describe anything played at
raves.

Trance- same as above with arpeggiating and flanging analog keyboard
tracks on every 16th note, song changes on the 16th and 32nd measures
and so on, 130-140bpms

Jungle- same as above with looped snare tracks and high hats on the 16th
notes, reggae samples (sometimes), de-tuned Toms used as bass lines, 2
or 3 breakdowns, 160-170 bpms

House- same as above with Kick on the 1st beat of every measure. High
hat comes in an 8th note later.  Samples of a woman singing a catch
phase or "wooohooohooo"  Simple FM keyboard line with 4-5 note riffs.
120-130bpms.

Industrial- same as above with Kick on the 1st beat of every measure and
the Snare on the 2nd beat, dark keyboards, samples from horror movies.

OK, WHATEVER!!!! (big w symbol)
I am, like, totally not serious, OKay!

Goldie

jimg/skoop wrote:

> Well Fuck!  How much do you need?  If it's not that much, as you say,
> I'd
> pitch in $10-20, and if a handful of other peeps on this list did,
> maybe
> that'd help you out somewhat.  I'd gladly toss $20 if I knew that it
> was
> seriously helping someone out...
>
> Well folks?  It's only the cost of one party...
>

     Wow, I don't know what to say...  I've never had to really accept
things from people, nor have I ever really needed to.  But if you really
want to help me out, I have to swallow my pride and gratefully accept.
No matter how adament I normally am with regards to accepting help of
the monetary kind, I know that as screwed up as my situation is right
now, it would be incredibly stupid of me to refuse help, regardless of
pride.
      Just to make sure, though, I hope you and no one else on the list
felt like I was fishing for people to give/loan me money.  That was not
my intention at all.  I guess I was just putting some of my frustrations
into words and using the list as a sounding board.  If people want to
help me, I'll accept (hard as it is) and be incredibly grateful, but I
am, by no means trying to make people feel obligated by
pity/sympathy/whatever reason they might have.  I'm not saying that's
how you feel, either, but I want to make sure people know that I had no
ulterior motives/intentions in making my post.  Thank you, thank you,
THANK YOU, for caring about someone you don't know further than my words
that I have commited to this list.  If you're serious about the $20,
I'll let you know that it will be used to fill my tank to get to school
for a week.  I transfer to U.C. Berkeley in January, and I'm finishing
up my last few lower-division classes at a community college in Sonora
(a twenty-minute commute from my house), and I don't want the lack of
gas money to get in the way of my journey to my dream school, which I
worked so hard to get in to.  That's my biggest priority right now
beyond my beautiful girls, but thankfully, I have them completely taken
care of for the month and the only suffering resulting from my situation
is being taken by me and not by my kids.  I know that was probably more
information than you needed, but sometimes when people help people, they
want to know what it is being used for, how it is helping that person.
    Anyways, before I waste any more bandwidth with my personal
situation, I'll shut up.  But once again, thank you.
                                Love,
                                    Julie Mae

for people to be able to contact me, but just in case, here it is again,

open.

discovered a friend!

The strangest event has taking place.. 

I come home from work, and I have a new mouse pad on my desk. It's a really
cool MMX "See it! Hear it! Experience it!" 3D logo. But I still don't know
how it got here. Everyone that lives here has denied it. And they were
pretty sincere. No one knows what the hell I am talking about.. It's so
freaky, I wouldn't be surprised if my computer has disappeared by tomorrow
after work.
And that would really suck. Everyone at work would be feeling so sorry for
me, they would probably give me another computer. But where do you go after
loosing seven gigabytes of information, entertainment, and past
experiences? Who do you turn to? I guess I better delete all my nudie
pictures..

=]:. ..:.
I mean, ravE pictures.. Don't want nobody trying to black mail me when I
run for president. 

Thanx for the mouse pad nStuff.
Jeff
I suppose this could be, somehow tied to the ravEs.
Maybe it was this freakin annoying spirit that's been bothering me. The
ghost keeps making my tools disappear..And it literally try's to make every
little thing NOT go my way. Maybe it gave me the new mouse pad as a way of
saying, the jokes on me or something.

i know we have varying tastes and all, but ive been to the gathering, ive 
been to sunset, gateway, a bundle of FnF's, many ccc's, to burningman 
twice, and let me tell ya something magical happened at tsunami that 
makes it stand out easily as one of the best. pure raw energy! 
not being able to make it to that campout this weekend i ended up going 
to tsunami, totally unsuspecting of the immense experience in store -- 
they dont call it by that name for nothing =)
i hadnt danced so connected to everything and everyone in a long time, 
especially in the morning when daylight came into the room and everyone 
was groovin hard, smiling, tranced out till the last track... 




your local phreaked out day glo goan still glowing from burningman 
recharged to the max all over again.

I think the main v-mail lists all the info about where you can get tix.  The 
number on my flyer sez 415.541.5030, there are local numbers for other areas 
but I don't wanna list them all.  Look at the sfraves calendar!

Looks like you can get flyers if you live in SF, Berkeley, San Jose, Sac, 
Santa Cruz, Palo Alto, Santa Rosa, Hayward, Portland, Seattle, and Las Vegas.  
There's a whole lotta SF ticket places.

Presale tickets are $25 (but I know here in Sac the store selling them charges 
a $1 service fee, so they may be more).  I believe they are $30 at the door, 
but I'd buy presales to avoid some waiting and save some money ($5 extra bucks 
for water)!

I'm getting my presales on Wednesday!  Woohoo!

xoxo--Miccaela Badger

ONE COMMENT ON THIS:  Freedom of the press is exactly that; freedom of the 
press.  The press can and does regulate itself as to what to cover and what 
not to cover.
Don't confuse government regulation of the press vs private 'control' of the 
press.  Just because you take a picture or write your opinion about 
something, doesn't mean that anyone wants to or is obliged to print it.

Also, don't forget (I think) it was the paper's chief editor that made this 
statement.  Personally, the less I see of Chelsea in the news the better.

Thomas
B-)
 ----------
