> Date: Mon Sep 08 16:51:23 PDT 1997
> From: andy@saturn5.com
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org 
> Subject: Fiction
> 
> 
> As many of you have seen, I occasionally actually get ahead of my work and
> start some hella long and boring SFRaves message... it's this little
> fiction I came up with in my head.  No politicans were harmed in the
> writing of this story.
> 
> IF CHELSEA WAS A RAVER...
> 
> Excerpts from an interview of a proud new addition to the Stanford
> student body...
> 
> Interviewer:	So, Chelsea, how have things been for you as far as
> outside activities go?  Met any boys?
> 
> Chelsea:	Yep.  I like boys.  They are, after all, just under 50% of
> the population.  The male vote is important, and although I'm not actively
> pursuing a career in politics, it's good not to sever any ties.  But
> honestly, some of my best friends are guys.
> 
> Interviewer:	Well, What I meant was, any possible love interests on the
> horizon?
> 
> Chelsea:	Well, I am seeing this girl in my PreColumbian American
> History class... she always wears her hair in these pigtails and wears
> these hella worked pants that she buys used and then flares out with the
> cutest little patches that she sews in herself... plus she's got a fine
> little face and a pierced hood.
> 
> Interviewer:	Alright... well, er... so what have you been doing other
> than that?
> 
> Chelsea:	What do you mean?
> 
> Interviewer:	Seen any good movies lately?
> 
> Chelsea:	No, movies kinda suck lately, except for the music.
> Soundtracks have been getting better lately.  I listen to the
> Trainspotting soundtrack all the time, and I'm stoked about some of the
> stuff from the new batman flick.
> 
> Interviewer:	Oh, you mean the recent outbreak of movies featuring
> Techno music in their soundtracks?
> 
> Chelsea:	Well... I don't really like Techno all that much, I'm a
> little more into the edgier jungle... ya know, hard techstep, hardstep...
> even some jumpup when I'm feeling freaky.
> 
> Interviewer:	My my... have you gone to any good ... er... jungle
> concerts lately?
> 
> Chelsea:	Concerts? What egg did you hatch from?  I mean, I've seen
> a couple live PA's... but no concerts.  I don't want to sit there with
> Budweiser presents this, Miller presents that... it's all so old.
> 
> Interviewer:	Live P.A's?
> 
> Chelsea:	Yeah.  You know, when an artist performs live at a rave as
> opposed to spinning.
> 
> Interviewer:	Rave?  Are you saying you go to raves?
> 
> Chelsea:	sometimes... could I get some water?
> 
> Interviewer:	So, at these raves... what do you do?
> 
> Chelsea:	Meet people, dance.  What do you think we do there?
> 
> Interviewer:	Oh.. I mean, there's just a lot of press about drugs and
> craziness.
> 
> Chelsea:	No, no... It's about the music and the community.  Yep,
> the people and the DJs and the general overall vibe.
> 
> Interviewer:	So do you have any favorites performers?  I'd assume
> there's a couple DJs you like more than others...
> 
> Chelsea:	Um... I dunno.  I really LOVE Thad... I think he spins as
> HAK now... and Science floats my boat, and he's so cute!  ReAch rocks
> too.  But I don't just like jungle... I've been really into deep house
> lately too.  Sounds really good... well... kinda around 5am.  I just like
> DJs that get a fat groove on without getting stale.
> 
> Interviewer:	5am!?  So these are the genuine article these raves.  Like
> the kind in England back in the late eighties, early nineties.  Hmmm...
> Say, have you ever tried ecstacy?
> 
> Chelsea:	Um... I tasted it, but I never swallowed.
> 
> Interviewer:	So, any plans to get more involved in the scene here, or
> is this just an opportunity to unwind from some of your grueling Stanford
> cirriculum?
> 
> Chelsea:	Yeah, but not around here.  I mean, I love the people, but
> the scene needs help in other places.
> 
> Interviewer:	Like where?  Seattle?  LA?
> 
> Chelsea:	No, Washington DC... I know this PHAT location.
> 
> Peace,
> AndyW
> 
> 
>

Precedence: bulk

At 5:13 PM -0800 9/8/97, Glitterboy wrote:
>>Nikita vs. Release....aren't they both at 1015 Folsom? Just on different
>>nights?
>>Neal
>
>Yep...I was just wondering, in the event I only had energy to go out one
>night on any given weekend, which way would I maximize my fun :)  Each has
>the possiblity of being at 1015 Folsom, but they are on Friday, Saturday,
>and Sunday, respectively.
>Thomas

Nikita (along with Spundae) and Release are put on by two different
production crews. The Spundae guys do a great job of bringing in big-name
talent from all over the world... they are top-notch at this. They deserve
major thanks and support for bringing in the amazing DJs and live acts that
have graced their stage. While I think 1015 attracts some people who aren't
necessarily on the "good vibe" side, I think most of the people at their
events are there for the one thing that counts - the music.

You can't really say this about release - that's put on by Martel, and the
DJs are generally a very small crew who do most of his parties. Martel also
does I-spy at VSF on Friday nights, and the Leopard Lounge at the bar
"Blues" in the Triangle (ick!) on Sunday nights.

Personally, I avoid Martel's nights. IMHO, they have a really
pickup-oriented crowd who are there to see and be seen (or is that scene?)
and not for the music. Generally lots of attitude, soaked in alcohol. I
should qualify this by saying that I haven't really spent much time at any
of his nights recently, so I don't know if that's changed...

I do have to give respect to Martel, though, for his longevity and success.
It takes a lot of work to throw parties, and he's been doing it forever.


A final comment about 1015 - Whatever you think about the crowd, it's a
great large-size space, with a good sound system, cool lighting, and lots
of different environments to play in. It's not in any way "underground,"
but it's not a bad place. In a lot of ways, it is what you make of it. If
you're there with a bunch of friends, it can be fun. Remember that "vibe"
is very often as much your own attitude about a crowd, the music, and the
space, as it is what you're picking up off everyone else. (And while you're
sitting there, stewing about a place with a "bad vibe," you're sending out
those bad vibes yourself!) I've been at UG parties where everyone was
raving about the great vibe (no pun intended, of course), but I was in a
pissy mood and didn't think the vibe was all that great. And at "clubs"
where other people said the vibe sucked, but I was in a great mood and
thought otherwise!

--
Brian

and pass on gossip....  This is not only disrespectful, but its plain
ignorant behavior.

> not everybody 'enjoys' this large and somewhat dangerous events.

Please speak for yourself, not  for everybody.  As far as I know, everybody
that has ever come out to a Feel Good event has, for the most part, enjoyed
themselves.  Maybe if you actually had first hand experience, then It would
place some value on your opinion.

> i went to the planet new year make-up party, which i must point out
> WASN'T a fge party,

At least you got that right.  Cool World, and FGE are very different
productions

> but a massive none the less, and i watched two
> girls get in a cat fight and i got pushed back against the wall.
> ouch!  that was 1 in 4 fights that i personally witnessed.  so i stayed
> outside mostly.

> watch, or to even be 10 feet near.  and you don't need to be sailing
> on the love boat sipping rum and cokes to be making a profit.  find
> another meal ticket is all i'm saying.

That's unfortunate that all that happened at that $6 party.  But all
because you did not have fun at some other production companies massive,
you think that I should stop throwing parties and get a job?  WOW... that's
something I've never thought of...  Thank you so much for making that
revolutionary suggestion.  I have one for you that may be just as absurd.
Since you did not have fun at the party, maybe you should STOP Raving
entirely.  And what does it matter to you what I do for a living, you have
never come to support any of my events, so its not YOUR money that I'm
"supposedly" getting.... so where's the beef?

> no, i have yet to throw a party, but someday i probably will.  and i
> sure as hell won't charge 20 bucks a head at the door with tight ass
> security patting people down.

I wish you the best of luck at your party, whenever it is you decide to do
it.   I hope you have a great party, and charge whatever you want, and have
whoever you want there.  But whatever you do, please do it with a good
attitude and for the right reasons, because that is what is going to shine
through to the people that come to your party and create the vibe.

> ok, i'm going to end this before i really start pissing people off.
> sorry, i didn't mean to offend anyone if i did.  just my two bits.

We are all entitled to our own opinion.... and you just read mine.

Keep it real

Ray Vonie

To: renegade@linex.com (Sean Murray)

> 
> invisible cola wrote:
> 
> > "Now this was a goooooooooooooood party.. chatted to a good few people
> > & nearly all reckoned that this was the best party they'd been to in
> > the Bay..."
> 
> Guess You never been to one of the Bay's oldest & finest underground
> parties, SUNSET.  Check it out while you still here, ifin'
> you have a chance.  Ask around for the Hotline #.  Last Sunday was
> beautiful. Peace.

Let me preface this by saying I love sunset.  The house vibe on a lazy
sunday afternoon is always pleasant.

But you can't compare Sunset to Tsunami.  Sunset has been playing the same
style of music for about 3 years, that goovy house.  Tsumani, on the other
hand, had the most state-of-the-art dance music on the planet.  The psy-trance
at Tsunami was so far beyond any other dance music I have heard in the
bay area or anywhere.  Myself, and many others, had such incredible
expereinces there... dancing FAR beyond our physical limits, using
"jedi powers" to quickly bounce around the dance floor without bumping
into anyone (using extra-sensory perception to keep from hitting people
out of our line of vision).  Experiencing super-human strength and agility
that the music allowed us to access within ourselves.  I am still glowing
from what happened on saterday.

I guess what I am trying to say is, that there are levels we can take
this culture beyond our imagination.  It is parties like Tsumani that push
the evelope, and show us just how incredible our electronic dance music
culture can be.

-troy

I am going to avoid personal attacks and instead focus on just your flawed
logic. Here is an example of what is wrong with it:

(As an extension of your logic)

I dislike the KKK. I have been, nor do I ever plan on going to a KKK
rally to "give these folks a chance," or get "first hand knowledge" of
what they are about. Their reputation preceeds them, and I have no desire
to look much further. Am I therefore ignorant and disrespectful of them
and what they are about?

Now, it would be stupid of me to compare you to the KKK or any other such
nonsense. However, I hope that the above might demonstrate to you
that because someone does not have have "first hand knowledge" of you
and/or your events, a picture can still be drawn. Whether that reputation
is earned is of course always a subject for debate.

warning: the opinions expressed below are just that - opinions. if you
disagree with something that i'm about to write, please think about your
response and point out why you disagree. calling me a fool who doesn't know
how to throw a party (which has been done before) does little to educate
me.

At 12:38 PM 9/9/97, Ray Vonie wrote:
>Doreen wrote:
>> no, i have yet to throw a party, but someday i probably will.  and i
>> sure as hell won't charge 20 bucks a head at the door with tight ass
>> security patting people down.

opinion #1: i know promoters who charge $20/head and _still_ don't make any
money. do you know how much it costs to throw a party?

#2: my first west coast party had 2 stabbings. shit. give me the tight ass
security any day. i've got nothing to hide, unless you count the end of a
blowpop as a weapon. sure, it's a pain in the ass. but wouldn't you rather
be alive? i think that there can be ways of keeping security as protection
rather than as a nuisance... i've not often found security guards to be a
nuisance to me. but then again, i'm just there to dance and have a good
time. not to be clich, and i'm seeing my age more often than not in my
opinions of things, but times have changed. there are 12 year olds at
parties. doing drugs. there are weapons. that kill. wake up. yes, these
things happen (i think) more often at massives... but this 'scene' is an
urban one, which attracts urban elements, and along with that comes crime.
yes, i've found that i prefer the smaller parties. but you know, sometimes
you've just got to go and hear someone spin, and that might bring you to a
massive. so what all this dribble boils down to is that i'd rather have
fucking metal detectors if it will ensure a safe, good time.

oh yeah, and i've been under the impression that actually having these
tight ass security guards does help in keeping the cops at bay....

cheers - e. :)

Crew,

Instead of calling the various types of music people who rave enjoy, why
not call it "dance music," or "underground dance music"?  That's how I'm
starting to refer to it.  After all, it's not found exclusively at raves.
Moreover
(hardly ever get to use that word!), if you let someone listen to a little
ambient,
or goa, or hardhouse, or jungle, etc., and tell the listener "this is rave
music,"
that person will get too narrow a view of what might be heard at a given
party.  Class?  Anyone?  Anyone?

Peace & beats,
Eric

On Tue, 9 Sep 1997, e.menon wrote:

> #2: my first west coast party had 2 stabbings. shit. give me the tight ass
> security any day. 

I would hope as a result that you have a better idea of which "parties" to
avoid now. Rather than "give me the tight ass security" I much prefer
"give me people that aren't interested in hurting each other." 

> i've got nothing to hide, unless you count the end of a
> blowpop as a weapon. sure, it's a pain in the ass. but wouldn't you rather
> be alive? 

Sure, which is why I don't go to parties that I wouldn't feel safe at,
parties that there is no necessity to search people at. I really feel that
there are some trust issues involved, and by invading ones personal
privacy by seaching your body, the party-thrower is expressing their
distrust in you. This is the unfortunate side-effect of having
parties that are too big. Why go to a party where you don't trust the
promoter, and they in turn cannot trust you? 

>i think that there can be ways of keeping security as protection
> rather than as a nuisance... i've not often found security guards to be a
> nuisance to me. but then again, i'm just there to dance and have a good
> time. not to be clich, and i'm seeing my age more often than not in my
> opinions of things, but times have changed. there are 12 year olds at
> parties. doing drugs. there are weapons. that kill. wake up. yes, these
> things happen (i think) more often at massives... 

In my personal experience, it would be more appropriate to say
*EXCLUSIVELY* at massives. I have never been to a UG event where I have
witnessed a fight, stabbing, or killing. That is not to say they have
never occured, however I have never seen or heard of any.

> but this 'scene' is an urban one, which attracts urban elements, and
> along with that comes crime.

B.S. Don't you think that the bored suburbanite gangster wannabes don't
cause as many of these problems as anyone else?

> yes, i've found that i prefer the smaller parties. but you know, sometimes
> you've just got to go and hear someone spin, 

When your life is at risk? Sorry, there is no one that is that good. 

> and that might bring you to a
> massive. so what all this dribble boils down to is that i'd rather have
> fucking metal detectors if it will ensure a safe, good time.

All that it helps ensures is that there will be less metallic objects at
an event. It ensures *nothing* 

Want proof? When going to SFO on countless occasions, I have a
several inch long folding pocket knife that I regularly carry with me. I
also carry a lot of change, a phone, two pagers, various pieces of
paper, etc. in my pocket at any given time. I have found that if I dump
the knife on the bottom, with the change, phone, etc. on top, they *never*
find the knife. This is all in plain view, right in front of trained,
certified, security-cleared airport security guards. Now, how efficient
are those $5.00 rent-a-cops? Want to bet your life on it? 

					Black Adder

re:all the junk below....

the underground in london is nowhere near ded & buried....u just didn't 
find it............anyone who even CONSIDERS going near the Ministry of 
Shite is never going to get anywhere near wot is good in 
London..........the G Club & Shaft died out long ago too.....u lucked 
out kid!

As for Londoners being cold.........UK people in general will be more 
reserved than Americans in general....it just takes a little more 
effort.....a lot of americans i ve met who know brits, like that 
.......we are a completely diff. culture & so u should respect that when 
u visit  other places....it ain't going to be the same as being in SF or 
the US.....an open mind please.....................

(remember...it was a joke about the London thing!)


Remember: the best vibe is wherever u make it.....& that can be SF, 
London, NYC, A'dam, Barcelona, Hamburg, Berlin, Moscow, Sydney, Cape 
Town, Malawi, Bali, Pushka, Rio, Ibiza and many, many more 
places......go visit lots & lots of other places & then u may realise 
that no-where wins......and anyone who thinks that one place does, loses 
out on a lot of fun.....

One final thing....don't call women birds u sexist idiut!

love

invisible cola

> mixing & tricks but can't really keep it together on the floor.


-->	Ummm, I dunno about that.  I am never disappointed by Ethan or
Dutch (from what I remember of Dutch) or Garth--I would have added Dan,
but I wasn't too impressed by his Nikita performance last Friday *Hi
Glitterboy :) *.  I tend to think there is too much "Geridge" (aka
Garage; which was never clearly explained to me--probably just 
Breakbeats)
in the London scene.

 
> Oh yeah, just to clear up....im not from the West Coast, im from 
London 
> (im visiting, DJing, doing record co stuff & generally having 
> fun).....so i dont have to get involved with all this west coast vs 
east 
> coast slanging.....London towers over both musically so we can look 
down 
> on your colonial bickerings & smile benevolently (HUMOUR ALERT....feel 
> free to comment but dont get too heated!)
> 
-->	Err, I don't agree with that either.  Maybe the scene in London
has more offerings, but the music isn't necessarily better.  I went to 
the
parties at The Fridge and The Gardening Club and The 'Shaft and the
whatnots all over town (the worst has been @ The MInistry), but wasn't 
too
impressed.  If the music happened to be good, the people were too cold,
but that's how it is with the blokes an' birds in London, period.


> As for all that noisy jungle stuff....yeah i like but ive had it going 
> for the past 8 years so something different is good....i don't know 
how 
> long you've been into it but come back to me after 8 years & tell me 
if 
> yer still jumping-up!

-->  	Ditto! I was at Logical Progression one night (not a pure jungle
venue, I know) with a good DJ/MC combo, but it still left me cold.  I
dunno, D&B, Breakbeat and Jungle don't do nothin' for me; but I _am_ 
able
to appreciate (and occassionaly dance to ;) ) a good set.


	Maybe it's different at the raves, but I didn't find any in three
months of searching.  I think the UG in London is dead and buried,
everything's just advertised in the Time-out.


:)
M&m
"The best vibe ist still in San Francisco"



> >space in the music for you eh, so stuff anyone ("shit yuppies") who 
> >likes it...........where to start...
> >
> >Ive lived in London for the past 8 years & have heard Drum & Bass 
> evolve 
> >from Ragga-ed up breakbeat hardcore thru to the myriad of styles we 
get 
> >today.......and as a DJ i enjoy playing all types.
> >
> >Ive found over in the US "Jungle" tends to mean the more mash-up 
> >styles.....as the scene has developed in a diff way over here there 
> >hasn't really been the Logical Progression ('scuse the pun) of styles 
> so 
> >maybe junglists do actually see the more mellow stuff as shit 
> >yuppie...Jungle Lite if you like.....try & get a sense of the whole 
> Drum 
> >& Bass scene (maybe hear some GOOD d&B DJs who can play the more 
mellow 
> >stuff & still move a crowd)....you're doing yourself a disservice by 
> >blithely dissing this stuff....
> >
> >One minor point to ponder on...ive noticed the word Jungle used a lot 
> >more over this side of the water (as opposed to Drum & Bass)...the 
term 
> >actually comes from the totally offensive & racist phrase "jungle 
> >bunny"....now the  J & D&B terms are pretty interchangable now & 
no-one 
> >cares/knows of the origins...so does it matter? PJ & Smiley (Shut Up 
& 
> >Dance), two of the original pioneers, preferred the term "Ragga 
House" 
> >and used to get really offended by the term "Jungle"....but then whos 
> >heard of Ragga House?
> >
> >Keep on having fun WHOEVER you are

I am pleased to introduce the latest member in the XOR Clan.  Dexter, please
step up and say "hi".  Dexter is a lil shy he likes to hide in his secret
palce all day, but at nite he is one impressive dancer.  pulling off moves
no-one can cop.  Dexter grew up in Puerto Rico, in the jungle, not in the
trees though, underground.  As some might have guessed Dexter is a big hairy
tarantula!!!!!! He is not so scary though, except when he shows you his half
inch fangs.  Dexter is known as a Stripe Knee Tarantula, he is about 4.5
inches fang to spindle.  Pretty scary if he comes after you.  Well just
wanted to introduce my new friend.

bye
shua

i know we have varying tastes and all, but ive been to the gathering, 
ive 
been to sunset, gateway, a bundle of FnF's, many ccc's, to burningman 
twice, and let me tell ya something magical happened at tsunami that 
makes it stand out easily as one of the best. pure raw energy! 
not being able to make it to that campout this weekend i ended up going 
to tsunami, totally unsuspecting of the immense experience in store -- 
they dont call it by that name for nothing =)
i hadnt danced so connected to everything and everyone in a long time, 
especially in the morning when daylight came into the room and everyone 
was groovin hard, smiling, tranced out till the last track... 




your local phreaked out day glo goan still glowing from burningman 
recharged to the max all over again.

----Original Message Follows----
Date: Tue, 9 Sep 1997 13:40:52 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: "Eric P. Peterson" <ericp@best.com>
Subject: Umbrella term for "our" music

Crew,

Instead of calling the various types of music people who rave enjoy, why
not call it "dance music," or "underground dance music"?  That's how I'm
starting to refer to it.  After all, it's not found exclusively at 
raves.
Moreover
(hardly ever get to use that word!), if you let someone listen to a 
little
ambient,
or goa, or hardhouse, or jungle, etc., and tell the listener "this is 
rave
music,"
that person will get too narrow a view of what might be heard at a given
party.  Class?  Anyone?  Anyone?

Peace & beats,
Eric

>> IF CHELSEA WAS A RAVER...
>> 
>> Excerpts from an interview of a proud new addition to the Stanford
>> student body...
>> 
>> Interviewer:	So, Chelsea, how have things been for you as far as
>> outside activities go?  Met any boys?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Yep.  I like boys.  They are, after all, just under 50% of
>> the population.  The male vote is important, and although I'm not actively
>> pursuing a career in politics, it's good not to sever any ties.  But
>> honestly, some of my best friends are guys.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Well, What I meant was, any possible love interests on the
>> horizon?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Well, I am seeing this girl in my PreColumbian American
>> History class... she always wears her hair in these pigtails and wears
>> these hella worked pants that she buys used and then flares out with the
>> cutest little patches that she sews in herself... plus she's got a fine
>> little face and a pierced hood.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Alright... well, er... so what have you been doing other
>> than that?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	What do you mean?
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Seen any good movies lately?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	No, movies kinda suck lately, except for the music.
>> Soundtracks have been getting better lately.  I listen to the
>> Trainspotting soundtrack all the time, and I'm stoked about some of the
>> stuff from the new batman flick.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Oh, you mean the recent outbreak of movies featuring
>> Techno music in their soundtracks?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Well... I don't really like Techno all that much, I'm a
>> little more into the edgier jungle... ya know, hard techstep, hardstep...
>> even some jumpup when I'm feeling freaky.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	My my... have you gone to any good ... er... jungle
>> concerts lately?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Concerts? What egg did you hatch from?  I mean, I've seen
>> a couple live PA's... but no concerts.  I don't want to sit there with
>> Budweiser presents this, Miller presents that... it's all so old.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Live P.A's?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Yeah.  You know, when an artist performs live at a rave as
>> opposed to spinning.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Rave?  Are you saying you go to raves?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	sometimes... could I get some water?
>> 
>> Interviewer:	So, at these raves... what do you do?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Meet people, dance.  What do you think we do there?
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Oh.. I mean, there's just a lot of press about drugs and
>> craziness.
>> 
>> Chelsea:	No, no... It's about the music and the community.  Yep,
>> the people and the DJs and the general overall vibe.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	So do you have any favorites performers?  I'd assume
>> there's a couple DJs you like more than others...
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Um... I dunno.  I really LOVE Thad... I think he spins as
>> HAK now... and Science floats my boat, and he's so cute!  ReAch rocks
>> too.  But I don't just like jungle... I've been really into deep house
>> lately too.  Sounds really good... well... kinda around 5am.  I just like
>> DJs that get a fat groove on without getting stale.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	5am!?  So these are the genuine article these raves.  Like
>> the kind in England back in the late eighties, early nineties.  Hmmm...
>> Say, have you ever tried ecstacy?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	Um... I tasted it, but I never swallowed.
>>

>> is this just an opportunity to unwind from some of your grueling Stanford
>> cirriculum?
>>

>> the scene needs help in other places.
>> 
>> Interviewer:	Like where?  Seattle?  LA?
>> 
>> Chelsea:	No, Washington DC... I know this PHAT location.
>> 
>> Peace,
>> AndyW

Yea, Troy I must concur.  I danced my ass off at Tsunami.  THe music
reached into my being and tapped into a very powerful energy source.  
Just between you and me, my legs are still super dooper sore.  I can
barely walk.  So much for super-human. :)

This party took my dance experience up to another plateau.   The grass up
here is greener, the air is crisper, the sky a deeper azure, and my soul
bubbles cool like a mountain creek.  Wait, what's that I see in the
distance?  :)

Does anybody what those black vests were that so many people were wearing
at that party?  They kind of looked like back braces with embroidered
patches on the back.

Having seen Juggernaut at this "International Event Center" as they're 
now calling it, lemme tell you the space is fucking huge. I thought I'd 
seen some big spaces before but this thing was like the belly of the 
whale. Two good sized side rooms and one monster. A few people came with 
lawn chairs, blankets, and lanterns, which was a new one on me for an 
indoor event. Hopefully the power situation will be a bit more sorted out 
than last time - the generators went out several times during Derrick 
May's set...Cheers!

Hi all -

 Anybody remember Berkeley's Naked Guy ? Back about three, four years
ago? A buff dude who had philosophical/political objections to clothes,
so started to attend his UC Berkeley campus classes in the nude.

  He showed up in his usual un-attire at some raves too. I think our 
Campout Naked Guy was too short & skinny to be the Original Naked Guy.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

At 3:20 PM -0700 9/9/97, Breedlove wrote:
>How about we just ick snay on the labeling of people and music and
>scenes etc.
>
>Just take life for what it is. Encapsulation was never necessary
>
>-Breedlove

Thank you so much!

So many arguments arise from misunderstanding.  Many of the terms
associated with the rave scene are slang terms, based on personal
experiences.  There is not always mutuality among those experiences.  Each
of us looks through our own eyes and hears though our own ears.

Can you Describe...
House?
Techno?
Jungle?
Ambient?
Visuals?
Fashion?
Raver?
Us?
Them?
Me?
You?

These are all, of course, rhetorical questions.  But I ask everyone,
including myself, to try to stop before using labels as definite
descriptions.  They are really quite limiting.  Once you get past needing a
name for everything, you might be amazed at what you find.

Bye now,
Megan

Let me first preface this question with a preconceived notion I have: 
DJ's store their records in crates. I'm not sure where I got this from; 
perhaps pictures of DJ's with crates full of records or seeing a DJ  
using a crate to carry their records to a party???? 
 
So where the hell do you get a crate that records fit into?? 
 
I have now obtained two crates in which a 12" doesn't fit into *neatly* 
It seems these crates are only 12" wide; where records require a slightly 
wider space. I have since traded a crate with a friend who has one the  
correct size and I noticed something... 
 
Crates bought from a store are slightly bigger than the kind you find: or 
at least the kind I've found. Which raises all sorts of questions in my mind. 
In particular I can imagine the designer who came up with the 
size (imagine Spinal Tap): 
 
Designer: Well the crate is slightly bigger than 12" 
Marketer: Why is that?? 
Designer: Ya know, when 12" just isn't enough. You need that extra something. 
 
Is there some DJ originally come up with the idea to make and sell crates 
because 
their records didn't fit into a milk crate? 
 
Is there something else you put into crates (other than records) that 
require a size a little bigger than 12"  Other than ... well crates or rulers?? 
 
Do the clothes and things college students put into crates fit better in a 
12"+? 
 
Did some marketing person think 12"+ crates would sell better because you can 
only get 12" milk crates? 
 
Is this all part of a conspiracy?? ie. records used to fit into milk crates 
than  
they shrank them slightly to sell bigger ones to milk the DJ market... 
 
Damn it I want answers!!! Who is an Illminuati member and understands the  
burgeoning crate industry?!?! 
 
Extra question: 
Does anyone know the penalty for having a non "registered crate"?? 
 
Zza

Dear Beautiful People,

Alex, Matt and myself have been throwing a free weekly for some time now.
For those of you who have gone, you know it's had it's ups and downs.
We've had some great talent stop by, we've had ambient, trip hop,
downtempo house, jungle, experimental, r&b, and other good, funky stuff.

But more importantly, we've seen a lot of new faces, and had an
opportunity to have a regular, nearly entirely SFR supported event in the
south bay.  It's nice to meet the people behind the posts, and the lurkers
and the hotheads... everybody has been a pleasant surprise.  Pleased to
meet you all.

So... one last chance to get roasted slowly this summer... as always,
free, but we'd appreciate if you help out the store by getting a cup 'o
jo (it's not our store, but rather a nice symbiotic relationship... they
sell coffee, we get to play with our friends). They'll even let you check
your email at the counter if you have AOL, a web based account, or a shell
account (you email geek, you... I bet you're reading email right now).

djs:	science * matt schmitt * andyw
time:	8-11pm wednesday 9.10.97
place:	City Espresso Roasting Company
	On Steven's Creek at Lawrence Expressway in Santa Clara
	Across Steven's Creek from Safeway
	Next to Rock'N Tacos, Payless Drugs, Mr. Chaus, BedBathBeyond

So come by, pull up a chair and get a mellow groove on.

We'll probably start back up in a couple weeks, as soon as we get the urge
to lift a sound system every wednesday again.  If we don't, it'll be
because we have something else in the works... cause that patio gets cold 
come December and some of you have been wanting to dance.  We'll keep you
posted (as if we didn't bsp enough already...).

Peace,
Alex/Andy/Matt

p.s.	Thank you all the DJs that have been by, all the people who have
taken time out to chill with us, and most of all the people who came
through with the rides, cartridges, last minute sets and pulled mixers out
of their butts to make this a weekly event all summer long (Noah + Li +
James!!! Woohoo...).  Thanks everybody.

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

THE Naked Guy went to my high school.  When I first saw the news
coverage I laughed my ass off, cuz he was really shy.  Berkeley does 
funny things to people.  Hehe..  

I think it'd be pretty liberating to go to a naked rave.  Have there
been themed parties like this?  "In the Buff" "Turn on, tune in, get
naked"  In all seriousness, though.  I think after the initial
uncomfort it would be quite unifying.  No worries about trying to present
a certain image.  You is what you is.

Has anyone seen the movie, "The Full Monty"?  It's great fun watching fat,
skinny, awkward scottish unemployed steelworkers dance.  I highly
recommend it.

The underground is fun but I personally prefer the massives... the
intensity is what I need I tell you! :) I love the big parties but I like
the smaller ones too... nothing remains underground very long once enough
people are interested.. because people tell others, and it becomes wide
spread and main stream. I think if less people ripped on the massives and
went to one once in a while they would change their opinions...  (prepare
for flames!)

Byroni

         / /  /  _/ __/ __/ __/ __ \/ _ \/ ___/ __/ ( ) _ \/_  /

                     SEPTEMBER 19TH & 20TH, 1997

Alright Rave-kids... here's the scoop on the massive Liforce event
that's
going off next weekend (19th & 20th). This is Liquid & M.Mercury from
the
SFR mailing list. We've been working with this event since April, from
the
flyers, to djs, to lighting... we were there. We're not making money by
sending out this email, but just dont want ANY of you to miss this
event!
We know there is a lot of talk about what's going on, where, who, ect...

we'll let you in on the truth behind this party. It's real, it's legit,
everyone on the line-ups are gonna be there, it's going to be like
nothing
you've ever experienced.

We (Sherry & Ryan) have been working hand in hand with the head promoter
dude
since April. We've given him advice on the lineups, trying to get
together
everyone (djs & liveacts) we could think of people always WANT to see,
or
only heard about, designed the flyers, and pretty much advised him on
what
'most' ravers would want from the the best party they could dream up.

This is FCP's (first contact presents) first party, before they've been
all
involved in theatrical productions. We keep telling people, ITS NOT
(necisarily) THE DJS/MUSIC THAT YOU'LL REMEMBER... ITS EVERYTHING ELSE!
They're building these huge movie-like sets and props, lights & lasers
sets,
make-up artists from Startrek! for the aliens that'll be there :) and
so much more; we can't wreck the surprise for you, and tell you
everything!
It's gonna be so fun, we can't believe it's in less than two weeks.

Another note:
Some people are talking about 2 other things. Corporate sponsorship and
price.
Yes this party is being sponsored; they are Southwest, American,
Dollar renta Car, Noahs Bagels, and Starbucks. Yes, they're
corporations, but
look at who they are... they're there for a reason; the airlines are
flying
people out, the car rental place are for the same people, and the
remaining
two are giving out a free breakfast for everyone. Of course all of them
will
make money some way or another, but they will be helping elements in
making
the party better. Think how different that is from someone like NIKE or
MTV
sponsoring a rave.

And price... yes, we all know that raves (some atleast) are getting more

expensive these days. But are the parties getting better? Some are...
but
how offen do you feel that your $20 or $25 or $30 is well spent? We
dunno,
but sometimes we feel a little let down by just black lights and
speakers
for the price. Granted, its not just the setup that makes a party great
but
really, what you're going to get for 25-bucks (presale) is going to be
some-
thing you will remember forever. Shoot, get the double-night ticket and
it's
even cheaper. Each night is going to be different, it'll feel like
another
party all together. Anyways, enough hype, enough explaining, enough
text,dang..
sorry this is SO long...!

CHECK **********        WWW.FirstContactPresents.COM        
*************
or 1-888-664-8879  for updates, the LINEUPS, info on FCP, and more...

So people... come out to this, you wont regret/forget it :)
We're here for your questions too, so email away, ok?!
It's going to be beautiful and we hope to see you all there!

Much love and dancing and smiles!
Sherry & Ryan (Liquid and Mercury)   - liquid hg design
 

P.S.  They're planning on doing a PRE-PARTY on the Thursday before that
will
      be free for the BOTH-night tiket holders, and $5 or $8 for
everyone else.
      They'll probably only have one of the smaller rooms open with a
few of
      the djs below, but will give you a taste! Our guess is, that if
you go
      to ThAT, you'll go to the next 2 nights for sure :)    You WILL
SEE!

At 11:58 AM 9/9/97, nathan.b.beckord wrote:
>If anyone missed the ABC special Niteline report on BurningMan, or the
Strange 
>Universe segment on it last night, I taped them both.  The ABC report was a 
>view of it from fairly conservative group's perspective, but it was not 
>critical or condescending; actually, the guys in suits kinda sounded like
they 
>wish they coulda gone.  

The ABC report of it was amazingly good - the commentators were talking in
very positive terms about how people have gotten fed up with being passive
consumers and Burning Man is a place where everyone is a participant.  The
best quote of all: it's like what Halloween used to be when you were
younger.  They also nailed Washoe County for being so harsh on the permits
and costs.  What was just so keen for me was that much of what they were
talking about also rings true for the rave scene, at the scene's best.

	Brian

Just for all you ravers that always seem to forget something at home (I
know I always do!) , here's a check-list of all items brought to raves.
This way you wont forget anythng at home!! Print this out and check your
items off before you leave.

------------------------------------------------
Raver Check List 

Accessories
[ ] necklaces
[ ] bracelets
[ ] gloves
[ ] pacifier
[ ] whistle
[ ] wallet chain
[ ] glasses
[ ] hat/visor
[ ] stickers
[ ] glitter
[ ] laminates
[ ] rainbow umbererlla
[ ] fake eye-lashes

Toys
[ ] E Baby (stuffed animal)
[ ] playdough/gak/stress ball
[ ] random kid toys
[ ] baby keys
[ ] bubbles

Tools
[ ] filter masks
[ ] water bottle carry strap
[ ] unity wrist band
[ ] flourescent crayons
[ ] rave book
[ ] disposable camera
[ ] flourescent highlighter
[ ] small container
[ ] vibrating massager
[ ] pen

Smart Drugs
[ ] Ginseng
[ ] Vivarin/NoDoz
[ ] Tums
[ ] Tylenol
[ ] Vics Vapo Rub
[ ] Vics Inhaler

Lights
[ ] bike light
[ ] glow sticks
[ ] light sword
[ ] glow belt
[ ] glow necklace
[ ] glow worm
[ ] oral glow stick

Candy
[ ] Gummy Bears
[ ] Sweet Tarts
[ ] Pez
[ ] Menthol Cough Drops
[ ] Pixie Stix
[ ] Star Burts
[ ] Twizzlers

Money
[ ] Entrance Fee
[ ] Water
[ ] *(optional) mind altering substance

Attitude
[ ] Smiles
[ ] Hugs
[ ] Kisses
[ ] "Hi, how are you?"

Personal Stuff
[ ] ________________________________
[ ] ________________________________
[ ] ________________________________
[ ] ________________________________
[ ] ________________________________

Luggage
[ ] Back Pack
[ ] Fannie Pack
[ ] Suitcase on wheels

* this is only optional
---------------------------------------------------

Anything I forgot???
This check-list can apply to everyone. From label hoes to candy ravers,
from spiritual ravers to massive ravers alike.

Love,
Paul*E*Wog

P.S. Let me know if I forgot something.

>> naked"  In all seriousness, though.  I think after the initial
><<SNIP>>

>There's a group of folks down here in SoCal that call themselves NRA :the
>Naked Ravers Association... rumor has it that they throw naked parties.
>I haven't been to one myself, so I can't really turn in a review...
>But I suggest that if you do this by the Bay that you do it in the warmer
>months.  I've been freezing at SF outdoors with all of my clothing on

Yes - definately a SoCal thing.  Back when I lived in San Diego, I once
went to a crazy party out on the water.  There was a little boat taking
everyone to and from shore, as well as between the *2* party barges.  One
was a big ass boat, owned by some rich old dude that owns a bunch of strip
clubs down there and is just down with the ravers.  In fact, he let us use
his boat for a Right To Dance demo one time - it's docked in direct view of
City Hall.  Anyway, there was a second, "clothing optional" party going on
in his huge floating castle - 3 levels of madness.  There was this crazy
ambient lounge - lots of red carpet and mirrors, naked bodies chillin' all
over the place.  MAn, wAlking into thAt party wAs A moment to remember, let
me tell yA!  Wait...
I just did.

night night
Megan

>using a crate to carry their records to a party???? 
>

>

>wider space. I have since traded a crate with a friend who has one the  
>correct size and I noticed something... 
> 
>Crates bought from a store are slightly bigger than the kind you find: or 
>at least the kind I've found. Which raises all sorts of questions in my
mind. 
>In particular I can imagine the designer who came up with the 
>size (imagine Spinal Tap): 
> 
>Designer: Well the crate is slightly bigger than 12" 
>Marketer: Why is that?? 
>Designer: Ya know, when 12" just isn't enough. You need that extra
something. 
> 
>Is there some DJ originally come up with the idea to make and sell crates 
>because 
>their records didn't fit into a milk crate? 
> 
>Is there something else you put into crates (other than records) that

> 
>Do the clothes and things college students put into crates fit better in a 
>12"+? 
> 
>Did some marketing person think 12"+ crates would sell better because you
can 
>only get 12" milk crates? 
>

At 09:40 PM 9/9/97 -0700, you wrote:

>hey guys... I've been searching around on the net for info on 
microdot,

>but can't find anything. Does anyone here know anything about this 
tiny

>little pill? It's a small orangish press tab, about a millimeter thick

>and about 2 millimeters in diamiter. I've heard it's acid, mescaline,

>and concetrated shrooms, anyone have the real facts?


>From what I know, "microdot" is not a nominal term for a drug but rather
a descriptive term for the tiny pill form in which the drug comes.  The
actual content is <bold>mescaline</bold>.  Maybe the confusion with acid
and shrooms comes from the fact that mescaline is a synthetic
hallucinogen just as LSD, but its effects are commonly compared to those
of 'shrooms.  


Hope this helps!


G

from

by

> event!

ect...

legit,

> nothing
> you've ever experienced.

promoter

> since April. We've given him advice on the lineups, trying to get
> together

see,
> or
> only heard about, designed the flyers, and pretty much advised him on
> what
> 'most' ravers would want from the the best party they could dream up.
> 
> This is FCP's (first contact presents) first party, before they've
been
> all
> involved in theatrical productions. We keep telling people, ITS NOT
> (necisarily) THE DJS/MUSIC THAT YOU'LL REMEMBER... ITS EVERYTHING
ELSE!
> They're building these huge movie-like sets and props, lights &
lasers
> sets,
> make-up artists from Startrek! for the aliens that'll be there :) and
> so much more; we can't wreck the surprise for you, and tell you
> everything!
> It's gonna be so fun, we can't believe it's in less than two weeks.
> 
> Another note:
> Some people are talking about 2 other things. Corporate sponsorship
and
> price.
> Yes this party is being sponsored; they are Southwest, American,
> Dollar renta Car, Noahs Bagels, and Starbucks. Yes, they're
> corporations, but
> look at who they are... they're there for a reason; the airlines are
> flying
> people out, the car rental place are for the same people, and the
> remaining
> two are giving out a free breakfast for everyone. Of course all of
them
> will
> make money some way or another, but they will be helping elements in
> making
> the party better. Think how different that is from someone like NIKE
or
> MTV
> sponsoring a rave.
> 
> And price... yes, we all know that raves (some atleast) are getting
more
> 
> expensive these days. But are the parties getting better? Some are...
> but
> how offen do you feel that your $20 or $25 or $30 is well spent? We
> dunno,
> but sometimes we feel a little let down by just black lights and
> speakers
> for the price. Granted, its not just the setup that makes a party
great
> but
> really, what you're going to get for 25-bucks (presale) is going to
be
> some-
> thing you will remember forever. Shoot, get the double-night ticket
and
> it's
> even cheaper. Each night is going to be different, it'll feel like
> another
> party all together. Anyways, enough hype, enough explaining, enough
> text,dang..
> sorry this is SO long...!

<excerpt>Date: Mon, 08 Sep 1997 10:04:09 -0700

To: sfrave@hyperreal.org

From: Brendan Braybrook <<brendan@club.net>

Subject: Re: Microdot. (clearing this up)

In-Reply-To: <<3.0.32.19970910091400.00caf890@wrs.com>


<excerpt>>hey guys... I've been searching around on the net for info on 
microdot,

>but can't find anything. Does anyone here know anything about this 
tiny

>little pill? It's a small orangish press tab, about a millimeter thick

>and about 2 millimeters in diamiter. I've heard it's acid, mescaline,

>and concetrated shrooms, anyone have the real facts?

>From what I know, "microdot" is not a nominal term for a drug but rather
a descriptive term for the tiny pill form in which the drug comes.  The
actual content is <bold>mescaline</bold>.  Maybe the confusion with acid
and shrooms comes from the fact that mescaline is a synthetic
hallucinogen just as LSD, but its effects are commonly compared to those
of 'shrooms.  

</excerpt>

from the alt.drugs lsd faq:


ommon Drug Slang Terms (NB: many of these refer to the carrier, ie,
"Blotter"

        or "Sugar Cubes".  Often the local names will refer to patterns
printed

        on the blotter, eg, "Blue unicorn".):


        Acid, 'Cid, Sid, Bart Simpsons, Barrels, Tabs, Blotter, Heavenly
blue,

        "L", Liquid, Liquid A, Lucy in the sky with diamonds, 
Microdots,

        Mind detergent, Orange cubes, Orange micro,  Owsley, Hits,

        Paper acid,  Sacrament, Sandoz,  Sugar, Sugar lumps,

        Sunshine, Tabs, Ticket, Twenty-five, Wedding bells, Windowpane,

        etc.


also: mescaline is one of the active hallucinogens in cactii. mescaline
in a pill is just a purified version. so, it's not truly a "synthetic
drug". 


</excerpt>=)

common misperception that they're mescaline.

At 10:23 AM 9/8/97 -0700, inquiring minds wrote:

>>hey guys... I've been searching around on the net for info on  microdot,
>>but can't find anything.
<snip>
>>From what I know, "microdot" is not a nominal term for a drug but rather
a descriptive term for the tiny pill form in which the drug comes.  The
actual content is mescaline. 
<snip>
>also: mescaline is one of the active hallucinogens in cactii. mescaline in
a pill is just a purified version. so, it's not truly a "synthetic drug". 
>

Actually, there are two forms of Mescaline. There's the "organic" version,
made from cactus stuff, usually it takes the form of either green sludgy
goo, or the more refined blue-green crystal shards.  There's also a
"synthetic", non cactus, lab version that's a lot more concentrated.
Depending on the production process, this version can be an orange, yellow
or white powder/pills.  

Having had some experience with both versions, I can say you need a whole
lot of the organic version to get anywhere, as opposed to NOT a whole lot
of the synthetic version to get stuck in a Picasso painting for 16 hours or
so...  I'm not so sure I would classify mesc as a recreational drug.  A
spiritual tool perhaps... To each his own I suppose 8-) 


You want the real "low down" on this and other fun stuff, read PHICAL by
A&A Shulgin.  You'll get a lot more info there than from web sites based on
hearsay and urban myths...  Plus a lot of the Clinical chapters from the
book are already on the web.

Er..uh..not that I advocate the use of illegal substances...n'stuff...

ChrisP

Zza~

 i formally werked in a dairy and i do believe ive worked out this whole
crat/size situation....

ok the average width of a 1/2 gallon milk container is 3 5/6 inches, and when
working in a business often places to store things isn't always available so
they wern't trying to conspire against DJ, they were attempting to save space
on a very minute level.
I don't know how many different dariys milk crates you have currently been in
contact with but i have found that wrekkids fit quite nicely in a Model Dairy
crate, they use metal around the top of the crate for re-enforcement while
making their plastic sides thinner. Also Odwalla crates have the same
structure.
As for fines surroundthe possession of a crate, it is up to $10, 000 and a
jail sentence, it should say that on the side of the crate. Most of the
crates say:
WARNING!
use by other than regestered owner prohibited by law
NO. 34564-34567
I have no idea of why this is so damn expencive but i think thet they
probably get a lot stolen and it effects their funds having to buy more
crates. 

As for the ones in the store, usually most of them arre used as sort of cheap
file cabnets and i think thats why they make it a little bit bigger, so you
can fit all thost wacked shaped papers in them...

 well if you have anymore questions, maybe i can help...
Dairy Gurrl Cheerio
JiL

for our last weekly event, we want to see as many of our old friends as

 Hello again,


       First. a mircodot, started in the 60's. It was generally LSD,
sometimes, it my be mixed with mescaline. It was and last time I seen it the
same shape. A tiny little dot. I had a friend who lost 8 hits, do to the
size.

      Next, a mic is slang for microgram, which is a measurement of drugs,
in general. From Digixion, which is a heart medication to Acid, mescaline.
The average amount needed or taken is a bout 350 mic in a hit. Sometimes
there is more and that would be stronger. I was once said that Jim Morrison
went out on stage and had consumed 5,000 mic's befor that show.


Peace, Luv, & Hugs
Rebel D Monteer
terrapin@lords.com
http://www.psnw.com/~terrapin

um, i make this a helluva lot easier on myself:

cute tanktop that makes me look gorgeous without the 'i'm trying hard' factor
jeans i can ruin (inevitably i spill or sit in something, never fails)
change of clothes if i'm outta town (leave those in the car tho)
too much money for you know what

i hardly think vivarin and/or vics are smart drugs - they're both bad for you.

and, pardon my attitude, cuz i'm a nice girl and all, but i rarely bring it
with me, cuz all eyes are focused on the dance floor here...

this girl would NEVER be seen with a pacifier...  maybe it's because
generally i substitute a cigarette or something, dunno. 

i do have to say tho, e is really bad for the orally fixated...

---Tom Leichardt <djtom@svpal.org> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> On Tue, 9 Sep 1997, Messiah Wannabe wrote:
> 
> > actually i'd really love to see some true goa fashions around here,
> > they're completely nuts - imagine taking a bunch of drug addled,
> > ultra-hyper-fashion-oriented brits, and giving them more less
> > unlimited access (read: extremely cheap) to totally crazy fabrics
by
> > the yard and tailors that charge about 50 cents to tailor a piece
of
> > clothing to each individual's fucked-up personal tastes.
> > 
> > the vests are just what the two-week tourists buy...
> 
> huh???
> 


so maybe some people don't know this...  goa is a state in india on
the west coast, there are a lot of nice beaches, and for the last few
years (well since the hippies, actually) phreaks have been gathering
there, basically to party (as it costs practically nothing to live
there), generally on the beach on the night of the full moon, more
often than not to hard, german-influenced dance music, thus goa
trance.  as i mentioned above, the fashions spawned there are very
distinct and interesting...

- messiah wannabe

First of all I would have to agree with Sr. Andy in the fact that Slow 
Roasted has been a success outside and behind the counter.  I'd say that 
everybody has enjoyed being a part of this event at City Espresso 
Roasting Co. and we'd all like for it to keep on happenning (if 
possible)  All you customers out there  (I wish I could be a customer 
tonight, but finances wont let me, Thanks mark and everyone that 
wouldn't ever cover my Wed. night shifts ;0) are great and I love being 
able to see all of my friends while I am working.  Once this thing is 
gone I am asking you ravers to keep on coming out to hang, talk, and 
talk to me :)
	On a sad note, I'd like to add  that a dear coworker, the Leo of all 
Leo's, Matt Schmitt and Allegra are going to be leaving to Seattle Wa, 
and this will be Matt's last Slow Roasted (I think) and if it is, well 
Matt, I really enjoyed working with you even though you thought I was  a 
"Big Dork."  You are actually a nice person which contradicts the 
previous thoughts I had about you in the beginning.  I wish you, 
Allegra, and Mohan if he is still going with you guys the best of luck 
in finding a good nest in which you will always let me stay at if I come 
and visit you?  Oh, and make sure the toilet seat is comfortably 
suitable to my big butt  :)  Take care and laters to ya all!

>Dear Beautiful People,
>
>Alex, Matt and myself have been throwing a free weekly for some time 
now.
>For those of you who have gone, you know it's had it's ups and downs.
>We've had some great talent stop by, we've had ambient, trip hop,
>downtempo house, jungle, experimental, r&b, and other good, funky 
stuff.
>
>But more importantly, we've seen a lot of new faces, and had an
>opportunity to have a regular, nearly entirely SFR supported event in 
the
>south bay.  It's nice to meet the people behind the posts, and the 
lurkers
>and the hotheads... everybody has been a pleasant surprise.  Pleased to
>meet you all.
>
>So... one last chance to get roasted slowly this summer... as always,
>free, but we'd appreciate if you help out the store by getting a cup 'o
>jo (it's not our store, but rather a nice symbiotic relationship... 
they
>sell coffee, we get to play with our friends). They'll even let you 
check
>your email at the counter if you have AOL, a web based account, or a 
shell
>account (you email geek, you... I bet you're reading email right now).
>
>djs:	science * matt schmitt * andyw
>time:	8-11pm wednesday 9.10.97
>place:	City Espresso Roasting Company
>	On Steven's Creek at Lawrence Expressway in Santa Clara
>	Across Steven's Creek from Safeway
>	Next to Rock'N Tacos, Payless Drugs, Mr. Chaus, BedBathBeyond
>
>So come by, pull up a chair and get a mellow groove on.
>
>We'll probably start back up in a couple weeks, as soon as we get the 
urge
>to lift a sound system every wednesday again.  If we don't, it'll be
>because we have something else in the works... cause that patio gets 
cold 
>come December and some of you have been wanting to dance.  We'll keep 
you
>posted (as if we didn't bsp enough already...).
>
>Peace,
>Alex/Andy/Matt
>
>p.s.	Thank you all the DJs that have been by, all the people who have
>taken time out to chill with us, and most of all the people who came
>through with the rides, cartridges, last minute sets and pulled mixers 
out
>of their butts to make this a weekly event all summer long (Noah + Li +
>James!!! Woohoo...).  Thanks everybody.

You're right about the fact that when a production company gets a lot of
followers it ends up getting main stream.  I think that happens because 
the prod. crew and the promoters let it get massive.  If they are serious

about underground then you can keep it underground.  I personally feel 
that you can have a thousand+ people and it still can be underground.  
It all about the vibe and that is completely up to the people who go to
the party.
There are people that go to massives with all the  wrong intentions and 
I personally don't like to party with those people.  

                                                      STAY TRUE,
                                                                 THE BLZO

P.S.  You can have that intensity that you love at an underground party
if you have a packed warehouse full of the most hardcore, karma addicted,
loving ravers like 
ourselves:-)

   I have actually only gone to Spundea's on the big weekends.  Ya know -
Memorial, and labor day and I think on Presidents weekend.  And all were
phat!  Top dj's and sick sets.  My only complaint is there were soo many
people.
 Nikita, OTOH, I've been to twice and had an unbelievable time on both
nights.  I want last Friday and saw Jeno and Dan both in the main room
utilizing the 3 decks.  Dan spun for 3 hours and I can tell you he took me
to knew hights.  Damn that boy was good but some drunk bitch was yellin' at
Dan in the middle of his set saying he sucked...  I think it effected him
for a few songs and then he blew it up agian.  People were cool, lighting
was sick and all my friends had a great time.

I'd recomend Nikita to start your weekend out.  But I only go to Spundea
when it's big weekend and I don't have to work or go to school on Monday.
You'll need the recouperation after a Sunday at Spun

About Release I agree with Brian Benitez:

>Personally, I avoid Martel's nights. IMHO, they have a really
>pickup-oriented crowd who are there to see and be seen (or is that scene?)
>and not for the music. Generally lots of attitude, soaked in alcohol.

I know many people who go to Release to front and herd women.  There are a
few girls I know that go to show off their shit to the on lookers.  Not
much of a crowd for vibe and straight groove...

peace_

	'Lo there, aphex peeps!  This dude is Ed Crowell from Auburn.  There waz a
phat article that I psoted about a few weeks ago that is really up ta snuff
on tekkno scene, esp Jungle.  Turns out, this guy started an entire scene
mainly devoted ta jungle n Georgia all by himself.  The other guy that
shows up is his partner in crime, named DJ Nymph.
	Also, mad kicks out ta byroni and Rubalicious! 8-))  I finally got ta meet
the peeps and they were sweet and cuddily,  I dug 'em!  Byroni wasn't
joking...the boy can dance!  'Lo ta Deepfog, hope that life is getting on
well, and the Berk place is picking up!  Take care...

On Wed, 10 Sep 1997, Austin Woffington wrote:

> utilizing the 3 decks.  Dan spun for 3 hours and I can tell you he took me
> to knew hights.  Damn that boy was good but some drunk bitch was yellin' at
> Dan in the middle of his set saying he sucked...  I think it effected him
> for a few songs and then he blew it up agian.  People were cool, lighting

I didn't see the yelling, but if what you say is true, it was completely
out of line.  My yelling was happening in my head, "Dan, you can do
better than this!"  Dan's set gets a C+ in my book.  The grading might
seem a little harsh, but I have high expectations when it comes to certain
DJs.    

Novelty moment of the night:  David Michael mixing in the theme song from
Magnum PI.  

Rok.

I'm going to be gone this weekend, so I'm going to miss some big parties -
Big Top and Electric Highway, both featuring some big acts and djs.  Then
sandwiched in there are are few smaller parties, plus the weeklies.  It
looks like a month of massives, check out the upcoming weekends.



                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

On Tue, 9 Sep 1997, invisible cola wrote:

> 
> As for Londoners being cold.........UK people in general will be more 
> reserved than Americans in general....it just takes a little more 
> effort.....a lot of americans i ve met who know brits, like that 
> .......we are a completely diff. culture & so u should respect that when 
> u visit  other places....it ain't going to be the same as being in SF or 
> the US.....an open mind please.....................

-->	That's the point.  I was comparing attitudes in the context of
party vibe, I was not bagging Londoners on their cultural differences
(okay, maybe a little; bread pudding, YUCK :P ).  Since you are more
reserved in the first place, that feeling of community is more lacking.  
In the small geographical contxt that is the UK, I've found the Irish and
Scotts more approachable, and for me, preferable.  Another comparison
(which you would dislike, I know; considering football and all), I think
the Germans are less reserved than the Brits (but hey, the Britisch Royals
came from Hannover in the first place), but not by much.  I do have an
open mind...my views and opinions are based upon a broad sample of
experience.

> 
> 
> Remember: the best vibe is wherever u make it.....& that can be SF, 
> London, NYC, A'dam, Barcelona, Hamburg, Berlin, Moscow, Sydney, Cape 
> Town, Malawi, Bali, Pushka, Rio, Ibiza and many, many more 
> places......go visit lots & lots of other places & then u may realise 
> that no-where wins......and anyone who thinks that one place does, loses 
> out on a lot of fun.....

-->	I _have_ been to more than half the places you listed, and I
always make an impression because I give off good vibes wherever I make
it.  But I have the best time in this place because it is unique and gives
me good vibes back.  After all, it takes more than one good person to make
a good party.
	As a note, I wouldn't touch Moscow with a 1000 mile pole.  This is
my prsonal prejudice from personal experience, but I HATE Muscovites. I've
never had that many people (young and old) _SPIT_ at me walking down the
street before, just because I was Vietnamese!  The US shoulda' nuked them
when it had the chance. (Sorry everyone for passing on the negativity, but
I know there are other SEAsians on the list who might want to know) 

> 
> One final thing....don't call women birds u sexist idiut!
> 

-->	I do not call womyn "birds".  I was using it within the context of
your national slang; you should call your own countrymen sexist idiuts,
not me.


Cheers,
M&m

Hmmmm . . .

Well, being that before April of this year, I was one of those non-raver types 
that would listen to 105 if I lived in that area (we have 102.5 here), I'm not 
so paranoid that "those" people will fuck (for me) up such a beautiful (read:  
damn talented performers & djs) event.

For those of you who have been in RaveLand longer than I, the outside world 
isn't that bad . . . a positive attitude can do wonders!

So . . . I'm pretty juiced about Big Top.  Plus, Moby, Eat Static, and 808 
State probably don't have the non-raver appeal of say, The Prodigy or Sneaker 
Pimps or something like that.  But that's just my opinion.

xoxo--Miccaela
P.S.  Oops . . . is this a flame?  sorry! (really)  I'm kinda delirious and 
cranky . . . I got food poisoning from Hard Rock Cafe in Sac . . . yee haw!

Top Ten Lists from LATE SHOW with DAVID
                                         LETTERMAN

            "Good Things About Rooming With the President's Daughter"

10. Bitchin' motorcade from history class to language lab
9. She shows up with beer coasters hand-knit by Betsy Ross
8. Your summer job next year: Ambassador to Belgium
7. Secret Service guys always available to buy you beer
6. Her care packages always include a tray of dad's "special" brownies
5. You become fourth in line for Presidency
4. At some point, you find yourself playing "quarters" with Ted Kennedy
3. When ordering from Domino's, you can take advantage of the President's
volume discount
2. If you receive poor mark on test, you can have professor slapped around by
Janet Reno
1. Somehow, you're not so embarrassed about your own father

;)

rob.

[BSP over, now some blabbering commentary]

I'm a little bummed

Does anybody else find it a little sad that the Bay Guardian, a weekly
publication that generates a lot of revenue from DJ driven advertising
doesn't have a clue about what's goin' on in their own back yard?  I
called to let them know that I wasn't exactly overjoyed that they
included Pablo's Sugar Shack in their editorial under 70's themed dance
clubs. I named a few DJs like Sneak, Garth, Jeno, etc. who have spun at
our club only to have the Guardian nightlife reporter say, "who are
they?" 

Seems to me that lately there are more DJ driven dance events gracing
their pages than live acts. But the nightlife editorial is always geared
towards some grunge or punk band that  all of 10 people witnessed down
at The Killowatt.

Is it just me? Perhaps I'm just especially bitter after the SF Chronicle
erroneously featured us in their "Clubs That Go Back To The 80's"
article a month ago. SF Chronicle writer Sam Whiting reported that 
"More than 1,000 people cram around the pool deck every Saturday night
to dance at Pablo's Sugar Shack."

The pool was removed from VSF (formerly the Oasis) over 5 years ago.

Like my friend Fajita Molly would say Whatever.

-SUNNY

P.S.  I guess I'm cool with being mis-labeled a 70's club but an 80's
club, that hurts.

this has nothing to do with raves but could put and end to raving
and breathing if there is another accident....
Nasa is about to launch a probe that contains enough
plutonium to destroy all life on earth. If an accident
like the challenger or the recent space station re-entry
then plutonium will be spread through out the earths atmosphere
destroying all life and poisoning this planet for millions of years.
Aside from not having anymore raves there would be no more life...
not even coach roaches. President clinton is about to make
a decision on this. 

                http://www.sonic.net/~west/cassini.htm

Two important points:
1.The rocket that will be used to launch Cassini does *not* have a good
safety record.  It's been known to explode on lift-off.
2.  The half-life of plutonium far, far exceeds the expected life of any
spacecraft known to man.  Even if Cassini makes it safely to Saturn, it
will
inevitably fail at some point in the future.  If it fails to reach
Saturn,
where *will* it end up? Why are we unnecessarily polluting space with
radioactive material?

There has already been a mishap with the craft.  A hole was torn into a
compartment on board, and this may well delay the launch - but it's 
anyone's guess for how long.

>
>Sept 21 - Oct 3
>     Round-the-clock vigil at Cape Canaveral main gate will be organized

>Might be a good time for you to schedule your vacation?  The protest is
spearheaded by the fact that Cassini will be carrying about 72 lbs of
plutonium on board.  After heading for Venus and orbiting twice there, it
will be sling-shotted on to Saturn, passing closely by Earth on its way
back
in 1999 - possibly close enough to enter our atmosphere.  What is NASA et
al
thinking?  


And here's an example of their petition: 

=================================================
No Plutonium in Space!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
We, the undersigned, call upon NASA and our elected officials to suspend
plans to launch the Cassini space probe to Saturn as long as any
plutonium
is scheduled to be on board. Presently, the project calls for 72.3 pounds
of plutonium 238 to generate on-board electricity. The risk of an
accident
at launch or during its "slingshot fly-by" above the Earth is not worth
the
gamble. We urge the use of alternative on-board power sources such as
solar
energy and long-life fuel cells for all future space missions.

Signature and Address:

1. _______________________________________________________________
2. _______________________________________________________________
3. _______________________________________________________________
4. _______________________________________________________________

Florida Coalition for Peace & Justice (FCPJ)

The "welcome to the world of AIDS" urban legend has circulated in many
forms... (lipstick on the mirror the morning after, note on the pillow,
etc. etc.). This is the first time I've heard about someone going around
sticking people with a syringe, but the "welcome to the world of AIDS"
tagline gives it away as just another mutation of the original myth.

At 11:32 AM -0800 9/11/97, Vanessa & Miccaela  wrote:
>Yeah, I think the syringe story is one of those urban legends.  I wouldn't
>get
>too scared about it.  Although there was a party in Sac where my friends
>saw a

[BSP over, now some blabbering commentary]

I'm a little bummed

Does anybody else find it a little sad that the Bay Guardian, a weekly
publication that generates a lot of revenue from DJ driven advertising
doesn't have a clue about what's goin' on in their own back yard?  I
called to let them know that I wasn't exactly overjoyed that they
included Pablo's Sugar Shack in their editorial under 70's themed dance
clubs. I named a few DJs like Sneak, Garth, Jeno, etc. who have spun at
our club only to have the Guardian nightlife reporter say, "who are
they?" 

Seems to me that lately there are more DJ driven dance events gracing
their pages than live acts. But the nightlife editorial is always geared
towards some grunge or punk band that  all of 10 people witnessed down
at The Killowatt.

Is it just me? Perhaps I'm just especially bitter after the SF Chronicle
erroneously featured us in their "Clubs That Go Back To The 80's"
article a month ago. SF Chronicle writer Sam Whiting reported that 
"More than 1,000 people cram around the pool deck every Saturday night
to dance at Pablo's Sugar Shack."

The pool was removed from VSF (formerly the Oasis) over 5 years ago.

Like my friend Fajita Molly would say Whatever.

-SUNNY

P.S.  I guess I'm cool with being mis-labeled a 70's club but an 80's
club, that hurts.

Subject: Grumpy Raver List
