And don't watch the movie "The Game" with Michael Douglas and Sean Penn. 
Man, that movie just straight warps you mind.  By the time the end of the
movie roles around, you're feeling so paranoid (yes, I was completely
sober) that you feel like everyone's out to get you.  I don't know,
basically, the main character gets so fucked over during the movie you
start feeling like you're the one who's getting fucked over.  If you're
going to watch it, take some Prozac before-hand or atleast go sober, it
won't be so bad then.

I don't know, just thought I'd warn ya'll.

Dear SFRavers,

I have come to realize something important this weekend.
The society we live in is corrupt. The government, the way all religions
has evolved from what they used to be, they way our parents, and grand
parents, and great grand parents were raised, and even the education in
school is corrupt.

Why do people go to raves?
They go to escape to a world that is just, sympathetic, unprejudiced,
and forgiving in so many ways. All of us in the scene know this. We have
come to realize it. Some, knew this from the second we stepped foot in a
rave. Others, needed time, and patience to understand it. 

We are born with 5 senses that handicap our 6th sense. The 5 senses are,
sight, hearing, taste, touch, & smell. The 6th sense is what all of us
call "vibe".  Our mind, body, & spirit create our vibe. Can you see a
vibe? No. Can you hear a vibe? No. Can you smell a vibe? No. Can you
taste a vibe? No. Can you touch a vibe with your hands? No. Then, which
one of our senses absorbs someone's vibe? Which one of our senses gives
of a vibe? The 6th one. None of the 5 we are born with lets us do that.
It is very hard to shut down those 5 senses and just use our 6th to
communicate, understand, and love each other.

All of us in the scene know how to let go of our 5 senses and rely on
our 6th. That's what we do when we rave. Still, we can not let go of the
5 that are used by the rest of the civilized world. Civilized World? I
am so sure! The rest of the world creates war, poverty, evil, and the
most terrible thing in life, money! If we did, let go off all
inhibitions, and pre-judices in the un-civilized world, it would all be
used against us. In the uncivilized world, kindness, is viewed as a
weakness. There for, we must be mean, rude, and never reveal the true
kind person we are. We must live with a huge front to protect us from
the society we live in.

Since, we are not born into a rave community, we must go through the
most influential parts of our lives (childhood) in the uncivilized
world. Us ravers have no earth or land of our own. We have no place to
truly call home. We have no place to live, where we can be who we are
and not need front. We need to live in a rave, where life is as it
should be. But, because the uncivilized society is afraid of us, they
try to shut us down. They force us to leave @ 7:00AM every Saturday
morning because, by law some us must go to school (where we learn
nothing about "vibe") or to a job to earn money (root of evil) to
survive in the uncivilized world.

I am only 16 and still haven't figured out everything. I am not mature
enough to grasp all this and because the un-civilized world believes
that minors are minor in every way, including their thoughts. I wish
that sometime, someone, anyone, all of us would start a fund to buy an
Island big enough to hold the vibe of ravers all over the world, where
we could raise children the right way, with the freedom to expand their
minds, body, & spirit that society will not permit us to do. I am not
saying permanent happiness. If you are constantly release happiness then
you will explode from not releasing any anger. Anger is not evil. Anger
is very good. Without anger there is no happiness.

One of the most interesting things about the fact that I have finally
come to realize this is the way I did it. By means of which the
uncivilized world frowns upon. Ecstacy & Mushrooms. Two drugs which are
forbidden in this un-civilized society. Ecstacy gives us the courage to
be ourselves. Mushrooms give us the power to expand our consciousness on
a level of high spirituality and and self religious emotion. There is so
much evidence of the positive effects of these drugs. And, so very
little of the damage it does to our health. Yes, they both change around
our neurotransmitters in our brain. That is because of the accelerated
learning we do on them. If I feel I have gotten such a positive
enlightenment from something that the uncivilized world views dangerous,
I must ask myself, why do they view it as dangerous? And the answer is
because they are afraid, afraid that we will realize what I have. That
they are screwing us so bad and it must stop!!!

Love,
Paul*E*Wog

On Sun, 21 Sep 1997, Paul Hayden wrote:
> 
> Why do people go to raves?
> They go to escape to a world that is just, sympathetic, unprejudiced,
> and forgiving in so many ways. All of us in the scene know this. We have
> come to realize it. Some, knew this from the second we stepped foot in a

I don;t mean to come off as too something, but I think that this is the
difference between the jungle scene and the quote unquote raver scene.  I
think you're right Mister Wog, I think people go to raves to escape.  And
I think that people bang out to jungle to cope, to try to go harder than
the world which tries to make our lives routinal and tries to make us like
it (in terms of predjudices and anger and other assorted evils).  Does
that make sense to anyone?

"Raving" is about losing yourself to a different world.  Jungle is about
rising above the world you live in, and raising your fist in unison with
the good parts, and in opposition to the bad.

I might be whacked here though, WARNING.

DUH,
MAX

what's up Paul.

I hella feel you on the points you made in your posting,
but this "forbidden" culture that we are in is in its infancy,
just like rock and roll  was once a taboo.

In the future people will realize there is a lot of good values to be
learned at raves ,
especially through  music and the understanding between people.

This world is not ready to accept drugs such as E and mushrooms to be a
learning tool for society. This is a sober world, the "other side" is
there to inspire and envision us.

I guess you saw this world as it should be, and hopefully it will be
like that someday.
Till then we should make the best of this evil filled world, 

It would be unproductive if everyone was always high,
and who would get up at 7:00 AM to go to school and learn how to make
the drum machines and keyboards that make the music, the turntables and
speakers that make the sound, the bricks and steel to built the space
where the party 's at. To make sure the records get pressed, and  to
make sure there's electricity to power the party.

It all interconnects.
 Reality is  big ball of shit that's rollin' and you can't stop it.
might as well have fun!

Pete
Reality is a sandwich I DID NOT order!

From: Paul Hayden <goodvibe@geocities.com>

X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.02 [en]C-DIAL  (Win95; U)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Bananas are psychedeics?
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Okay, I have been doing some research on hyperreal and there are some
old posts to alt.drugs and some articles saying that there is a chemical
in bananas called bananadine. It's supposedly has almost the same
structure of DMT and is a relative of the Tryptamine family. The reason,
eating bananas do not get us high is because it's in the peel of the
banana.Yet, you need to do all this soaking in chemicals over night to
secrete the bananadine.  Also, bananadine is only active when smoked. I
dunno. I am really curius about this because it's legal.

Also, there is supposedly something in Nutmeg that is quite similar to
(methylndioxyamphetamine) MDA. Not the same stuff, but similar. It saids
you need to buy a raw nutmeg and eat 20mg of it. Well, I said, what the
heck and so I looked in our cabinet for raw nutmeg but all we had was
the Trader Horn powdered kind. It said there was 22.2mg of nutmeg in the
container so I opened it up and poured a little in my mouth and almost
gagged! It tastes really bad. I got some a cup of water and poured the
all of the powdered nutmeg in the water and threw in tons of sugar. It
was still a little difficult to get down. In like 45 min or so I began
to feel just light headed and I got a very small tingle threw my body
and for some strange reason I seemed to ever so often see small "trips"
out of the corners of my eyes. It made my stomach really hurt and it was
not worth it. Maybe I did it wrong.

It's also legal to purchase San Pedro cactus seeds and plant the seeds
and let them grow. For those who don't know, San Pedro cactus contains
mescaline. You can purchase 100 seeds for $5. You are suppose to cut the
cacti and leave 1/2 left at the bottom for another cactus to grow. Then
you pluck all the seeds, peel the skin off the cactus and you cheww it
up reall good and swallow. Then you eat the fleshy inside and I suppose
in a while you should be tripping. Hmmmm?? 

That's not all? If you go and purchase morning glory seeds and plant
them. Then pluck the seeds from the flowers that grow. Put 4-8 seeds in
your mouth, chew them well and then swallow. If you don't know morning
glories contain lysergic acid amine. That's just about the same as LSD,
but not quite it. The trip is suppose to less uneasy than LSD.

Wow! I never knew that all these legal plants that you can own can get
you high. But, I dunno about the bananas. If you know something about
that, reply to this post in open form.

Love,
Paul*E*Wog

At 03:32 AM 9/21/97 -0700, you wrote:
>"Raving" is about losing yourself to a different world.  Jungle is about
>rising above the world you live in, and raising your fist in unison with
>the good parts, and in opposition to the bad.
>
>I might be whacked here though, WARNING.

nah, i dunno about whacked but this will be a fun one to discuss...

i'm just wondering why there is such a "rift" between "jungle" and "raving"
- they're both styles of music to dance to, and both of them came out of a
sort of "let's flee from the club/everyday shit that's provided since it's
not suited to us" - raves, you had kids breaking into warehouses so they
could throw parties and have the freedom to enjoy themselves the way they
wanted to...  Jungle, you had street kids taking the music that was already
out there and making it into something that fitted their own tastes and
lifestyles...  

sorta sounds the same to me...  either way, it evolved into the same thing
- to me, either one is about rejoicing in the face of reality's "bad shit"
and having a good time -although at this point in my life, yeah i'm leaning
towards the jungle thang because i'm sick and tired of coming out of "rave
utopia" and being faced with a double comedown of painful doses of reality
- i think i'd rather just walk out of a jungle event and think, "Yeah, I
had a good time DESPITE the 16-year-old crackhead with child I'm stepping
over at the moment."...  and personally, i'd rather go to a party that had
two rooms so you could get a bit of both...

dori
*still trying to understand why there are people out there who can't like
both house/techno AND jungle without putting a rift between the two*

i guess i'm just glad people are finally taking it a step further...

	  by emout09.mail.aol.com (8.7.6/8.7.3/AOL-2.0.0)
	  id MAA27034;
	  Sun, 21 Sep 1997 12:42:22 -0400 (EDT)
Date: Sun, 21 Sep 1997 12:42:22 -0400 (EDT)
Message-ID: <970921124013_1864624060@emout09.mail.aol.com>
To: goodvibe@geocities.com
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Bananas are psychedeics? (other legal highs)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I remeber in middle school i heard a rumor that you could get high by smoking
the tip of a banana so i dried out  a bunch of bananas but never smoked them
cause they got some mold on them.
As for morning glory seeds that contain  LSA (close relative to LSD), you
have to be careful about just eating the seeds or making a tea out of them
because the government laces almost all new seeds sold in nurseries and other
stores with lead so you either have to grow the flower and use the new seeds,
or find some that arent laced with lead. I wouldnt recomend trying this
unless you got a pretty strong stomach. LSA induces vommitting in most
people.
san pedro cactus seeds, along with shroom spores, dont contain the
ingredients that make them illegal, mescaline and psilocybin(sp). so you can
legally buy the seeds and spores and then grow them yourself. growing shrooms
is pretty complicated. heres are good references to check out if your
interested, http://www.lycaeum.org/drugs/plants/mushrooms/gg32/mmgg.htm
http://www.fanaticus.com/pf-tek.htm
you can also get high if you chug a bottle of robitussin. it contains a
hallucinogen/dissociative called DXM which is supposed to be pretty fun.i
have heard that it is a lot like K or pcp, but it also makes a lot of people
throw up. If you have a scale that measures milligrams accurately you can buy
pharmaceutical DXM powder form from this company called Wanman Industries.
then you can buy your own little capsules at a health food store and take it
in pill form.
I have also heard of a company called Biogenesis that sells pharmaceutical
GHB, but since its an illegal drug, i dont know the reliability.
Also over-the -counter drugs such as dramamine, you know, the stuff you take
when youre feeling car sick on the way down the Santa Cruz Mnts., can have
psychedelic effect if taken in high doses. check out this reference
http://www.lycaeum.org/drugs/synthetics/dram/dram_faq.html
-blake

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Sun Sep 21 09:47:22 1997

In-Reply-To: <3424E93A.72431225@geocities.com>

To: Paul Hayden <goodvibe@geocities.com>
From: Megan Haggerty <megan@twenty-hz.com>
Subject: Re: The way lif should be (Utopia)
Cc: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Precedence: bulk

At 2:30 AM -0700 9/21/97, Paul Hayden wrote:
>Dear SFRavers,
>
>I have come to realize something important this weekend.
>The society we live in is corrupt. The government, the way all religions
>has evolved from what they used to be, they way our parents, and grand
>parents, and great grand parents were raised, and even the education in
>school is corrupt.

First of all, I want to point out that the idea that religions have
"elvolved" into their corrupt state is untrue.  Ever heard of the Christian
Crusades?  How about all those missionaries who "spread the word" by
forcing ideas on ancient cultures and robbing them of their trditions?  Did
you know that there was a time (long, long ago) that the Catholic Church
accepted donations which were supposed to ensure the donators place in
Heaven?  Even the poorest of the congragation were intimidated into giving
their earnings to the Church.  Oh, did I mention their donations were often
disguised as "mandatory" taxes?

And I would be careful in saying ALL religions are corrupt unitl you have
some more experience with them.  Western religion and culture is the most
corrupt of any in the world.  Do not assume all others are just like ours.
If you are feeling frustrated, you may want to check out some others.  New
memebers of any faith are always welcome.  I watched a show on PBS the
other night about Islam.  Very interesting people.  Fastest growing
religion in the world , right now.

You are so quick to let our ancstors off the hook.  The present is how it
is due to *everything* and *everyone* which preceeded it.  This crazy world
was given to us by those before us.

>
>Why do people go to raves?
>They go to escape to a world that is just, sympathetic, unprejudiced,
>and forgiving in so many ways. All of us in the scene know this. We have
>come to realize it. Some, knew this from the second we stepped foot in a
>rave. Others, needed time, and patience to understand it.

There might be more people in the scene who disagree with you than you
might think.  I have never thought the rave scene to be any of the things
you have coined it  as.  It, too, has it's corruption, prejudices, etc.  Do
not forget that ravers were human before anything else.  We are no less a
part of this world than anyone else.  We are no better than people who do
not go to raves.  I sense you passing judgement on non-ravers and I think
this type of judgement is the easy way out of confronting the real problems
of society, at large.  I think evryone desreves credit for the good they
do, where-ever they do it.  I cannot accept the idea that ravers somehow
are changing the world by going out all night and sleeping all day.
Escapism should not be rewarded.  It is running away.  People who have
dedicated their lives to teaching, healing, providing and helping, deserve
more recognition than you, or the rest of our society, are giving them.

I am not saying that all ravers live with these attitudes.  I have met
wonderful people who do wonderful things in their lives.  But I think it is
unwise to assume all ravers spread the "vibe" in the outside world.  This
is the real challenge: taking what you feel at a rave and applying it to
your life.  Don't you think people who don't rave deserve to experience
what you have?  I don't think you have to be at a rave to experience,
justice, unprejudice, sympathy and forginess.

>
>We are born with 5 senses that handicap our 6th sense. The 5 senses are,
>sight, hearing, taste, touch, & smell. The 6th sense is what all of us
>call "vibe".  Our mind, body, & spirit create our vibe. Can you see a
>vibe? No. Can you hear a vibe? No. Can you smell a vibe? No. Can you
>taste a vibe? No. Can you touch a vibe with your hands? No. Then, which
>one of our senses absorbs someone's vibe? Which one of our senses gives
>of a vibe? The 6th one. None of the 5 we are born with lets us do that.
>It is very hard to shut down those 5 senses and just use our 6th to
>communicate, understand, and love each other.

I agree that it is hard to let go of the 5 senses.  But I should point out
that this which you describe above is the goal and premise of many
religions.  We ravers are not the only one's who know this "vibe" exists.
Others may have a different name for it: G*d, chi, etc.  Granted, these
religious structures may have problems, but I beleive many of the
church-goers have the same ideas of rising above the superficial, tangible
world, into the world of the spirit.

>
>All of us in the scene know how to let go of our 5 senses and rely on
>our 6th. That's what we do when we rave. Still, we can not let go of the
>5 that are used by the rest of the civilized world. Civilized World? I
>am so sure! The rest of the world creates war, poverty, evil, and the
>most terrible thing in life, money! If we did, let go off all
>inhibitions, and pre-judices in the un-civilized world, it would all be
>used against us. In the uncivilized world, kindness, is viewed as a
>weakness. There for, we must be mean, rude, and never reveal the true
>kind person we are. We must live with a huge front to protect us from
>the society we live in.

Sounds like you're giving in to those who dod not wnat you to beleive in
your true self.  I do not buy the idea that most of the people in the world
want this to happen.  The peolple who do want this, make themselves the
most visible in the hopes to have the greatest influence.  By giving into
their influence, you have let them win.  Now they have you right where they
want you - out of their way.  Do not step aside for them.  Continue on with
your true self, for it is the only thing that they CANNOT take away form
you.

Just a note about money...
it is NOT the most terrible thing in life.  I challenge anyone to come up
with a barter/exchange theory that would be more successful than the one we
have now.  I guarantee each will look like a winner unitl you introduced
GREED.  Greed is the problem, not money.  If greed were eliminated, money
would work for you.  And we are all guilty of greed.  Learning to live
simply is the key.  There is a theory of simple living called Afluenza,
which I reccommend checking out if you are tired of living in this material
world.  There are lots of books out on the subject of simple living.  One
titled, YOUR MONEY OR YOUR LIFE, is especially good.  It is a guide for
simple maney management based on evaluting the worth of everyday things.
We are used to paying for convenience but we are not resticted to it.  We
*give* our money away for things which have been disguised as quicker,
easier, better, but in reality, they are not.

>
>Since, we are not born into a rave community, we must go through the
>most influential parts of our lives (childhood) in the uncivilized
>world. Us ravers have no earth or land of our own. We have no place to
>truly call home. We have no place to live, where we can be who we are
>and not need front. We need to live in a rave, where life is as it
>should be. But, because the uncivilized society is afraid of us, they
>try to shut us down. They force us to leave @ 7:00AM every Saturday
>morning because, by law some us must go to school (where we learn
>nothing about "vibe") or to a job to earn money (root of evil) to
>survive in the uncivilized world.

See above for all my thoughts on this one...

>
>I am only 16 and still haven't figured out everything. I am not mature
>enough to grasp all this and because the un-civilized world believes
>that minors are minor in every way, including their thoughts. I wish
>that sometime, someone, anyone, all of us would start a fund to buy an
>Island big enough to hold the vibe of ravers all over the world, where
>we could raise children the right way, with the freedom to expand their
>minds, body, & spirit that society will not permit us to do. I am not
>saying permanent happiness. If you are constantly release happiness then
>you will explode from not releasing any anger. Anger is not evil. Anger
>is very good. Without anger there is no happiness.

I understand your frustration with your age.  We live in a soiety which
shuns it's youth and it's elderly.  The only suggestion I have for you is,
please don't run away.  Make yourself visible to those who do not want to
see you.  If you make enogh noise, they will eventualy notice.  Things may
not change iommediately but people will have to take notice.

As far as buying an island and all that, you can start a collective living
unit right wherre you are.  People do it all the time.  Besides, wouldn't
you want all the "uncivilized" people to see the good your doing with this
style of living?  I think it would do everyone some good to see this type
of co-operation.

But if you were really stuck on the living-on-an-island thing, you could
always call up Marlon Brando.  Maybe he'd let you come and stay on his
private island for a while. ;-)

>
>One of the most interesting things about the fact that I have finally
>come to realize this is the way I did it. By means of which the
>uncivilized world frowns upon. Ecstacy & Mushrooms. Two drugs which are
>forbidden in this un-civilized society. Ecstacy gives us the courage to
>be ourselves. Mushrooms give us the power to expand our consciousness on
>a level of high spirituality and and self religious emotion. There is so
>much evidence of the positive effects of these drugs. And, so very
>little of the damage it does to our health. Yes, they both change around
>our neurotransmitters in our brain. That is because of the accelerated
>learning we do on them. If I feel I have gotten such a positive
>enlightenment from something that the uncivilized world views dangerous,
>I must ask myself, why do they view it as dangerous? And the answer is
>because they are afraid, afraid that we will realize what I have. That
>they are screwing us so bad and it must stop!!!
>
>Love,
>Paul*E*Wog

I don not claim to understand the motives behind the war on drugs.  But I
will encourage anyone who does drugs to educate themsleves about it.  I
think a lot of people have been pasing out a leaflet or flyer or something
called Just Say Know.  I don't remeber much of thisdrug-education back in
the days when I was raving but I think it's a great idea.

Educate the people so that they may rise up!

On that note, have a lovely day!
Megan

Many of the posts on this list revolve around the lack of positive
recognition the rave scene gets.  This is why I find it interesting that
some of us are having difficulty recognizing the good of another.  Why is
it so terrible that he wanted to be recognized for his contribution?  I am
not understanding this.  Granted, it is a huge tax wrtie off but I think
once people get into the billions of dollars, money seems to take on a
different menaing, or lack of.

I am not "bowled over" by his contribution, either, but I do think he
deserves the recognition he gets.  I mean, the media is going to inflate
any info they get their hands on, so I don't know why anyone is surprised
by this.  But he should be recognized for giving a billion dollars away,
tax write-off or no tax write-off.

megan

At 1:10 PM -0700 9/20/97, e.menon wrote:
>i'm not discounting his gesture. a billion dollars over the next
>decade, and it will go to help the 'poorest people in the world, the
>people who need it the most.' and i suppose it is a fair chunk - the
>article i read on it states that it's about a third of his wealth.
>leaving him with ... 2 billion. my point is that it's not a big loss
>for him. and that he gets front page coverage for his gesture, while
>there are a *lot* of ppl who give their more valuable time and aren't
>recognised for it at all. i'd be really impressed if he had done it
>anonymously. but no, he made an *announcement* to the media and to the
>rich. (show and tell anyone?) yes, more ppl with his standing should
>do such things. but they should do it because they want to help, and
>this they could do anonymously. don't you think? as it is, no, i'm not
>impressed. but then i'm not often impressed by the super rich and
>their monetary gestures. as i said, and this is really only my
>opinion, it's no skin off his back, and it does give him some mighty
>nice media coverage. i'm not discounting it; it is a big help. i'm
>just not bowled over by it... and not surprised that he's getting
>front page coverage for it. disgusted, more like. is his donation more
>important thatn all the other news that really should be getting front
>page coverage? (but then again, i don't see the news value in chelsea
>starting at stanford, either. :P page 11, and very small: news on the
>nea; a bill to protect abused children... pg 17: civilians killed by
>security forces in india; bomb explodes near bosnia  police station,
>injuring 50.... and not to mention all the news that isn't supposedly
>'fit to print'.)
>
>cheers - e. :)
>

>anonymously. but no, he made an *announcement* to the media and to the
>rich. (show and tell anyone?) yes, more ppl with his standing should
>do such things. but they should do it because they want to help, and
>this they could do anonymously. don't you think? as it is, no, i'm not
>impressed. but then i'm not often impressed by the super rich and
>their monetary gestures. as i said, and this is really only my
>opinion, it's no skin off his back, and it does give him some mighty
>nice media coverage. i'm not discounting it; it is a big help. i'm
>just not bowled over by it... and not surprised that he's getting
>front page coverage for it. disgusted, more like. is his donation more
>important thatn all the other news that really should be getting front
>page coverage? (but then again, i don't see the news value in chelsea
>starting at stanford, either. :P page 11, and very small: news on the
>nea; a bill to protect abused children... pg 17: civilians killed by
>security forces in india; bomb explodes near bosnia  police station,
>injuring 50.... and not to mention all the news that isn't supposedly
>'fit to print'.)
>
>cheers - e. :)

Yes, i have heard about people smoking banannas... also about the nutmeg-
people in prisons snort for an easier, quicker high or you can roll it up in
a ciggarrete... because yes, even tho it is just an herb, it is poisoning
your body in a way, and that is why it has that effect on people.  For the
same reason mushrooms do! Rosemary can do the same things, if you ingest too
much.    
If you smoke mugwort, it has similar effects as marijuana, as well as being
somewhat more hallucinogenic.  So does sage, they enhance your dreams too!

On Sat, 20 Sep 1997, e.menon wrote:

> i'm not discounting his gesture. a billion dollars over the next
> decade, and it will go to help the 'poorest people in the world, the
> people who need it the most.' and i suppose it is a fair chunk - the
> article i read on it states that it's about a third of his wealth.
> leaving him with ... 2 billion. my point is that it's not a big loss
> for him. 

The same articles that discuss his contribution also discuss his net
worth. So it's not a big loss for him. Should he have just not done it,
because it wasn't impressive enough?

> and that he gets front page coverage for his gesture, while
> there are a *lot* of ppl who give their more valuable time and aren't
> recognised for it at all. i'd be really impressed if he had done it
> anonymously. but no, he made an *announcement* to the media and to the
> rich. (show and tell anyone?) yes, more ppl with his standing should
> do such things. but they should do it because they want to help, and
> this they could do anonymously. don't you think? 

I don't see what your problem is with this. He said "Here. Here's a
Billion dollars. I would encourage more wealthy folks to do the same." To
me that has much more value than doing it anonomously. He's setting a bar. 

> as it is, no, i'm not impressed. but then i'm not often impressed by the
> super rich and their monetary gestures. as i said, and this is really
> only my opinion, it's no skin off his back, and it does give him some
> mighty nice media coverage. 

Uh, hello?! Ted Turner *is* the mainstream media, or at least a good
portion of it. Do you think he needs to make monetary gestures in order to
get airtime?

So he gets nice media coverage. GOOD! Because his message was to encourage
others to do the same. That is a message that SHOULD get media coverage.

> i'm not discounting it; it is a big help. i'm just not bowled over by
> it... 

Neither am I. However I do see it as a very positive gesture and it's
really sad to see so much apathy. 

>and not surprised that he's getting front page coverage for it.
>disgusted, more like. is his donation more
> important thatn all the other news that really should be getting front
> page coverage? (but then again, i don't see the news value in chelsea
> starting at stanford, either. :P page 11, and very small: news on the
> nea; a bill to protect abused children... pg 17: civilians killed by
> security forces in india; bomb explodes near bosnia  police station,
> injuring 50.... and not to mention all the news that isn't supposedly
> 'fit to print'.)

Of the aforementioned articles, which, if any of them had a positive
message? That makes Ted Turner's gesture front page material in my eyes.

				 	Black Adder

Hello SFRavers -

 Looks like there will be a Sunset Boat Party next Sunday ( Sept. 28th ).
I'm making plans to go, but I have a question for those who have gone
before.

 I just went on my first off-shore fishing boat excursion on Thursday,
on a 65 foot fishing boat out of Half Moon Bay. Despite taking anti-nausea
pills before the trip, I was seasick for most of the trip.

 I assume that the Sunset Boat Party is held on a much larger boat, and
the S.F. Bay is much gentler on the inner ear & stomach than the open 
ocean. Has anyone had trouble with motion sickness on a Sunset Boat Party?

 "Queasy" Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Hello all,
    I came to a realization this past week, and it was kind of depressing.
 The scene was starting to bother me and I was getting really cold towards
other people that would ask me what raves were like and "would I take them?".
 This is an aspect of my personality I almost never see.  I'm always the
happy one who's smiling and loves to talk with anyone about raving or just
random topics in general.  
    However, all of the comercialization and bad vibes that I used to shrug
off, I actually spend time focused on now.  Then, finally, I realized what
was happening to me.  I'm not a September Child anymore.  I lost all that
ignorance and PLURRY VIBEY LOVEY stuff I used to thrive on.  OH! and I miss
it so much!  If anyone knows where my innocence went would please carefully
wrap it and mail it back to me??  I need to be annoyingly cheerful again.  I
would appreciate it so much if you could help me out!  Taking the weekend off
seems to have helped, but I need a little extra confidence to find the old
TeknoDiva.  I love you all and I'll be myself again soon (I hope)

           hugs n'stuff,
               'trice the tekno diva                        <<<<RAVEON>>>>

    "Make it a rule in life never
     to regret and never to look
        back."   --Katherine Gascoigne

>Also, bananadine is only active when smoked.

have any of you heard the Dead Milkmen song "Smokin Banana Peels"? Well the
directions to doing so are on the inside cover of the tape/cd...we tried it
once like 5 years ago, tasted like the worst poo ever and i don't recall any
sort of high off it, but everybody else got a good laugh over the fact that
we actually did it! :o) 

> It saids you need to buy a raw nutmeg and eat 20mg of it.

don't ever ever EVER try this!!!!! You will never be able to look at nutmeg
the same again!! Everytime i see nutmeg i gag...damn that poo is nasty,
especially in large quanities!!!! I all i remember is a massive stomach ache
and falling asleep on the couch, and this terriable taste of nutmeg
EeEEEewWWWwwWW!!!!!

growth spurt soon.

i can only tell you what i know about sea-sickness... i went to
sailing camp as a teenager (shhhhh!) and they used to tell us that
sea-sickness came from fear. i really don't know if there's any
validity in this or not, but perhaps you're holding onto some
deap-seated fears pertaining to the water? not that you could resolve
them all by sept. 28th, but it's a thought! anyway, my mom used to
give us saltines and coca-cola for our upset tummies. it helps!

cheers - e. :)

*LOL* That's the reason I wouldn't make a good student anymore. I would 
get into too many arguments with the professors because they think their
word is GOD(DESS)....

					Black Adder

Subject: Re: Sunset Seasick ?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

The boat used for Sunset boat party is relatively large and stable (it's one of 
those Blue and Gold or Red and White boats down at Fishy Wharf).  However, it 
DOES rock back and forth, making for some interesting dancing at times.  I went 
to the last boat party, plus several parties on those in college, and each time 
I was VERY ready  to get off when it got back to the dock.  Drinking amplifies 
the effect.

IF you're really worried, there are small 3/4" circular patches you can buy 
that you place behind your ear that counteract the disequilibrium.  You may 
need to wear it for a day before, but they DO work.  

Nathan

Subject: we played nice! :)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

yay! what a great way to end my sf visit! jeremy threw a bombass party,
and if you didn't go, you missed out! :)

we (me, stariana, cricket, and sindhu) got to the mappoint right before
11pm, and after a minor hiking expedition, we got to the location itself.
the spot was just so beautiful, a big "sand pit" right by the beach. you
could climb up the walls of the pit and get down to the water. 
sound system wasn't up and running until a little after midnight, but
no one seemed to mind. it was just a lot of "good vibe people", and
we all just kicked it waiting for the music to start. ;)
the music finally started, and we were treated to some drum'n'bass. now,
personally i consider d'n'b to be chillout-music, no matter how fast
it is or how intense the bassline is. it's just really hard for me to
get in a "party mood" to d'n'b. fortunately for me (and everyone else
looking for some simple 4/4-beats), kid bippy got on the decks a little
later. his hardcore set was just so awesome! starting out with classics
such as prodigy's "everybody in the place" and human resource's 
"dominator", and then progressing into badass hardcore...it was one of
the best sets i've heard in a long time.
micron spun too. micron is the bomb, that's all there's to it. we love
you dan! :)
at the end of the night, we were treated to some nice d'n'b. by now
more than fifty percent of all the peeps had left, and those of us who
were still there were in a chillout-kinda mood, so it all worked out
beautifully. :)

what else can i say? lots of beautiful people, many of whom looked like
they've never been to a party before! it's always fun with people who
go to their first rave with a positive attitude and a good vibe! :)
i ran into _one_ sfraver that i hadn't met before (hi beth!). big ups
to all my other friends! i love you! :)

i think we're going to sunset tonight, then tomorrow i get on the plane
back to lovely sweden! i'm going to miss you guys, but i'll be back!
or hey, you could all just come to europe! ;)))

much love.

jonas the spaceboy

                CHECK OUT  www.partnercomm.com/~raveinfo/ 	


                  The RAVEDATA project needs your help!
 

 Some of you have seen our messages on the list, some can tell you how
they like using our "North American Rave Promoter Index" also known as the
"fonebook" to get connected, and still others might say how they have
enjoyed trading mixtapes and flyers with us...

 That's just the beginning!  We've been aggresively compiling data for
20 months, known as the Ravedata project...  We're just about ready to
present the result: the world's largest rave-oriented database -- tracking
all KINDS of information,worldwide!  Why?  

	1 - To bring more talent and energy together (unity)
	2 - To recognize those in the scene who have done so much
             (respect)
	3 - To factually "set the record straight" after a lot of bad 
             news media (peace)
	4 - To bring alive those memories of our favorite events gone-by
             and our friends who were there to share them with us (love)


If that's RAVE D-A-T-A, What's this RAVE I-N-F-O stuff??
--------------------------------------------------------
 Raveinfo is what we call our attempt to ask YOU for those missing
bits and pieces of information we've missed along the way.  We can't do it 
alone... So, check out the site and e-mail us with *ANY* info you may
have!!  We've just re-organized some things to make it even easier to get
around and will finish that up tomorrow.

 We hope you look forward to seeing the ravedata site sometime in December 
and requesting your copy of the Fonebook ('98 edition) sometime in 
January (as always, it will be free).

Thanks!!

Love and Lollipops-
  Matt & Nicole
  (Cyphonix & Angel)


------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The RAVEDATA Project                               ravedata@partnercomm.com   
                                 flyer trades:  www.partnercomm.com/~flyers
                               mixtape trades:  www.partnercomm.com/~tapes

---Megan Haggerty <megan@twenty-hz.com> wrote:
>
> At 2:30 AM -0700 9/21/97, Paul Hayden wrote:
> >Dear SFRavers,
> >
> >I have come to realize something important this weekend.
> >The society we live in is corrupt. 

you are just realizing this now???


(paul)
> >Why do people go to raves?
> >They go to escape to a world that is just, sympathetic,
unprejudiced,
> >and forgiving in so many ways. All of us in the scene know this. 

(megan)
> There might be more people in the scene who disagree with you than
you
> might think.  

hear hear. i go to raves to dance, to have fun. the only ideal i
attach to this 'scene' is hedonism. that's *all* it's about. i have
met some of the most corrupt people through this "just, sympathetic,
unprejudiced world". please. okay, so you're only 16. but this is
being naive to an extreme, isn't it?  as megan states, we're all
human. just like those "uncivilized" non-ravers. GAWD. can you see
what you're written? don't we sound like our white forefathers? i'm
_gagging_.  *shudder*. 


(megan writes)
> this type of judgement is the easy way out of confronting the real
problems
> of society, at large.  I think evryone desreves credit for the good
they
> do, where-ever they do it.  I cannot accept the idea that ravers
somehow
> are changing the world by going out all night and sleeping all day.

no _shit_. what a farce.

> Escapism should not be rewarded.  It is running away.  

yes, but isn't it *fun*? c'mon, folks. we all have lives, full of
problems, stresses, responsibilities. i love having the opportunity to
chuck it all out the window if only for one night. i had a discussion
with someone on this list once about why ppl seem to have the need to
validate their fun. my theory is that the protestant work ethic is so
engrained in our society, we feel guilty for wanting to have *fun*,
just for the sake of it. so we come up with all sorts of
rationalizations for it - yeah, we're changing/saving the world.
bullshit. we're out there, having fun, dancing our asses off, meeting
new people, enjoying the music. forgetting our lives for a night. but
you know what? it's _okay_ to want to have fun! really it is! you
don't need some cockameyme rationalization for doing so. but i digress.
> 
> I am not saying that all ravers live with these attitudes.  I have
met
> wonderful people who do wonderful things in their lives.  But I
think it is
> unwise to assume all ravers spread the "vibe" in the outside world.  

unwise? no. naive? yes. but i find in this particular naivete some
frightening strains. we're no better than anyone else. we just like
good music! ;)

> I agree that it is hard to let go of the 5 senses.  But I should
point out
> that this which you describe above is the goal and premise of many
> religions.  We ravers are not the only one's who know this "vibe"
exists.
> Others may have a different name for it: G*d, chi, etc.  Granted,
these
> religious structures may have problems, but I beleive many of the
> church-goers have the same ideas of rising above the superficial,
tangible
> world, into the world of the spirit.

and isn't that what's it's all about - finding some meaning, some
validity, and definetely some community. but i call to those of you
who are trying to gain meaning and validity in your life from the rave
'scene' to go look elsewhere. better yet, look within yourselves.
scary thought, there! i just can't see validating the meaning and
purpose of my life with an all night party. 

(paul)
> >The rest of the world creates war, poverty, evil, and the
> >most terrible thing in life, money! If we did, let go off all
> >inhibitions, and pre-judices in the un-civilized world, it would
all be
> >used against us. In the uncivilized world, kindness, is viewed as a
> >weakness. There for, we must be mean, rude, and never reveal the
true
> >kind person we are. We must live with a huge front to protect us
from
> >the society we live in.

these are the thoughts that i find frightening. i'm at a loss. 

(megan)
> The peolple who do want this, make themselves the
> most visible in the hopes to have the greatest influence.  By giving
into
> their influence, you have let them win.  Now they have you right
where they
> want you

okay, so i'm going to take this out of context for a minute only
because i find it ironic that this is the same person who applauded
mr. turner's billion dollar publicity stunt, and didn't see it as a
man who "made himself the
most visible in the hopes to have the greatest influence"....

(paul again)
> >Since, we are not born into a rave community, we must go through the
> >most influential parts of our lives (childhood) in the uncivilized
> >world. Us ravers have no earth or land of our own. We have no place
to
> >truly call home. We have no place to live, where we can be who we
are
> >and not need front. We need to live in a rave, where life is as it
> >should be. But, because the uncivilized society is afraid of us,
they
> >try to shut us down. They force us to leave @ 7:00AM every Saturday
> >morning because, by law some us must go to school (where we learn
> >nothing about "vibe") or to a job to earn money (root of evil) to
> >survive in the uncivilized world.

you are *so* frightening. i don't think that when 'they' said 'love
thy neighbor', they meant only the one who was just like you. you do
see the hypocracy in what you write, i _do_ hope. 

> >I am only 16 and still haven't figured out everything. I am not
mature
> >enough to grasp all this and because the un-civilized world believes
> >that minors are minor in every way, including their thoughts. 

your thoughts ... hmmmm. well, i am not going to validate the above.
yes, it's true, that minors are treated extremely unfairly. (i could
turn the tables on you and bring up how minorities, no matter what
their age, are treated...) but you say yourself that you are not
mature enough to grasp all of this, and me... i'm nearly twice your
age and still so naive about things. but growth only comes when you
open yourself to it. please, keep your mind open to life. the world
will greet you with a mirror. embrace it, and for the most part, it
will embrace you. see evil everywhere, and sure enough, there it will
be! i used to have this big luvvie rottweiler - a big lug, a
sweetheart, sloppy with his hugs and kisses. but if kids in the
neighborhood walked by and were afraid, he would sense that, and
become afraid himself. life is just like this. don't be afraid. you
could miss out on some wonderful things. 



> >One of the most interesting things about the fact that I have
finally
> >come to realize this is the way I did it. By means of which the
> >uncivilized world frowns upon. Ecstacy & Mushrooms. Two drugs which
are
> >forbidden in this un-civilized society. Ecstacy gives us the
courage to
> >be ourselves. Mushrooms give us the power to expand our
consciousness on
> >a level of high spirituality and and self religious emotion. There
is so
> >much evidence of the positive effects of these drugs. And, so very
> >little of the damage it does to our health. Yes, they both change
around
> >our neurotransmitters in our brain. That is because of the
accelerated
> >learning we do on them. 

uhhhhh..... i beg to differ. not that i can explain what exactly
they're doing to the synapses in our brains - i'm no neuro-scientist.
yes, the drugs have their benefits. but please don't fool yourself
about the effects they're having on your brain. they're *toxic*.


If I feel I have gotten such a positive
> >enlightenment from something that the uncivilized world views
dangerous,
> >I must ask myself, why do they view it as dangerous? And the answer
is
> >because they are afraid, afraid that we will realize what I have.
That
> >they are screwing us so bad and it must stop!!!

ahhhh.... there are many reasons that drugs become illegal. and i,
like megan, don't claim to know them all. i do know that there are
political motives behind declaring things illicit (and some that go so
far back into our history it isn't even funny), but i also know that,
at least with 'e', there are real dangers. i don't really know how
much research has been done on long-term effects of heavy usage -
maybe you're right and there is no harm. but i'd rather not be the
guinea pig for neuro-toxicity research. 

anyway, i've rambled on far too long - please don't misunderstand me -
this is not a flame. i am just concerned about what i've read here. 

cheers - e. :)
................................................................

and day, to make you like everybody else - means to fight the hardest
battle which any human being can fight, and never stop fighting."

Hi Folks -
> 
> i'm trying to find sunsets too. the info line doesn't say where it's at. if
> it's at its normal spot then it's at Point Malata in Richmond. 

 Yup. Started at 2PM - if you go there, don't forget to park as far into 
the parking lot as possible, not near the entrance. It's almost always
the case that folks see a lot of cars on the entrance side of the parking
lot and assume the whole lot is full, and so park alongside the entrance,
which the park rangers don't like. I've seen the entrance clogged with cars 
and empty parking spaces at the far end of the lot.

> ...the buzz line # is 415.569.3300

 ...but that's not the Sunset info number. The message does have the 
Sunset info number ( said once , so have pencil and paper ready , or
record the message with your answering machine and play it back).

 The Buzz Line has old info - the Sunset message has been updated with the
location info for today's Sunset (Richmond), and has a description of their
upcoming boat party next week Sunday.

> but no one knows. let me know if you find out anything
> lots of love
> Danielle
> 
Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

By the way, it's Pt. Molate in Richmond, not Pt. Malata , in case you're 
trying to find it on a map. HW 580 West .

 It's a very tricky exit - as you drive around the last corner from Richmond
to the Richmond/San Rafael bridge, you'll see the toll booths , and
the exit is immediatley to your right - last exit before the bridge!

Don't get me wrong!  I have had some really super super incredible
beautiful experiences with house music, with techno, with crazy Santa Cruz
acid break.psy-goa nonsense!

But I have never fallen into the whole "reconnect me to pigtails and
pacifiers, and let me ignore the reality of life around me, running from
the stress."  and that's why I can fit better into the house/techno stuff
than many "ravers" can fit into the jungle scene, in my opinion.

Jungle is a music that is often based on, and even created with stress in
mind.  It's fuckin gnarly a lot of the time you know?  Not happy.
Artists' conceptions of spaceships crashing into domed colonies, or
locusts descending on your evil-ass farm.  And THAT is why it's nice.  It
can be, for me, a way to get SO STRESSED out, and SO HYPED, that my feet
hardly touch the floor, and my heart nearly explodes, fighting against it.
Or am I fighting with it?  Or am I fighting IT alongside IT?

I am not saying that all jungle is war.  I'm saying the most jungle is
rough business, and doesn't take itself lightly, and doesn't care if you
don't smile about it.  It's just more attitudinal, I suppose.

ANOTHER point I've been thinking about is that although sometimes jungle
really unifies crowds, and people are all slapping each other five and
yelling beside each other, oftentimes, people are completely lost in their
own concentration on the beats.  To stay with their raggedness?  Because
the beats are like walls of sound?  Because there are other sounds hidden
in the first ones, and people are hearing them?

So, while I feel I am overgeneralizing everything, I feel safe saying that
jungle may be a little less PLURy (in the huggies candy toys way) than the
'raver' scene, I think that's because jungle reflects a life that doesn't
always want or need PLUR.  It mirrors the dirt on the ground and the
tangles of machete-requiring bullshit that we have to cut through no
matter if you hug us or not.



What am I talking about, HI HOW ARE YOU,
DUH,
MAX

Seanie Boy and Rabbit In The Moon were pretty tight and were able to make me
and my company smile.

Bum party overall. Definitely NOT worth $25!!! I was able to meet some kewl
people and made the best of things...

I really do believe that 85th and Baldwin is a cursed location. There's
always something not right with the parties held there. It's either acts
don't come through, or there's absolutely NO vibe. I dunno why.

Anyway this weekend was a seminightmare I saw coming sometime, I never knew
when, but it hit me in the face. My friend' s and my parents have now
discovered that we are ravers...

In a message dated 97-09-21 18:27:36 EDT, you write:

<< Seanie Boy and Rabbit In The Moon were pretty tight and were able to make
me
 and my company smile. >>

Well, Rabbit and the Moon definately never played.  (They were there,
everything was set to go for them, but, they had some problems witht the
promoters.)  However, Skylab 2000 funked everyone up with an extra-long set
of hard acid brakbeat and trance.  They even played an old-school hardcore
anthem that I especially love to rock out to.  (This because there was no DJ
to follow them???)

Bassbin Twins also bombed the bass for a still dancing early morning crowd.
 It was the same set they played on Friday, which included among other
tranks, my favorite that goes "Nobody move, nobody get Burned..." and
something super funky using an old SKA sample.  

And I absolutley love the video projectors on all the walls.  

A word on the vibe...  I thought for the most part this party went off.
 Everyone who was there was dancing, dancing hard and doing some way cool
moves.  There wasn't alot of people crashed on the floor, or standing and
watching.  The crowd that showed up definately came to have fun and make the
most of a very poorly organized production.  But, hey, it was this promoters
first event.  And to do two in one weekend was quite a feat to undertake.
 Things are bound to go wrong.  There is a lot to do to insure that the show
goes on, and it must take trial and error to perfect the "massive
experience".  

I give it a thumbs up, mostly because the bands really gave it their all on
the performances and the dancers intereacted with the music beautifully

This is ridiculous.   Let's all give Turner a pat on the back, lots of
press, and a gold star.

Also, let's not forget the process by whic one man can amass an obscene
fortune worth three billion in a country with 35 million people going hungry
every day (yes, the U.S.).  Did Turner work to earn that money?  How many
hours a week would you have to work to earn a Billion?  Other people's labor
made that money for him.  He got that money, and they didn't. 

Give away a billion?  Great.  Now take away most of the other two billion
and leave him with what he earned through his labor, physical and intellectual.

The media will eat this up across the spectrum, whether he owns it or not.
The meadia is owned by and operated for other people of Turner's class, and
I bet they love to see how "generous" they are.  Gosh, aren't billionares
really just nice people?

OK.  I am out of bile.  Sorry about the rage, folks.

Peace and love (and I mean it!),
Kerry

get it'.
point is, without the (sometimes) naive attitudes that us youngins have, the
world
probably wouldn't get much better (and it is getting better!  could you
imagine 
living under Hamurabi's Code? heck, even that was better than before)...

PEACE
Dizzy

Baggy JNCO's are perfectly reasonable and ok to wear in public and that $50
is a normal price for them, I promised her I wouldn't wear glitter for three
weeks.  HELP!! I've never gone for so long without glitter.  I'm not even
sure what my face looks like anymore without it.  What can I do??? I'm going
to have to sneak around with little canisters of it in my bag.  I'll put it
on after I leave the house and wash it off before I get home.  What have I
done?!?!?!  This is insane, but if I go back on my word I know she'll do
something rash.  Oh the horror!!  I need sparklies!!

Secretly, deep down I hoped this would fail, so with a little joy I'm glad it 
did.  ALong with many on this list, I worry about the influx of corporate 
sponsors bastardizing the music and scene.  If Starbucks, American Airlines, Bf 
Goodrich (EHT), etc. etc. invest their money on this "rave promotion 
experiment" (or whatever they call it in the boardrooms) and the return on 
investment is minimal, they will divert  their money elsewhere and the scene 
will remain (relatively) untouched.  
To: sfraves @ hyperreal.org  @ internet
cc:  (bcc: Nathan B. Beckord)
From: emdash @ rocketmail.com ("e.menon") @ internet
Date: 09/21/97 11:12 AM
Subject: Re: lifeforce
what a waste of money. get this: their info line said that "we made a
promise, now we're keeping it". they are SO FULL OF SHIT! the only
reason i went didn't show (along with others), and HA! *loved* the
shuttle that was promised from the bart station (we walked), and their
'complimentary breakfast buffet' consisted of some sort of packaged
creme pie like you might find at a greyhound station. and it was so
loud that i couldn't enjoy the music. really. why do people think that
louder must be better? the bass just sounded ugly. too much space for
too few ppl, and too many cops with billie-clubs. this will be my last
massive for a while. (sad that i'll be missing carl cox next week, but
if i'm to learn anything from the last 2 massives i've been to.... i'd
be better off at the movies.)

cheers - e. :)

it's all good girl.  i was the same way as you are. in fact i occasionally
get like that. sometimes i actually get annoyed with raving and every weekend
seems like the same ole thing. so what i usually do is take a big break from
raving, usually like a month without going. then i'm all excited to go again
and i miss it so much. that's the best advice i can think of, it usually
works for me. i also prefer to go to smaller parties where you can meet lots
of people and there's a good vibe. i wish you lots of luck.
lots of love and hugs,
Danielle

Hello all,
    I came to a realization this past week, and it was kind of depressing.
 The scene was starting to bother me and I was getting really cold towards
other people that would ask me what raves were like and "would I take them?".
 This is an aspect of my personality I almost never see.  I'm always the
happy one who's smiling and loves to talk with anyone about raving or just
random topics in general.  
    However, all of the comercialization and bad vibes that I used to shrug
off, I actually spend time focused on now.  Then, finally, I realized what
was happening to me.  I'm not a September Child anymore.  I lost all that
ignorance and PLURRY VIBEY LOVEY stuff I used to thrive on.  OH! and I miss
it so much!  If anyone knows where my innocence went would please carefully
wrap it and mail it back to me??  I need to be annoyingly cheerful again.  I
would appreciate it so much if you could help me out!  Taking the weekend off
seems to have helped, but I need a little extra confidence to find the old
TeknoDiva.  I love you all and I'll be myself again soon (I hope)

------=_NextPart_000_0000_01BCC6CE.73E855A0
Content-Type: text/plain;

Hey there,

     =20
> saying "mini thins"  or "mini pseudo".  =20
> the tech-name is pseudo-ephedrine - I believe it's a
> decongestant/anti-asthma pill,  the way it works is it dilates every
> membrane in your body , especially arteries and lung tissues, allowing
> everything to "flow" faster.    or something like that.  to tell you
> the truth, I doubt if it's particularly good for you.

      Well this is some incorrect info in the above statement.=20

1) In mini-thins there are two active drugs (Ephedrine 25mg and =
Guaifenesin 200mg). The generic name for one actually being talked about =
here is "Ephedrine Hydrochloride".  "Pseudo-ephedrine" is "Actifed", and =
if you bought "mini pseudo", you'd be buying  generic Actifed.

      Actifed is a decongestant, but is not an anti-asthma pill. This =
would be a good pill to take if you have a stuffy nose, not dance all =
night.=20

      Ephedrine is a broncodilator, and adrenergic. With this in mind, =
it's not the broncodilator that gives you "dance all night fever" it's =
the adrenergic. When a drug that has this property, and is introduced =
into the body, it cause the body to release it's own "epinephrine"

      Epinephrine is a hormone made in the human body. Another name for =
epinephrine is Adrenaline

>it dilates every membrane in your body , especially arteries and lung =
tissues

      The truth here is the Ephedrine actually cause the blood vessels =
to constrict, but at the same time cause the airways in your lungs to =
dilate, by causing the muscles in the lungs to relax.

You shouldn't take this drug if you have heart problems, high blood =
pressure, thyroid problems, or diabetes.

When taking Mini-thins, remember to drink lots, and lots, of water. Some =
things that can happen when taking this drug, nervousness, tremors, =
sleeplessness, nausea, headache, palpitations, rapid heart beat, dry =
mouth, large pupils, increased blood pressure loss of appetite. Rare =
side effects (if taken at the normal dose) include: chest pain, =
hallucinations, dizziness, difficulty urination, and muscle cramps.



>BECAUSE IT'S ABSOULITY FUCKING LEGAL!  THATS WHY!  THAT'S RIGHT, I'M
>GONNA SHOUT IT AT THE LOP OF MY VIRTUAL LUNGS!  ABSOFUCKINLUTELY 100%
>COP-PROOF PHARMACEUTICAL-GRADE LEGAL! =20

    Legal, for now. People in the FDA, are trying to remove this from =
the market. Due to the increased abuse of this drug.


Peace, Luv, & Hugs
Rebel D Monteer
terrapin@lords.com
http://www.psnw.com/~terrapin=20

In a message dated 9/21/97 7:10:43 PM, you wrote:

<<So how was the party?  >>
Um...it was OK, I guess. It definately suffered from a lack of organization,
though. I'm sure someone will chime in on that aspect, but bascially,
considering how the party began, it turned out to be a pretty OK event.

Micron, myself and posse arrived in Monterrey at around 11:30, just about the
time when Micron was supposed to play. We were told that the sound system
wasnt ready yet--there were a few extension cords to be found and the bass
amps needed to be brought to the site. We parked and walked over to where the
party was taking place. Now, if you've ever been to "The Pit" for a Cloud
Factory party or whatever, you know what this place is like. If you've never
been, well, let's just say that the name is very appropriate. A huge pit in
the middle of the sand on a beach.  The music comes on and people start
yelling excitedly that the night is going to finally begin. But the DJ on is
just the sound man, doing a soundcheck. Darn! Besides, the turntables had to
stands to be propped upon at this point, and those pesky bass amps hadnt
arrived as yet either. 

Soon after, they both arrived and it was time to get down to business with
some serious music by Re Ach. Re Ach laid it on 'em heavy, like he always
does, but some drama seems to erupt during his set(not really involving him).
Since the party started late, the DJ schedule was naturally pushed back. I
was originally scheduled to play at 2:30 but was now told that I would be
able to play until 5:30. OK.....pass me a Red Bull, Micron, this is gonna be
a long one! Well, I see some guy yelling at Jeremy and Jeremy, obviously
upset, responding to him. Turns out this guy came with Kid Bippy, and was
demanding that Kid Bippy be put on immediately to play. Re ach had been on
about a half hour at this point and sets were schedlued to be 1hr 15mins. I
didnt hear everything the guy had to say, but it was clear that he wasnt
happy and didnt care about the fact that the party got delayed. He didnt care
that all the other DJ's time were pushed back either, he just wanted Mr.
Bippy or whatever to play at the time he was scheduled, no matter what the
deal was. Jeremy didnt budge, nor did Re Ach, even though this guy asked Re
Ach to get off the decks after about 20 mins.

When this Bippy person got on, I couldnt believe it.


It was, IMO,  one of the worst DJ sets I've ever heard. Almost every track he
played was from 1992 or thereabouts. Rave techno, straight up. I vociferously
implored the Bipster to play something, *anything* from '97, to no avail. I
pleaded with him to rock a track from '96 maybe, but no response.  How about
'95 or '94? I gots no love, from this guy,  people!

I was appalled. Not only was this guy's lackey completely rude and
insensitive to the situation, the music this guy was playing was a lot less
than something to write home about. But hey? Who am I to say, if the candy
kids like it, let the candy kids have it, I guess, but how are you doing your
job as a DJ by playing records from 1992? If what we do is about progression
and experimentation and new forms of musical exploration, then where does
this fit? Sure, a lot of these kids werent around when this music first came
out, but they can find this stuff on one of a million CD compilations that
come out every week in record stores. I dont think a set of Rave hits was
appropriate given the situation. That situation being that the year is 1997,
not '92.

I'm sorry if I'm rambling, it's 11 pm and I havent had the chance to sleep as
yet. I jst had to share some thoughts about that party since Jen asked......

--Monty


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Mon Sep 22 00:24:36 1997

Date: Mon, 22 Sep 1997 00:24:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: jughaid aka justin <jrmiddle@best.com>
To: My Happy Tribe <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Really Nice Play Nice
Message-ID: <Pine.BSF.3.96.970921232804.26959A-100000@shell9.ba.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Ok, so the party had its techical difficulties...but then again, I try not to
rely too much on technology for my personal enjoyment :)

Anytime I hear that a party is going to be at the pit, I know it's going to be
killer. I could go on and on about morphic resonance and the weird wonderful
energies that exist at the border between two different worlds; I'll just say
that many different kinds of life have been having a really good time there
for quite a while, and it's nice to be able to spend the night there and
pick up on it.  The moonrise was stellar, the fog rolled in just in time
to be quite the effective (and ecologically sound ;) smoke machine. The sun
rose and cast a pink tint on an ocean washing up green algae against a
backdrop of wispy clouds and fog.

As far as human intervention goes, I must thank asr for bringing *plywood*
for a dance floor, as the one thing the pit doesn't provide naturally is a 
danceable surface. The music for the most part was excellent...kickin
jungle set (gosh that stuff feels good in my tummy), and an excellent
throw-down session by brother micron. The partygoers responded in kind by
coming together to create a vibe which really makes the bay area scene
something special. And the best part, making new friends...and I THINK I
can remember everyone's names...Carleen(sp?), Julia, Kathleen(sp?;-), Garret,
Roland, Keith, Hi, Mike, Mike, Fauna, Shamus...well, I'm sure I'm forgetting
someone...

The human intervention aspect that really annoyed me, however, was the number
of beer and other bottles left strewn about the dunes...cummon folks, we have
beautiful places to party out here, let's not take them for granted. Doing
so is bad for the everyone involved, from the various fauna and flora to the
person who cuts her/himself on a shard rolling down the dune at the next party.

Back to really happy thoughts, this review would not of course be complete
without a few words about Amber's most excellent pre-party...got there late,
but in time to see DJ Thorfio spin a killer hard trance set, make the most
wonderful Beth a bracelet, and hug Amber, which is the *best* way to start a
saturday night. 

Thanks everyone for making my first party since lepidoptera a great one.

love/justin

At 01:54 AM 9/22/97 -0400, Tekno313@aol.com wrote:

>I was appalled. Not only was this guy's lackey completely rude and
>insensitive to the situation, the music this guy was playing was a lot less
>than something to write home about. But hey? Who am I to say, if the candy
>kids like it, let the candy kids have it, I guess, but how are you doing your
>job as a DJ by playing records from 1992? If what we do is about progression
>and experimentation and new forms of musical exploration, then where does
>this fit?

i didn't make it to this party; but from what you describe i think that
sounds like an excellent set.  nowadays it seems like one trance set after
another, and if you're in SF, many house sets in between...

it would be really cool if there were a bunch more old school breaks
interspersed there as well.  music often takes giant leaps forward by
taking old elements and making something new with them--rock and roll came
from blues, after all...and some of the most exciting new stuff i've heard
borrows from the old days--like some of the new psy-breaks and, well, all
of jungle.

most of those old compilations are really cheesy, and hardly any are mixed.
 to get the true early '90s vibe you've really got to grab a mixtape, and
with distribution the way it was back then, how can you realistically get
ahold of one?

it would be really cool to reissue some of the classic tapes, back when the
sound was fresh and unheard of, and techno and breakbeat were mixed as
aggressively as any hip-hop you'd care to name.

i suppose people who want one kind of music will probably be disappointed
by another.  but remember, if you'd never heard any music that you didn't
choose to hear, you'd probably still be working your way through your Raffi
tapes.

not to dis Raffi--he lays down some fresh grooves.
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

Play Nice, my first underground, gave me my first real sense of family in
the dance community.  Yea, it's great to be on the dance floor getting
into a groove with others, but clubs and massives were all I knew.  That
is, until last night.  Big fat heaping tablespoons of praise and thanks to
ASR for showing me a part of life I've been missing.   I've been going
through a phase of loneliness and last night I was totally embraced in the
loving arms of a community.  healing processes at work.  a state of
continued mindfulness.  

And in that state of mindfulness, I forgot my blue jacket, lined with
white fleece next to the stage right speaker cabs.  Any chance that
someone picked it up?  

A warm hug to all the peeps I met.  You taught me some invaluable lessons
in love and giving.  I didn't get a chance to get all the contact
information from everyone that I wanted to, so if we connected, please
please, please, PLEASE send me email, cuz i dunno when I'm going to
see some of you's.  And in case you didn't remember that my name is
George, let me give you a visual reminder.  I was wearin a fuzzed white
wool beanie and having a wonderful time.  :)


Hugs,
George

Hey Dori,

I did not post this to the list because I did not want it
to get mis-interperted and get flamed for it. (its all good Paul 8) 

>paranoid freak (or a southern baptist preacher)
Why did you have to go here? 

I am an educated man Dori, (pre-med i could go on) and my brother is a
staff scientist (bio-inorganic) for AIDS research at John Hopkins
Univ. so I know what I am talking about. What I stated are clinical
facts. I have the info. to back me up, I was simply stating the truth.
I wasn't saying all hell and damnation shit. I am so far from
religious that this struck me as funny. You shouldn't label people
period! What if I was a baptist preacher? Are all southern baptist
preachers like this? Don't make generlizations you can't back up. I
wasn't saying, "stop all drug use now your going to hell"! I have the
knowledge and the facts to back up what I say! Until you know me don't
judge me...

Layne

From: Dori <luvnlyfe@freshmilk.com>

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org

looks like it went to the list to me!  I hit reply and that
sfraves@hyperreal.org addy automatically placed itself in the cc...  i
don't think that was sheer coincidence...

regardless, stating that AIDS and Crystal Meth are substances that are
being used to hopefully remove half the population of the earth are
paranoid statements, at best...

As for references to southern baptist preachers, well I DO have a bit to go
on, yeah (tie in personal experience with a year or so of comparitive
religion studies):

I grew up in the Bible Belt, thumping my bible with the best of them...  As
well, for years I had it drilled into my head the following:

AIDS is a plague on homosexuals for committing heinous & unbiblical acts
Cartoons such as the smurfs have hidden and satanic agendas
44,000 INDIVIDUALS WILL BE SAVED at the time of Christ's return (i guess
this is where aids & crystal meth come in?)
All other religions are incorrect

The church that I attended for several years was one of the largest in the
southeast, and is currently televised, in possession of youth & cultural
centers that families can go to for all sorts of things, and in the
practice of helping homosexuals convert to a "Christian" and heterosexual
lifestyle...

As well, this organization is fond of sending out rather militant
door-to-door "salesmen" to preach to unbelievers, and then patting
themselves on the back for "saving" them from the doom of hell.

Am I bitter?  No.  It was there for me when i needed it and yeah, for a
while it pulled me out of some serious mental and drug abuse, depression,
and a near-high-school dropout, but still...  One day I was sitting in
church thinking, "God, you know what?  These people are really
closed-minded..."  And I realized that all the help I thought I'd gotten
from this "church" was built on personal strength.  This was probably due
to the fact that a close friend of mine, who finally came to terms with and
accepted herself, was in love with another woman and couldn't be happier,
yet our "loving, caring church who represented the love of Christ" was
basically telling her that her future held nothing but  AIDS & hell...

I am of the personal opinion that the Southern Baptist church and most
other 'christian' beliefs operate on guilt and submission...  Fun if you're
into whips & chains but not when it pertains to how you construct your
life...

As well, mother earth has been in existence far longer than us humans - and
if/when she feels that we are getting entirely too out of hand, she'll make
some moves that put us in our place (she can start by that promised
earthquake that's going to send LA into the Pacific - JUST KIDDING!!!!)
That's if our own stupidity and ignorance doesn't do us in first.

So yeah, i can see where your PRE-medical experience and your brother's job
would give you insight on the effects of crystal meth - but I don't see
where either of those indicate that AIDS & crystal meth will be removing
half of us from the planet.

little too late.  Plus I was asleep most of the night anyway . . . damn 
prescription drugs!

Haven't been to a party since Big Top either.  Saving up for Happy Daze (here 
in Sac, looks like it's going to be a PHAT party) and the Tribal Massive on 
Halloween . . . oh yeah . . . It's amazing how much other stuff there is to do 
besides party.  Forgot about the outside world for awhile.

that sooo bad . . .

Dori,

Did you read my post? Where did I state that these are "being used to
remove half the population from the planet"???? Where Dori?? You need
to read before you reply. I'll let you read again without ASSUMING
then reply. 

I said the world (as an entity) is going to find a way to reduce its
population (not people, maybe your being a bit paranoid 8) and if you
have studied any history (or science) you know that this is the
truth.There is nothing paranoid about it, its reality. Black Plague -
Oh! I'm not going to deffend what is commonly known. (frustrated)
Let me tell you straight out. There will never be a cure for AIDS -
NEVER - hopefully someday there will be a vaccine that will curtail 
the disease and if you have read as extensively as you say you would
know this. But Dori, this is a long time in the waiting and thousands
and thousands of people will die before this happens. I could argue
about this all day but look at the reality.

There is a reason why Crystal Meth is being called an epidemic- take a
good long look in a dictionary at the word before you reply this time.
There is a reason why task forces and millions of dollars are being
dedicated to stopping this EPIDEMIC (yeah right). Lets take this off
line Dori....


Layne

I have to agree w/B.A. here ....  are we all so cynical that there is
nothing that is considered a positive thing?

how sad it makes me when I see so many on this list take positive events
and cast such a cynical eye on them that it completely negates the
positivity?

is this contribution completely selfless? no, nothing is completely
selfless.  and, really, what the hell is wrong with not paying income tax
on money you are passing through in a move that could affect world piece,
for chrissake??

is it an amazingly good thing that he is doing this and taking the
opportunity to encourage other people of wealth to do the same thing?  fuck
yeah.  this is what leadership is  all about.  this is exactly what "put
your money where your mouth is" is all about.

and he gets slammed?  just like someone on this list slammed Mother Theresa
full-on 100%.  Was she *all* good?  possibly not, when you consider her
religious perspectives that might be too hard-core for some.  but was she a
million times better than anyone most of us have ever encountered in our
daily lives? yes.  did she accomplish more good than most in our world ever
could even conceive of?  yes.

so come on folks.  it's one thing to be wisely skeptical and realize
there's always more than meets the eye.

it's another entirely to become so close-minded that you suspect
everything.  it's an open mind and heart that makes us different is it not?
otherwise, we're just another incarnation of the KKK or fundamentalists.

(and sorry, a million dollars is a million dollars, it ain't never no drop
in no bucket, no matter how much you have .... and a billion dollars is a
ocean of a lot of money)...

leslie

From: "Corey Alambar" <corey@ncd.com>
