Date: Mon, 22 Sep 1997 10:48:10 -0700
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (4.0.1 13Jan97)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Lifeforce review from a near-newbie
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, I'm not gonan say up or down - there were good and bad points.  The good
ones seemed really really good, and the bad ones... Let me explain.

(Disclaimer: I am only just now attending these events regularly.  My opinion
should be taken as that - opinion, and froma newbie at that)

I only went Saturday night - I was hoping to meet up with osmeone, but we
eneded up missing each other.  I heard Friday night had a number of problems...

Security sucked.  I would have expected more courtesy from a southern cop
(note: I'm a long-hair fag... This can cause trouble!)  Indoor security in
black is bad juju - you feel like you're in a police state.  And then, if
something DOES happen, finding security in a dimly lit environment can be
difficult.

Security also shouldn't slink about and harass people.  They are there to
reflect the order the promoters and the producers want - they are not the long
arm of the law.

Conversely, the strong security presence seemed to keep vandals down,
particualrly outside, but there are some prices not worth paying, IMNSHO.

I know the party had commercial backing, but I didn't expect to have to pay $3
for the only size water they offered.  That gets REALLY pricey, and aliter of
water is not good to drink at once, but is also very easy to lose.  By 3 am,
the main dance floor was soaked.

Skylab 2000 kicked!  I loved their show - so much that it got to the point that
I couldn't move afterward. The DJs in general were really good - I felt fine
just sitting and listening.  However, there seemed to be a little trouble in
getting the next acts synched up.  Unfortunately for me, this is where the
party ended - I was sore, exhausted, and had to drive all the way back to Santa
Cruz, so I vanished around 4:30.

All in all, it was not a bad evening, but there are a numebr of ways I could
have seen it done better.

-Corey

                                WE NEED YOUR

                               *** HELP ***
                               *** VIDEO ***
                               *** PHOTOS ***


        Liquid (ryan) & I (mercury/sherry) are making a CD-ROM all
        about the rave scene addressing the issues someone from
        out of the area would want to know about the scene here.  Here
        are the topics we've come up with so far.  Please let us know
        what you think, what we can add, and if you have any video &/or
        photos we could use to put on it.  Here's our 'outlin':


        1. PEOPLE
                - ravers
                - promoters
                - djs
        2. ART
                - flyers
                - bombing/graffiti
                - fashion
        3. PARTIES
                - locations
                - photos
                - video
        4. HANGOUTS
                - locations
                        - Haight
                        - Telegraph
        5. HISTORY
        6. FUTURE
                - MTV
                - commercialism


                                              ** let us know what you think **

                                                ;) mercury

From: Interplanetary Monkey Jockey <anarchy@galaxy.galstar.com>
Message-Id: <199709221818.NAA23558@galaxy.galstar.com>
Subject: Play Nice/Not Nice/The Horror ..The Horror
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Mon, 22 Sep 1997 13:18:12 -0500 (CDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]

Precedence: bulk

Okay Peeps,

First of all no great party goes off without its little glitches and problems
but all were overcome by the end of the night/next afternoon and what resulted
in a bomb ass party.

First off was Re-Ach spinning some mad ass drum -n- bass.  What a way to start
off the party.  Great set.  After him was Kid Bippy.  I will get into that 
later.  After him was Turrac and man does he lay down some sick tracks.  My 
mind was pudding after he was done.  I don't know where he finds some of those
songs but they should come with a warning label! = ) 

After him was Micron who played some great cybertrance.  I liked the songs he
played but I couldn't get over the mass of girls hovering in front of him
screaming at him.  It was very much like when Elvis and the beatles debuted on
the Ed Sullivan show.  He also had some difficulties matching a few tunes but
a nice set overall once you got over the cheerleaders.

Monty was next and did a great job.  He had some tight beats.  After him was
Science.  There were a lot of sound difficulties during his set which might have
distracted some people but he played some of the best tek-step.  The sun was 
coming up and man can he tear up the decks.  Sitting at the top of the dunes
with the waves behind you watching the sunrise.  It was definately a beautiful
morning.  After science was his tag team partner Siphon.  Some even more
beautiful drum-n-bass. Start the party off with some and close it out with some
more.  w0w.  Another great set.  He went all out showing off his skillz and 
played some sick beats.  I loved his faced when he layed down this funky 
track, it was one of near disbelief.  

Thank you to all the DJ's above you made it a great party.

Okay now listen up all kids, please read thru all of this before passing
judgement.

I have never felt so insulted and violated as I did after Kid Bippy finished
his set.  First of all it started out with his manager bitching at anyone
within listening distance saying how they should kick Re-Ach off the decks so
Kid Bippy could spin right at 1:00 am so he could get home in time.  Get home
in time ? for what ? he can't even stick around for the rest of the party?
Is he not good enough for us ? Oh its the I am a (wanna be) DJ and thus I am too
cool to dance and mingle with the common folk. Plus what is the manager stuff.
Oh man this is not what being a DJ is about and being a part of the scene.

Okay let me continue.  That whole incident left a bad taste in my mouth to start
off with, and after hearing the first two songs I knew it was going to be 
painful.  To best describe his set is this:  

Someone went back in time to 1992-1993, kid napped a DJ and his records (this 
would also explain how some of his 5 year old rekkids sounded so clean) and
brought him hear to 1997 to play.  I can play you mix tapes of my friends
spinning back in the day and you will hear all the songs he played and all the
same mixes, cutins/cutouts that he used.

I have been doing this for a while and all
those old skewl songs mean a lot to me and to have hear them again under those 
circumstances was not a positive experience.  I am not saying that no one can
play old stuff,  I emplore DJ's dropping some old school beats every once in a
while.  Also if they have been in the scene for a long time and DJ since 1992
they probly do play the songs.  BUT then again do not make it your thing! Kid
bippy has not been spinning for 5 years, and if he has he hasn't bought a new
record since.  He played those songs NOT out of love or respect for the songs
and the scene they represent/represented.  There were not so many diverse
genre's back then so every DJ played this style of techno. 

Another point is that I want to say to avoid so confusion is that I love those
songs a lot and they are very dear to me, and for all the people that heard
these songs for the first time, I am happy for too for they are great songs
with lots of energy.  I want a lot of people to enjoy them.

It all comes down to intention and what the DJ puts into his style/set. Does 
Kid Bippy jsut like old school soo much he wants all to share it with all of 
you?  If thats true then show some class, style and respect.  None was displayed
saturday night by him or his "manager".  

Does he want to spin popular songs/easy songs, identifiable songs  
that everybody likes and will dance to so it makes him look like a better DJ
than he really is?  Yes and this is where I have my problem. Anyone can
get behind the decks and spin that same set and get the same crowd reaction.
Prolly a little better cuz hopefully they would not have the occasional train
wreck and manager jumping up and down behind him/her while they spun.

Does he really care about the scene or is he just in it for the fame/fortune?
Well he and his manager took off awfully quick after he finished.  Plus what
is it with this whole "The schedule says 1:00 so he spins at 1:00am no matter
what" It was a underground/renegade party!! Its not going to go a s smoothly
as it was planned .. thats a part of doing it.  It makes it more real down to 
earth.  Plus where is all the PLUR in that as well. The repect for the DJ 
spinning he wanted to kick off, the people he was screaming at, the rest of the
people at the party. 

No he wants to become a big name popular DJ, and he (and his manager) figure 
that the easiest way was to use these songs. I seriously doubt that he or his
manager gives a shit about this scene.  Its obvious they haven't been in it long
or I would hope that they would show more respect than that.

Sorry to ramble on so much but after doing this for so long, I get very 
emotional when I see the scene I love exploited for someone elses personal
gain.

SOOOOOOOOOOOO Please all of you out there.  DO NOT support Kid Bippy and what he(doesn't) stand for.  If he is spinning at a party you know of don't go, if you
find yourself at a party he is spinning at, go to the other room or go outside.

You might say where is the PLUR in all of this, but when someone doesn't show
respect in the first place, they get no respect in return!

I hope all of you had fun this weekend,

Herb

On Fri, 19 Sep 1997 BTIME37042@aol.com wrote:

> every one makes their own choices, but check out my story.  Over the last two
> years I have realy tried to be more true to my self.  I have not put anything
> up my nose and I have also came very close to not drinking spirits.  It was
> the music back in 92 that began bringing me to my current reality check.  I
> still hit the buds, but i have come to  peace with my self about this because
> there are a lot of positive effects of pot.  So here I am in 97, spinning
> records for a couple years, being myself, just being, and all of a sudden
> WHAM!!! BIG reality check,  I find out my girfriend for 3 years has just
> tried or has been doing speed(crank,meth,DOPE!!!). I lost my shit, I cant
> hang with this.  I have spent several years of my life turning my
> evil-vandalism-drug-dealing-life around hoping to stay as distant as possible
> from shit like this.  And now someone so close to me has lost all my trust.
>  She did not come to me and tell me "Hey I got this fucked up urge the other
> day to do something stupid," no, I found out from her friends and ceased the
> dope out of her purse my-self.  She lied to me and told me she would never
> think of doing it.  She should know better, we live with her mom who vaccumes
> at 3am and looks 60+ when she just made 50.  I am having so much trouble with
> this and I dont know where to turn.  Sometimes I wish I could vanish
> completely into the underground( im all ready half-way there).  All i am
> lacking now is more family , and i know they are out there.I feel i should be
> going to these raves by myself, not bringing my girlfriend or any other
> un-adjusted people.  I want to meet more hard-core people that dont go out to
> parties for the drugs or even the music( it all kicks ass anyways!) but for
> the LOVE!!!! THE FIFTH ELEMENT!!!!!!!!!!  That is my high-wire now.  I love
> music, I love all organisms, and most of all I love myself and the creator.
>  Self confidence is the key to happiness, and if you are happy you should not
> need any of those

And the word is THANKS to all the people there.

Despite some technical problems (which happen) I was very glad to spin
this party. Monty, in particular, really had me feelin it. I was sorta
half-asleep lying down for Micron's set (sorry dan, but it was pretty
damn soothing) when things started getting funky. I figured I'd better
get up or I'd sleep through my slot. It's incredible how a dj can just
grab you plop you into the groove. I went from half-asleep to
head-boobin, to dancing in 3 tracks. Sweetness...

The reason for the THANKS is also because I had a good old friend from
Paris visiting who had just flown in that evening. Although Dan wasn't
into all of the music, he had a great time and said it reminded him of
the old days. So thanks so much for letting him in, kids. Whenever I
start losin the love a little you guys kick me in the ass and show me
that after 6 years in this scene it's still going strong for the right
reasons.

take care

Science

sorry for any confusion there, elizabeth, but my comments were meant for
the list as a whole, but because i chose a post to reply to that had text
from you and from Black Adder, it may have looked like i singled you out...

but i must say that, upon rereading your post as requested, that yes, I do
believe you were discounting his donation by belittling its value because
he is hugely wealthy and because you are skeptical of his public
announcement of it, and that he has something to gain...  (though i can't
imagine how much p.r. one would need to get back in order to have it be
worth a billion dollars!)

"sharing your wealth" can present a dilemma on how to "value" someone's
contributions ... on one hand, i do believe that if you are profoundly
poor, and you give 50 cents of your last dollar to help someone else, then
you have made a huge contribution of half of what you own.

but on the other hand, if you are immensely rich, and you give a billion
dollars to help someone else, but it's only 1/3 of what you own, you've
just give ****a million dollars a thousand times**** ... and that's way
better than 50  cents, because it can do so much more.  (in fact, that is
SO MUCH MONEY that it might actually have an effect on the entire world)

(though frankly, giving ONE THIRD of your total worth is huge no matter how
you look at it ... how much are your parents or your wealthiest relatives
worth?  can you imagine them giving away one third of what they own????)

sometimes many of us carry issues about money and who deserves it and that
people who have it can't be truly good .... and so on and so on .... if you
(that means 450 people out there, e., not just you) have issues like that
that color how you see the world, you may want to examine them and try to
get over it ... because money *can* be used to do good, but if you think
people with money are inherently bad, then it's not likely that you will
ever have any ....

it just seems so silly to me that i hear people say things like "if I had a
million dollars, i would do this, and this and this.." but then turn around
and be suspicious of people who actually have that kind of money and are
willing to use it for what they think is important.

money can do great things .... but not if you don't have any.  here's
someone proving that (at least it appears that is his intention) ...

over and out, back to work to earn a dollar or two!

leslie

Well im kicking myself in the ass cause I missed the party. I was
scheduled to play the after party so I figured I will just attend that
cause I was tired from work plus I did not want to drive back and
forth from Monterey to SJ I heard the party Went off!! My Day Starts
with a phone call at 7:30 am from Beth saying "Where are you" im like
it is 7:30 and im tired. She tells me to come to the party cause it is
sunny and nice so I ask if I can play early as I was supposed to play
at 1:00 pm. She asks Jeremy and he says sure come on down. So im like
kewl I will do that. Then I think Shit!! I have not arranged my
records yet there is a pile of records all over my floor cause I was
frustrated with my sound and I was trying some new stuff. So I get a
bunch of them and stuff them in my Technics bag. And off I go. I get
there and it is kewl I have never been to the "Pit" it was a nice spot
nice sun kind of breazy im like awwww this is kewl. Plenty of peeps. I
say high to everyone some nice Jungle and Disco was played by a CFC DJ
and some other Monterey kids. I talk with Jeremy and he tell me how
Mikey (Kid Bippy's MGR.) Totally bitched him out and he was drunk and
acting a fool. That is not kewl he should have understood that shit
happens. BTW if you are going to boycott Kid you should also do so his
MGR. Mikey is the guy that does "Planet Rock" Just A FYI he is the
main man behind that krew. I have never been to any of his parties but
I heard his last couple of ones were sketchy with times and acts not
even showing up?? So I would think he would be understanding but I
guess not? NE-Wayz I don't know either one of them personally so im
not even going to talk shit or go that route. I just think he should
have understood how things go. Sound was good space was  good I hope
you guys liked my Groovy House even though people were expecting me to
play Hard Tekno I just could not do it in the middle of the day I
thought house fit the mood. It was nice to see some old faces  high
Dan "Micron Ladie killer" heheheh...
You know what's up kid Sorry I missed your cybering beats hey Monty
and the rest of everyone I saw out there.  In closing it was a good
party and good day. See you all at Abyss this weekend if you haven't
heard about it you betta ask somboda...

Macadio (Mack-Audio)

well...i read monty's post......and decided that i had some thoughts
on this too.

but first.....never drink red bull after eating a
burrito...yuck.....my stomach will never be the same.

okay..back to the party....

KIDS!!!!  if u want to throw a party...which i definitely encourage u
to do...PLEASE be organized.  i can't tell u how many times i've been
to or played at a party that was not organized well.  If u have never
thrown a party before...talk to some of the experienced groups that
have (like viberation, cloud factory, FnF, etc.) and really get a feel
for what is involved.  I'm not pissed, just getting tired of party's
not going off, or barely going off due to so many problems.

Now about kid bippy.....
if u would like to play music that's all from 1992 and on MTV's rave
compilation...that is totally cool with me, everyone has their own
style and i can respect that.  BUT please do NOT walk around like u
are the shitza and DEMAND to play NOW...regardless of circumstance.  
We are all dj's and of equal importance to the party, so whether u are
dj dan or mr. nobody u all deserve to play.  So, i guess what i'm
trying to say is that u should be MUCH more considerate to the
promoters and other dj's.

BTW...nice sets monty, re-ach, science, siphon and terrac.  u guys ALL
rocked.

=)
micron

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Hawtin + Play Nice
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

What a weekend!
Hawtin was hot in both senses, going through a crazy musical journey over 5 hours, encompassing hard techno, detroit techno, trippy mad techno, oldskool techno, chicago house, even some vocal garage thrown in there towards the end. Brilliant. The DJs on before him were very good too, especially the crazy electro beatz.
Play nice really blew my preconceived ideas about what the Californian scene was about. Coming from London involves a healthy dose of cynicism about the whole "PLUR" thing - it's been seen, done, sold and killed. But there was such a feeling of openness and unpretentious acceptance of everyone there that it really surprised me.
Plus the venue was killer. Who needs a smoke machine when you've got fresh fog rolling off the sea ;) And as for the stagediving down the dunes - wow!
Music went from vey good to very cheesy - Started with great jungle (hell, you gotta love jungle if you're from London), but rapidly the tone went decidedly cheesy - Urban Hype's "The Key", anyone??
However, all was saved by a DJ who I think was called Terrac (not sure though) but he started with Dave Clarkes Red 3 and ended with this amazing New Order remix that really made me moove and groove.
All in all the best five dollar's worth I've ever had. Well done, guys. Think I met Jeremy and Pyro (briefly) and saw some guys with sfraves laminates on but was in a little world of my own 8).
Seeya all at sunset boat party next w/e.
Overnout
C@weasel.

Precedence: bulk

Dan/Micron brought up something I"ve been wanting to say for a while...


>KIDS!!!!  if u want to throw a party...which i definitely encourage u
>to do...PLEASE be organized.  i can't tell u how many times i've been
>to or played at a party that was not organized well.  If u have never
>thrown a party before...talk to some of the experienced groups that
>have (like viberation, cloud factory, FnF, etc.) and really get a feel
>for what is involved.  I'm not pissed, just getting tired of party's
>not going off, or barely going off due to so many problems.


I'd like to go a step further.  If you want to throw parties, that is
completely great, because we always needs new blood coming in and doing
things in a new way...

but i suggest that you don't just *talk* to more experienced promoters and
crews....

i STRONGLY suggest that you actually help put on a few parties first before
you try your own...  be in on it from the planning stages all the way
through to the chill-out when the cleanup is done.  and i mean *working*
and *paying attention to details*  ....  make those lists, work those
shifts, learn it by doing it.

think of it as an apprenticeship of sorts .... a way to learn from behind
the scenes how many details there really are to all kinds of parties, from
the tricks of beach parties all the way to the red tape of permitted
parties... learn what you can, and don't count on the more experienced
people to bail you out.... calling up someone on Saturday afternoon cuz you
just realized you don't have any decorations is sorta silly, wouldn't you
agree?  or not having a working generator or -- even worse and more easily
avoidable -- not having enough gas for the gennie?  (these are just random
examples)

it will be better for you and your crew in the long run, and will certainly
be better for the people who are turning over their friday or saturday
night to you, if you have a little practice at what you're doing!

love, leslie

p.s.  sound like play nice played nice.  wish i'd have been there, Jeremy!

At 07:09 PM 9/21/97 +0000, jen wrote:
>So how was the party?  
>
>

Well my side of this whole thang goes something like this....

The party itself was cool.  It was Jeremy's first party so as far as
production, and whats actually possible to do at the PIT (what you feel
like hauling up and down this brutal task)....the wood was an excellent
option for the people shaking their booty's.  The rug under the dj was
great for stability and keeping our record boxes, bags, and rack mounted
gear that much cleaner... =)  The lights that were used were pretty cool,
behind the dj by the generator and up the pit wall.  There were black
lights that gave it that wonderful effect we use black lights for.  There
was some ASR props.  I think I saw a matress, but I wasn't sure.  The fog,
mist, what ever that stuff was, was an added natural plus.  Except for
getting a little damp at times.  It wasn't that bad.  It cleared up later.
Thats when it got cold. =(

The crowd was young energetic and having fun, despite the sound problems
and whatever drama there was.  I slept most of the time till my set @
7:30am right after Mr. Science (alex).  I was soooooooo tired!  Sorry.

About Kid Bippy, well I wasn't impressed.  Matter of fact I went to sleep
after a while during his set.  I heard about all the drama that happened
after I woke up.  My take on it is a dj needs to be more thoughtful towards
the other dj's, the promoter/s, and the people.  Its all about respect and
supporting this scene.  If you want to be a rock star then you're in the
wrong scene.  Keep your body gaurds/thugs/personal promoter/manager at home
this isn't the MTV Music awards...enough of that...

I think we need to thank AndyW for his support in this whole party and
Cloud Factory.  Without them this party wouldn't have happened.  Jeremy
thanks for having me spin.  I had a good time spin'n for you all.  

Other than that I hope everyone had a good weekend.  And until next time,

Bu_bye...

    S       i       p       h       o       n
_________________________________________________
http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Alley/7995
____I'm a schizophrenic......and so am I!  ;)____

I can relate.. I think it's called is "comparison syndrome".  A "so-so" 
thing will be really disappointing when you've gone to lots of 
"yes-yes!" things.  It's all new in the beginning, so everything 
including the so-so things are great, after a while things aren't so new 
anymore, so it's not as exciting.  Personally, I realized that I was 
sick of E and not of raving.  So I took a break from E and found raving 
a completely different experience, but still enjoyable.
Hope this helps.

From: "peter sandifer" <boomerangflip@hotmail.com>

Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Mon, 22 Sep 1997 15:30:29 PDT

Precedence: bulk

Hey, Mista DJ;

At BBQ & Beats, I was chilling at my tent when I heard screaming coming 
from across the campground.  In a panic that someone had been hurt, I 
ran toward the screams; to see that 
they were screaming about you.    The bottom line is, it's not your darn 
fault.  You're just playing records, for god's sake.  Techno music is 
pretty emotional stuff and I can understand 
the desire to attach that strong emotion  to a human face.  That's the 
dj's curse.

Which brings me to my one big gripe about SF:   Most of the smaller, 
underground parties only have 2 speakers, not 4; and everybody dances 
facing the DJ!!!
This is not a slam on SF, but it is an odd phenomenon that appears to be 
regional.  For example, at parties on the east coast, there are always 
at least 4 speakers, one in each corner.  This was, the music spins a 
web around the listener and completely ensnares the dancers.  Why do 
promoters in SF use only 2 speakers?    There is a natural instinct to 
face the music, which also means facing the DJ.

Personally, I hate it.   I even prefer circle dancing to DJ-dancing.  
It's such a nicer environment when dancers are facing each other, 
communicating with their bodies,  rather than worshiping the DJ.   
There's a certain emptiness in everybody facing the same direction, I 
think.  At many east coast parties, the DJ is not even visible to the 
dancefloor.  (He or she is often on an elevated platform, so that they 
can monitor the dancefloor reaction; but there is none of this 
rock-concert environment on the dancefloor.


I have a feeling that the two-speaker party is partly responsible for 
the rock-concert environment.  So why don't more promoters create 
four-cornered sound systems?  Is it because of expenses?   Or is it too 
hard to find a sound crew that can appropriately balance the speakers in 
4 corners.  I do understand that it's a lot harder than with 2 speakers, 
but why can't anyone go to the trouble?   Laziness?    

It really disturbs me sometimes.   There really is a lot of vibe that 
gets sucked away.

Alrighty, I'm through.  you rock the house, Micron.  that's why they're 
screamin'

If anyone has any answers or flames for me; I'm all ears.


-b))merang

Subject: what's wrong with retro (was Re: Not nice???)
In-reply-to: Your message of "Mon, 22 Sep 97 01:54:41 EDT."
             <970922015440_1107610299@emout20.mail.aol.com> 
Date: Mon, 22 Sep 97 16:18:35 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


So i'z skimmin da list and see people dissing the soundz of '92. No, I
wasn't at play nice, so i didn't get to see the actions of Kid Bippy...
but, seems like people here are dissing him for playing "retro" '92
classic choonz. IMHO, those were the best soundz that ever got played,
and all the diversity of style that we revel in nowadays just don't
have the soul and the groove of a classic techno rip-up ala Jeno or
Garth of that era (IMHO, of course), or any of the mixing/production by
the grand-masters of yore (e.g. F.Knuckles, D.May, T.Terry).

It still causes the crowd's booty to schwang when you can pull out some
forgotten track and play it again and it sounds just as good or better
than any of the latest shit that makes all the glitter-spangled
pubescents cream their diapers ....  Seems like music today is being
made to throw away -- why would I want to waste my time listening to
music that was designed not to stand the test of time, for a public
that seems to exalt a limited artistic attention span as a way of
life?? Why is it that this one art form requires equating "good" with
"new" or "latest"  or even "underground" -- do y'all act like that when
you go to art galleries "dude, the Louvre sucks, all that art is OLD
SCHOOL!"

Besides, there's some really good "classic" tunes that came out in
1987-88 that are just about impossible to find nowadays and they'll
still shred on a lot of the choonz churned out today, e.g. (stuff i
picked up recently):

	-- Ce Ce Rogers' "Someday" (1987) -- vocal house at it's upliftingest

	-- Bam Bam's "Give it to me" (1988) -- rude and nasty dance choon
					       with a great booty shaking 303
					       proto-acid bass sound.

	-- A Guy Called Gerald's "Voodoo Ray" (1988) -- great rhythm, good
							sampling.

Retro rules. "We like the music ... we like that disco sound!"

And if Kid Bippy was an asshole, just say "kid bippy was an asshole" 
and leave it at that.

 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==>>                    Niels Mayer (mayer@netcom.com)                   <<==

I received a private response from the "16 year old with lots of ideals and
fears" in which the he praised me for being so respectful in my
communication with him.  He elaborated on some points and we continue to
engage in an interesting conversation.  In light of this, I will not take
your criticism too harshly.
I believe in truth.  The truth is that we live a world which does not
reward naivete.  Those who chose to walk around with blinders, covering the
realities of modern society, are taken advantge of in this jaded world of
ours.  Being naive is not something which aids progress.  It is something
that leaves people behind, playing the perpetual game of catch-up,
desperately trying to figure out what hit them.
I know how it feels to be 16 and have unrealisticly high ideals of what I
want the world to be.  I have felt his frustration.  I wish someone had
told me all of this when I was his age.  I was just sharing my own
experiences in hopes of improving his.  You make it seems as though he
wouldn't be able to handle what I was saying.  I guess I just gave the kid
a little more credit.  His passion was inspiring and I felt compelled to
encourage him to not give up on the world.  He can make a difference, even
if it is only on a local level.  Change starts in the community.  We all
need to take responsibility for that.

And I think I forgot to mention in my original repsonse, if you are 18
years old or over, please VOTE!!!!!!!!
Things may not be perfect, but if we give up, they're only going to get worse.

Hi Everyone!

Been lurking out here for a while and thought I'd finally let y'all know who
I is. My name is Brian and I've been in the scene for about a year and a
half. I've been listening to the music for much longer, though (remember
hearing "Numbers" from Kraftwerk when 1st came out and loving it ((that puts
me on the Jurassic scale of age, I know). Do mostly the club thing but do hit
raves occasionally. Would go more frequently but the sense of community is
hard to feel when you outage most by 10 years. 

Musik-wize I'm a trance Freeeek. Also into most house (Xcept the deep
stuff....yech!), Jungle, and almost anything else that has some originality. 

I'm local-grew up in Marin, school at UCSC and have now lived in S.F. about 5
years. Don't know if I'll ever be abel to leave this place, the people and
the area is so fucking BEAUTIFUL!

I'm kind of stuck in a 9-5 yob for a while (but not too much longer!!!) so
can't get to many of the events I'd like too during the week. Those parties
can be soooo much nicer just cuz' there's room to actually dance! Anyway, you
all are a great crowd and I'd love to hook up with you at the next (smallish)
event. 

By the way, if anyone went to Release this weekend I was the guy with short,
brown hair in an orange Diesel shirt trying his best to shake his ass clean
off at the end of Demilo's set (and probably looking pretty silly, was
feeling pretty silly). 

On the NRR tip...I'm looking to get into someone's snowboard cabin for the
winter. Anyone out there board and has a slot?

Later,

Brian Wolfe

Play Nice was a great party despite a bad trip that I had. Apparently 
the e that i had taken had mesculine in it and along with the 
candyflipping, well, lets just say it was waaaaay too overwhelming.  My 
friend who was taking e for his first time also had a scary time but we 
managed to be a lright once the sun came up.  
   Thank you so much for everyone that was trying to help Joel and 
Myself: Jenny, Blake, Lisa, and others.  My eyes were closed for most of 
the time because everyone looked very threatenning.  Joel and I ended up 
babysitting eachother and really bonded because of it which I am 
greatful for.  The fog, lights, blake with the cool trippy blinking red 
lights and multiply everyone by 15 and think of cutting your head off.  
It wasn't very PLURry so if people were trying to say hello and I 
couldn't talk, well that is why. I apologize and I wont be going to a 
rave for a while. 
   After the sun came up I was doing much better, I didn't realize who 
was all there cuz I couldn't move until I could see.  Everyone was soo 
beautiful and enjoying every bit of the party and dancing and laughing 
sharing stories and providing huge smiles.  This is what I loved.  The 
music was so cool even when I was way screwed up, well you dj's just 
made me sick.  It was a good thing though, I guess. props to AndyW for 
helping out with everything, along with Kid Bippy even with the drama 
that I heard about (sorry, but I love the old stuff)Siphon "Da Bomb" 
Ruiz, Science, Micron, Chris...I love the Oingo Boingo-sorry everyone 
but when I start spinning a bit more I'm gonna make everyone love cheese 
music and trance.  Don't think of it as dumb, but very fun  :)
   On kind of a bad note, Chad in the Blue had a very bad trip also and 
if you guys see him, make sure you give him a huge ass hug.  Despite the 
2 and two white fluffs, I want everyone to know that I learned a lot of 
valuable lessons...chill with the drugs, enjoy sobriety, and enjoy the 
love.  
   I am also asking that all dealers out there to notify anyone that 
buys stuff off of you to inform everyone if there is a surprise 
sub'satan'ce it will save us all a very bad time.  PLEASE PLEASE 
PLEASE!! I cannot beg you enough.  
   Later on I danced my heart out had ablast and then I had to go.  But 
to top things off,  My clutch was blown to smitherreenies and it took 
all day to get back home. and my car is still in Monterey :(
   Thanks to all the people that wouldn't help us out at all, you know  
who you are and I'm not talking about the people that had full cars.  
PLUR didn't exist that morning  when I tried to ask people to try to 
drop the friends I was with off in San Jose anywhere.  I was very angry.  
But thanks (sincerely) to the people that offered Pyro, Fernando, and 
others.  I got to bed finally, and had the best night of sleep in my 
life.

Thank you Jeremy!!!!!!!! I love you  :)
And we'll all  see you at City Espresso some time huh?
Don't worry , I still love everybody
Peace,
Danny "bAByHueY"Picard

From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: [NRR] Cassini...
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9709222119.A13659-0100000@netcom12>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


So, this evening CSPAN2 showed a lecture and slide presentation by Ellis 
Miner, Cassini Science Manager as recorded at JPL in Pasadena.  The 
presentation was very informative and even covered some of the claims 
that were in that sensational post to SFR a couple of weeks back.  I find it 
interesting, so I'd like to share a few of the things I learned:

One of the claims that really disturbed me was the one that said the 
launch vehicle had a horrible performance record and had detonated on the 
launch pad in the past.  The main launch vehicle is the Titan 4B rocket.  
The Titan 4B has only been used on one other mission and that was in 
February of 1997 to deliver USAF payload and the vehicle performed 
flawlessly.  
The secondary rocket is the Centaur rocket which has been used with great 
success on other satellite deployment missions.

In regards to radioactive elements of the Cassini unit:
Certain electronic units on the craft cannot withstand the extreme cold 
of space.  To this end, heaters have been installed to keep the units 
functional.  These heaters are powered by radioactive isotopes.  While 
on Earth (eg. from now until it gets into space) these parts of the unit 
are being cooled by an extensive air-conditioning system.  Also, the 
radioactive isotopes are housed in protective covers, etc. to prevent 
leakage, contamination, etc.

One other claim that really got me was the one about the recent re-enrty 
of a space station to Earth's atmosphere.  I really have no idea what 
these folks were talking about here.  MIR is still orbiting, the 
International Space Station (ISS) is not in orbit yet...  Could they have 
been referring to Skylab which re-entered back in the late 70's?  In an 
environment where 1992 is considered ancient history, I'd say 1979 
couldn't really be touted as "recent".


As always, I encourage you to not take my word for it.  Go find out for 
yourself.  As they used to say back in the Hippy Days, "Feed your head."

:)

plur

>respond to you very kindly. in many cases i was merely reiterating
>megan's points. and not too harshly. the only thing i was harsh about

>of some pretty horrific things happening at raves, and i've been
>burned by quite a few ravers. having this naive attitude will only get
>paul hurt. if being straight and not coating my comments with sugar
>makes me harsh, then i guess i am. but this wasn't my intention. 

i understand your intention, and you *shouldn't* have to sugar coat every-
thing, but sometimes, to quote Mary Poppins, "a spoon-full of sugar helps
the medicine go down."  Often we, as 'social doctors' (to carry on the 
medical analogy) give the right prescription, but forget about the care-
giver part of medicine.
 
>second, i am not some sort of old fogey, or however you put it.
>(calling me that was just plain rude.) i've been the naive 16 year old
>who thought i knew it all. i was angry that people didn't see or hear
>me. now i realize that i didn't really know anything, and this is the
>point i was trying to make. if i had kept my mind closed, i never
>would have grown. the same applies to me today... i hope to grow and
>learn until i die. to me, the world is both a wonderful and sad place.
>but if i refuse to see the wonderful in everyday things, then i'd
>probably have a pretty miserable existence. why is saying this harsh?
>looking at older people as old fogeys will only close you off to a lot
>of learning. and i'm not saying that i know it all - i'm only
>beginning to see how naive i really am. and this is the only path
>toward growth, imho. but hey, if you've got another way, go for it.
>this is the way i've chosen. i guess i was fortunate to have a good
>eduction - both in high school and in college. i never saw my profs as
>trying to feed me bullshit. one must realize that everything is coming
>from one person's perspective, and take it as that. but this doesn't
>mean you can't learn from it. i would be really saddened if paul gave
>up and didn't take advantage of the good in life. closing himself off
>and isolating himself in the rave community, imo, would not be a good
>thing. he's far too young, and has far too much to learn. and yes, i
>was extremely offended by his 'uncivilized' comments. he should be
>prepared to take responsibility for what he's written. or is that too
>much to ask of a 16 year old? 

I apologize if you where offended, I did not mean to call you an old
fogey, I was trying to say that you might *APPEAR* to be one to Paul.
I commend you on your never ending search for truth, and i hope that
you truly listen (to me and yourself) and grow from the conversation 
that we've been having (i know i have.)  I also agree that, in general,
a 16 year old should be responsible for what they say and write, but
keep in mind that he (like the rest of us) is still growing.  And he (like
the rest of us) should be nurtured, and not cut down.

>anyway, why hasn't paul written me about this? you were the only
>person who jumped down my throat, and i don't think that the way you
>approached it was very appropriate or constructive.  i mean, really.
>is that the best you can do? i'm only 30, and to tell you the truth, i
>feel like i have as much to learn about the world as i did when i was
>12. i asm only now becoming prepared to assimilate all that there is
>out there.  

That is a good question, I think it's interesting that he responded to 
Megan and not you.  He probably found more constructive and 
nurturing guidance from her.  And my approach might not have been
perfect either.  Hey, I'm workin on it ;)

>as cliche as it may be at this point, "open your mind". *this* was my
>point.

I agree, and i'm listening to all of your points.  I apologize for anything

From: "e.menon" <emdash@rocketmail.com>

okay, first off i'm a she. :) and i really didn't mean to be too
harsh. but you have to see how calling the non-rave world uncivilized
is a bit nazi-istic (if that's a word). i only meant to show this kid
that the world will give to you what ever you see in it. if you see
everyone on the street as uncivilized, sure. they're not going to
respond to you very kindly. in many cases i was merely reiterating
megan's points. and not too harshly. the only thing i was harsh about
was his looking at the world as being uncivilized, and praising the
rave scene as some sort of god-sent group of ppl. please. i have heard
of some pretty horrific things happening at raves, and i've been
burned by quite a few ravers. having this naive attitude will only get
paul hurt. if being straight and not coating my comments with sugar
makes me harsh, then i guess i am. but this wasn't my intention. 

second, i am not some sort of old fogey, or however you put it.
(calling me that was just plain rude.) i've been the naive 16 year old
who thought i knew it all. i was angry that people didn't see or hear
me. now i realize that i didn't really know anything, and this is the
point i was trying to make. if i had kept my mind closed, i never
would have grown. the same applies to me today... i hope to grow and
learn until i die. to me, the world is both a wonderful and sad place.
but if i refuse to see the wonderful in everyday things, then i'd
probably have a pretty miserable existence. why is saying this harsh?
looking at older people as old fogeys will only close you off to a lot
of learning. and i'm not saying that i know it all - i'm only
beginning to see how naive i really am. and this is the only path
toward growth, imho. but hey, if you've got another way, go for it.
this is the way i've chosen. i guess i was fortunate to have a good
eduction - both in high school and in college. i never saw my profs as
trying to feed me bullshit. one must realize that everything is coming
from one person's perspective, and take it as that. but this doesn't
mean you can't learn from it. i would be really saddened if paul gave
up and didn't take advantage of the good in life. closing himself off
and isolating himself in the rave community, imo, would not be a good
thing. he's far too young, and has far too much to learn. and yes, i
was extremely offended by his 'uncivilized' comments. he should be
prepared to take responsibility for what he's written. or is that too
much to ask of a 16 year old? 

anyway, why hasn't paul written me about this? you were the only
person who jumped down my throat, and i don't think that the way you
approached it was very appropriate or constructive.  i mean, really.
is that the best you can do? i'm only 30, and to tell you the truth, i
feel like i have as much to learn about the world as i did when i was
12. i asm only now becoming prepared to assimilate all that there is
out there.  

as clich as it may be at this point, "open your mind". *this* was my
point.

cheers - e. :)

................................................................
"To be nobody but yourself - in a world which is doing its best, night
and day, to make you like everybody else - means to fight the hardest
battle which any human being can fight, and never stop fighting."    
- e.e. cummings

I don't know about you guys, but I've been doing a lot of reading about
this kind of thing. Including conspiracies, etc... and it really opens
your mind up to things that you have no control over and all it does is
add stress and anxiety to my life. Even though it's really interesting
it's still very frightening. We have no control over what the government
does (realistically), and if the space ship is going to blow up
and kill us all I'd rather not know about it. You know what I mean?
What could I do?? ha. Run to the nearest bomb shelter and hide, and
never know when it'll be safe to come out?? 

But one good thing about this is that it motivates me to call that gal I met
a few weeks ago ... who I had a fantastic evening with.... She's the
best. And I'm not going to be hesitant to call her. Cuz byroni could be
vapor in the not so distant future.. if this whole thing goes haywire and
humans longer exist.... so we should all start doing those last minute
things before the earth turns into a barren wasteland.. and all we hear is
DEAD CITIES playing on humongous speakers....

Byroni

Ps. Check out this web page if you're interested in some interesting
conspiracies and info on the illuminati:

http://www.impropaganda.com/~street/detour/ill5.html



On Mon, 22 Sep 1997, Noah Apodaca wrote:

> 
> So, this evening CSPAN2 showed a lecture and slide presentation by Ellis 
> Miner, Cassini Science Manager as recorded at JPL in Pasadena.  The 
> presentation was very informative and even covered some of the claims 
> that were in that sensational post to SFR a couple of weeks back.  I find it 
> interesting, so I'd like to share a few of the things I learned:
> 
> One of the claims that really disturbed me was the one that said the 
> launch vehicle had a horrible performance record and had detonated on the 
> launch pad in the past.  The main launch vehicle is the Titan 4B rocket.  
> The Titan 4B has only been used on one other mission and that was in 
> February of 1997 to deliver USAF payload and the vehicle performed 
> flawlessly.  
> The secondary rocket is the Centaur rocket which has been used with great 
> success on other satellite deployment missions.
> 
> In regards to radioactive elements of the Cassini unit:
> Certain electronic units on the craft cannot withstand the extreme cold 
> of space.  To this end, heaters have been installed to keep the units 
> functional.  These heaters are powered by radioactive isotopes.  While 
> on Earth (eg. from now until it gets into space) these parts of the unit 
> are being cooled by an extensive air-conditioning system.  Also, the 
> radioactive isotopes are housed in protective covers, etc. to prevent 
> leakage, contamination, etc.
> 
> One other claim that really got me was the one about the recent re-enrty 
> of a space station to Earth's atmosphere.  I really have no idea what 
> these folks were talking about here.  MIR is still orbiting, the 
> International Space Station (ISS) is not in orbit yet...  Could they have 
> been referring to Skylab which re-entered back in the late 70's?  In an 
> environment where 1992 is considered ancient history, I'd say 1979 
> couldn't really be touted as "recent".
> 
> 
> As always, I encourage you to not take my word for it.  Go find out for 
> yourself.  As they used to say back in the Hippy Days, "Feed your head."
> 
> :)
> 
> plur
> 

Byroni... .. .    
(The Space Cowboy)

> Not a flame but if you can do it better than go ahead. I don't know 
how 
>many parties you have set up yourself but it is a LOT of hard work and 
>cost cutting is a big concern for everyone.
>
> I personally try to go with 4 stacks but it is not always easy finding 
>and transporting the equipment.


What, you mean throw a party?  Me?   What are you, nuts?
I would never be crazy enough to throw a party.  But if I was so wacky,
I would definitely use 4 speakers.

Yes, cost cutting is a big concern,   but the whole point of raving is:
 
  o  the music
  o  communion through dance

in my opinion, by cutting the speakers from 4 to 2, you are cutting the 
experience
in ha/lf

   If the music doesn't

    sur (me) round

and snag me like a spiderweb;

and I am looking at Ran's buttocks rather than Ran's face while I dance,

I feel like I am 

  o  not experiencing the full potential of techno music.
  o  not experiencing the full potential of having a cosmic body 
conversation with Ran D. Dreams.

My question was based on more of a sociological phenomenon than anything 
else.  I have also been to high budget parties (Richmond Civic Ctr, 
HomeBase, The MooMoo Palace) where they use two stacks instead of 4.

It is curious that a culture made up of techical wizards and music 
aficionados would choose to cut 1/2 of the most important elements from 
their budget.

But mad props to anyone who has ever thrown a party.  I know that I'm 
too scared to even think about it.


b))merang

Hey guys, you might have already seen this, dunno...  (my friend produces
Rocktropolis, not that it matters but i thought i'd throw that in)...
After all the EH and BT reviews i thought someone might find this
interesting...


>this is from rocktropolis.  wow, no alcohol AND no vibe.
>bummer, man.
>
>>
>>ORGANIC PLAGUED BY BAD VENUE, NO ALCOHOL, NO VIBE
>>
>>  A last- minute location change killed the vibe of this year's Organic
>>Festival. Last year's critically- acclaimed event, held at Snow Valley
>>Resort in the San Bernadino Mountains, brought forth acts like
>>Underworld, Chemical Brothers, The Orb, and Orbital in a fashion close
>>to Europe's popular festival culture -- something only barely
>>accomplished in the U.S. with Woodstock and early Lollapalooza. Its
>>success gave rise to the possibility that England's huge dance music
>>scene could descend upon America in a major way.
>>
>>  If this year's Organic is any indication, it suggests the music will
>>remain underground.  Coming just after two under- performing national
>>summer tours promoting electronic and DJ culture (Electric Highway and
>>Big Top), the promise of a regionally- promoted, previously-
>>accomplished event remained with acts like Faithless, Crystal Method,
>>Sneaker Pimps, Aphex Twin, and Talvin Singh scheduled to play Organic's
>>all-night outdoor setup.
>>
>>  Unfortunately, two days prior to Saturday's (Sept. 20) event, promoter
>>Philip Blaine announced a location change due to adverse weather
>>conditions (fire hazards and flash flood possibilities). As a result, it
>>was held at the sterile  National Orange Showgrounds in San Bernadino,
>>California where Big Top and Electric Highway had just taken place the
>>previous weekend -- with some of the same headliners (Crystal Method,
>>Aphex Twin). Instead of featuring trees, stars, horseback riding, and
>>multiple beer and wine stands, the event offered no alcohol or food, a
>>soul- less gymnasium aesthetic, and not even enough water for sale to
>>meet the needs of those diehard fans who braved the ill-attended event.
>>
>>  Backstage, bands and DJs from the U.K. complained that it was one of
>>the worst events they had been to in America. Even so, acts like
>>Faithless -- whose blend of dance, rap, and rock captured America's ear
>>with this year's hit single "Insomnia" -- gave sophisticated, powerful
>>performances, but left immediately after performing. Aphex Twin and
>>their gimmicky dancing bears remained a crowd favorite, and
>>unfortunately, the latest U.K. buzz act, Supersonic (formerly known as
>>Supercharger), came on so late that few stayed.
>>
>>  Ironically, the colorful Organic '97 flyers handed out all week at
>>local raves promised "You remember the first, you'll never forget the
>>second." It's true, but for reasons other than the ones promoters
>>intended.
>>
>>-Kim Taylor
>

To: socal-raves@UCSD.EDU
From: Juce <nohjuce@loop.com>
Subject: re: lifeforce: review
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

hey all!  here's my take on lifeforce:

well, let's see...  my sister, her 2 friends (all rave-virgins and there
should have been 2 more, but you know, shiznit happens), and i take off
from berkeley a little after 9.  we stopped off at the market to get some
candy, power bars, and a disposable camera for the evening.  finally get to
the location in oakland a little before 10.  found a nice close parking
spot right near the front.  there were probably about a 100 or so kids
waiting in line to get in.  they weren't letting anyone in for about a half
hour or so, if i remember correctly.  thankfully, there was a porta-pottie
outside; nature always seems to call when your waiting in line.  the rest
i'll break down by category.

LOCATION/SETUP:

huge ass place in oakland, about a mile or 2 from the oakland airport.  all
you sfravers already know about the location, but let me just describe the
place for everyone else.  it's this enourmous silo type complex with many
different sections, 5 that i know of; however, they only used 4 for that
night.  i heard that they used 5 the night before with less people (will
get into this later).

after finally getting in (sometime after 10:30 i think), you hit the first
room.  the tables are setup at the end of the room with, i think, 6 tv's of
space-related video loops.  there's a red carpet in front of the tables
(hmmm...pay homage to dj?)  and a golden camel and some other props setup
behind the dj.  a little different, kinda cool, i liked it at least.
there's a walkway on the right side of the room where it takes you to the
other areas.  immediately at the intersection of this walkway and the
walkway perpendicular to it, is this 6 foot long fluro fairy-type thingy
hanging off the ceiling.  liked that a lot so i took a picture of it.  from
the intersection, i went left.  the 2 other rooms were to the right, but
were closed off cuz they were still getting things ready.  so i go through
this walkway which i ended up calling flyer row (don't think i need to
expand on this).  so i get to the end of this which isn't long and leads
into the second room.  pretty dark, 3 still projected images on the right
side of the dj and one of those green lasers that look amazing and spell
stuff out.  well, wandered between the 2 rooms for a bit, met some people,
and danced in the first room for a while until the third room opened up.
djs on the left side, sound and visual guys in the center this room also
had all the concession stands and the 20 or so porta-pots.  SIDENOTE:  the
food/drink stand sold some food, $2 juice bottles, and $3 water bottles.
some of you might be saying what the f*$k?  well, fortunately, they were
liter bottles.  much better than the $2 dinky ass bottles we get down here.
 the 4th room didn't open up until 12, but i took a look a peek inside.
the stage was setup at the end of the room for the performers.  sound and
visual guys plus the turntables for the djs were setup in the middle of the
room. the whole right wall had acid warp images projected onto it.  

i liked the setup a lot, but i was expecting more, but i was happy with it
anyways.

MUSIC:

let's just say that SF loves there house music.  grooved to it for a little
while, but it just wasn't doing much for me.  if you're going to have
multiple rooms, i personally, think you should have different styles of
music going in each.  something i thought which was really cool was that
some of the djs in a couple of the rooms decided to get a little more
experimental with their track selections.  throughout the early part of the
night,  i got so confused with who was playing where and which room was
which.  the schedule didn't even help, especially since things got set back
a bit.

once the fourth room opened up about 12, i spent most of the night in
there.  first came terry mullan spinning some nice stuff.  danced for a bit
and wandered around until skylab 2000 came on which was close to 2.  got up
to the front of the stage, danced pretty hard, and was in awe watching
dennis just go off, mc a bit, and just plain having fun while intermitently
jumping around.  after a while, more people started coming into this room
to hear sklab.  majority of the people were in that room cuz all the other
rooms were starting to thin out.  while watching the crowd dancing, i
noticed how a lot of them were going nuts when sklab were building to a
climax.  so i decided to get on the stage, have a seat and bounce around
with glow sticks in hand.  when the next build came on, i just had to get
my camera out and took some crowd shots, plus some candids.  i gotta say
that there performance was the highlight of my night.  also, i must have
had close to 30 people ask me who this group was.  told them who they were,
and all the responses were positive to "fuck yeah," "oh my god,"  "they are
the shit," and other similar type of responses.  

after, they were done, i walked around for a bit and noticed that a lot of
people had left.  this was really sad.  since most of the people were in
this room, all the other rooms were virtually empty.  you could almost
count the number of people in each room on maybe 3 or 4 hands.  they even
started to tear down the equipment in the 3rd room with the concession stands.

after the dj that followed skylab, don't even know who it was.  for that
matter, i didn't know majority of the djs, when they came on if they did,
or where they were.  so sorry i can't give a more in-depth review of all
the djs, as if this post ain't long enough as it is.

around the time that skylab finished, my sister came up to me and told me
that her and her friends were getting tired.  i told them that we had to
wait for rabbit in the moon to come on.  unfortunately, they never did.  i
asked around and found out that they were getting paid and were discussing
when they would go on, but for some reason they didn't.  i was kinda
bummed, after seeing them at nocturnal wonderland last year, i really
wanted to have my sister experience a performance by them.  

so instead, bassbin twins came on.  they had a bit of technical difficulty
after about 5 minutes.  but came back with some beautiful, slower beat
stuff.  and although we only stayed for about half hour of the set, my
sister and her friends enjoyed that music the best.  however, this is not
to say that they didn't enjoy the rest of the stuff.  as a matter of fact,
they danced the majority of the night.  hardly even took any breaks to sit
down and rest, and this was from 11ish to 4:15.  

FINALLY:

okay, i'll make the rest of this short.  i had a really good time and so
did my sister and her friends.  i knew that this was supposed to be a
massive though the number of people didn't show it.  there was too much
space for the draw they got, so it did make things a bit difficult for the
close-knit vibey atmosphere.  i, personally, didn't see any negative vibes.
 i met a lot of cool people up there.  unfortunately, i only met one
sfraver, sherry (mercury).  and watching the smiles on people's faces
during s2000's set, made me really happy.


i could say a lot more, but i won't.  and if any of you actually read this
whole thing, i'm really impressed.  i was ready to delete this and just
say, yeah i had a good time and so did my sis and friends.

juce


btw, to all you sfravers, i will be up again sometime before the end of the
year.  i'm really close with my sister, so i can't go too long without
seeing her.  she definitely wants to hit up another party; next time we'll
go small ug style.  i definitely want to meet more of you.

From: scott3000@thegrid.net (scott)
Subject: Sillier Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

this was a rad party.  the new space was great.  i hope people didn't tag
it up so it can be used again.

boomerang, his friend jamie, and marshall and i got there at around 11:30.
downstairs in the main room hiz boy elroy and marcellus both spun fantastic
acid breaks/breakbeat sets that really had everyone dancing.  The energy
level was very high in the room the entire night.  henrik's set varied from
trance to more breakbeat and kept the place going.  not sure of the details
of the other djs, but all of the music i heard was great.  at one point
lots of peeps were clapping as people took turns trying to destroy - the
raver pinata!!! :)  yes, it was a real pinata, but it was filled with
things ravers like, candy, glow stix, and some other incendiaries that that
a few people to scan the floor with flashlights looking for anyones that
all the people snagging the stuff on the floor might have missed.

upstairs was a very crowded, but very cozy chill room with lots of happy people.

props to the sillier crew for a job well done.

you can dance if you want to,
/scott

I wasn't going to say anything, but you did say HELP!!  and ask "What
can
I do???" and "What have I done?!?!?!".

So let me help you with the 2nd question first.
You have agreed to not wear glitter for 3 weeks in exchange for your
Mom buying you a pair of overpriced baggy jeans.
 

To answer the question, "What can I do?":
Here is:      PLAN A

First, take a few deep breathes.
Now, get out a photo album and look at some pictures
of your sweet pretty face without glitter.  Breathe, it's okay.
Realize that you as beautiful without the glitter as you are with it,
IF NOT MORE SO.
Breathe some more.
Know that you will be okay and that
the glitter will still be there in 3 weeks.  It is NOT going anywhere.

Feeling better?
If not, here is PLAN B:
Return the jeans.
 

Hope this helps...

jen

I find myself facing the dj a lot.  I tried to get out of the habit because I 
told myself not to focus on the dj but to feel the music because that's how 
you really get down.  Right?

So I turned around and had my back to the dj.  And you know what I see?  
People standing around on the floor not dancing!  People in the middle of the 
dancefloor not moving a muscle (maybe bobbing their head or smoking a 
cigaretter or something), like they're too cool to dance . . . even when the 
dj is spinning phat beats!  Boo!  No parking on the dancefloor, at least not 
in the middle!

So fuck it!  I face the dj . . . but I close my eyes most of the time.

xoxo--Miccaela

----------

From: scott3000@thegrid.net (scott)
Subject: Sillier Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

this was a rad party.  the new space was great.  i hope people didn't tag
it up so it can be used again.

boomerang, his friend jamie, and marshall and i got there at around 11:30.
downstairs in the main room hiz boy elroy and marcellus both spun fantastic
acid breaks/breakbeat sets that really had everyone dancing.  The energy
level was very high in the room the entire night.  henrik's set varied from
trance to more breakbeat and kept the place going.  not sure of the details
of the other djs, but all of the music i heard was great.  at one point
lots of peeps were clapping as people took turns trying to destroy - the
raver pinata!!! :)  yes, it was a real pinata, but it was filled with
things ravers like, candy, glow stix, and some other incendiaries that that
a few people to scan the floor with flashlights looking for anyones that
all the people snagging the stuff on the floor might have missed.

upstairs was a very crowded, but very cozy chill room with lots of happy people.

props to the sillier crew for a job well done.

you can dance if you want to,
/scott

after all the bitching about kid bippy's set, i just have to say something.
(again!)

to be

noom

to be

in there.

old thing
about how everyone has different preferences.

I wasn't going to say anything, but you did say HELP!!  and ask "What
can
I do???" and "What have I done?!?!?!".

So let me help you with the 2nd question first.
You have agreed to not wear glitter for 3 weeks in exchange for your
Mom buying you a pair of overpriced baggy jeans.
 

To answer the question, "What can I do?":
Here is:      PLAN A

First, take a few deep breathes.
Now, get out a photo album and look at some pictures
of your sweet pretty face without glitter.  Breathe, it's okay.
Realize that you as beautiful without the glitter as you are with it,
IF NOT MORE SO.
Breathe some more.
Know that you will be okay and that
the glitter will still be there in 3 weeks.  It is NOT going anywhere.

Feeling better?
If not, here is PLAN B:
Return the jeans.
 

Hope this helps...

jen

Received: by release.gwainc.com with SMTP (Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.995.52)

Message-ID: <c=US%a=_%p=GW_Associates%l=RELEASE-970923213434Z-982@release.gwainc.com>
From: "Neves, Kathleen" <kneves@gwa.com>
To: "'SF Raves'" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: CAUTION: Daddy's Records Ripped Me Off, Don't Let it Happen To You!
Date: Tue, 23 Sep 1997 14:34:34 -0700
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.995.52
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

If you are a consumer who shops for records, be especially aware of 
shopping at Daddy's Records in Berkeley. There is a chance that you 
may get ripped off, blamed for it, and then treated rudely by store 
staff because of it. Read below to learn how I (the consumer) learned 
the hard way:

** Don't let This Happen To You*

I recently bought a used, domestic record that I thought was hard to 
find for fifteen bucks. Then today, I find out that the record is 
still widely available (new) on record store shelves for $7.00. When I 
called Daddy's Records to confront them about this, I was told (in a 
nutshell) that since I hadn't done my research on the availability on 
this record, that I deserved to pay that price. Then the guy (the guy 
said his name was Jason) told me about some of the records being on 
consignment and that the owner of the record determined the price, not 
Daddy's. I asked him then why there wasn't anything posted about 
records being sold on consignment and why was there a Daddy's price 
tag on the record? He belched on the phone, grew rude and told me that 
I should go buy the record somewhere else then. Oh, he did offer me to 
put the record back up on consignment. I declined and told him that 
that would just cause someone else to be ripped off. But he finally 
told me hastily to bring the record in and I would receive a full 
refund. It took 10 minutes to come to this conclusion and I verified 
he's refund offer and his name. Poor customer service. You won't see 
me in there again!

>realities of modern society, are taken advantge of in this jaded world of

>desperately trying to figure out what hit them.

Okay,  I wasn't going to say anything, but you did say HELP!!
and ask "What can I do???" and "What have I done?!?!?!".

So let me help you with the 2nd question first.
You have agreed to not wear glitter for 3 weeks in exchange for your
Mom buying you a pair of overpriced baggy jeans.
 

To answer the question, "What can I do?":
Here is:      PLAN A

First, take a few deep breathes.
Now, get out a photo album and look at some pictures
of your sweet pretty face without glitter.  Breathe, it's okay.
Realize that you as beautiful without the glitter as you are with it,
IF NOT MORE SO.
Breathe some more.
Know that you will be okay and that
the glitter will still be there in 3 weeks.  It is NOT going anywhere.

Feeling better?
If not, here is PLAN B:
Return the jeans.
 

Hope this helps...

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I can't really comment one way or the other about this poster's experiences 
with Daddy's, but I've found the place to have great music sold by good 
people.

As far as buying a record for an "inflated" price, that's due to what is 
called an "imperfect market".  It's a phenomenon caused by the fact that 
all people don't have access to the same information at the same time. 
 It's what allows a thing called arbitrage occur in the financial markets. 
 It's a fact of life.  If the poster failed to do their research on the 
record, that's pretty much how it goes when buying vinyl.  It's what makes 
it more interesting than spinning down to the Virgin Megastore.

Oliver



On Tuesday, September 23, 1997 2:35 PM, Neves, Kathleen 
[SMTP:kneves@gwa.com] wrote:
> If you are a consumer who shops for records, be especially aware of
> shopping at Daddy's Records in Berkeley. There is a chance that you
> may get ripped off, blamed for it, and then treated rudely by store
> staff because of it. Read below to learn how I (the consumer) learned
> the hard way:
>
> ** Don't let This Happen To You*
>
> I recently bought a used, domestic record that I thought was hard to
> find for fifteen bucks. Then today, I find out that the record is
> still widely available (new) on record store shelves for $7.00. When I
> called Daddy's Records to confront them about this, I was told (in a
> nutshell) that since I hadn't done my research on the availability on
> this record, that I deserved to pay that price. Then the guy (the guy
> said his name was Jason) told me about some of the records being on
> consignment and that the owner of the record determined the price, not
> Daddy's. I asked him then why there wasn't anything posted about
> records being sold on consignment and why was there a Daddy's price
> tag on the record? He belched on the phone, grew rude and told me that
> I should go buy the record somewhere else then. Oh, he did offer me to
> put the record back up on consignment. I declined and told him that
> that would just cause someone else to be ripped off. But he finally
> told me hastily to bring the record in and I would receive a full
> refund. It took 10 minutes to come to this conclusion and I verified
> he's refund offer and his name. Poor customer service. You won't see
> me in there again!

Hmmm..

 Not to disagree with my buddy Boom))nStuff.. But.
 I personally like it better when all the speakers are against one wall. I
think it's more powerful this way. It gives off a more 'in your face' kinna
feeling. You got to much...stuff...bouncing off the walls when you have
speakers all around you. Maybe if they had surround sound? =]:.. .. 3D
enchanced nStuff? Or ofcourse if they had the speakers raised and facing
alittle downward on each corner, that would be cool..

They should just splurge at every ravE. And get thoughs damn cabinets you
see at the Freedom ravE thingies. Just go balls out. See it! Hear it!
Experience it!.. Have like exotic dancing babes hanging from the ceiling so
Jeff can act like he is not starring at them. UFO's on every wall.. And
maybe even some florescent remote controlled airplanes flying around.

Anyways.. What is this thread about?
 I think people should throw parties if they want to, and goto parties if
they want to. And to make things less damned surprising.. They should just
re-record the info lines atleast once an hour, letting people know how
things are turning out. Keeping people informed.
 I always see promoters getting on here saying sorry. "Man, sorry guys, but
we couldn't get that bungie jumping thing up at the last second" bla, bla
bla.. Well, once this harsh reality hits the promoters, I think they should
change the damned message or something. Like: "Boom, boom, boom, hey, hey
everybody. Allright, tonights the night. We got a killer line-up for you
all this evening.." blah, blah. .. Oh and uh, Terry Mullan missed the plane
to San Francisco again.

You know?
I don't nStuff

see why.

Hey Jason,

I will state this first off - I don't support Coolworld Productions
for my own personal reasons. However, I went to the first Cyberfest at 
Henry J. Kaiser and I had a fuckin' blast. If your going to pay $25
for a party this one has a lot to offer. I prefer small intimate
parties
but massives can be fun, its all in your attitude, be positive and you
will have fun.  

I will say this, the thought of 20,000 plus (probably at least half of
them high individuals) kinda scares me. Too much of anything isn't a  
good thing ya' know.

Theres going to be a good party in Sonoma with some of the local
talent that is sure to go off - you can guarantee good solid DJ's and
music and
the vibe will be, well lets just say a little more positive to start.

You make the call.

Layne

you, see, vlad will know what im talking about nStuff (hi Jeff!)

You, see, long ago, there were a couple of pizza places owned by Tom and
Jeff.  

Tom felt guilty charging too much for the pizzas.  For instance, the
large combo was $14.22 at his store, while the same pizza in Belmont
(though sometimes more soggier) costed you $16.76.  

You see, Jeff was Tom's partner, and he made gOOd yummy pizzas.  But he
didn't feel guilty charging more for the pizzas.  His philosophy was
that people will complain, but most will still pay the price.  His
philosophy was to get them to get as much money out of their pockets as
possible before they will say 'too much' and go to Mickey Dee's down the
corner.  

And that's what I see happening in the rave world.  People complaining
about paying $25-30 but still paying it.  

The only reason gas is $1.60 per gallon is because we pay it.  I
guarantee you if everyone got together and said 'we're not going to buy
gas until it is 80 cents per gallon', the oil companies would FIND a way
to drop the price.  But you and I both know that will not ever happen.  

And that won't ever happen in the rave world either.  There are some
pretty goood $25 parties.  There are some pretty shitty $25 parties,
too.  I'm a little biased, I just don't like paying to get into these
things anymore, so  I usually find something or some way to contribute
to the party and just get in.  You know, I bring like a cow or a sheep
or a goat, something equitable to trade.  A chicken...;]

See then there is this other thing.  

The only Funky Techno Tribe party I ever went to was like 4 years ago. 
I was having a perfectly wonderful joyous time.  

But a friend of mine there wasn't.  He said, it was ok.  

So it's all about perception sometime.  If you had talked to me the next
day, I would have said it was a great party.  If you had talked to
Casey, he would have said the party was just ok.  

So...go if you want to a $25 cyberfest.  i don't have any idea if it'll
be good or not.  Maybe you'll have the time of your life.  some of those
massives can be good.  You might have a great time.  But they won't
notice if you're there or not, cause there will be so many people
already.  Don't expect a little card in the mail saying 'sorry we missed
you.  here's a coupon for $5 off the next party.'

dEEp

(((initiate bisexual transmissions)))

> > help is appreciated.

-----Original Message-----
From: Neves, Kathleen <kneves@gwa.com>
To: 'SF Raves' <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Tuesday, September 23, 1997 5:18 PM
Subject: CAUTION: Daddy's Records Ripped Me Off, Don't Let it Happen To You!



>If you are a consumer who shops for records, be especially aware of
>shopping at Daddy's Records in Berkeley. There is a chance that you
>may get ripped off, blamed for it, and then treated rudely by store
>staff because of it. Read below to learn how I (the consumer) learned
>the hard way:
>
>** Don't let This Happen To You*
>
>I recently bought a used, domestic record that I thought was hard to
>find for fifteen bucks. Then today, I find out that the record is
>still widely available (new) on record store shelves for $7.00. When I
>called Daddy's Records to confront them about this, I was told (in a
>nutshell) that since I hadn't done my research on the availability on
>this record, that I deserved to pay that price. Then the guy (the guy
>said his name was Jason) told me about some of the records being on
>consignment and that the owner of the record determined the price, not
>Daddy's. I asked him then why there wasn't anything posted about
>records being sold on consignment and why was there a Daddy's price
>tag on the record? He belched on the phone, grew rude and told me that
>I should go buy the record somewhere else then. Oh, he did offer me to
>put the record back up on consignment. I declined and told him that
>that would just cause someone else to be ripped off. But he finally
>told me hastily to bring the record in and I would receive a full
>refund. It took 10 minutes to come to this conclusion and I verified
>he's refund offer and his name. Poor customer service. You won't see
>me in there again!

Hi all!  ]=}



 On the issue of speaker stacks; When you only have two stacks (a stereo 
pair) you get a *much* cleaner, tighter, punchier sound (assuming 
everything else is done correctly) due to the physics of accoustics. When 
sound waves from multiple sources (speaker stacks) combine they affect 
each other (think of ripples in water interacting with one another). This 
interaction *can* be nice but is usually destructive to clearly hearing 
the sound. A two speaker stack will potentially produce stronger bass 
with less cabinets and amps (read less exspense and set up work).

 I had a bi-amp stack once (subs and top cabinets seperately amped) and 
at one point I lost one bass bin. The system sounded *better* without the 
2nd cabinet! The bass was tight and punchy without any washed out feeling.

 If done correctly, a 4 stack system is lovely. However to get really 
intense bass you need to have a bass bin stack that is seperate from the 
main stacks or at least only under one stack. Also it helps if the main 
subs (the cabinets clustered together) are only producing bass that is 
120 Hertz or lower. At 120 Hz. and lower sound moves in all directions 
whereas above 120 Hz. it moves in a 'beam' fashion (like a flashlite 
beam). To "beam" the sound from 4 corners is kewl but to have stuff from 
120 and lower coming from two or more physically seperate positions is 
asking for audio mud.

 I hope this answers a few of your questions Mr. Fidget.  ;)

hugz,



Ran D. Dreams


				    (Namaste)

                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~
