Let's get one thing straight, I am not out to "bash" anyone. My 
purpose for the caution posting was to INFORM all of you out there of 
a nasty incident that happened to me as an average consumer in hopes 
to prevent it from happening to anyone else. Bringing people and their 
business down was and is not my purpose here. Just to merely 
inform.......

Yes I am the same Kathleen Neves (in regards to the Garth CD 
postings), but I did not RIP OFF anybody. You need to personally 
contact Rhythm Music and talk to Matt Mau (408) 298-8299 and discuss 
any unsolved issues you may have about your CD fiasco.

In the case of the posting of the Garth CD, I was supporting a friend 
whom had produced and funded that project. I had no financial 
obligations what so ever to anyone, so how could I (Kathleen Neves) 
possibly rip anyone off?

The Garth CD was not in any way related to Rhythm Music. The CD was 
produced by Universe Music. The only thing the CD and store had in 
common was that the CD was sold there (among many other record stores) 
and the person who produced it happens to work there.

I have no intentions on "bashing" anyone. I was psyched to check out 
Daddy's. I was impressed, ended up buying a pretty good size stack of 
records, and even recommended people to Daddy's. When I found out that 
I was overcharged, I calmly called the store to find out why. But with 
the response I got on the phone which was rude and bad business, made 
me think otherwise.

I support ALL the businesses directly involved with the scene, not 
just the record store where my friend works at. I know this may be 
hard for some of you out there to believe but if Rhythm Music were to 
rip me off or mistreat anyone, I'd make a bloody mess of the incident 
as well.

-----Original Message-----
From: Neves, Kathleen <kneves@gwa.com>
To: 'SF Raves' <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Tuesday, September 23, 1997 5:18 PM
Subject: CAUTION: Daddy's Records Ripped Me Off, Don't Let it Happen 
To You!



>If you are a consumer who shops for records, be especially aware of
>shopping at Daddy's Records in Berkeley. There is a chance that you
>may get ripped off, blamed for it, and then treated rudely by store
>staff because of it. Read below to learn how I (the consumer) 
learned
>the hard way:
>
>** Don't let This Happen To You*
>
>I recently bought a used, domestic record that I thought was hard to
>find for fifteen bucks. Then today, I find out that the record is
>still widely available (new) on record store shelves for $7.00. When 
I
>called Daddy's Records to confront them about this, I was told (in a
>nutshell) that since I hadn't done my research on the availability 
on
>this record, that I deserved to pay that price. Then the guy (the 
guy
>said his name was Jason) told me about some of the records being on
>consignment and that the owner of the record determined the price, 
not
>Daddy's. I asked him then why there wasn't anything posted about
>records being sold on consignment and why was there a Daddy's price
>tag on the record? He belched on the phone, grew rude and told me 
that
>I should go buy the record somewhere else then. Oh, he did offer me 
to
>put the record back up on consignment. I declined and told him that
>that would just cause someone else to be ripped off. But he finally
>told me hastily to bring the record in and I would receive a full
>refund. It took 10 minutes to come to this conclusion and I verified
>he's refund offer and his name. Poor customer service. You won't see
>me in there again!

Deepfog wrote:

> you, see, vlad will know what im talking about nStuff (hi Jeff!)
>
> You, see, long ago, there were a couple of pizza places owned by Tom and
> Jeff.
>
> Tom felt guilty charging too much for the pizzas.  For instance, the
> large combo was $14.22 at his store, while the same pizza in Belmont
> (though sometimes more soggier) costed you $16.76.
>
> You see, Jeff was Tom's partner, and he made gOOd yummy pizzas.  But he
> didn't feel guilty charging more for the pizzas.  His philosophy was
> that people will complain, but most will still pay the price.  His
> philosophy was to get them to get as much money out of their pockets as
> possible before they will say 'too much' and go to Mickey Dee's down the
> corner.
>
> And that's what I see happening in the rave world.  People complaining
> about paying $25-30 but still paying it.
>
> The only reason gas is $1.60 per gallon is because we pay it.  I
> guarantee you if everyone got together and said 'we're not going to buy
> gas until it is 80 cents per gallon', the oil companies would FIND a way
> to drop the price.  But you and I both know that will not ever happen.
>
> And that won't ever happen in the rave world either.  There are some
> pretty goood $25 parties.  There are some pretty shitty $25 parties,
> too.  I'm a little biased, I just don't like paying to get into these
> things anymore, so  I usually find something or some way to contribute
> to the party and just get in.  You know, I bring like a cow or a sheep
> or a goat, something equitable to trade.  A chicken...;]
>
> See then there is this other thing.
>
> The only Funky Techno Tribe party I ever went to was like 4 years ago.
> I was having a perfectly wonderful joyous time.
>
> But a friend of mine there wasn't.  He said, it was ok.
>
> So it's all about perception sometime.  If you had talked to me the next
> day, I would have said it was a great party.  If you had talked to
> Casey, he would have said the party was just ok.
>
> So...go if you want to a $25 cyberfest.  i don't have any idea if it'll
> be good or not.  Maybe you'll have the time of your life.  some of those
> massives can be good.  You might have a great time.  But they won't
> notice if you're there or not, cause there will be so many people
> already.  Don't expect a little card in the mail saying 'sorry we missed
> you.  here's a coupon for $5 off the next party.'
>
> dEEp
>
> (((initiate bisexual transmissions)))
>
> > > I'm kinda skeptical about taking them to this and want to suggest
> > another
> > > spot.  Is there any other place you can recommend for saturday
> > night?  Any
> > > help is appreciated.

i've posted before, but i'm getting a little stir crazy, so i'll hope 
this reaches the right ears. i'm looking for a place in s.f. preferably a 
loft share. a lot of you know me at least a  little by now, i'm a 29 yr 
old financially (emotionally, chemically 8]) stable artist, writer and 
interacitve media designer with turntables, a sound system, lots of books 
and two well behaved cats. i have a bit of furniture, sound, woodworking 
and computer equiptment, etc, so space is an issue. i'm staying with 
relatives in silicon valley, but would love to get out of their hair 
asap. i am capable of keeping common areas clean, paying bills, doing the 
whole roommate thang. i'm also a fairly handy re-habber if anyone is 
thinking of setting up a new space, i might be game. supposing nothing 
comes of this, i might be interested in a shorter term apt/space to land 
while i look for the right situation.

seamus

I don't know about anyone else, I thought that Kid Bibby was great at *Play
Nice*.  I don't care if his records were 5 years old or 500 years old, he had
everyone out there up and dancing!  I never realized that the most important
thing about a DJ was his records.  I always thought that talent and technique
rated above the year that their records came out.  I don't know too much
about being a DJ, all I know is that Kid Bippy made everyone happy and isn't
that what it is all about?

                                                                  -nichole

 Friendship is a strange thing....we find ourselves telling each other
the
deepest details of our lives...things we don't even share with our
families
who raised us...But what is a friend? A confidant? A lover? A fellow
email
junkie? A shoulder to cry on? an ear to listen? a heart to feel?...A
friend
is all these things...and more.  No matter where we met,....I  call you
friend. A word so small...yet so large in feeling...a word filled with
emotion. It is true great things come in small packages.
   
   Once the package of friendship has been opened, it can never be
closed...it is a                           constant book always
written...waiting to be read...and enjoyed. 
   
   We may have our disagreements...we may argue...we may concern one
another... friendship is a unique bond that lasts through it all.... A
part
of me is put into my friends...some it is my humor...some it is my
listening
ear...some it is real life experiences...some it is my romanticism...but
with
all, it is friendship. Friendships forged are a construct stronger than
steel
 built as a foundation....necessary for life...and necessary for love.
:-)
       
     Friends, you and me.... 
        you brought another friend...
           and then there were 3...
              we started our group...
                 Our circle of friends...
                    and like that circle...
                       there is no beginning or end..
     
 Keep this going.... 
 Email all your friends this message.... 
 Email all those friends you never met.... 
 Those you have... and those you've lost along the way...
 
 
 This is to all wonderful people I have met personally or online! 
 @}----}----
  
  Pass this rose on
 and let them know
 that you care about them!!!
 don't let the rose die!!!
 JUST SENd iT!!
 
 >>

Ok heres my thoughts on my party . . . .

(1) Andy W is Da Man with out him this could not have happened. I know
that
if no one else does.
(2) On organization, I learned never depend on others if you can get
the job
done yourself. Sorry the sound didnt get up on time. 
(3) I wanna thank all of the DJ's for making the trip down to Monterey.
Can
you believe  we do that every weekend, the opposite dirrection.
(4) Thanks Jer for picking up the sound.
(5) I think this party had a great vibe and was appreciative of
everyone who
came out in support of ASR Productions first party. I threw this party
for
you.
(6) I wanna thank CFC namely Scott and Chris without your support i do
not
know what i would have done.
(7) I wanna thank Mike (ASR Productions)  for taking care of the manual
labor
the night of the party as I ran around.
(8) Ok here it goes *pluR*, yes the *R* is for respect. That is
something I
dont think was shown the night of the party by Mikey. Ok to fill you in
Mikey
is the promoter for Planet Rock. Mikey is also Kid Bippys Promoter
Manager
type thing. I didnt know Dj's had managers. I guess I'm lucky im in da
underground scene. I'm gonna keep it that way too. ok, here's what
happened,
the sound did not get there until late so, the party did not get
started on
time. Each DJ's set was cut from the hour and a half to a hour and 15.
the
lineup was moved around due to some crazy otha stuff. well mikey wanted
kid
bipp to start at 1 for a two hour set. i had tried to accomadate him,
when he
asked for a 1 am time slot, but that was before the sound sotuation.
well he
felt it was his job to get his dj' the best time. truly i could give a
fuck
who he was, big name or not. he kept repeating to evereyone bippy could
get
300 dollars if he left and went and spun at life force. i suggested
they both
leave then. he said what are ya going to do escort me. i simply wanted
him
gone, so i said he could go on next and get a hour 1 hr 15 set, just as
all
the dj's got. i'm sorry i wasnt going to treat him better than any of
the
dj's. I'm sorry thats just me. well i do want to make it clear, it
wasnt Kid
bippy yelling at me, it was his represanative. Greg = Kid Bippy, well
greg
was being very nice and understanding, but he also said nothing to me
about
Mikey's actions. I hope Mikey as well as Greg had a blast at *Play
Nice*,
just as I wish everyone did. But for me that was a bit of drama that I
didnt
need to handle at that time. but hey. its "all good." i guess. 
(9) I can't thank the Dj's enough for making the trip to Monterey. I
hope it
was worth the drive. i know you made my night.
(10) I can't believe I almost forgot to thank Marcos. thank you for the
lights you made the night beautiful. i hope to work with  you again.

Well I hope all you kids had fun, it was great to see you guys there/
love~jeremy
~Remember to *Play Nice*~

big part in the overall vibe of a party. even if you don't know what's
going on behind the scenes, it does reflect on the vibe of a party.
anyhow apparently I heard from several people that kid bippy can't beat
match for shit, and his 'lil manager mikey (the guy who throws planet
crock), is a 'lil asshole threatening people, and acting like a complete
and total bitch. "waaah waah waah, my kid bippy is going to play at 1am
whether you fucking like it or not! I don't care if you had problems,
he's playing at 1" that drunken fool. some people just don't get it...

I would try to avoid Tweekin on haight also...
A while ago, they insisted that I pay $10 for two Bottom Heavy records.  I
told them that Bottom Heavy is an LA label and the records should be $6
like all their other domestics.  
Then crazy evil white lady started yelling at me.

(Here's the part where I was stupid) I bought them anyway.
On one hand, I was dumb.  On the other hand, why the hell do you have to
be shady to your customers, even if in a particular instance you can get
away with it? Please never shop there.

Anyone involved with music (record store owners/employees, DJ's,
partygoers, whoever) _should_ be in it for the love of music, no?
To me, this extends to respecting others also loving that music.

-steve
(Zebra, Drop Beat, Trance & Jungle... -- almost anywhere, actually -- are
all MUCH less shady than Tweekin, those low motherfuckers.  I've never had
problems with Daddy's, and at least you finally got your cash back, but
shit, just goes to show people will get away with whatever the hell you
let them get away with.  It saddens me.)

  I would say definately NOT to take them to Cyberfest! Now I can't
say I've gone to one and "oh this happened and I had horrible time..etc.."
but I have been to a few Massives(i.e.this and last year's Freedom) and if
it had been my very first rave I don't think that I would of walked away
with a clear and positive concept of what a 'rave' actually was. I don't
feel safe at the maasives and probaly never will. It's always a vibe
killer for me when I walk into the party and there is this huge line of
people ready to sell you the drug of your choice.
  I would look on the calendar and see if there are any *small* parties
going on. It seems best to introduce a newbie to raving at one of
the smaller ones. This gives them a chance to get used to things at their
pace and not be bombarded by what's going around them..Ya know there is
the
Sunset boat party going on this Sunday=)..If you don't think that is their
thing..maybe push their 1st rave experience back a week...Whatever you
guys decide to do;I hope you have great time!....Still, I'm sure others on
the list will share my view about Cyberfest....
                                  -Reagan

p.s.- If I see anything interesting on the list;I'll e-mail it to ya!

The moral of the story is "pay attention while they ring you up and make
sure you don't get ripped". It really doesn't matter which store it is...
If it were my store I would have a hard time taking someone's word that
they were charged for a record they didn't receive or something... I guess
if you were overcharged for a single record and brought the whole stack
back with the reciept, that might be a bit different. It's pretty tough to
take your word that you got overcharged or charged incorrectly once you
walk out the door... Make sure the stuff is straight b4 you leave.

I ask for some type of discount whenever purchasing a "stack" of records.

Peace,
 m

Hello SFRaves,

A few weeks back there was some talk about a website with pictures of 
SFRaves folks.  Weeell, Byroni and I think that it is a good idea so we 
are trying to make it happens.  Byroni will setup the website so to 
anyone out there who is interested in knowing who's who visually, pls 
help contribute and send to him a digital image of your splendid self, 
and also don't forget to mention something, anything about yourself too.  
And for those of you who don't have a picture in computer form (or 
whatever you call it), I will be happy to scan in a photo for you and 
forward it to Byroni.  My address is: 3014 Crater Lane, San Jose, CA 
95132.

Here is my experience of Play Nice.  Hitched a ride from Justin and 
Garvin so figured I "Play Nice" in return and helped out with the gas. 
Oh, earlier in the evening went to Amber's house for the pre-party, 
"Play Nice" and brought some fruits and muffins.  In Monterey, had a 
Nice walk to the crater of paradise, calmly waited, and then...  uh.. 
sorry guys, I couldn't find words to describe it but just imagine that 
you danced, hugged, and smiled all night under the stars, in the cool 
misty air, and sands under your feet.  And imagine morning came with 
warm sun rising from east and blue ocean from west...  Well this will be 
my last rave review because I just can't seem to describe how much 
aliveness I feel raving in general.  That's a tribute to all of you.  

vibe'aciously,
Hai
(HI Justin, Garvin, Rolan, George, AndyW, Hope, Beth, Rebecca, ...)

Yes, observation has its rewards, SOME djs are way entertaining to watch.
But it's just a part of a process for those of us who want dancing.

My strategy is to seek the optimal spot on the dance floor vibe-wise (facing
the dj) (placeholding)(resting).  Then...when the beat becomes fully
compelling, turn away from the dj to find others who dig this same groove
and busta move with them. 

I learned this at Raving 101 as standard operating procedure.

Raving on as usual,  

Rhoda

High SF ravers...

Earlier today, Randy Cohn posted an apology to the sfraves community for 
his behavior a couple of weeks ago. For whatever reason, he specifically 
kept me oput of this apology.

In response to this, I wrote Randy a personal message asking why he held 
so much anger towards me. (ie: the name calling like...dipshit, fucking 
asshole, idiots, rich kid, etc...)

Even after being called all of these names, and being threatened, I was 
still interested in trying to work this out. I called Randy at his 
home...and he hung up on me shortly after finding out who was on the 
other line.

I don't really feel that a point by point response to Randy's 
anger-driven letter is necessary. It is enough to say that he has no idea 
who I am, where I have come from, or what I do. Yet, he still feels that 
these attacks are relevant and reality based.

I am posting this to SFRAVES for 2 rerasons. 1, because Randy attacked me 
so viciously for whatever reason. 2, because he is threatening me, and 
that behavior shouldn't be tolerated by any community based on PLUR.
Additionally, it should be noted that my entire involvement in this 
free party that Randy remembers so vividly from 4 years ago was renting a 
sound system from Santa Cruz Sound, and returning it the next day.

PEACE>>>
ES

Precedence: bulk

At 09:54 PM 9/22/97 -0700, you wrote:
>
>One of the claims that really disturbed me was the one that said the 
>launch vehicle had a horrible performance record and had detonated on the 
>launch pad in the past.  The main launch vehicle is the Titan 4B rocket.  
>The Titan 4B has only been used on one other mission and that was in 
>February of 1997 to deliver USAF payload and the vehicle performed 
>flawlessly.  
>The secondary rocket is the Centaur rocket which has been used with great 
>success on other satellite deployment missions.

This is, unfortunately, not true.  A Titan IV rocket blew up in California
in 1993, destroying a one billion dollar spy satalite, sending its debris
into the Pacific ocean.  NASA Chief Scientist Frances Cordova acknowledged
that the Titian IV does not have a 100% success rate (Space News, March 14,
1994).  

>In regards to radioactive elements of the Cassini unit:
>Certain electronic units on the craft cannot withstand the extreme cold 
>of space.  To this end, heaters have been installed to keep the units 
>functional.  These heaters are powered by radioactive isotopes.  While 
>on Earth (eg. from now until it gets into space) these parts of the unit 
>are being cooled by an extensive air-conditioning system.  Also, the 
>radioactive isotopes are housed in protective covers, etc. to prevent 
>leakage, contamination, etc.

Not just any radioactive isotope.  Plutonium. The most toxic subjstance
known to man.  One millionth of a gram is a carcinogenic dose.  One pound,
evenly distriuted around the earth, could kill everybody.  It is only
dangerous in particulate form, though.  

Thus, the biggest danger is the slingshot maneuver, in which the Cassini
will buzz the earth in August 1999 at 42,300 MPH, 312 miles above the
surface of the earth.  If it came in too close, it could burn up in the
atmoshpere. NASA's Environmental impact statement states that if this
happened, seven to eight BILLION PEOPLE "could receive 99 percent or more of
the radiation exposure".

Estimated deaths in such an event:  NASA estimates 2,300.  Course, they
might have a vested interest in lowballing.  Prof. Ernest Sternglass,
professor of radiological physics at U. Pittsburgh School of Medicine,
estimates a death toll of 30 to 40 million people.  

Keep in mind that the plutonium is there to generate a mere 745 Watts of
electricity to power instruments. That's it.  Solar power could handle this
requirement...
 
>
>One other claim that really got me was the one about the recent re-enrty 
>of a space station to Earth's atmosphere.  I really have no idea what 
>these folks were talking about here.  MIR is still orbiting, the 
>International Space Station (ISS) is not in orbit yet...  Could they have 
>been referring to Skylab which re-entered back in the late 70's?  In an 
>environment where 1992 is considered ancient history, I'd say 1979 
>couldn't really be touted as "recent".

I think they meant Russia's Mars96 space probe.  It fell over Chile and
Bolivia, breaking up over a 10,000 square mile area.  Not such a problem
under normal circumstances, except that it had a half-pound of plutonium in
it.  If it fell to the ground intact, there is a danger of nuclear
proliferation.  If it burned up in the atmosphere, there is an enormous
increase in the risk of cancer for those oiving in the area.  We don't know
what happened to the canisters containing the plutonium.  The biggest danger
indicator:  the US predicted it would fall on Australia.  Clinton called
Australia to warn them.  Our space tracking capabilities are not that good.
What might this mean for Cassini?

>
>As always, I encourage you to not take my word for it.  Go find out for 
>yourself.  As they used to say back in the Hippy Days, "Feed your head."
>

Consider the following article by Karl Grossman, professor of Journalism at
State University of New York.  :  http://www.caq.com/CAQ57.risk.html

Peace,
Kerry

Subject: NRR -- Dark Alliance Revisited (WoD, Crack, CIA, Media, Gary Webb)

------- Forwarded Message

Found at:
http://www.mediawatch.org/chicago/

Chicago Media Watch Newsletter August 1997
The Chicago Media Watch Interview
Gary Webb Speaks
Conducted by David Peterson

          Try calling Gary Webb these days at the
          San Jose Mercury News, and you're in for
          a surprise. After suffering close to a
          year's worth of ridicule from his
          mainstream colleagues for his three-part
          series "Dark Alliance: The Story Behind
          the Crack Explosion" (Aug. 18-20, 1996),
          Webb's paper in early June pulled him
          from the story he'd been investigating
          for two years, and transferred him to its
          bureau in Cupertino, California. There, a
          recorded voice answers your call with the
          greeting: "You have reached the San Jose
          Mercury News West Bureau editorial office
          and the home of the Community Focus
          Calendar, birth announcements and
          Lend-a-Hand Volunteer Column. No one is
          available to take your call right now."
          We wonder why Oliver North's career
          hasn't taken so ignominious a turn.

 That's because Webb's series broke one of the ten commandments of
 respectable journalism: he accumulated a ton of evidence from which
 he drew the reasonable if unflattering conclusion that the U.S.
 Government routinely engages in activities of a kind that it would
 condemn, were an enemy government to engage in them. In doing so,
 his series challenged the official history of U.S. interventions in
 Central America since the overthrow of the Nicaraguan dictator
 Anastasio Somoza by the Sandinista National Liberation Front in
 1979. Far more important, Webb's series offered an alternative
 history for some of the drug-related "blowback" from the
 U.S.-sponsored Contra war, a sponsorship that in Webb's words
 "opened the first pipeline between Colombia's cocaine cartels and
 the black neighborhoods of Los Angeles, a city now known as the
 'crack' capital of the world [and that] helped spark a crack
 explosion in urban America..." (San Jose Mercury News, Aug. 18,
 1996).

 We were able to catch up with Webb in June for an interview. He
 explained to us that his "union contract with the Mercury News
 gives the paper full control over [his] writing outside the paper,"
 and that since he believes the paper "will look for any excuse to
 fire [him,]" he is "not doing outside writing while at the paper."
 But, he graciously added, he "would be happy to answer some
 questions."

 (Note that when Webb uses the words "we" and "our," he's referring
 both to himself and to his colleague Georg Hodel, a Managua-based
 reporter who in Webb's own words "made a major contribution to this
 investigation, especially in regards to the Central American
 aspects of it.")

 CMW: Today, what do you believe were the most important findings of
 the investigation that culminated in your series, "Dark Alliance?"

 Gary Webb: The most important thing our research found was that the
 crack market in South Central L.A.-the nation's first and
 biggest-was begun and supplied for almost a decade by a drug ring
 connected to the Nicaraguan Contras, and that these traffickers
 were in direct contact with CIA agents before and after they
 started selling cocaine in L.A.

 CMW: Do you believe that your series had any serious flaws?

 Webb: There were no major flaws in the reporting or the writing. To
 my knowledge, there isn't a single significant factual error in the
 entire series, as Jerry Ceppos acknowledged last October in a memo
 to the staff. Some aspects of the story were not explained as fully
 as I would have liked, but that wasn't my choice. Because of space
 limitations imposed by my editors, what was in the paper was the
 most I was allowed to write. Still, what appeared was accurate. My
 editors deemed the stories detailed enough for their liking and
 found them fully substantiated-otherwise, they wouldn't have
 printed them in the first place.

 The biggest problem with the series, as I see it now, is that it
 wasn't long enough. We didn't provide enough background on the
 earlier investigations of Contra cocaine trafficking, the earlier
 efforts by other investigative reporters to expose this drug
 pipeline. Nor did we explain the CIA's history of involvement-both
 benign and malign-with drug traffickers. That would have helped the
 public understand that this seemingly bizarre relationship really
 wasn't so bizarre after all. As we have discovered since, the
 series didn't go far enough in the area of U.S. government
 knowledge of these traffickers and their activities. (See excerpts
 from Kerry subcommittee report, page 6.)

 CMW: On May 11, San Jose Mercury News executive editor Jerry Ceppos
 took the unprecedented step of publishing a column under his own
 byline that charged "Dark Alliance" with failing to meet the
 newspaper's "standards" of good journalism. Later on, Ceppos noted
 that "reporter Gary Webb, who wrote the series, disagrees with my
 conclusions." What, exactly, are your strongest objections to
 Ceppos' charges?

 Webb: My main objection to Ceppos' column is that even if you
 accept his complaints as valid, which I don't, they don't change
 the thrust of what I wrote. In fact, if you read his column
 carefully, he acknowledges that the story was right and that there
 was solid evidence to support the main finding: that the Contras
 were selling dope to the gangs. He cites no factual errors. No one
 was misquoted. Nothing was invented, plagiarized, fabricated or
 misinterpreted. The documents we cited exist, and we posted them on
 the Internet so everyone could see them and judge the context for
 themselves.

 What he ends up objecting to are mostly "suggestions" and
 "inferences," omissions and some unspecified "imprecise language."
 When one is reduced to criticizing a story for what people might
 have inferred from it-rather than for what it actually stated-it's
 a good indication of the level of desperation involved.

 CMW: In his May 11 column, Ceppos detailed a number of specific
 charges as to why he thought your "series was less clear-cut than
 the way it was presented."

 First, Ceppos complained that the series failed to note the fact
 that the Nicaraguan expatriate Danilo Blandon had testified in the
 trial of "Freeway" Ricky Ross that in 1982, he, Blandon, stopped
 sending cocaine profits to the Contras.

 Webb: The charge is not only insignificant; the allegedly
 "important evidence" that was cut out is almost certainly false.
 Yes, Blandon testified under oath that he stopped selling cocaine
 for the Contras in 1982. He also testified under oath-at the same
 trialhe stopped selling the cocaine in 1983. Two years earlier he'd
 told a federal grand jury, again under oath, that he stopped in
 1983. The day before the trial, the U.S. Attorney who put Blandon
 on the witness stand said in court that he stopped in 1984.

 The Drug Enforcement Administration, the FBI, the L.A. County
 Sheriff's Office and the Bell Police Department all had information
 from participants in the drug operation that Blandon was selling
 coke for the Contras as late as August 1986. More importantly,
 Blandon told the Senate Intelligence Committee that he gave drug
 money to Contra commander Eden Pastora in 1985, along with a couple
 pickup trucks and the key to his house in San Jose, Costa Rica.
 Blandon's 1983 claim was reported in the original text of the
 series, as well as some of the contradictory evidence. Those
 paragraphs were cut to save space, as Ceppos acknowledges. To me it
 is quite telling that the prime example of "important evidence"
 that wasn't in the series was a falsehood that was cut by my
 editors.

 CMW: Ceppos' second charge is that the series failed to stress that
 its numbers for the "millions in profits" that it reported were
 sent to the Contras were at best estimates, not hard data.

 Webb: Guilty as charged. We should have made it clearer what the
 "millions" language was based upon. I myself thought it was fairly
 obvious that the number was an estimate, since there was no
 specific figure attached to it. But maybe that's just me. I also
 think this is a sin newspapers commit every day, in far more
 callous fashion. How many times have you read a story reporting "$X
 million worth of drugs seized"? And how many times have those
 stories disclosed that the number, an extrapolation based on an
 unknown formula, was plucked from a police press release and no
 independent attempt was made to verify its accuracy before passing
 it along to readers as a fact? I'll answer that: Never. My
 estimate, on the other hand, was based on court testimony, court
 records, and interviews with cocaine dealers.

 CMW: Ceppos states that "Another clear implication of our series
 was that the Blandon-Ross drug connection played the critical role
 in the crack explosion in urban America"-an implication that Ceppos
 now calls an "oversimplification."

 Webb: Baloney. The series never said this drug ring played "the
 critical role" in the nationwide crack epidemic. The reason is that
 there never was a "nationwide" crack "epidemic," as those terms are
 generally understood. It was an invention of the media. Widespread
 crack use began in L.A. in 1982-83, in Miami in 1984, and in much
 of the rest of the country between 1986 to 1989. When the national
 media finally woke up to the story in the spring and summer of
 1986, crack markets were popping up all over the place.

 But since neither the press, the Congress nor the DEA could admit
 that they'd been snoozing for four years, crack was declared to be
 a sudden tidal wave that had come out of nowhere and spread
 instantaneously from coast-to-coast-appearing like Athena,
 full-grown from the brow of Zeus. The fact that supposedly
 knowledgeable people still believe this nonsense is not surprising;
 the Washington Post trotted out this scenario to "prove" that one
 drug ring couldn't have had the impact that we, allegedly, had
 attributed to it.

 What I wrote was that this Contra drug ring played a critical role
 in the spread of crack from South Central L.A. to other black
 neighborhoods nationwide, since the dope was being sold mainly to
 the L.A. gangs. As far as Ceppos' "oversimplification" charge goes,
 if you want to find the root of a crack market, you find the
 market's source of cocaine powder. If there's no powder, there's no
 crack. Simple as that.

 CMW: Finally, to quote Ceppos' exact words: "Finally, though we
 [i.e., the series] never said the CIA knew of, or was involved in,
 this Contra funding effort, we strongly implied CIA knowledge....I
 feel that we did not have proof that top CIA officials knew of the
 relationship."

 Webb: This is an admission to something that has never been denied,
 at least not by me. The series did much more than "strongly imply"
 CIA knowledge of these traffickers and their activities. I quoted
 people, by name, who came right out and said it. We quoted from an
 FBI cable to that effect. We pointed out that a CIA agent gave
 these traffickers their fundraising orders and produced a picture
 of the head of the drug ring meeting with another CIA agent during
 the time these drugs were being sold. But the series never
 suggested "high level" CIA knowledge, as Ceppos disingenuously
 claims.

 CMW: You told the New York Times (May 13, 1997) that your newspaper
 "has been sitting on a series of follow-up stories," but has yet to
 publish them.

 Webb: Yeah. I was told directly by Ceppos that the paper would not
 print the follow ups, but would assign someone else to follow up on
 some angles. We'll see.

 CMW: University of Wisconsin professor Alfred McCoy always cautions
 that "it's important not to run down the track like the blind dog
 facing the hare of intentionality: Did the CIA know? Can we
 actually track it to Langley? That's a false issue," he contends.
 "The real issue is the consequences of these operations." Well,
 what were the real consequences?

 Webb: This drug ring certainly increased the flow of drugs to South
 Central Los Angeles, San Francisco, Portland, Seattle, San Jose,
 New Orleans, Oklahoma City, Houston and San Diego. And, as I wrote,
 the money the street gangs made from selling this ring's product
 allowed the gangs to expand and arm themselves with high-powered
 weapons. The consequences of that are mind-boggling.

 CMW: When your series began to receive national attention last
 September, CMW was struck by how vehemently the mainstream media
 turned against it, after a very brief honeymoon.

 Webb: Jesse Jackson said my series was dangerous because it
 challenged the moral authority of the government. Preserving the
 myths of the drug war-in which the media has played a central and
 often shameful role-was more important to most news outlets than
 preserving the myths of the Contra war, I think. Finally, this
 series caught the CIA right as it was struggling to justify its
 continued existence. And as we have seen, the CIA has many
 important defenders.

 CMW: What have the media's broadly negative reactions to the series
 taught you?

 Webb: The media, with few exceptions, show less and less interest
 in helping people understand their world all the time. Foreign news
 is almost non-existent in most daily papers. Stories keep getting
 shorter. Context and perspective disappear entirely so that it
 appears to most readers that events happen in a vacuum. But we sure
 get exhaustive coverage of sex scandals, celebrity crime and phony
 outrages like outing the fatcats who slept in the Lincoln bedroom.

 CMW: Has the flak that you've had to suffer because of your series
 turned you into a pariah among your colleagues?

 Webb: No. Not really. My friends are still friends. And I've never
 been much of a joiner. I belong to no journalism organizations,
 subscribe to no professional journals and, until this year, hadn't
 been to a journalism convention in a long time. Frankly, talking
 and reading about journalism never interested me half as much as
 doing it.

 CMW: Your predicament calls to mind the case of Raymond Bonner, who
 the New York Times yanked from Central America in the early 1980s
 because of the backlash that it was suffering over Bonner's reports
 on the El Mozote massacre in El Salvador, then a terror state that
 was heavily supported by the U.S. Government. Where has the
 backlash against your series left your work today?

 Webb: I think that's something that remains to be seen. History has
 a way of sorting out these little disputes.



 Gary Webb tells us that the writing of "Dark Alliance" would not
 have been possible without the investigations of his partner in
 Nicaragua, Georg Hodel, and Hodel's wife, attorney Carmen Maria.
 But, Webb reports, both Georg and Carmen have been receiving death
 threats fairly regularly since Jerry Ceppos' column first appeared
 in the Mercury News in mid-May. Supporters of the "Dark Alliance"
 investigation, as well as of freedom of speech around the world,
 are trying to scrape together enough money to get Georg and Carmen
 safely out of Nicaragua. A fund for this purpose has been
 established in Washington by Dick Gregory and Joe Madison. Proceeds
 will be used not only to protect Georg and Carmen, but to continue
 their investigation. For more information, write the C3 Research
 Fund at P.O. Box 14185, Washington, D.C. 20044.


Copyright 1997 Chicago Media Watch, an Illinois 501(c)3 nonprofit
organization.   CMW publishes a quarterly newsletter and regularly hosts
educational events on media issues.  For more information or to join our
mailing list, call 773-604-1910 or visit our Web site at
http://www.mediawatch.org/chicago .

------- End of Forwarded Message

At 11:34 PM 9/24/97 -0400, you wrote:
>is it just me or is the phrase "i love you" thrown around way too much in
>the scene?

lara, 

there are like 5 or 6 billion people on this planet.  that's a lot.
basically, if you could stop the world so people were not born and did not
die, it would take you between 161 and 193 years to meet everyone on the
planet if you met one person every second.

our scene is small; like real small.  i'd guess that there are maybe ten
thousand ravers in the bay area, but that's just my guess.  We are between
1 and 2 percent of a percent of a percent of the world's population--that
is, for every million people on this planet, there are one or two of us.

we are literally one in a million people on this planet,
so it's not so cheapening of what love is to love that kid next to you.
you may barely know him/her, but 'we all start off as strangers--it's where
we end up that counts'.

spread the love,

rj

     Hey everybody I was in a position a while back where I was 
desperatley looking for a place, I found one, renting from my two cool 
parents up in the beautiful 
Santa Cruz Mountains.  I know someone out there is looking for a place 
and I could really use some help with rent and just, well a darn good 
friend to talk to and party with.  
     It is very relaxing and peaceful up here.  I enjoy sitting out on 
my back deck staring at the stars and listenning to the giant redwoods 
talk to you (I'm not that weird, but it is that beautiful)  The commute 
isn't bad but anyone that would be interested should have a decent car 
for the drive (my '81 Honda works fine)  I'm a good, straight forward, 
caring, cancerian who works two jobs down in Santa Clara and Cupertino.  
We are about 8 miles from Santa Cruz, about 20 to San Jose (my family is 
very liberal (hippies :) It is a studio that is downstairs from my 
parent's place, two rooms, Around 700 square feet (great for wild orgies 
and blacklights) With functional kitchen and bathroom (for those hard 
times with Mr. digestive system) and we have an awesome view of the 
Majestic Mother Earth.
It would be easier if you were like me and was considered a male(it 
really is just as easy to put the toilet seat up as it is to put it 
down) Anyways, I hope I have convinced somebody out there who is 
reliable and has a good job....and way Bitchin'
Danny Picard
Pgr 408 353-7998
Hm 408-353-1739

motherfuckers' is unfair, but who am I to tell you what to think, right?

Unless one of the listed acts is your absolute, do-anything for, has never
played here and probably never will again favorites, I would avoid it,
especially for newbies. This will be more like a huge rock festival/concert
than rave. If that's what they want though, go for it if you can afford it.

sfraves calendar. (Though Carl Cox and Peshay are great - no one can perform
up to their best if there's no vibe - or worse - BAD VIBE)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Thu Sep 25 07:46:52 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) id HAA19154;
	Thu, 25 Sep 1997 07:46:52 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from send1.rocketmail.com (attach1.rocketmail.com [205.180.57.81])
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) with SMTP id HAA19085
	for <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>; Thu, 25 Sep 1997 07:46:43 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID: <19970925144514.6363.rocketmail@send1.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [204.94.209.1] by attach1; Thu, 25 Sep 1997 07:45:14 PDT
Date: Thu, 25 Sep 1997 07:45:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: Layne Loomis <lucke@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Re: =O
To: Derek J Fieldsoe <drek1@juno.com>, SFRaves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I'm not saying that you need to say "I Love You" to people that
you do not love but remember that what you say or do has effects
on people:


  He was in the first third grade class I taught at Saint Mary's
School in Morris, Minn.  All 34 of my students were dear to me, but
Mark Eklund was one in a million.  Very neat in appearance, but had
that happy-to-be-alive attitude that made even his occasional
mischieviousness delightful.
       Mark talked incessantly.  I had to remind him again and again
that talking without permission was not acceptable.  What impressed me
so much, though, was his sincere response every time I had to correct
him for misbehaving - "Thank you for correcting me,!"  I didn't know
what to make of it at first, but before long I became accustomed to
hearing it many times a day.
       One morning my patience was growing thin when Mark talked once
too often, and then I made a novice-teacher's mistake.  I looked at
him and said, "If you say one more word, I am going to tape your mouth
shut!" It wasn't ten seconds later when Chuck blurted out, "Mark is
talking again."  I hadn't asked any of the students to help me watch
Mark, but since I had stated the punishment in front of the class, I
had to act on it.
       I remember the scene as if it had occurred this morning.  I
walked to my desk, very deliberately opened my drawer and took out a
roll of masking tape.  Without saying a word, I proceeded to Mark's
desk, tore off two pieces of tape and made a big X with them over his
mouth.  I then returned to the front of the room.  As I glanced at
Mark to see how he was doing he winked at me.  That did it!  I started
laughing.  The class cheered as I walked back to Mark's desk, removed
the tape and shrugged my shoulders.  His first words
were, "Thank you for correcting me." At the end of the year I was
asked to teach junior-high math.  The years flew by, and before I knew
it Mark was in my classroom again.  He was more handsome than ever and
just as polite.  Since he had to listen carefully to my instructions
in the "new math," he did not talk as much in ninth grade as he had in
the third.
    One Friday, things just didn't feel right.  We had worked hard on a
new concept all week, and I sensed that the students were frowning,
frustrated with themselves - and edgy with one another.  I had to stop
this crankiness before it got out of hand.  So I asked them to list
the names of the other students in the room on two sheets of paper,
leaving a space between each name.  Then I told them to think of the
nicest thing they could say about each of their classmates and write
it down.
It took the remainder of the class period to finish the assignment,
and as the students left the room, each one handed me the papers. 
Charlie smiled. Mark said, "Thank you for teaching me.  Have a good
weekend." That Saturday, I wrote down the name of each student on a
separate sheet of paper, and I listed what everyone else had said
about that individual.On Monday I gave each student his or her list. 
Before long, the entire class was smiling.  "Really?"  I heard
whispered.  "I never knew that meant anything to anyone!" "I didn't
know others liked me so much!"
       No one ever mentioned those papers in class again.  I never
knew if they discussed them after class or with their parents, but it
didn't
matter. The exercise had accomplished its purpose.  The students were
happy with themselves and one another again.
        That group of students moved on.  Several years later, after I
returned from vacation, my parents met me at the airport.  As we were
driving home, Mother asked me the usual questions about the trip - the
weather, my experiences in general.  There was a light lull in the
conversation. Mother gave Dad a side-ways glance and simply says,
"Dad?"  My father cleared his throat as he usually did before
something important.  "The Eklunds called last night," he began. 
"Really?" I said.  "I haven't heard from them in years.  I wonder how
Mark is."
Dad responded quietly.  "Mark was killed in Vietnam," he said.  "The
funeral is tomorrow, and his parents would like it if you could
attend."
To this day I can still point to the exact spot on I-494 where Dad
told me about Mark.
       I had never seen a serviceman in a military coffin before.  Mark
looked so handsome, so mature.  All I could think at that moment was,
Mark, I would give all the masking tape in the world if only you would
talk to me. The church was packed with Mark's friends.  Chuck's sister
sang "The Battle Hymn of the Republic."  Why did it have to rain on
the day of the funeral?  It was difficult enough at the graveside. 
The pastor said the usual prayers, and the bugler played taps.  One by
one those who loved Mark took a last walk by the coffin and sprinkled
it with holy water. I was the last one to bless the coffin.  As I
stood there, one of the soldiers who had acted as pallbearer came up
to me.  "Were you Mark's math "teacher?" he asked.  I nodded as I
continued to stare at the coffin.  "Mark talked about you a lot," he
said. After the funeral, most of Mark's former classmates headed to
Chucks
farmhouse for lunch.  Mark's mother and father were there, obviously
waiting for me.  "We want to show you something," his father said,
taking a wallet out of his pocket.  "They found this on Mark when he
was killed.  We thought you might recognize it."Opening the billfold,
he carefully removed two worn pieces of notebook
paper that had obviously been taped, folded and refolded many times.  I
knew without looking that the papers were the ones on which I had
listed all the good things each of Mark's classmates had said about
him.  "Thank you so much for doing that" Mark's mother said.  "As you
can see, Mark treasured it."Mark's classmates started to gather around
us.  Charlie smiled rather sheepishly and said, "I still have my list.
 It's in the top drawer of my desk at home."  Chuck's wife said,
"Chuck asked me to put this in our wedding album."  "I have mine too,"
Marilyn said.  "It's in my diary."  Then Vicki, another classmate,
reached into her pocketbook, took out her wallet and showed her worn
and frazzled list to the group.  "I carry this with me at all times,"
Vicki said without batting an eyelash.  "I think we all saved our
lists."
    That's when I finally sat down and cried.  I cried for Mark and for
all his friends who would never see him again.
       THE END
        written by:  Helen P. Mrosia



        The purpose of this letter, is to encourage everyone to
compliment the people you love and care about.  We often tend to
forget the importance of showing our affections and love.  Sometimes
the smallest of things, could mean the most to another. I am asking
you,to express your love and caring by complimenting and being open
with communication.  The density of people in society, is so thick,
that we forget that life will end one day. And we don't know when that
one day will be.  So please, tell the people you love and care for,
that they are special and important. Tell them, before it is too late.
  ?o ` o?o,,,,o?o ` o?o ` o?o,,,,o?o ` o?oo?o ` o?o,,,,o?o ` o?


Layne

Posted at 8:55 a.m. PDT Thursday, September 25, 1997 


Here's the article straight outta SJ Mercury News:
_______________________________________
Navy halts plans for weekend `cyberfest' concert

ALAMEDA, Calif. (AP) -- A heavily promoted concert expected to draw
thousands to the nearly abandoned Alameda Naval Air Station this weekend
has been canceled by military officials.

``Cyberfest '97,'' was to run from 7 p.m. Saturday night until 8 a.m.
Sunday. But it was canned Wednesday by the Navy -- even though the
promoters, Cool World Productions, had received permits from the Alameda
Planning Commission and a license from a citizens' base reuse committee.

The Navy still owns the land, and rejected the license.

Sason Perry of Cool World Productions said he was stunned by the decision,
and said his company stands to lose about $250,000. An estimated 10,000
people were expected to attend the event.

``We've been working on this for the past six months and now, at the
eleventh hour, we're being told by the Navy that it can't go on,'' Perry
said. ``We weren't even dealing with the Navy.''

Perry said the concert was about halfway set up on Wednesday, with fences
erected, tents put up and other details finalized.

Navy spokesman Jeff Young said he believed the community around the base
``doesn't like loud music or any other kind of late night event that would
draw crowds late into the evening. We (canceled it) out of respect for
these people.''

Perry said he could not understand why the Navy felt compelled to get
involved in the concert.

``These (Cyberfest) concerts are very peaceful,'' he said. ``I haven't even
seen a fight at any of them in the past. It's just a very good,
multi-ethnic crowd.''


Glad I didn't buy presale!

nico@accesscom.com
http://www.accesscom.com/~nico

Navy Cancels Cyberfest Dance Party 

Catherine Bowman, Natasha Stovall, Chronicle Staff Writers

The Navy has pulled the plug on Cyberfest '97, an all-night rave that
was scheduled for this
weekend at the former Alameda Naval Air Station. 

The event had been approved by the city of Alameda Planning Commission,
but on Tuesday the
Navy said no. 

``The party is canceled,'' said Navy spokesman Jeff Young. ``It's not an
event the Navy wanted,
and it was not an event that many of the city officials wanted.'' 

The base, which closed in April, is being converted to civilian use.
Until it is completely out of the
Navy's hands, -- Young said, the Navy and the city must agree on any
events held there. 

``This is completely ridiculous, completely unconscionable,'' Cyberfest
producer Sason Parry said
yesterday from the naval base, where he said the event was ``40
percent'' set up. 

He would not give an exact figure but estimated that Cyberfest would
have sold out, which would
have resulted in an audience of 20,000 for the more than 40 disc jockeys
and musicians -- including
electronic dance superstars Aphex Twin and the Sneaker Pimps -- who were
scheduled to appear.
The show, which Parry dubbed a ``dance festival,'' was to run from 7
p.m. Saturday to 8 a.m.
Sunday and feature food, light shows and five dance floors. 

Parry said he had had a permit for Cyberfest '97 from the Planning
Commission since August 11,
when he attended a commission hearing at Alameda City Hall. In addition,
he said, he went before
the commissioners again on September 15 and they again gave their
blessing. According to Parry,
the permit he holds extends from last Saturday to October 4. The party
was to be held on a 30-acre
site on the west end of the base, and tickets were selling for $25.
Although the event has been
promoted since the beginning of August, Navy spokesman Young insisted
that the Navy could not
have acted any sooner than it did to reject the application. 

He said city officials had notified the promoter Tuesday that the event
was off, although portable
toilets and telephone lines were still being set up yesterday afternoon. 

``We can't deny a permit until we have it physically in front of us,''
Young said. ``Everybody was
surprised it got this far -- virtually no one expected this to be
approved by the city.'' 

Alameda Mayor Ralph Appezzato said he understood the Navy's decision.
Had the Navy not acted,
he probably would have called a special meeting of the City Council to
review the Planning
Commission's decision. 

Young said the rave was not an appropriate use for the site, noting that
people near the old base
have made it clear that they do not want a lot of noise, traffic or
all-night activities there. 

``The primary reason was the noise,'' Young said. ``The other is fears
of vandalism or possible
injury. Military bases are essentially an industrial area -- no matter
how good the security is, it can't
always prevent someone from wandering off into an area where they could
conceivably be injured.''
Young said the Navy, the city and Bay Area leaders received more than
200 angry calls after the
Navy allowed the Army to conduct late- night training exercises at the
base a few weeks ago. The
soldiers were practicing hostage rescues until 11:30 p.m. and made
plenty of noise in the process. 
Parry, who has been producing musical events for 12 years, said that he
believed he had the support
of the city and that he never had any indication that the Navy could
revoke his permits. ``For them to
say, at the 11th hour, that the event cannot go on is just wrong.
There's got to be some decency
here. It's discrimination against a youth culture that bureaucrats don't
understand.'' 

Parry said his company, Coolworld, stands to lose upward of $300,000 if
Cyberfest '97 is
canceled. 

He is looking into alternate venues but conceded that ``the possibility
is not very good.'' If the event
is canceled altogether, Parry said he believes that tickets can be
returned at their point of purchase. 

The Coolworld information line is (415) 979-4543. Sason said last night
that he would update the
tape to reflect the latest information.

	Look, you are the consumer. If you don't like the service or the
prices at a certain place, don't go there. If you got ripped off,
guess what: it's your fault. It's happened to me, and I guarantee you,
you'll do a lot more price-comparisons in the future. Vote with your
dollar, it's the american way. 

As for the Tweekin' problem, I've noticed a definate attitude there,
but who says everyone has to be a PLURry happy representative of the
scene. Every time I go in there I find at least one thing I've not
seen anywhere else. Now I usually only end up buying ONE thing there,
b/c they're pricey for SF, but still, it's all about being a consumer.

I think it's funny that if anyone isn't cool and laid back, people say
they're not in touch with the scene and are in it for the wrong
reason. However a lot of big dj's like Keoki, which half of this list
idolizes, are grade A assholes, but you don't hear people saying he's
in it for the wrong reasons... 

-Science

(Optical tonight. Reprazent, Sfraves!)

know the record and know its available in an other store for lesser
price. But that does not excuse any sales rep. to be rude.
I personally support TWEEKIN for house imports. Darren (owner) is always
most helpful when he's not
stuck over seas in England. If you have a problem with a rude employee
speak up and complain to him.
For fair priced domestics go to SOLID GROOVES.  Harry  and/or staff are
always there to help.
Sometimes if you know a little tune and are not shy to sing,  Harry might
be able to figure the title for 
you. They are also very good on ordering records for you. All in all keep
the scene alive and don't bash
especially if you could've avoided the problem in the 1st place.
RACHEL

perhaps you're not as bombarded by advertising as we are...

what's so scary about this?  duh, you answered your own question - having
to determine who the hell the father is in the first place...  the simple
fact that a product or service like this needs to be advertised is pathetic
- okay, since it's probably apparent how i feel about sex generally, i
guess i'm not one for most "traditional" family values, but i'm saying,
even if you're going to be at peace with your sexuality (no matter how
rampant it is, hehehe), the thing is, you can still be responsible about
whether or not you're going to have a child, etc. etc...

WHO'S THE FATHER!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!!?!?!?!?!

first of all, in the age of aids, it's scary enough if you're pregnant and
don't know whose it is...

second, having to resort to a dna test to determine the father of a child,
to me, is shitty.

that poor child.

you have a few different scenarios this could apply to, among others - the
first ones that came to MY mind were:

promiscious mother (again, i'm thinking AIDS & STDs here that can be
transmitted to a child)
pregnant woman claiming some rich fuck is the father so she can get money
(typical new york scam)
baby is product of rape or molestation and no one will own up to it
(unfortunately it's true, there are a lot of fathers out there fucking
their daughters and getting them pregnant - it's a sad truth)...

that's what i think is so scary, okay?  sometimes it seems like we're all
going to hell in a handbasket...

Ok kids check this out im flipping through the boob tube and I run
across people court. Im like yay I have not seen this show in years.
But know they have a website poll so you can vote for the plaintiff or
defendant a little more High Tec then it was in my younger day. So you
hear the cheesy music that they do before every case. and the title is
"the rave party that never happened" or something like that and I was
like cool let see what this guy has to say. This rave promoter walks
in young guy mid 20's with several witnesses. Then the defendant comes
in this greasy short guy middle aged balding guy. With what looks like
a lawyer but turns out to be his son. The Case gets under way. This
takes place in NYC just a FYI I was hoping they would say the name of
the party but they did not. To make a long story short. The party
promoter was very through on Dates, contracts, verbal and written
agreements. He even had a Tape recorded conversation with the
defendant. The defendant that had the space tried to Fuck him out of
his cash cause he did not open the doors for the party when it was
supposed to start. He tried to make up some excuse and keep the kids
$3,000 pretty cheap for a space that holds 3,000 people espically for
NYC. The rave promoter won cause he had contracts was very honest and
had witnesses. The moral to my stupid story is We can win cases in
court, contracts do mean something. When I have signed contracts in
the past I thought it was stupid but I learned a lesson in this case.
Hope you all did too. have witness's and have those contracts signed
and Justice will prevail.

Macadio

From: peter@niles.com (Customer Service)
Subject: the tank          <nrr>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I just got out of the tank.

For the first five years of the rave scene; I was living large:  scoring on
all the lollipop ladies, and making all kinds of loot by slanging bunk e.
It didn't matter to me what kind of e I was working...sometimes it was
crushed-up lightbulbs, other times it was any old tabs laying around the
house.

"Yeah man,"  I'd tell 'em,  "They're baby Tylenols."    And I wasn't even
kidding.

And then one day, Destiny dropped her cold hand on my shoulder.  My days of
hanging out at the doorway mumbling "X. I got bomb X, dood,"  were through.
I got busted, even though what I was slanging was bunk.

The party was over.

Judge Ricketts sent me Upstate for 8 years;  but before them deputies done
drug me away, my homeboy Slider, who was faithfully  by my side in court,
shouted to me,  "Don't let 'em turn you into a Mama, Boomerang!  Whatever
happens when you get to the Big House, make sure you tell 'em you're the
Papa!"

Slider's advice didn't really make no sense to me, partly on acount of
because I'm a little slow to begin with, and partly on account of because I
was drunk at the time.

Well, once I got Upstate  Slider's advice began to make sense.  My cellmate
was this huge old dude name Sticky Fingers Freddy, who was doing life for
murder.    Every day, Sticky Fingers just /stared/ at me.   Really creepy
like.

I tried keeping tough by making barbells out of some cinderblocks taped to
an old broomstick, but old Sticky Fingers Freddy was one of the meanest,
biggest mothers I've ever seen, and no weightlifting would make me as
strong as him.

Then one day, old Sticky Fingers says to me, he says, "You obviously don't
know how it works around here, do you, Boomerang?"

"Eeep."  said I, trembling in my britches.  "Well, I guess not, Mr. Fingers."

"In every cell,  there's a Mama, and there's a Papa.  Now, since you're new
around here, I'mma give you the option to choose.  Which one are you gonna
be, the Mama, or the Papa?"

"Gulp,"  said I, thinking quick to gain the upper hand.  "Well, sir,  I
guess I'll be the Papa."

"Allrighty then, Papa.   Why don't you come on over here, and suck Mama's
ding-a-ling."



3  0  0  |\/|  e  r  @  |\|  9

lara wrote:

>is it just me or is the phrase "i love you" thrown around way too much in

>the scene?

|||||| then ||||||

rj wrote:

>we are literally one in a million people on this planet,

>so it's not so cheapening of what love is to love that kid next to you.

>you may barely know him/her, but 'we all start off as strangers--it's where

>we end up that counts'.

****

The love you have for your Mother or Father, is different than the love you have for a best friend, lover, even a favorite beach or high mountain camping spot ("I love it  here").


As long as you have love to share, you might very well choose to love the kid next to you, maybe they need it...  What you have to decide is what love means to you, and how you choose to use the word... after all, love is an emotion, going beyond being just a phrase that you "throw around".  


Everybody needs love, everybody.


luv ya.

> "the rave party that never happened" or something like that and I was
> like cool let see what this guy has to say. This rave promoter walks
> in young guy mid 20's with several witnesses. Then the defendant comes
> in this greasy short guy middle aged balding guy. With what looks like
> a lawyer but turns out to be his son. The Case gets under way. This
> takes place in NYC just a FYI I was hoping they would say the name of
> the party but they did not. To make a long story short. The party
> promoter was very through on Dates, contracts, verbal and written
> agreements. He even had a Tape recorded conversation with the
> defendant. The defendant that had the space tried to Fuck him out of
> his cash cause he did not open the doors for the party when it was
> supposed to start. He tried to make up some excuse and keep the kids
> $3,000 pretty cheap for a space that holds 3,000 people espically for
> NYC. The rave promoter won cause he had contracts was very honest and
> had witnesses. The moral to my stupid story is We can win cases in
> court, contracts do mean something. When I have signed contracts in
> the past I thought it was stupid but I learned a lesson in this case.

Though I'm sure there's more here than meets the eye, let's think twice
about this, folks ... here is a properly permitted event (I am assuming, I
don't know any of the people involved) ... with a large amount of planning
and production costs invested...  and at the last minute the Navy (who
apparently didn't have to approve legally in the first place, since the
permits had been issued without them) said, to paraphrase, "the neighbors
don't like loud music."  He said "we cancelled it out of respect for these
people" ...

This kind of last-minute slam might not happen to our underground parties,
because we avoid the process and risk the bust ... but larger parties in
this day and age need to follow the rules.... and here's one that (we have
to assume) did follow the rules, and this happens anyway.

Whether you like this kind of party or not, this kind of thing effects us
all.  Don't ever think that the Navy or the people who let this happen
(because we don't know who really is responsible for this) would do this to
Cool World and not to your party group.  Because they would, we're all the
same to them.

Last New Year's Eve, they shut down Cool World, they shut down Gateway and
they shut down Nomad.  It's all the same to them.... the violent response
at Cool World could have happened in the street outside the other parties
in my opinion, because I was there and felt the energy.  For crying out
loud, they even shut down 1015 Folsom that night.

This won't effect my weekend, cuz I wasn't going to this, but it may have
an effect in other ways in my life, and in yours too.  Just like the
yanking of the permit on the pier last year in SF felt like a turning point
in that city as far as venues were concerned.

Sucks.

Leslie

scene. After the apparent failures of parties like Big Top and Electric
Highway, I think its just a sign that the scene needs to keep diggin'. Just
because the music is being heard by more people than ever right now doesnt
mean that we're going to be allowed to have huge events anytime we'd like. We
need to re-think what's happening here in SF in regards to this because the
situation is dismal. What ever happened to the Right to Dance movement? It
seems as though after they had the party at the Fed I havent heard
anything...I have friends who were involved with that so dont take that as an
attack of any kind please.

I have a challenge ... for all you folks who so easily throw out the
phrase, "I Love You" to friends, acquaintances, etc. ....  try this.

Next time you're tempted to let those words roll so easily off your tongue,
try digging a little deeper, getting a little more real.

Say "One thing I really like (or, ok, love) about you is the way you
.................." and fill something that you actually admire or respect
or whatever about them....

I really appreciate a heartfelt compliment from people ... but I hear the
"I love you" stuff so often from people who hardly even know me, that it
becomes meaningless in that context.


Leslie

>I really appreciate a heartfelt compliment from people ... but I hear the

>"I love you" stuff so often from people who hardly even know me, that it

>becomes meaningless in that context.

****

Again, I think you are putting too much meaning in the usage of those three little words.  Love is an emotion, something you feel.  It goes beyond words.  There are so many other (better) ways to say "I love you", the words *are* almost boring.  I think they mean what people think they mean... whatever that may be from person to  person.  


At a party, it most probably means something like "Hey brother/sister raver, thanks for sharing my vibe."  Honestly, I don't use the words that often, I feel similar to you in that respect.  Although, in any context it still is sharing good feelings.  As long as that stays real, you can't go wrong.


If you put a damper on how people feel comfortable about expressing themselves, you may find people less likely to share shooga instead of salt. 


What do you do when someone says "I love you" at a rave?  Hopefully not shoot them down by verbally flaming them for using those words you hold so dear... that would be a bummer.  They are only trying to share thier good feelings, and feeling of brotherhood amongst friends and co-existers.  If saying "I love you" is the only way you feel right expressing your true love to someone, or the only way you can recieve it... dang, sorry, you're missing out.


Just saying "I love you" feels good.  If there is feeling or emotion behind it (which I would have to say is certain, under any condition), you are recieving someone's friendship, and oops... love... for however long.  It seems hard to believe anyone could be annoyed by someone sharing that.  I would agree hearing it can become old and repetative... but, hey, they are just trying to give what love they can.  


Your advice is sound, but harping on people for saying "I love you" is just not right, and it certainly isn't spreading any shooga.  Which we (as a people) are in desperately short supply.




--------------------------------------------------------------------------

**stay balanced, co-exist, and share peace.**

_____________________________________

--------------------------------------------------- SOL --------------

Precedence: bulk

Okay, okay, we've seen both sides of the fence... And here's the basic problem.

Greek has at least three words for love - English has only one.  This is a big
problem.

In Greek, "eros" means what we commonly assume love to mean -0 though it coverd
the gammut from lust to deep, overriding love for the physical.  "Agape" is the
kind of love that you feel for very close friends and acquaintances - it is a
chaste love,but can be very intense.  I don't rememebr the word for the third
type, but it is the kind of love one feels for family, parents or children, as
well as teachers, confidants, and one's home.

So both sides are right in this case - the phrase "I love you" is over-used,
but conversely people are putting too muh weight on it.  There's no very easy
way to remedy this without trying to force new words into usage in English,
unfortunately.

-Corey

Subject: Ravers/promoters/what the hell is going on (WAS CYBERFEST)
Date: Thu, 25 Sep 1997 14:27:05 -0700
X-Msmail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1161
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I think that the promoters have alot to do with it... but when it comes
down to it, the people have changed.

Many of us will agree that the scene today is completely different than the
scene of a few years ago due to the following facts:

1) There are a hell of a lot more rave-goers 
2) There is a hell of a lot more money to be made
3) The promoters opened up the scene to a hell of a lot more people by over
promoting which brought in another huge element of people (x% of which are
very cool and that we like to be around and y% that we can't stand)

Im glad of all of the new cool people which I, and other promoters, have
brought to this scene, and if I could go back in time to when I started
promoting I wouldn't do anything differently (i.e. not promoting so hard,
etc.) What has happened to this scene is inevitable. It happens to every
scene (the hippies, rock & roll, grunge, goth, etc.) Everything will
inevitably become commercial. (Even country music went commercial, and if
country can go commercial, anything can:)

Did the promoters do the wrong thing by opening up the scene... I don't
think so.

Did the promoters open up the scene for the wrong reasons... yup... money
is a corrupter of people. But this was inevitable. Wherever there is a
chance to make money, people are going to try to make money.

(and I wont even try to lie by saying that I haven't been tempted by the
cash either)

But I've said it before and I've said it again... those of us who feel the
vibe have got to keep on spreading the vibe.
----------

>That was why I put the sarcastic response.  I too think the same thing. 
>While I may love the personal raver friends that I've made, I have to be
>honest in saying that the person that I know absolutely nothing about
>dancing next to me cannot receive my love.  Maybe my respect for being at
>an awesome party or whatever but until I get to know who they are and
>respect them for who they are, I won't be sayin' "I love you" to anybody.
>
>dErEk
 

And when you do say it to that person you love, MEAN IT!  Be sure about it.
Don't be saying them words for the moment, and not mean it.  You'll end up
hurting someone that thought you were telling them the truth.  Lessons in
life!

Take care,


    S       i       p       h       o       n

http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Alley/7995
____I'm a schizophrenic......and so am I!  ;)____

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi sol (and cc-ing the list of course)...

Once again, I invite you to try to substitute real content for shortcuts
.... yes, love is an emotion, but no, i don't think i'm "putting too much
meaning in the usage of those three little words."

Just as I think we fall into lazy patterns in many social interactions (hi,
hug, how are you? quick shallow interchanges) ... I think we fall into lazy
patterns of expressing ourselves verbally.

If you're at a party, and you want to thank someone for sharing the vibe
with you, why not say "Sol, your energy is awesome and I want to thank you
for sharing this amazing vibe with me tonight."  Now, I don't know about
you, but I'd much rather hear something personal like that than "Dude, I
love you."  I mean, we didn't need a beer commercial to show us how silly
that can sound.

Do I "shoot people down by verbally flaming them at a party"?  Sheez, you
obviously don't know me.  I cherish the open loving nature of the people in
our community and I treat them and their emotions with complete respect.
But as one of the "elders" of this scene (yep, older than dirt), there are
things I've learned and feel a responsibility to share.

So, sometimes when someone says to me "Leslie, I love you" and I have the
feeling that they may not be quite conscious of the actual meaning and
importance of the words they say, I might look them in the eye and say
"Thank you.  What is it about me that makes you say that," coming from a
place of love and respect myself.

See, to me, operating from a place of love and allowing that conscious
awareness to permeate your daily life is the goal .. and just saying the
words without recognizing the true meaning underneath actually ends up
separating you from the very essence of love.

So, for those of you who I have said "I love you" to on this list... please
know that when I say it, I mean it.

Much love (which is a much more universal feeling and therefore different
from "I love you"),

Leslie


>>I really appreciate a heartfelt compliment from people ... but I hear the
>>"I love you" stuff so often from people who hardly even know me, that it
>>becomes meaningless in that context.
>****
>Again, I think you are putting too much meaning in the usage of those
>three little words.  Love is an emotion, something you feel.  It goes
>beyond words.  There are so many other (better) ways to say "I love you",
>the words *are* almost boring.  I think they mean what people think they
>mean... whatever that may be from person to  person.
>
>At a party, it most probably means something like "Hey brother/sister
>raver, thanks for sharing my vibe."  Honestly, I don't use the words that
>often, I feel similar to you in that respect.  Although, in any context it
>still is sharing good feelings.  As long as that stays real, you can't go
>wrong.
>
>If you put a damper on how people feel comfortable about expressing
>themselves, you may find people less likely to share shooga instead of
>salt.
>
>What do you do when someone says "I love you" at a rave?  Hopefully not
>shoot them down by verbally flaming them for using those words you hold so
>dear... that would be a bummer.  They are only trying to share thier good
>feelings, and feeling of brotherhood amongst friends and co-existers.  If
>saying "I love you" is the only way you feel right expressing your true
>love to someone, or the only way you can recieve it... dang, sorry, you're
>missing out.
>
>Just saying "I love you" feels good.  If there is feeling or emotion
>behind it (which I would have to say is certain, under any condition), you
>are recieving someone's friendship, and oops... love... for however long.
>It seems hard to believe anyone could be annoyed by someone sharing that.
>I would agree hearing it can become old and repetative... but, hey, they
>are just trying to give what love they can.
>
>Your advice is sound, but harping on people for saying "I love you" is
>just not right, and it certainly isn't spreading any shooga.  Which we (as
>a people) are in desperately short supply.
>
>
>
>--------------------------------------------------------------------------
>**stay balanced, co-exist, and share peace.**
>_____________________________________
>--------------------------------------------------- SOL --------------

In-Reply-To: <l03110704b0508be04b50@[38.248.198.94]> from "Leslie Ayres" at Sep 25, 97 04:25:50 pm

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
