Precedence: bulk

Sheesh - aren't we all getting a little serious here? Flaming
someone 'cos they say "I love you"?

One of the things I find so wonderful about this whole scene
is the refreshingly positive vibe that refuses to go away no
matter how cynical and weird things get on the list sometimes.
And I have to say it really picks me up when Randy or Stariana
or Jen or whoever just broadcasts a happy "Love you all!" message.
Jeez, I even SAVE messages like that for rainy days!

I don't need to dissect it and think "well I don't think I ever
even MET Jen, so who is she to say I love you?". Obviously it's
not that kind of love. To me it's love for the scene that we're
all a part of.

I'm not the kind of person to go up to strangers and say "I love
you" at a party, but I do feel a very powerful sense of love for
the scene and the people that are all a part of it. I think it's
this that people are trying to express.

I'll never forget taking a looong nap at a Lightseed party at Organic
earlier this year, and waking at about 4am and wandering downstairs
and just basking in the vibe - the music was totally going off and
people were dancing their little hearts out, and I was filled with
awe and, yes, love, of this whole scene and how people work their
behinds off, not for money but to give people a good time, and how
people come together and commune all night in dancing and sharing.
And you catch a stranger's eye and you smile and you can tell they
feel it too. Yes, I love this scene and the people that make it
happen. That's a different kind of love than you feel for an
individual, but no less valid.

It would be a sad thing if those people are now too scared to share 
that feeling, 'cos last time someone else did, they got flamed!
So let's not come down on people who feel that sense of love and
feel like they want to shout it out loud - hell, I do sometimes!

Love!

- Martin

Should be an interesting weekend, with some new wrinkles.  I might
head over to Density tonight, then the Arc party looks to be a little
adventurous, and the ResFest party should be a good show too.  The
CyberFest thing will be huge as usual, then the Folsom Street Fair
on Sunday (plus the Spundae) is always interesting...

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

Cybertribe,

On the topic of this "I love you" thread...

In New York City, we had sort of a similar problem in the rave scene. 
People were using the phrase, "You fucking asshole!" far too loosely and
often--even when what they really meant was "That wasn't very nice of you
to sell me bunk E," or "I don't appreciate you talking about me behind my
back," or "I think that's my backpack," or even "Excuse me, you just
stepped on my foot, and a minute ago your 'tickle me elmo' was hitting me
in the face as you were trying to do something that looked a lot like
dancing." 

So, after a lot of heated discussion on the topic, we solved the problem
by learning to reply, "Up yours, dickhead!"

Leslie wrote:
>with you, why not say "Sol, your energy is awesome and I want to thank you
>for sharing this amazing vibe with me tonight."  Now, I don't know about
>you, but I'd much rather hear something personal like that than "Dude, I
>love you."  I mean, we didn't need a beer commercial to show us how silly
>that can sound.
*****
I wholeheartedly agree. 

>Sheez, you obviously don't know me.  
*****
No, you're right, I don't.  Although, my point was to say "shooting
down..." would very obviously be the lame thing to do... and that we *all*
should be accepting in eachother's forms of communication.  From crude like
a stone tool, to the full meaningfulness of an emotion which holds the
fabric of life together. 

>So, sometimes when someone says to me "Leslie, I love you" and I have the...
>..."Thank you.  What is it about me that makes you say that," coming from a
*****
I think that's a pretty deep thinker for a raver who's  probably just
trying to keep from biting their binki in half while aligning the fur on
their teddy... although, I agree that they should perhaps put more thought
into their choice of words.  

I choose to interperate and use those words as you do Leslie.  "Just saying
"I love you" feels good."  The reason is those words evoke (or should
evoke) an emotion, as you very obviously well know.  I know the "what do
you do at a ..." question may not have seemed so, it was... in fact,
rhetorical.  I made an attempt at being all-encompassing with my last post.
 I certainly did not mean to infer you would actually be that harsh. My
statements were not meant to be directed at any one person, I simply felt
the posts were more or less flaming people for expressing themselves in a
positive, friendly way.  I don't see that as wrong, and find it hard to
swallow these people deserve "training" of any sort for their choice of
words.  They will learn in time.  Perhaps *we* should be more lienient
instead.  

and *that* makes *me* feel old.

peace through elbow grease.

-sol

 Well, I don't throw around the words "I Love You" carelessly, but I do say
them quite often.  It's just for me, there are different degrees of love.
 There's the love you have for your friends, your family, your BEST friend,
signifigant other, or someone you just met.  I personally love all ravers
because we share something special, and I'm so thankful to be a part of it
that I want to heap my happy feelings on everyone.  So when I say I love you,
I mean it... it just might not be as huge as you're making it out to be.

 Hey there,

:hey, a weird question: is ketamine made for horses or cats?

    Good question, Ketamine is used on both humans and animals. The use it
produce anesthesia.

Now for the technical stuff.

     Ketamine hydrochloride is a nonbarbiturate substance, that is used IV
and intramuscularly (a type of shot) to produce anesthesia. The patient
becomes cataleptic ( a trance like state) and may appear to be awake, but is
unaware of the environment and unresponsive to pain.

     This really only applies if you were to take the suggested amount which
would be more that most people would want to take for recreational purposes.
I read in one of those book you find in a head shop, that you can mix the
ketamine with, I think, baking powder, and then bake it do to just a powder
and snort it.

   I remember when I took my dog to the vet to get something done, and they
gave her that. I asked if I could get some also. MAN, did I get a weird
look.

To whinny or purr is up to you.

Feel free to direct all medical and drugs related questions to
terrapin@lords.com

Peace, Luv, & Hugs
Rebel D Monteer
terrapin@lords.com
http://www.psnw.com/~terrapin

At 07:39 PM 9/25/97 -0700, Messiah Wannabe wrote:
>
>hey, a wierd question: is ketamine made for horses or cats?  none of

ketamine is a general veterinary anaesthetic.  but it is also used as a
children's anaesthetic because you don't have to worry so much about the
tricky heartrate and breathing stuff that you do with opiates--hard to
calculate the morphine dosage for an 8-year-old.  a FOAF went in for some
surgery and asked for ketamine but was told that "they don't use it for
this procedure because it can give adults 'nightmares.'"

"nightmares."  or just a really deep k-hole?

tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

Just what exactly is a "twamp"??? Does that mean I'm an elderly twamp
because I remember them vividly??  =)

I remember the Gemco in Dublin -- I used to buy 8 track tapes and Atari
2600 games there!

how about these flashbacks:
-Kid Power shoes (mid 70's)
-Andre The Giant bodyslamming Big John Studd for $25,000 (back when WWF
was cool)
-Watching the evening news as they counted the days of the Iran hostage
crisis
-When Reagan got shot
-Tuesday nights on ABC--
	8:00 Happy Days
	8:30 Laverne & Shirley (hated it...)
	9:00 Three's Company 
	9:30 The Ropers (Stanley kicked ass...)
-Friday Night Fights on MTV back in '83 or '84 (they'd show two videos
and then people would call in to vote for their favorite... Def Leppard
was champ for like 8 million weeks straight...)
-Old school cable boxes where if you punched in certain numbers at the
same time, you could unscramble the channel (great when you're 14 and
your hormones are raging like crazy and you just found out that Playboy
came out with their own cable network...)
-The "ghost" in Three Men and a Baby
-Girls with poofy hair (Hair Bears) or that f*$%*ed up look where they
would make their bangs straight up
-Big Wheel
-Sit 'N Spin (don't they still make these?)
-The original version of the board game "Operation" where it would give
you a jolt of electricity if you messed up (how masochistic is that?)
-Atari 2600,5200,7800, Intellivision, Coleco Vision, Vectrex (anyone
remember Vectrex?  I STILL play with mine once in a while...)
-Mr. Potato head packaged with a pipe
-Rubik's Cube, Rubik's Snake, Rubik's Revenge
-Reggie candy bar (named after Reggie Jackson)
-Le Tigre' shirts (Remember their commercials? "Hold that tiger...")
-Gennerra HyperColor clothes
-Cavaricci pants
-Pac Man Fever (I have it on 12"...  why I'm admitting that, I don't
know.)
-When Milli Vanilli got busted
-Does anyone remeber Monchichis? (monchichi monchichi, oh so soft and
cuddly...)
-etc., etc.

Anyways, my 2 cents...

Subject: Massives, Amsterdam style
In-Reply-To: <41EB1EA0.1962@kaoinfo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSF.3.96.970926030035.17502B-100000@shell7.ba.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Ok, folks this is a LONG ass post, so...

This summer I was lucky enough to do a solo trek through Europe and during
my wayward travels, I ended up going to all manner of dance clubs,
discotheques, grungy bars, and raves.  Well, raves should be singular,
because I only went to one rave.  But, let me say, it was the biggest
party I've ever been to, as well as an intensive learning experience.
Here's a little review of the party from the eyes of a neophytic raver.

Set outside at  "recreatiegebied spaarnwoude", an outdoor park about the
the size of golden gate park, with lots of open hills and valleys.  There
were big stone sculptures throughout the park.  One of them, size and
appearance, looked like the Millenium Falcon had crashed into the hillside
and was sticking straight up, buried in the earth.  It was held during the
day from 10:00 - 23:00.  When it got dark they went crazy with the lasers
and lit up the stone sculptures with geometric designs and such.  I was
really impressed with the location.  Gorgeous.

Now as far as the music was concerned, also huge in scope.  I heard all
that dance music has to offer, and learned a lot in the process.
This was all taking place in 11 circus tents spread throughout the valley.
Themed after the Solar System, here's a breakdown of the areas; The Sun
(Main Stage/Global Grooves), Saturn (Detroit/Minimal Techno), Uranus
(Techno/Trance), Jupiter (Hard-house/Techno), Neptune(Happy Trance),
Mercury (Acid Trance), Mars (Goa Trance), Milky Way (Dub), Pluto
(Triphop/Chemical/DrumN'Bass), and Moon (Ambient).  Carl Cox, CJ Bolland,
Joey Beltram, Derrick May spun as well as a slew of local DJs.  

I stood out like a wrinkled pea in a sea of smooth peas, but it didn't
matter and everyone seemed to dig the fact that I was there having a good
time.  I was in heaven.  Beautiful blue eyes, rosy cheeks, blond hair.
I'm a sucker for scandinavian women.  Anyways, I spent most of my time in
Pluto and Uranus, but I visited each planet and people were going nuts.
They just let loose with SO much energy and abandon.  I didn't see any
circle dancing, because everyone was bouncing around and sharing the
experience.  Granted, they're not great dancers, but with that much
energy, who gives a fuck?  I guess what I'm saying is that there were no
inhibitions and I really fed off of that.  Sharing the vibe with 15,000
other people, it was too much for me, at times.  The party was also
incredibly well-organized as far as I could tell.  Schedules were posted
everywhere and ran pretty much on time.  They had pretty in-depth
booklets giving locations, schedules, and dj profiles.  Beverage coupons
were sold and could be redeemed for beer, water, soft drinks.  There were
vendors of party goods, corporate sponsors, what not.  It was all very
smooth and well run.  The one problem I had was that after the party, the
whole place was covered with empty water bottles and trash.  It was
everywhere.  

[what follows is a more personal account, which you can skip because the
above is a sufficient description of the party, but if your curious read
on! :)]


Now that you've got a general perspective about this party, I'm going to
relate from a more personal perspective.  The night before, I was in
Prague at a preparty where Afrika Bambaata was spinning some really funky
shit (that's another story).  At this point, I planned on staying in
Prague for another night, when while digging through my shit I see the
DanceValley flyer that I picked up in Amsterdam a week ago.  Made a quick
decision, consulted the train schedule, and was able to catch an early
morning to Amsterdam.  When I got into Am'dam at 8:00, I cruised over to
My Home hostel, where I stayed 2 weeks ago, (I highly recommend it)
chatted with Chris the manager and left my bags to get my "other gear".  I
bought a dose of Copelandia cubensis (magic mushrooms:) at Conscious
Dreams, and then I cruised over to a coffee shop got some of my favorite
stinky buds, Jack Herer and White Widow.  (God, this place is nirvana if
ever there was.)  All stocked up along with some E from the only place I
call home, San Francisco, I was ready to send myself off on a spiritual
journey of a lifetime.  There really is nothing like taking mind-enhancing
substances in foreign environs.

So, I hop onto a shuttle full of kick back easy going Dutch people, and
prepare myself.  I haven't gotten a ticket yet, $40.  So when I get there
I'm directed to the entry gate, where a large crowd is being funneled
through 4 gates of security guards taking tickets and frisking people.
It's hot and sunny, and after waiting 30 minutes sharing sweat with
strangers I'm told that I need to go back to the ticket booth and get a
ticket.  I'm feeling really stupid, especially because I'm going to have
to wade through a mass of people.  Shit. Well, one girl named Hanakah was
sympathetic to my woes, and it turned out to be the beginning of a new
friendship.   Anyways,  I play it cool and make it out.  End up going to
the guestlist entry booth and the security guard sneaks me in and takes my
admission fee.  Guess he had his little racket going on the side.  So I
make it in without getting frisked, but who gives a fuck since they're not
confiscating drugs, anyway?   Usually at our massives I'm a little worried
they'll find my pipe and stash.  Haha I love it. Amsterdam rules.

Well, on my way in I bump into Hanakah again and I tell her my little
story.  Then I'm off on my own again and am amazed as I walk into the
valley by the magnitude of this party.  First thing I do is hike up a hill
plant myself down, skin up a joint, and soak it all in.  Some English guys
cruise over and say hi, and while sharing joints I ask them about the DJ
lineups and what I should check out.  They tell me the skinny, and then
leave after getting pleasantly buzzed from Amsterdam's finest.  The
mushies in my bag are calling my name; I promptly chomp about 1.5 grams of
dry and distinctively tasting mind candy and wash it down with some
orangina.  Hehe, the Millenium Falcon took a nose dive into the other side
of the valley.  Well, I'm about ready to find a place to get a groove on,
so down the hill and through the valley I go.  I end up finding some happy
trance music and start bouncing around with the 100 or so other people.
At this time, it's about 1:00, and the tents are still waiting to fill up,
but people are having fun, and so am I.  Happy trance gets to be a little
to fast for my unwarm legs to handle so I cruise over to find something a
little less frantic.  I end up in the Dub tent, and chill for a little
bit.  Around this time, people are showing me their auras around their
faces and skin.  Everyone is glowing with so much happiness I can see
their energy emanating from their bodies.  Everything is resonating with
vibrancy, colors are alive and pulsing.  I want to be a part of that.  I'm
having an ok time, but still feeling a bit like an outsider,  I go off and
start wandering again.  I start thinking about the challenges of
readapting in new environments, and how rewarding it is.  I start thinking
about home, my buddies, my ex-girlfriend.  Thinking about Erin gets me
into a funk, so

My next stop is the Sun, main stage area, where I do a little dancing.  I
get the feeling that everyone is looking at me without really looking.  At
least they're polite about not staring, which is not the case in Spain.  I
feel out of place so I sit down by some sound mixers.   Along comes
Hanakah to save me.  We end up talking a little, and she gives me her
notebook to write in.  At this point, I guess everyone feels that it's ok
to stare now that I'm talking to Hanakah so I now I feel I'm on stage, but
I'm suffering from stage fright.  Hanakah takes off for a couple of
minutes to leave me to my musings.  Well, my writing abilities are gone,
so I end up taking a fistful of colored pencils and draw swirly lines over
the page.    Shit, is that all I can do?  When she comes back, she takes
me to another tent and introduces me to her group of friends, Leisha,
Michele, and Eduardo.  They take me into their family and we have a fun
dancing to jungle.  Their love and warmth cheer me up more than they know.
Now that I'm feeling positive, at this point, I decide that some E would
be nice to experience in this setting.  Well, once I start e'ing, I find
that zone called self, and then Hanakah for some reason starts hitting a
funk.  So I try my best to cheer her up, but she tells me its beyond that
and releases me to go explore and have fun with Eduardo.  Eduardo and I
hit the goa trance tent, and get lost in our mind space.  Well, it's
gotten dark, and the rest of the evening I'm cruising to different areas
dancing and having a good time. Occassionally, I stop and check to see how
Hanakah is doing and give her hugs.  Towards the end of the party, Carl
Cox starts spinning and the main stage valley is packed with people going
crazy.   I lose my new friends in the mass, and end up finding the
community of happy bouncing people.  I had such a great time.
Unfortunately, I don't get a chance to say goodbye to hanakah and her
friends, but the next morning I get a call at the hostel from her, even
though she didn't know where I was staying.  By some act of fate, the
first number she called on her hostel list ended up being the right one.
I thought that was pretty nifty.  So she ends up showing me around her
favorite parts of Amsterdam for the next day and a half, but that's
another story. 

Well, this turned out to be a huge post, but it's also going into my
journal, so I really couldn't skimp on details.  If you made it this far,
I hope you enjoyed the story, thanks for reading, and if you like I could
tell you stories about Ibiza, summer rave-island retreat for Europe. 
And one thing more, while I had an amazing experience at Dance Valley, it
doesn't top the love I felt at PlayNice, go figure.  :)  

WIth love,
george

Hi John-
Great idea-you can't complain if you haven't tried to do something about it.
The party at the pier last year that was cancelled was "Nation", by Spundae
productions.  They also had their New Years party at 1015 Folsom shut down
last year. (That's why I'm headed to London for this NYE-don't want to risk a
repeat performance this year). 
Let me preface this by saying I generally prefer smaller more intimate
underground events, but admit I usually manage to enjoy myself at massives as
well (as long as the music's good). Some of my best times have been at huge
commercial events - not here but overseas- Mayday, Love Parade, and Tribal
Gathering. You need commercial support to have as much talent,diversity and
depth as is encompased by those type of events. Enjoy each for what it is.
Both of those events involved top, well respected and influential
international talent, (Sasha, Laurent Garnier respectively -although it
would've been just as bad to shut down Joe no-name bedroom DJ). The city
officials don't realize they are cutting off their nose to spite their face.
SF comes across as a backwater disorganized throwback to the rest  of the
civilized world. By shutting down safe, permitted parties they are driving
all parties more underground (which is cool in most respets but usually less
safe) and extinguishing chances for increases in tourism and the influx of $$
associated with that (you'd think that's what the city would want-not
necessarily what I want though). In Europe and Japan there are entire travel
agencies based on rave travel. Berlin's techno festival "Love Parade" brings
over 1 million people to that city every year, making it the second biggest
tourist event. Why is American culture so reluctant to accept new things and
ideas?
I'm by no means saying that we should all of a sudden have huge commercial
events all the time, but I do believe there is a place for successful,
sanctioned, commercial type events. It won't kill the underground. They are
two different animals entirely. No one will force you to go to a commercial
event, so why wish it out of existence?
I know there is the tendency to reject anything that ends up being accepted
by the mainstream (i.e. if it becomes popular I can't like it anymore)...but
that indicates that the driving force of your involvement in "rave" or
whatever you call it is rebellion and desire to be different. That's OK but
shouldn't it come down to the music? At the end of the day it's the same song
whether it is being played by Carlos at a Full Moon party or by that guy on
LIVE 105 Sat night at midnight. It moves you or it doesn't.
True eventually it might end up getting watered down but then you just have
to sift through the junk a little more to find the gems.
The above is all IMHO of course - thanks - jd

down. See ya there! jd

It appears Cyberfest is still on, but I wanted to address the "apparant
failures" of Big Top, etc. I assume you meant financial failure or sheer
turnout failure. I didn't go to the Electric Hwy so this just refers to Big
Top. 

Its true there were about half as many people as expected and no matter how
many people turn up that limitless expanse of space located in Oakland at
85th and whatever street will always LOOK empty.

Even though there was nothing resembling a vibe and no continuity or flow due
to scheduling band, DJ, DJ, band, DJ etc and jungle, techno, d n b, trance,
techno..start stop start stop start...and splitting the line-up fairly evenly
in two rooms so you constantly ran back and forth and worried about missing x
y or z (you get the picture)....seeing Derrick May and Juan Atkins on 4 decks
side by side was one of the high points of my musical experiences.Not so
little a slice of history there, only magnified by the presence of Kevin
Saunderson, Joey Beltram and Grooverider. A virtual Hall of Fame that
musically speaking could only be considered a success. (IMHO)  jd

Dori (luvnlyfe@freshmilk.com):

>this i just can't understand...
>
>maybe he can mix, but my days of old-skool new york club scene are over...
>
>with that went keoki, as far as i'm concerned, along with all my vinyl
>clothing...
>
>not that i was heavily involved in it anyway - it was on its way out the
>door when i moved here - i never understood the keoki fascination, but then
>again, maybe it was all the bridge&tunnel cheeseballs that seemed to like
>him...
>
>not to mention his ego is the size of fucking montana.
                                       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
                                       (that was my favorite episode of 
The Real World).

>ain't into that...  keep it behind the tables...

I give Keoki credit for being a good marketer, for creating a personality 
that people can latch on to easily when they first discover techno 
music...Kinda like the Madonna of techno...The title and art of his CD 
makes that "I'm hyper-aware of my own image presentation" comparison with 
Madonna easy....Think back -- if you were 17 years old and just 
discovering techno, the rave scene, and LSD concurrently -- wouldn't 
Keoki's music appeal to you and wouldn't his personality attract you if 
nothing other than for the fact that he makes himself highly visible?

I think for a lot of people Keoki serves as a very large and ornate 
gateway to the infinitely larger worlds of club and rave culture, and 
IMHO that's not such a bad thing to be. Someone's gotta do it. 

I'm not even one of those people, I didn't pass through the Keoki Door to 
get into the Church of Rave (more like I was conceived and born within -- 
at least I like to think I was =), but I still go back and lsiten to 
older Keoki tapes and CDs once in awhile and even years later, though 
it's completely contribed now, I can still feel and understand that 
spaced-out-and-futuristic appeal he sprinkles through your glo-stick head.

Speaking of heads, his ego is much maligned in the media, but from my 
personal experiences I've found him approachable, pleasant, and a lot 
nicer than some groups of kids I see at parties week after week. I'm the 
only one I know who feels that way, though, for what it's worth. =) He's 
not angelic, he's not evil -- take him for what he is and move on past 
his doorway. 

It's the American in us that keeps us relatively intrested in Keoki -- 
he's charging down a path that dead rock stars pave and repave time and 
time again. With all the changes he's experienced in life, all the 
rumors, half-truths, and truths that shadow him, I think he deserves a 
little more peace (though he doesn't want it) than we give him as he 
steamrolls down that road.


Man, I can't believe I just wrote a page of text on Keoki. I must be 
pretty damn bored.

love and happy friday,
 





                                             andyhawks@usa.net

I read an interesting interview recently with Keoki (i think in Mixmag 
...?)

anyway, he is pretty much unashamed to admit that his full intentions 
have been, from the start, to become
the superstar of the scene, to manipulate himself, his image, and his 
lack of skills to appeal to the Idol-hungry masses.

His sheer honesty almost made it acceptable, in a twisted, pathetic, 
cool kind of way.   It's kind of inspiring, a rags-to-riches, American 
Dream sort of success...you can become anything you want if you present 
yourself the right way...
(in this case, an arrogant, polyester wearing, trainwrecking fashion 
model crackhead.)

Funny thing is, it worked.


-b))merang

Well I head on out to Justice League in SF around 9:30pm.  This new club
was pretty impressive with its decor.  Plenty of places to sit and nice art
work.  It took me about 40 minutes to find parking, but it was worth it.
While I was looking for parking I saw a scene shooting for "Party of Five"
on some corner.  The officer wasn't to happy with me sitting at the stop
sign rubber necking. ;)  He came up and said something like "This ain't
your private driveway".  Ok.  So I drove off.   

So I finally find a place to park, and I walk to the club.  Noel was on
when I got in there.  Good music, and a nice set. =)  It was nice to see
Thad, Alex(science), Lola, and Sho.  There were also some heads there like
Jason(spun), and Tony.  That was odd seeing them at a Drum & Bass thang.  I
saw a couple more folks whos names I forgot.

So I kicked it till Optical came on.  Or should I say falling a sleep on my
chair.  I was even doing the head banging thing, you know when you can't
keep your head up and you try as hard as you can, but it just looks like
you're banging your head to some metal! ;)  Ha_ha! 

Anyways, Optical came on and he had the dope tracks.  Can you say Dub
plates!  He had that place going.  The bass he was dropping was awesome,
but the club needs to invest in some subs, bass bins, something!  There
just wasn't enough to fill the room.  The ceiling was to high and the sound
was bouncing.  All well, over all the club was cool, and it has a lot of
potential.

I headed on out about 1:45am.  I dreaded the drive back to Santa Clara, but
I had a great time! =)  

Nothing like three hours of sleep and going to work...

Bu_bye!


    S       i       p       h       o       n

____I'm a schizophrenic......and so am I!  ;)____

Yeah. The Coolworld make up party was strange. The only think I liked
about it was Hardsequencer. It was too crowded to boogy. 

I say that we demolish the 89th street (the wharehouse need home base that
is being used for the large parties now). It's the worst venue... in my
opinion (and many others) it radiates a cold, dark, empty, vibe. There is
this vast emptiness in there. You have one big wharehouse and there are
only 3 music arenas. There should be a seperation in the main room that
could create two areas... and maybe add some black light in the middle of
that place... some couches, a chill room... it's just too dark and cold.
Anyone that ever trips in there would hate walking through there alone...
it sucks..... every party I've gone to there has giving me and my buddies
the same feeling. Unless you're into the dark techno stuff you'll probably
feel the same way. I wish I could have been there on Friday to see what it
was like....

Massives are great if they possess the right kinda of ravers to create the
vibe you want. You have to have twice as many Candy ravers in there to
make it extra happy... I wish you kids would come over to this space one
time and make it extra joyful..... receiving a fat hung from one of you
candy ravers while I'm walking through *the void* would make it much
nicer.. hehe. :)

Byroni

Hi there..

I am sittin' here at work kinda zoned... looking out into the buildings of
downtown Oakland... a thick blanket of gray clouds hover high above. The
sun is pushing the blanket away and the blue sky is starting to poke it's
way through....    and I'm thinking... "This Sunday is the Folsom street
thing, and it would be a great opportunity to meet a lot of you guys and
for us to hang out..."..  I know that Derek and I are going, plus some
none raver friends of mine...   and I was going to e-mail some of you and
ask ya.... so If you wanna do something and hookup.. lets definatley do
this... I'll get Rubilicious to go as well... we can all meet and place
faces to names....  and have some fun.... watch BT up on the roof... maybe
go up there too and chat with him.. maybe push him off and start our own
little thing.... (forgive me my brain is tired ... stressful week... and
my morbid sense of humor is shining through)...   

Sound cool?

Byroni... .. .

Dear kids at Sfraves

I'm sorry to say this will be my last post on sfraves for some time.
unfortunately at this time the scene seems to be hurting my home life
more than helping further myself. I love the Sf UG scene, but at this
moment i can only stay away. I hope everyone had a lot of fun at my
party, I threw it for you guys. Well anyways, at this time school is
number 1 priorty, number 2 priorty is to get out of the dog house I've
seem to put myself in at home. 
I don't know when the next party I will be at or the next time I'll
post to the list but until then "I'll miss you all."
Have a good day, a good week, and remember to do something for me
*Play Nice*.
love~jeremy

Dori (luvnlyfe@freshmilk.com):

>sorry, i don't HAVE a glo-stick head...  never did...

well: a) a spacey glo-stick head isn't necessarily a bad thing, I was 
jsut trying to articulate a state of mind, b) I wasn't refering to you 
and probably not anyone here on SFRaves -- the paragraph was referring to 
newcomers to party culture and that sense of awe and wonder when you 
first get into it -- that's what Keoki appeals to. sorry for not 
communicating more clearly on that one.

>um, i'm taking him for what he is - an egotistically idiot...  and his ego
>is apparent in more than just the media...  keoki was a common new york
>street occurrence you could deal with on a near daily basis, bumping into
>him at record stores, etc...  he was always accompanied by some spaced-out
>kheads in 16 inch platforms and expecting people to clear the floor for
>him...  (I'd clear the floor for him but i think he can do a pretty good
>job of that himself)...

i dunno i think there's a lot of attention-needing egoists in every town, 
in every club scene. do we as a culture really need to isolate Keoki for 
this when there's local groups of club kids who are just as obnoxious and 
attention-seeking, if not moreso? and what's worse, is they don't pull it 
off as well.

i mean, not to bring up the dreaded d word, but some people nurturely 
like drama, like creating it and rolling around in it, and i don't think 
it's necessarily o.k. to not like someone simply because they need drama 
and attention in their life -- especially if you can pull it off by 
"branding yourself" (not in the physical sense but in the marketing 
sense) with these qualities the way keoki does.

it's not somethign i want to surround myself with, it's not something i 
want anyone i surround ymself with to be surrounded with, but some people 
-- for whatever psychological fuck-up -- need that. i'm not going to feel 
ill-will for someone simply for that.

>you guys can HAVE the "new improved keoki" over there...
>we're not so forgiving over here...

why not? =)



>>Man, I can't believe I just wrote a page of text on Keoki. I must be
>>pretty damn bored.
>
>i'd agree...  i can't believe you did it either.  ;-)

i can't believe you replied.

i can't believe i replied to your reply.

didn't mean to upset you Dori -- which I think I did -- i'm sure neither 
of us really care that much either way about Keoki anyway. =)

have a good weekend. =)



                                             andyhawks@usa.net

Corey said...

>Well, this should date me - I remember when they were having the bicentennial
>celebrations (!!) and the live firewords down around the Statue of
>Liberty, and
>the comments about the battleship in harbor being able to shell my sleepy

>remission, and I think I'm cured. :)


I don't feel my age too often, but I sure did when I found myself telling
one of my friends about how amazing the fireworks were in Philadelphia on
July 4, 1976 during the bicentennial ...

my boyfriend (later husband) and I watched from the roof of our warehouse
in Old City, just 2 blocks away from two of the main spots they were
shooting them off at the waterfront and Independence Hall... and these
HUUUUGGGEEE crazy things would explode DIRECTLY over our heads as we laid
there on the roof....  BOOM and showers of color!!! amazing...  now THAT
was a party!

.... and he said, um, Leslie, you know I wasn't even *born* then!!

where's my cane?

;^)

you go up to someone to talk to them "JUST" to see if they have an ego or
whatever. You yourself actually give off a distrustful vibe...a vibe that
makes the other person feel like he is being interagated or something.  So
if you just go up to someone to "JUDGE" them, don't expect a bunch of
positive responce back.

don't know, haven't met him. Thats MY problem by the way. ... And the guy
might even unintentionally be distant with people just wanting to be his
friend. Because well, when you have so many people getting the wrong
impression of you, you become alittle distant like that.

But I bet he is not stuck-up or anything. Everyone just likes to assume
stuff in the scene still.

Thursday, September 25, 1997 =B7 Page C1        c1997 San Francisco Chron=
icle =

------------------------------------------------------------------------
     =

                               [Click Here.]
     =

Navy Cancels Cyberfest Dance Party
     =

     Catherine Bowman, Natasha Stovall, Chronicle Staff Writers
     =

          The Navy has pulled the plug on Cyberfest '97, an =

          all-night rave that was scheduled for this weekend at =

          the former Alameda Naval Air Station.
     =

          The event had been approved by the city of Alameda =

          Planning Commission, but on Tuesday the Navy said no.
     =

          ``The party is canceled,'' said Navy spokesman Jeff =

          Young. ``It's not an event the Navy wanted, and it was =

          not an event that many of the city officials wanted.''
     =

          The base, which closed in April, is being converted to =

          civilian use. Until it is completely out of the Navy's =

          hands, -- Young said, the Navy and the city must agree =

          on any events held there.
     =

          ``This is completely ridiculous, completely =

          unconscionable,'' Cyberfest producer Sason Parry said =

          yesterday from the naval base, where he said the event =

          was ``40 percent'' set up.
     =

          He would not give an exact figure but estimated that =

          Cyberfest would have sold out, which would have resulted =

          in an audience of 20,000 for the more than 40 disc =

          jockeys and musicians -- including electronic dance =

          superstars Aphex Twin and the Sneaker Pimps -- who were =

          scheduled to appear. The show, which Parry dubbed a =

          ``dance festival,'' was to run from 7 p.m. Saturday to 8 =

          a.m. Sunday and feature food, light shows and five dance =

          floors.
     =

          Parry said he had had a permit for Cyberfest '97 from =

          the Planning Commission since August 11, when he =

          attended a commission hearing at Alameda City Hall. In =

          addition, he said, he went before the commissioners =

          again on September 15 and they again gave their =

          blessing. According to Parry, the permit he holds =

          extends from last Saturday to October 4. The party was =

          to be held on a 30-acre site on the west end of the =

          base, and tickets were selling for $25. Although the =

          event has been promoted since the beginning of August, =

          Navy spokesman Young insisted that the Navy could not =

          have acted any sooner than it did to reject the =

          application.
     =

          He said city officials had notified the promoter Tuesday =

          that the event was off, although portable toilets and =

          telephone lines were still being set up yesterday =

          afternoon.
     =

          ``We can't deny a permit until we have it physically in =

          front of us,'' Young said. ``Everybody was surprised it =

          got this far -- virtually no one expected this to be =

          approved by the city.''
     =

          Alameda Mayor Ralph Appezzato said he understood the =

          Navy's decision. Had the Navy not acted, he probably =

          would have called a special meeting of the City Council =

          to review the Planning Commission's decision.
     =

          Young said the rave was not an appropriate use for the =

          site, noting that people near the old base have made it =

          clear that they do not want a lot of noise, traffic or =

          all-night activities there.
     =

          ``The primary reason was the noise,'' Young said. ``The =

          other is fears of vandalism or possible injury. Military =

          bases are essentially an industrial area -- no matter =

          how good the security is, it can't always prevent =

          someone from wandering off into an area where they could =

          conceivably be injured.'' Young said the Navy, the city =

          and Bay Area leaders received more than 200 angry calls =

          after the Navy allowed the Army to conduct late- night =

          training exercises at the base a few weeks ago. The =

          soldiers were practicing hostage rescues until 11:30 =

          p.m. and made plenty of noise in the process.
     =

          Parry, who has been producing musical events for 12 =

          years, said that he believed he had the support of the =

          city and that he never had any indication that the Navy =

          could revoke his permits. ``For them to say, at the 11th =

          hour, that the event cannot go on is just wrong. There's =

          got to be some decency here. It's discrimination against =

          a youth culture that bureaucrats don't understand.''
     =

          Parry said his company, Coolworld, stands to lose upward =

          of $300,000 if Cyberfest '97 is canceled.
     =

          He is looking into alternate venues but conceded that =

          ``the possibility is not very good.'' If the event is =

          canceled altogether, Parry said he believes that tickets =

          can be returned at their point of purchase.
     =

          The Coolworld information line is (415) 979-4543. Sason =

          said last night that he would update the tape to reflect =

          the latest information.
                       [previous] Prev   Next [articles]
                           article in this section
     =

te
     =

blkadder@value.net wrote:

> On Thu, 25 Sep 1997, Ray Vonie wrote:
>
> > Organized entertainment is always out to destroy independent promoters,
> > under any means possible.
>
> Geez Vlad Live 105 was advertising Cyberfest fer chrissakes. Don't you
> consider them part of the "Organized Entertainment" industry?

Yes you're right, they are VERY organized, on the corporate level, ... but
they are forced to be somewhat neutral and non biased on the listener level,
due to the fact that they are REGULATED by the FCC, and other regulatory
agencies.   Therefore their actions hold HIGH accountability.  They are not
the problem, they are not even entertainment... just glamorous marketing and
advertising medium, as all commercial radio is.  There is a bigger picture
going on here that is probably very hard for you and many others to grasp
because it is way our of many peoples scope of reason....

> I don't know if I should be happy or sad. I'm happy I suppose because
> people that had permits and had gone through the process aren't going to
> get them pulled at the 11th hour. I'm sad because I'm sure it will be
> yet another in a string of vibeless, fucked up money fests for Cool World.

Well, here again you are missing it entirely... CWP expected to loosing some
money at this event.... Even from the start, this event would have broken even
AT BEST.  You see, LIFE is about the CHALLENGE of doing something new that
no-one has done before, or else life is not worth living..... Money is just a
tool, that does not immortalize you as well as your achievements in life.
This event is a milestone, and not a cash cow....   It's real easy to jump to
conclusions, especially when you don't understand the big picture...   Lets se
how this one plays out before we prematurely judge something before it has
happened.

> Anyone want to take bets on how many people get hauled away in ambulances
> this year?

This is a real sad thing to say... relishing on peoples misfortune is a
cynical attitude toward life....  Lets HOPE that people party responsibly,
weather its at a rave, a concert, or in their own home...

Keep it Real

Vlad, aka Ray Vonie

Nah, dood.   Check out some of the old XLR8R letters-to-the-editor from 
a year or so ago..  there was a series of letters from fellow DJ's who 
took a whole bunch of crap from the boy.  Doing stuff like not getting 
off the decks to let the next guy on because he didn't "feel like 
it"...throwing hissy fits about get VIP treatments, etc.

Normally I might pass stuff off as hearsay, but there were a LOT of DJ's 
talking about personal experiences with him. Of course, that was a year 
or 2 ago when he was in his crack heyday...I have heard that he's 
mellowed out.  But he defnitely admits (by magazine interviews and album 
titles) that he's on an ego trip.  it's kind of cool (I guess) that he 
admits it, and doesn't appear ashamed by it.  I reckon a lot of people 
get turned on by that reckless, arrogant presence.  Kind of like Jim 
Morrison...larger than life, sexy, cocky, and proud of it.

alrighty.

> CoolWorldProd is large and organized.  They better be to be throwing

Unfortunately, in this world, there is always someone bigger, always beyond the
normal scope of thought there is something else going on... well this situation
is no different....

Conspiracies exist.  And there is a big conspiracy being played out here.   I
would love to someday write a book about this industry and all the MAJOR players
in it... but I would probably get killed before I finished it... so I'll just
leave it at that...  Entertainment is a world power factor....  And there are
Many well established organized entities out there wanting to keep it ALL to
themselves.  Independent promoters are a threat to there empire, regardless of
what the independent promoters are producing... weather its concerts, music,
shows, dances, raves, movies, plays, videos, or anything that could cut into the
"OVERALL long-term projected profit margin..."   The world is not a simple
place... keep it in mind...

Keep it real

Ray Vonie

Oh my Good God Damn.


First question.  Can anyone confirm or deny the allegations that last
night (the newly unstoppable JUSTICE LEAGUE on Divisadero and Hayes in SF)
was OPTICAL's first US performance?

Now...

Holy Mary.  That was some pretty incredible everything.  I was pleased to
finally see Grooverider a short while ago.  I was absolutely astoudned by
the things that Optical is doing.

I don't know if I'm out of the loop, but when I heard him throw down his
remix of To Shape the Future... I knew while jungle reigned righteousness.

How can I go over his set, when hardly any of the tracks had names yet?
Like I was saying last night, when someone writes a story about jungle
culture, there better be some DUBPLATE JACKERS in it.  They would have hit
Fort Know last night.  End of line.

I simply do not know what to think about the future of jungle, besides the
fact that no matter what people say, no matter if he makes tech
now...Optical will be smiling.  That dude is IN THE NO.

And finally, I have found a crew that with time and perseverence will
represent the Bay Area when the tin-pan sound make a comeback.  Enormous
and unfadeable props and thanks and respect to Billy Culture and SEN-C
MEDIA.  After so long, I've finally found you.  Mateo rock out, yall
Aragon badmen.  415!

PAX,
DUH,
MAX

PS:  If you have the chance, see Optical when he comes through.  by any
means necessary.  I really had a divine time last night.  Divine man in
the booth.  Divine gente in the floor.

hey everyone.

On Fri, 26 Sep 1997, Ray Vonie wrote:

> > Geez Vlad Live 105 was advertising Cyberfest fer chrissakes. Don't you
> > consider them part of the "Organized Entertainment" industry?
> 
> Yes you're right, they are VERY organized, on the corporate level, ... but
> they are forced to be somewhat neutral and non biased on the listener level,
> due to the fact that they are REGULATED by the FCC, and other regulatory
> agencies.   Therefore their actions hold HIGH accountability.  

When you say "neutral... on the listener level", are you talking about 
their programming? 

Because, while the FCC does regulate programming that 
may be considered indecent or obscene, or (theoretically) prohibits 
"calls to action" (for example, it's illegal for an on-air personality to 
say, "drink some miller, get a baseball bat, and take your  
modern-rock-attitude down to city hall"), the FCC is certainly not 
responsible for the neutrality (i.e., mediocrity) of live 105's programming.

The only people responsible for that are live 105's programming people, 
who have decided that the best (i.e., most profitable) way to run their 
radio station is to appeal to the lowest common denominator.

-radon

ps. what does live 105's neutrality or the fact that "their actions hold 
HIGH accountability" have to do with your argument about them not being a 
part of the organized entertainment industry? i don't mean to sound 
pedantic, but your post is confusing.

pps. if you get the time, I'd be interested to hear about the "bigger 
picture" going on.


 > They are not
> the problem, they are not even entertainment... just glamorous marketing and
> advertising medium, as all commercial radio is.  There is a bigger picture
> going on here that is probably very hard for you and many others to grasp
> because it is way our of many peoples scope of reason....
> 
> > I don't know if I should be happy or sad. I'm happy I suppose because
> > people that had permits and had gone through the process aren't going to
> > get them pulled at the 11th hour. I'm sad because I'm sure it will be
> > yet another in a string of vibeless, fucked up money fests for Cool World.
> 
> Well, here again you are missing it entirely... CWP expected to loosing some
> money at this event.... Even from the start, this event would have broken even
> AT BEST.  You see, LIFE is about the CHALLENGE of doing something new that
> no-one has done before, or else life is not worth living..... Money is just a
> tool, that does not immortalize you as well as your achievements in life.
> This event is a milestone, and not a cash cow....   It's real easy to jump to

yes we are the consumers.  Yes, even if some customers complain, most of
the stores can keep thier fucked-up business.  Yes we live in capitalism.
It's true that most of customers voice won't change anything, especially
this crazy system.  

But I do not want to accept this system without complaining.  I know it's
pretty silly, but I can't stand some sotre owners taking shit for granted.
It's like saying, "I know my vote won't change anything, so I won't vote."
As long as you are a customer, you have a right to complain, at least try
to make it better.

yuko

absolutely has the right to say "bite me, go somewhere else."

shop around, and had a misconception on the rarity of a piece of vinyl.

Two Keoki memories...

During a really crappy set at 1015 Folsom (bad mixing, bad music choices in
my opinion, no groove) ... some silly clubster bumped into the turntables,
and his response was to *actually stop the music* to glare at the
interloper, before starting the music again...

then (the same weekend i believe) he played a much better set at sunset,
with the added treat that he was in his socks because, if i recall
correctly, his platform shoes were impractical on the bumpy dirt surface.
either that, or he had blisters .... at least he was more real..

i have a friend who thinks keoki is the master ... and appreciates that he
is willing to be a drama queen no matter what people think...  however my
friend is also a drama queen, so ... peas in a pod, i guess!

Ok, ok...
 What about (6th grade for me) when Break Dancing was becoming popular.
Seemed like everybody in the whole elementary school that Christmas got a
BOOM-BOX.. It's like.. We all brought our boom-boxes to school thinking we
were cool.. The speakers came off of my boom-box. And the tape recorder
slided out making it a walkman.. Thoughs were the days.
 I remember back then. All I did was play with my friends. We all would go
to my house and watch my dads band practice. I got to experience first hand
at a young age, the negative effects drugs can have on a band.
 Can you believe it? I had the coolest jacket in the whole school six grade
year.. Yep.. I had a real leather red Michael Jackson jacket! We had cutout
pictures of Michael Jackson pasted up on every wall in our classroom. But
me and my friends were slightly cooler then the rest of the school, because
we also listened to Prince and hung out with 7th graders.
 It wasn't that long after, they finished building the New Park Mall in
Newark.

 My friends and I (Joel & Juan) choreographed a killer break dancing show
we put on the last day of school. PHAT. Better than thoughs doods dressed
in white at the ravEs.. Oh..   =]:

 But.. Who else on the list can say they cut class in preschool. Yep.. Me,
my brother and three other friends cut class at noon. Because we did NOT
want to take our nap! I guess you can say music has always been a part of
my life. In preschool we all dressed up, painted our faces to look like the
band KISS, and put on a lip syncing concert.

 Anyways. Just some memory sparks.
 Have good weekend people. Yes.


Jeff

Well, the fact of the matter is that there are people who really enjoy
massives.  They have a great time and they like the mass amount of people
and the energy that generates.  Along with the massive sound you get at big
events.  You see some folks get off on the fact that there are so many
people in one place under one roof.  

It took someone dear to me to learn this aspect of the massives.  I myself
don't go to many, but I do at times.

All I know is that its not for everyone, and none of us have the right to
put anyone down for choosing to go to a massive.  Some things are better
left unsaid, and I feel we all need to stop bagging on those who choose to
go to massives.  No ones better than the other if they choose to go to one
or not.  We're all equal.

Who are we to say that the vibe will be bad.  Are we actually trying to
ruin the good time they might have, all because we are to head strong about
massives that you don't want others to experience it.  People need to find
out for them selves if they enjoy them or not.  Lets leave it to the
individual.

Just my thoughts.  Everyone have a good weekend.

Bu_bye!

Siphon

true. I guess it's things like this that make it hard for me to beleive even the
most serious of hear say at times.

You know?
But I don't really know...
 I remember back when I used to play guitar for a thrash band. We had the
pleasure of playing a gig with a "glamour" band.. And thoughs people.. I go up to
the guitar player to introduce myself before the show. I hold out my hand and say
"what up" or something. The dood just says something like "don't even try to take
one of my guitar picks. if you only brought one with you thats your problem. I
don't let people borrow my picks" And the guy had lipstick on..
 Now that I think about this guy. Maybe Keoki is really stuck-up or something.
They do exist..
 I remember I went to go check this Keoki dood out at Nikita. A couple of people
came up to me and told me Keoki was "wacked".. And I was like thinking. Ok.. I
don't like any of his CD's either.. I just hang out here. Jeez..

don't even remember the last time!

Okay, so I'm horribly late!  Naughty me...
But my gratitude is still genuine.  Thank you so much to the turntable overlords...DJ
Shimmer, DJ Pillow and DJ Thorfio.  Without your talents I couldn't have irritated
the neighbors.  It was great to see some new faces, but I know that not everyone
who called came.  Everyone fit comfortably in my apartment.  I don't want to be so
lucky next time.  A big thank you to the gang who swung by on their way to the party.
 I was sorry you couldn't stay but it meant a lot that you came by. Everyone was
fantastic!!  I hope you have lots of good memories and lots of new jewelry.  Special
thanks to Hai and Mike who fed everyone, I had enough left over to get me through
half this week.  
See you all next time!!

Any resemblance to persons living or dead is purely coincidential.
>:) Amber

     Does anyone remember some movies that teachers would make you watch in 
     Elementary school???
     
     I remember 3 very well...
     
     * The Red Balloon! Where the little kid had the balloon and was chased 
     around by thugs, who destroyed the poor balloon's LIFE!!! English I 
     think??
     
     * The Donut Shop? Where a kid went to a donut shop, and some lady lost 
     her ring inside the batter, and there were trays and carts of 
     donuts... They destroyed many a donuts that day....
     
     * Charlotte's web! Charlotte had a very sexy voice!!! Bacon anyone? 
     blah.
     
     shit, i'm old... Oh yeah! HAPPY FRIDAY EVERYONE!!!
     
     Peace... <JCO>
 
 
 ______________________________ Reply Separator 
 _________________________________
 Subject: Re: Feeling old... NRR
 Author:  "Mr nStuff@work" <stuff@hooked.net> at Internet_mail
 Date:    9/26/97 4:08 PM
 
 
 Ok, ok...
 What about (6th grade for me) when Break Dancing was becoming popular.
 Seemed like everybody in the whole elementary school that Christmas got a 
 BOOM-BOX.. It's like.. We all brought our boom-boxes to school thinking we were 
 cool.. The speakers came off of my boom-box. And the tape recorder slided out 
 making it a walkman.. Thoughs were the days.
 I remember back then. All I did was play with my friends. We all would go
to my house and watch my dads band practice. I got to experience first hand 
at a young age, the negative effects drugs can have on a band.
 Can you believe it? I had the coolest jacket in the whole school six grade
year.. Yep.. I had a real leather red Michael Jackson jacket! We had cutout 
pictures of Michael Jackson pasted up on every wall in our classroom. But 
me and my friends were slightly cooler then the rest of the school, because 
we also listened to Prince and hung out with 7th graders.
 It wasn't that long after, they finished building the New Park Mall in
Newark.
     
 My friends and I (Joel & Juan) choreographed a killer break dancing show
we put on the last day of school. PHAT. Better than thoughs doods dressed 
in white at the ravEs.. Oh..   =]:
     
 But.. Who else on the list can say they cut class in preschool. Yep.. Me,
my brother and three other friends cut class at noon. Because we did NOT 
want to take our nap! I guess you can say music has always been a part of 
my life. In preschool we all dressed up, painted our faces to look like the 
band KISS, and put on a lip syncing concert.
     
 Anyways. Just some memory sparks.
 Have good weekend people. Yes.
     
     
Jeff
     
----------

 Ok, ok...
 What about (6th grade for me) when Break Dancing was becoming popular.
 Seemed like everybody in the whole elementary school that Christmas got a
 BOOM-BOX.. It's like.. We all brought our boom-boxes to school thinking we were
 cool.. The speakers came off of my boom-box. And the tape recorder slided out
 making it a walkman.. Thoughs were the days.
 I remember back then. All I did was play with my friends. We all would go
to my house and watch my dads band practice. I got to experience first hand
at a young age, the negative effects drugs can have on a band.
 Can you believe it? I had the coolest jacket in the whole school six grade
year.. Yep.. I had a real leather red Michael Jackson jacket! We had cutout
pictures of Michael Jackson pasted up on every wall in our classroom. But
me and my friends were slightly cooler then the rest of the school, because
we also listened to Prince and hung out with 7th graders.
 It wasn't that long after, they finished building the New Park Mall in
Newark.

 My friends and I (Joel & Juan) choreographed a killer break dancing show
we put on the last day of school. PHAT. Better than thoughs doods dressed
in white at the ravEs.. Oh..   =]:

 But.. Who else on the list can say they cut class in preschool. Yep.. Me,
my brother and three other friends cut class at noon. Because we did NOT
want to take our nap! I guess you can say music has always been a part of
my life. In preschool we all dressed up, painted our faces to look like the
band KISS, and put on a lip syncing concert.

 Anyways. Just some memory sparks.

<randomness>

speaking of that Jungle and Kung-Fu flick nexus,

what's the name of that Jungle track that has the english dub of 
some kung-fu movie where the guy says "my style is the best"

and for that matter, what's the name of the movie where this comes from.

PS: curiously enough, if any of you remember the Kevin Mitnick internet
hacker case from a few years back, Mitnick left a message on
whatsisface's the anti-hacker guy (who worked at the San Diego
Supercomputer Center) answering machine boasting about his hacking
style in a mock english accent saying the same "my style is the best"
line (tho he was talking about his hacking prowess, not his kung fu
prowess). Extra points for anybody that can point me to the URL of
Mitnick's phone threats that were on the internet a while back).

PPS: I'd have to agree w/ Max that the Jackie Chan Drunken Master
series of Kung Fu movies are probably the best, most interestingly
choreographed, and funniest kung-fu movies ever made. i accidentally
walked into the wrong move at the mill-valley film fest a few years
ago and found myself discovering/watching/laughing at one of the
Drunken Master films (v2, or v3??) even though I had originally 
planned to watch some serious art-wank flick instead.

</randomness>

"Independent" means the freedom to throw any kind of event you want.  CWP
may be huge but I don't know that they are connected to anything TOO
coporate.  (Mind you, I don't have extensive knowledge of them.  Please
correct me if I am wrong.)  The dance community should have the option of
attending a massive if they so desire.  Personally, I prefer smaller, more
underground parties/clubs but I respect that others may have different
preferences.  I agree with Vlad that it is sad that this party was
cancelled.  I had no plans of going but the manner in which it was
cnacelled seems shady and underhanded.  It is only a matter of time before
that underhandedness reaches into the underground, as well.
Megan

I have to agree about Sat Lifeforce. A lot of people I went with left early
or were complaining - I couldn't figure out why - the music went off and most
people there were friendly and seemed to be having a great time. The
promoters obviously had their heart in the right place. You could tell there
was a lot of effort put in - it was the best I'd seen that cavernous
werehouse ever look. Too bad more people weren't there to enjoy it. But I
sure had a blast with plenty of room to dance and plenty of air to breath. In
fact we closed out the 2nd room till 8AM!!
jd

Subject: Qualitative words(was Re: Church of Keoki ?)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

That is such a good point. I have to make a conscious effort (and need to
remember that I need to make that effort) not to ever use qualitative words
such as "good", "bad", "it sucked", "it was amazing" etc etc. If I do find
myself letting one slip (which is almost impossible not to) I rephrase by
adding first, "for me....." or "for my taste, others might disagree...." 
Yeah, this might seem obvious or rhetorical, but you don't realize how much
you could insult someone or hurt their feelings if they happen to love the
thing you just said was crap. They might not give a sht about your opinion
anyway, but it still is the considerate thing to realize, when it comes down
to it, that is all it is...your <opinion>.
Still frankly I can't fathom how someone can sit and listen/dance to certain
music, while I honestly don't believe they aren't moved by kick-ass techno
(of the detroit and acid variety). I think they are all in denial. But
diversity is what makes horse races (or some expression like that).
It all comes down to respect. If you want it, you've got to give it.
jd

On Sat, 27 Sep 1997, Megan Haggerty wrote:

> "Independent" means the freedom to throw any kind of event you want.  CWP
> may be huge but I don't know that they are connected to anything TOO
> coporate.  (Mind you, I don't have extensive knowledge of them.  Please
> correct me if I am wrong.)  

Hmmm. Does Live 105, which is owned by CBS count? That seems pretty
corporate. The connection that I see that makes them having more than an
advertiser/customer relationship was a little paradoy of "In the Navy"
that was played on the station a couple of days ago in which the
cancellation of Cyberfest was the subject. Seems odd to me that somebody
with a simple advertiser relationship to a client would go so far as to
produce such a thing. But that is admittedly purely conjecture on my part.
But nonetheless I still find it suspect.

> The dance community should have the option of
> attending a massive if they so desire.  Personally, I prefer smaller, more
> underground parties/clubs but I respect that others may have different
> preferences.  I agree with Vlad that it is sad that this party was
> cancelled.  

I'm not. Then again I have hear tales of near riots at the front gates at
past events, sketchy experiences with other attendees, as well as seen the
article in the paper last year about all the people(15 or so if memory
serves) found wandering the streets after their New Years party in a
drug-filled stupor. Wow, sounds like some place I want to go. Think of it
this way: perhaps by the cancellation of the event, some lives were
saved, literally. 

> I had no plans of going but the manner in which it was
> cnacelled seems shady and underhanded.  

Check out the front page of the Oakland Tribune. The people that are
culpable in this is the City of Oakland who didn't tell the promoter that 
he needed permission from the Navy as well as the city for use of the
site. 

> It is only a matter of time before
> that underhandedness reaches into the underground, as well.
> Megan

The reason why the underground is underground is because it bypasses a lot
of the bullshit. And for the most part, people will try to look out
for each other.


					Black Adder

From: Robert Pointer <rwpointer@citiscape.com>

Organization: CITISCAPE Media Design, LLC
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.01 (Macintosh; I; PPC)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Review: Cyberfest DJ's @ Sound Factory
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Welp,

It's 9:38 in the morn and I just got home. Still a little wired from the
whole night, so I thought I'd post a review...

Walked into Sound Factory about 2:30 a.m. to a packed house. Not having
been to a "proper" club in ages (besides 1015 for spundae's a few weeks
ago) I have to say that I was impressed. Tons of people dancing in the
main room and the DJ was spinning some high energy house. I think the
sound at Sound factory is the best I've heard in a club. Deep bass,
perfect midrange, crisp highs, w/o any distortion. It makes the music
100% better.
Anyway:

1) Doc Martin or Aphex Twin never showed.
2) The guy from Leftfield was there. DJ'd starting around 3:30 a.m. Very
sparse set, with few hooks to draw me in. Every now and then he would
drop some very tasty basslines and some vocal treats, but for the most
part, I liked the Sound Factory DJ's better that were on before him.
3) Italy's #1 DJ was there. His set got me going again. played great
Dance music 'cuz there were fat samples and groovy basslines.
4) SuperSonic played live. Imagine Crystal Method, but harder breakbeats
with nothing but old skool hip hop samples ( a la Run DMC, KRS-ONE, etc.
and a taste of Rodney O and Joe Cooley.) I'd give them a thumbs up.
5) Danced until 7:30 w/ this cool person named Judy. I met her 'cuz I
thought she might have been an SFRaver. I was wrong, oh well.

Until we meet,

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

Was up ya'll this is Seth.  I really wanted to thank everyone for coming 
out last night.  The music last night majorly went off. All of the djs 
spun spectacular soul shakin sets. Micron Macadio Trace Jelo my two main 
men James Christopher and Logik (aka Ornette) and every one else really 
went all out.

I think the majority of the had a really really good time.  The outdoor 
space was beautfull.  Tons of stars to watch.  I'd like to thank Amber 
for the permission to use this amazing site.  The vibe was terrific and 
everyone contributed to that.

Im sad to say that we did have a few problems.  We had some trouble with 
some traffic because somehow are party got posted on the hotline so a 
space ment for 200 people had to accomdate close to 400 at the peak of 
the evening.  It was a little dusty & dirty but we lived. 

Unfortunatly at the close of the evening we had a car accident so if we 
could all wish the best of luck to those involved. Luckily no one was 
injured to badly.  

I really want to thank everyone that volunteered there help when things 
were getting rough. you know who you are. Hugsnkisses to ya.
I really hope that everyone who came out had a good time and enjoy the 
music and the people. see ya soon

        love phathum

>That is such a good point. I have to make a conscious effort (and need to
>remember that I need to make that effort) not to ever use qualitative words
>such as "good", "bad", "it sucked", "it was amazing" etc etc. If I do find
>myself letting one slip (which is almost impossible not to) I rephrase by
>adding first, "for me....." or "for my taste, others might disagree...."
>Yeah, this might seem obvious or rhetorical, but you don't realize how much
>you could insult someone or hurt their feelings if they happen to love the
>thing you just said was crap. They might not give a sht about your opinion
>anyway, but it still is the considerate thing to realize, when it comes down
>to it, that is all it is...your <opinion>.

being non-judgemental is just soemthing to think about, maybe not to
perfectly live it al the time, cause even in some of the books i've read,
they say it's important to express feelings.  and if someone pisses you
off, let them know!  and if someone's music sucks, throw up on them!!!

oooh.  i have a feeling this keoki guy would have a lot of vomit on him the
way everyone's talking about this cd.  in fact, i was feeling a bit queasy
myself (and im not even a cancer) when it was being gruefully explained to
me.

>Still frankly I can't fathom how someone can sit and listen/dance to certain
>music, while I honestly don't believe they aren't moved by kick-ass techno
>(of the detroit and acid variety). I think they are all in denial. But
>diversity is what makes horse races (or some expression like that).
>It all comes down to respect. If you want it, you've got to give it.
>jd

yes, just like little 3 year old cassandra gave me a nickel this mornign,
and i felt compelled to give her a quarter.  see, whatever you give, you
get 5 times back!  ;]

>> correct me if I am wrong.)
>
>Hmmm. Does Live 105, which is owned by CBS count? That seems pretty
>corporate. The connection that I see that makes them having more than an
>advertiser/customer relationship was a little paradoy of "In the Navy"
>that was played on the station a couple of days ago in which the
>cancellation of Cyberfest was the subject. Seems odd to me that somebody
>with a simple advertiser relationship to a client would go so far as to
>produce such a thing. But that is admittedly purely conjecture on my part.
>But nonetheless I still find it suspect.

I don't listen to the radio, therefore had no idea of the connection
between the two.  I stand corrected.

>
>> The dance community should have the option of
>> attending a massive if they so desire.  Personally, I prefer smaller, more
>> underground parties/clubs but I respect that others may have different
>> preferences.  I agree with Vlad that it is sad that this party was
>> cancelled.
>
>I'm not. Then again I have hear tales of near riots at the front gates at
>past events, sketchy experiences with other attendees, as well as seen the
>article in the paper last year about all the people(15 or so if memory
>serves) found wandering the streets after their New Years party in a
>drug-filled stupor. Wow, sounds like some place I want to go. Think of it
>this way: perhaps by the cancellation of the event, some lives were
>saved, literally.

Can an event be held responsible for the actions of it's attendees?  I'm
torn on this issue, myself.  I beleive each individual is responsible for
his/her own actions.  But on the other hand, should an organization which
has repeated problems at its events continue to put on those events?  I am
not close enough to the situation on either side of the arguement to draw a
sound conclusion.
But I do see your point.

>
>> I had no plans of going but the manner in which it was
>> cnacelled seems shady and underhanded.
>
>Check out the front page of the Oakland Tribune. The people that are
>culpable in this is the City of Oakland who didn't tell the promoter that
>he needed permission from the Navy as well as the city for use of the
>site.

I found out about the cancellation in the SF Chronicle.  It sounded a
little fishy to me.  All parties were not informed of all necessary
details, thus the misunderstanding, leading to the cancellation.  I am not
so naieve as to think what I read in the papaer is the whole truth, but it
just doesn't seem right to me.

>
>> It is only a matter of time before
>> that underhandedness reaches into the underground, as well.
>> Megan
>
>The reason why the underground is underground is because it bypasses a lot
>of the bullshit. And for the most part, people will try to look out
>for each other.
>
>
>					Black Adder

But the underground is growing larger and larger, becoming less underground
all the time.  I still believe that the bullshit can potentially leak in.
People try to look out for one another but this is no gaurantee that there
will not be problems.
Just My Opinion,
Megan

was a f**cking bombass party. :-)

getting stuck and spinning tires out on the dusty dirt road, but we 
made it and boy am i glad we did.

spazzed out during somebody's set (i think it was cloud's) cuz the 
energy level was so intense.  yeah, that was me with the blinking red 
reflector on collar of my shirt.  and yeah, like i said, i met so 
many rad new people...
the weather was perfect too.  i didn't even need to bust out my 
trusty green sweatshirt.  and as if looking at all the beautiful 
people there wasn't enough, i could always lay back and check out the 
stars.  like i said, wow!
-doreen.

From: "peter sandifer" <boomerangflip@hotmail.com>
