Subject: The Sound Factory
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Sun, 28 Sep 1997 13:23:22 PDT
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Boeeey, you know I was pumped when I heard that Cyberfest was
relocated to the Sound Factory.  They said not to show up until 3am,
but you you know I had to get down there early to get loaded and scope
out the freshies.

So once I had a beer in each fist, I started freakin my way across 
the floor toward the girlz dancing in the cages.    I took off 
my shirt and started with the ole shirtless, drawers-showing boomerang
freak; flexing my pecs and thrusting the old rocketship.   Eventually, 
this hotty caught my eye, so I strolled on over to where she was 
dancing atop the speaker stacks and said, 

"Hey, Baby, ain't your name 'Damn'?  Cause that's the first thing I 
thought when I seen you!"

Well, naturally she was all charmed by my wit amd not to mention my 
smooth dance moves,   so all it took was a couple more drinks to 
convince her to hit the road and see if we could make some music 
of our own.

Only problem was, once we got back to her crib, there was some chump
sleeping in the sack!   

"What's this?" says I.  "Don't expect me to be doing any menatch
ah-twa or any of that kinky french booty knockin.  I came here for the 
REAL, baby, the 1-on-1, you know what I'm sayin?"

"Aww, don't worry about Bulldawg,"  she said.  "Here, come on, get 
in bed.  See, when  Bulldawg goes out drinking, he passes out stone 
cold.
Now, pull a hair out of his fanny.  It won't even wake him."

I yanked a hair right out of his butt, and sure enough, ole Bulldawg
didn't budge.

So me and the miss commenced to dance the Horizontal Bop like it was 
going out of 
style.

Naturally, she wanted me to go for a second round.  I got a reputation
around here--Boomerang-the stick that won't quit-- so I had no choice 
but
to oblige.

So I yanked another hair out of old Bulldawg, and he didn't move.
I was beginning to fear maybe he'd drunk himself to death,  but
then I got distracted by the lovely lady.

I was ready to collapse when she said she wanted to go for the 3!
"Damn baby, you're gonna kill me!  I got a heart condition, and 
stuff!"

But I had yo please, so I yanked another hair out of the old boy next
to me.  

And then I heard this growling that sounded like a rabid dawg ready
to strike.  Old Bulldawg turned around and looked me in the eye and said

"Look, it's bad enough that you're getting busy with my lady
in my own bed, but do you have to use my ass as a scoreboard?"

Jeff wrote: 
>>>Ok, ok...What about (6th grade for me) when Break Dancing was becoming 
popular.
Seemed like everybody in the whole elementary school that Christmas got a
BOOM-BOX.. It's like.. We all brought our boom-boxes to school thinking we
were cool.. The speakers came off of my boom-box. And the tape recorder
slided out making it a walkman.. Thoughs were the days.<<
 

Boom-boxes were the definers of the social hierarchy in skool, kinda like the 
social order in a group of orangutan or something; i.e., the bigger the 
boombox, the cooler you were.  You'd be playing your music on your boombox, and 
someone with a bigger one'd come up, and you'd have to turn yours off.  I only 
had a small one, but it had a 3' b&w tv in it, so it was cool.


>>Can you believe it? I had the coolest jacket in the whole school six grade
year.. Yep.. I had a real leather red Michael Jackson jacket! We had cutout
pictures of Michael Jackson pasted up on every wall in our classroom. But<<<


I remember when these came out, they wer like $200 or something.  NO ONE bought 
one, except this one unpopular girl that REALLY wanted to fit in, and it was 
kinda sad cause the kids teased her even more for trying so hard.  Then the 
vinyl knockoffs came out for $30 or so and made it even worse for her.  ;-<



>> My friends and I (Joel & Juan) choreographed a killer break dancing show
we put on the last day of school. PHAT. Better than thoughs doods dressed
in white at the ravEs.. Oh..   =]:<<<


I bought the Breakin' and Beat Street records.  The Breakin' record had a large 
fold-out poster that had instructions for all the popular moves on it.  My 
parents re-did the parquet floors in the kitchen, so they were really smooth 
and slippery. I practeiced the back spin thing for weeks.  Never got good, 
though.  But boy could I pop it and lock it!


Mini-reviews:

Resfest:  pretty cool, took my 12-year old brother.  He fell asleep.  I liked 
the Coldcut films the best.  That guy with the chainsaw was rad!

Psy-Harmonics:  I took the 12-year old to this too, perhaps the youngest raver 
in town last night?  He had a killer outfit, though:  big red bell bottoms, 
matching red vest, matching red jacket.  Glowing rings, glitter, smiley 
medallion.  He can't dance much though.  He's in town visiting for the weekend, 
and he made me take him to a rave.  

The music was good, vibe pretty good (I love the ppl who dress up in dayglo 
psychedelic outfits for psytrance parties!).  REALLY hot and moist in there, 
and a little too crowded, but I'm sure it was better than the massive.  

Peace, 

Nathan

Hello lovely peoples,

Well, the evening started like this...

Mack-audio picks me up and we hit the road for the long trip to Santa Rosa.  It
seems hella long.  The directions are kinda wonky, but after a few trys we find
a lot of ravers in the road.  The parking situation was totally whack when we
got there.  There was this big hill that a coupla cars couldn't get up and like
six cars blocking the road.  Heads were parking right there and walking up!  We
park the car and catch a ride in a truck - RIGHT ANSWER!

So many people!  Yowza!  What a party!  I missed Jelo and Cloud and James
Christian =(.  I really wanted to see Jelo - see, he's a new DJ and I've seen
him spin at house parties before - but this was the big debut.  He rocked the
block from what I heard!

I did get to see my man, Macadio do his thang.  I really liked his set, even
though I know he didn't get to play all the rekkids he wanted to.  After him,
another hometown favorite, Micron.

I wandered around talking to peeps and setting up my tent and didn't pay
attention to who was spinning again until my boys got up again for a really
nice hard in the morning set - Jelo, Macadio and Micron all tag-teaming.  I got
my best dancing of the party in then!  Hella props, doods!

This was a kick ass party.  The Phanthum crew did an amazing job, despite all
the parking trauma.  Good lights, good sound [the XOR boys], good vibe.  Clay
et al. - you guys rock.

On a side note, does anyone know Ian that moved to Santa Rosa two months ago
from San Diego?  I want to get a hold of him.

Lotsa love and hugs,

Beth
Rave Mama

Hey, my spell checker caught 'vibe'.  What up wit dat?

Jody_Orsburn_at_KaoFremont@kaoinfo.com 
(Jody_Orsburn_at_KaoFremont@kaoinfo.com):

>     Does anyone remember some movies that teachers would make you watch in 
>     Elementary school???

Free to be You and Me -- this shaped my foundations for love, family, 
gender roles (I was, what, 5 at the time, and nothing since has had as 
much of an impact on me)....Mel Brooks and Marlo Thomas as babies in the 
delivery room trying to figure out which one's the boy and which one's 
the girl....And my theme song when I was 5 was William and his doll:

"a doll, a doll, william wants a doll..." ... "i'd give my bat and ball 
and glove, to have a doll that i could love...."  

oh and there was the one about crying..."it's alright to cry...crying 
something something out of you...it's alright to cry...it just might make 
you feel better!" 

This wasn't in school, but Sid & Marty Krofft shows had the same amount 
of impact on me....Cool to see those are back on the air again....I loved 
those shows, just like Land of the Lost, that take you to another world...

At school on Friday afternoons we used to have movie day, and it was 
usual some Disney thing -- Herbie the Lovebug, 20,000 leagues under the 
sea, etc...But the ones that had a big impact on me were Escape from 
Witch Mountain, The Black Hole, and The Cat from Outer Space, or whatever 
it was called....When I was that age (5, 6, 7, 8), all I cared about in 
terms of the media wre anything that showed me things that I thought were 
all part of "The Force" from Star Wars -- ESP, telekenesis, outer space, 
animals and plants communicating, etc...And I used to think anything that 
*showed*, like, energy or looked all energy-like was extra cool....Secret 
of Nimh...Dark Crystal...Xanadu, Logan's Run, The Wiz....

Man, looking back, I was just doomed to do hallucinogens....I don't think 
I really had a choice...

And on the breakdancing thing, man, we had one guy at my school when I 
was in 3rd grade who could do headspins -- you're typical upper-middle 
class kids in the suburbs trying to breakdance on cardboard at recess -- 
so every recess he was this big hero, but then back in class or at lunch 
he was just nobody, but his 15 minutes of fame came at recess when we'd 
all sit around the Kivas (these cement bleacher half-circle things), 
someone would always put on that Breakin' (or maybe it was Breakin 2, 
Electric Bugaloo) soundtrack and he would do his thing....

We had 2 Kivas at school, and towards the end of the breakdance phenom 
there were 2 different crews, 1 for each Kiva, forming -- I can remember 
one day when a battle led to a fight, and somebody kicked the Martinez' 
kid's ghettoblaster across the Kiva and it smashed. That was the end of 
breakdancing at my elementary school. 









                                             andyhawks@usa.net

Subject: I Was Pulled Into the *-/ABYSS\-*(review)

Lovee dovees to all!
Last night wasn't going to be a normle night for me...I had nothing to 
do so I decided to do absolutly nothing with Sir Joel at my coffee shop. 
Eck...Aura's ride flaked (for lack of better terms, sorry Andy) Aura and 
friends decided that they would be generous and give me gas money if I 
were to drive them...I wasn't looking forward to the drive (especially 
the day after I got my car out of the clutch shop in Monterey) After a 
few days of driving, we finally made it to a dirt road that was totally 
blocked with cars, people, and a few more cars.  we started hiking, 
doing the "trust walk" thing and then we got a ride the rest of the way 
up (thanks Nick!) One car stuck, and a second about to flip...the vibes 
were sooo intense that it pushed these cars over the EDGE, well that's 
what I think caused all the rucus ;) People were dancing like mad, dust 
everywhere lights, awesome, people happy as ever.  I was very thankful I 
went.
   Macadio was the first to hear, and as always...the  BoMb. I was 
dancing like crazy bumpin into everybody. Sorry.  :)   It was amazing, I 
met so many new peoples that uh, uh uhhhh well, I was very glad to meet 
all of you.
   This was my first north of SF party with all of the Fathom 
guys...Props to Ornette, Nick, Clay, Seth, David, Jay and who ever I 
forgot you guys gave us a great time! It is great to see a big group of 
good, close friends be able to work together like you guys did. 
   One thing in particular that I thought was amusing were the kamacazi 
sp? moths and other bug paraphanallia that would keep on running into 
our foreheads while we were dancing , talking, or peeing,  they never 
failed.  Great added touch guys!  :) they look really cool in the black 
lights too....I thought it was fun....  . ... .. bzzzzz 
  In the morning, our bodies were tired, a friend and I bonded even more 
than before (thanks Troll, I love you) and I neeeded water.  
Leaving we decided to stop the car  and observe the accident, well we 
didn't really have any choice, thanks Macadio ;)  But I do sincerely 
hope that everyone  eventually got home safely and not too shakin up.
   Was it me or was it the weather or something?, uh, it was hotter in 
S.F. than I really would have liked it to be...ick... 
   (holding the mirror of ravers)I see Lisa,Neeta.Joel,Steve,chad, 
Aura,Kyle,you, you , oh, and you thanks for joining our crazed world of 
fun...back to fingerpaints and paste for me...Doh!
Take care all  of you lovely, great, hAppennin , groovy young lads and 
ladeees, we love you
AAarrgh...damn moths,

    Danny
>0<bAByHueY>0<

next time, don't forget your

Slinky

   0  O  o

Subject: (NRR) ANIME ON TV!! SPREAD THE WORD!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hey all, 

  I tried to send this earlier today, but the server said there was an error.
 :o\  Oh well, better late than never.

 Channel 54 (KTEH) in the Bay Area is trying to help bring more Anime into
the US.  They are doing this by buying episodes from Japan and airing them on
their station every weekend.  At the moment, they have Robotech and Tenchi
Muyo.  Since they are a non-profit station they have to rely on member
support and donations.  Last night, they had a huge pledge drive to show
Tenchi Muyo for it's U.S. Television Premiere.  They were giving gifts like
lil' Ryo-Ohci dolls, T-shirts, Tenchi videos, etc.  I don't know if they
would still be giving these out, but I do know they will still accept pledges
and any ideas you may have on anime, bringing it to the states, where to get
it, and esp. what to get -- subbed or dubbed.

If you want to help, call them at 1-800-225-5454 or if you're in the Bay
Area, call 408-795-5454.  Also, for those of you that can receive it, Channel
54 (not cable, so get out that antenna) airs Robotech and now, Tenchi Muyo
every Sunday at 9pm.  You can check their webpage (http://www.kteh.org) to
get exact times for each show.  

I hope everyone can help. :oD

LuV -N- BiG HuGZ,
~^V^~PhoeniX~^V^~

P.S. if you know someone that's interested, please forward this to them. ;o)

To: "Those Silly Ravers..." <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Tall Paul <deepfog@hooked.net>
Subject: Do YOU care ???
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

 This message i will try to keep short & sweet, yet i feel it very
important to
express my deepest concerns for the future of our survival in this scene!

     Last night i attended "ABYSS" up in the beautiful mountains of Santa
Rosa. & enjoyed talkin' & hangin' out w/friends & star gazin' under the
clear skies up there. It was BEAUTIFUL, i saw 12 shooting stars & then
hiked up a hill later on to greet the most amazing sunrise! Those who know
me usually find me groovin' in the speakers all night long but last
night...i just felt like relaxin'.The music was o.k. & there was alot of
dust in the air from people dancin'. It was good for a free outdoor event
UNTIL!!! When departing back down the long winding dirt road this morning,
i came across some very shaken and distraught friends as their car had
flipped off the side of the cliff and smashed into a large tree!!!   The
driver was still in shock and i crawled down to help them recover some
belongings & be there to support them in their dire need of help! They
luckily, survived without severe injuries and if it weren't for that great
big tree, they would no longer be here with us!!!

     Also, after helping them out, i finally made it down to my own ride &
witnessed that ANOTHER friend's car window had been smashed by a rock that
was thrown through it!!! WHAT the FUCK is going on!!! In the last month
alone iv'e lost count with the amount of cars broken into & fights breaking
out & backpacks being stolen & total kaos @ our events!!!

     Eventhough, i'd like to wish that we have alot of power to prevent
these  occurences, we're not invincible to them happening to us. It
especially
terrifies me that we could've also experienced a very tragic incident this
morning that would've resulted in several untimely deaths of our own family
members!!! Whether YOU even know them or not...they belong to our scene, &
they're apart of our tribe!!!

     It is SO important that WE, as a family, bond together & communicate
to each other & we look out for each other and respect one another! It's
AWESOME to celebrate our music & gather together to partake in every
positive aspect of a movement such as ours...The music truly is the
drug,YET, we obviously need to focus alot more & partake in moderation & in
a very responsible & mature manner so that we can continue to be strong &
survive & gain ground in this not so positive world of ours! We can then
prove to the world that PLUR isn't fantasy, we know it works & we must
share with others our experiences of how we think,feel,& GROW!!!  Maybe
then... the world will LISTEN & begin to understand that change is good, it
comes from within.

     WE all have a purpose in our scene & in our lives on this planet!
Reflect, Accept, Know & Understand!!! If we love ourselves, then we can
love one another, & if we love each other... then PLUR is real!!!

                            Actions speak LOUDER than words,
                        peace and love to all who really DO care...
                                                       tall paul :)

At 2:03 PM -0700 9/25/97, John_Robertson@cc.chiron.com wrote:
>     Guyz & dolls,
>
>     When does such unacceptable behavior by the various authorities get
>     bad enough to provoke more than whining on this list ? We all know the
>     litany of events screwed by the man. Perhaps we cared more or less
>     about some of them. If you remain silent who will speak out when they
>     come for you ?

Lets not forget something before we start wrapping up a cancellation of a
PARTY with some type of inalienable right.  It is after all a party, with
the two purposes being entertainment and money making.  They THEY you talk
about are elected representatives of the people, who, ideally represent the
constiuents demands.  Screwed because somebody couldn;t get a permit?  This
is far different than denying someones civil rights.

Althouhg I agree with your outrage and agner, it is afterall a party.  And
a party that was going to occur on govt. property.  To date the only person
to successfully pull of anything on govt. land has been Martin O'Brien, the
one and only who brings you Basics and the Gathering.  Maybe they shoulda
called him up for some pointers as to how things can be done.

>
>     Lets start causing a fuss !!
>
>     I would like to compile a list of legal, permitted bay area events
>     ruined or harassed in the recent past. This would be useful in a
>     letter writing campaign.

To whom?  To what ends?


>
>     9/27/97 Cyberfest '97 - Navy cancels in week before event

Navy's perrogative.  Also the dance community has done a shitty job of
portraying itself than anything else than a massive drug fest so (take a
look at the flyers, the hidden drug references , etc..  do you really think
the authorities are that stupid?).

>     9/1/97 Burning Man - Extortion & harassment by local authorities

Didn't happen last year.  Decided to play with the authorities and got what
any party would get given the publicity of the past.  Once again, since (I
beleive this didn;t occur in CA, who would you write to?).

>
>     :
>     :
>
>     1/1/97 Cool World - Shut down
>     (Leslie - were Nomad, Gateway parties permitted ?)

Permits!  Now there's the answer.  The process needs to be changed.  A good
place to start?  I dunno...

>
>     Anybody remember which party @ pier 45 was dumped on by Willie in the
>     week prior ?

Er, uh, there have been all night parties on several of the piers there
(did you know that?), how?  Becuase of some insider who knows the Mayor and
the port authority.  You have GOt to pay to play in this city, or anywhere
else.  The key is organization, accountability, and good ol politics.  If
you plan on doing anything here or anywhere else, I think these are the
prereqs.

>
>     How about a demonstration parade/party ? Lets get on the news with
>     this ! Can we get it together and really UNITE to save our scene ?

You mean clog up the streets, put toghter a protest, all because you want
to have a party?  How about organizing and becoming a force like the
gay/lesbian community and the other factions here in the city.  Only the
organized, who can deliver votes, gets anyone's ear here.  Just a reality
of city life.

>
>     Your parents wouldn't have put up with this crap for pity's sake.

Your parents are the ones who put these bozos in power in the first place.
And many have capitulated thier resonsibility by opting out of the
political process, and by not holding people accountable for their actions.

On the contrary, if I were a parent in Alameda, I would congratulate the
council for the fine decision making, given what I know about raves/all
night parties.

The only answer is the underground.  Other than that it will be a long
protracted, political battle with one side having the arsental of time
(i.e. elected officials stay in office longer than ravers stay raving),
money, and general support of the community who elected them.

It can be a good fight, but it will most assuredly be a long one.

>
>     Land of the free - my arse.

Nobody is truly free.  In this country freedom is measured in degrees.  The
more money you have, the greater degree of freedom you are alotted.  Sad
but true.

nostalgia-inducing soundtrack, I was struck by whatever that song was...  The

version, too, if I remember.  Two questions:

hi there,
my name is darren and i own tweekin records, i would like to reply to some
of the comments which appeared over the last few days.
first of all i am involved in this scene because first and formost i am a
music lover and a collector. if i was only interested in making money i
would not have bought a small independant record store, i would have opted
for a business where the mark-up on an item is more than $1 ! ( which is
what i make on a domestic record, if i am lucky)
to the the guy who bought the 2 bottom heavy records, i spoke to marjorie
(the evil WHITE woman who served you) and see assured me not only did she
apologise at the time but sold you the records at the correct price. even
though your attitude was the one which made her fell so unconfortable that
she had to ask somebody who was walking past into the store.
if you feel so wronged i will refund your money in full !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
one question i would like to ask at this point, is, what relevance does her
colour have to your problem ?
we at tweekin try to provide people with a pleasant enviroment to buy
records, if you do not like the prices or attitude of the people who work
at the store, it is siimple.
GO SOMEWHERE ELSE !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
thahks for your time
darren.

I agree - I hadn't planned on going but I know a lot of people who have never
had the chance to see Carl Cox or Aphex Twin. Can anyone tell me how you
could manage to see/hear/experience either one of these influential and
talented artists (OK yes they are also popular but that doesn't diminish
their influence or talent) at anything other than a massive type event? 
Unless you were in England back in the day and were lucky enough to see them
before anyone knew their names, or now are so well connected you can get them
to turn up at your house for a go on your decks, there isn't much choice.
Putting a CD in is never close to vibing off Carl Cox's bouncey energy and
big smile while you can feel the bass of the big sound system in your chest.
Even if you have to wade through 5000 16yr old gangsta kids to do it. (That
is what I've been told is the major problem with Cool World - I don't know if
this is true or not or even if it by definition is a bad thing). jd

When we arrived at around midnight, 115 minna was already a complete
sweatbox.  Within an hour I was completely soaked, head to toe, as if
I had just jumped into a pool.  The heat and humidity was probably due to
the fact that the music totally rocked... starting with streight-up
psy-trance (none of which I had heard before), then moving into some
sick breaktrance.  breaktrance is the bomb!  fast breakbeats with
lush synth lines over it...  around 5-6am they were spinning techstep
jungle! and then they brought it back around to pure psytrance in the
morning.  It was really fun hearing this sort of variety of music.  Props
to the crew for letting people freely hang out on the street to cool
off... I couldn't beleive how loud the music was outside and the cops
didn't seem to care... Hmmmm... I'm not complaining, though!  

-troy

From: macadio <macadio6@rocketmail.com>
Subject: **ABYSS Review** (Long)

MIME-Version: 1.0

Well my Saturday starts off with picking up Miss Beth in the City to
go to the party. She hands me a Red bull I was like Yes scored!! I
love red bull now Thanks to (Micron) heheh I remember that morning.
Well we start off on our Journey and let me Tell you it was a F**king
journey I live in the South bay and this party seemed like forever to
get to we got kind of lost a few times and when we finally find it we
still had like 2 miles to go to get to the party at this time it is
like 12:30 In my head im like no problem I got plenty of time cause I
was supposed to spin at 1:00 Im greeted by Seth one of the phatum boys
and he is like "Shit there is way to many people here"  This is at the
front gate keep in mind. I told him I thought no one would be there he
tells me there is like 400-500 people already. Then I thought Shit,
how am I going to get up there. We Drive up the road and there are a
shit load of cars all over the place one car stuck in the road. When
we get all the way up the guy tells us it is about a mile still to go.
But not to many people can make it up "The hill of death" it was a
steep hill. I was not about to drive my car up the hill I thought my
hoopty would not make it. Then this guy in a truck behind me offers me
and Beth a ride cause im a DJ and I was supposed to be playing 5
mintues ago. So we get up there I run to the decks cause there was
confusion on who would be playing next? I hate to be late to anyware
it is just Me. So I get there and the spot is perfect nice hills
Massive people everywhere dancing up a storm. I mean a Real Dust
storm. Can you say Dusty cough,cough. I Did what a consider a shitty
job at spinning it was very dusty and I could not see where my tracks
ended or broke down. The lights and sound was great. I am sad I missed
Cloud, Jelo, and James I heard they Rocked!!  I did get to hear this
Kid Named Trace look at for him all he is Dope he was playing some
good Cyber. Dan rocked a bit for beeing sick. Ornette was kewl to for
his first time out. In the morning as the sun came up Me, Dan, and
Jelo did a nice tag team set. It was a great party Thanks Phatum crew
and all the kewl people that showed up it was such a good party
despite the Few problems and the crash problem. Sorry about your Car
Alec. Thank God your alive Kid. For all the cyberfesties Sorry you
kids did not get to party. I posted the party too the list to give
everyone a chance to come out. Either some of you did not get the post
till it was too late or you just deleted it. In any case you missed
out on a kick ass party. Hopefully next time all will get to attend
the next phatum party. I look forward to the next one. Danny sorry for
the hold up in the morning. hehehe. Take care people and DRIVE SAFE!!!

Peace, love, cybersex ;-)
Macadio (Mac-Audio)

What a fucking disaster...sorta.

Did ANYBODY meet ANYBODY from this list there?

My friend Erik and I got there around 9:20 and went to the dome by the
pond.  Nuthin but skaters EVERYWHERE...damn near impossible to find people
there...there musta been 200+ skaters.

We walked around and finally found the box office, bought our tix, and
went into the lobby, and just as we did they opened the doors to the
theater, so we headed in.

I thought I saw e.menon over on the other side of the place with 2 other
peeps, but I couldn't get over there to say hi.

The movie was pretty cool...I got my $10 worth on Coldcuts' 'Timber' and
'More Beats'n'Pieces'...fucking brilliant...made me all warm and fuzzy
inside.

Afterwards, we hung out in the lobby looking for people, but none were to
be found.

DAMN, because I even wore my green jacket and a big paper nametag...just
like I said I would.

All's I wanted was to meet some of you...

ohwell.

-jimg/skoop

  I went to the earlier show. Sorry we didn't hook up!
  On the rave/techno front:
  There was a very nice program called Mixman that they were demoing in
the inner meeting area. It doesn't run on the web like the elegant
"DJDemo" crafted by SFR's  Derek Chung and Jeremy Cooper from BayMOO
(http://130.212.41.61/TURNTABLES/BAYMOOMIX.HTML), but it was a very sweet
standalone program. Wish they had it for the Macintosh.
  One of the films from the earlier show had a section of what I can only
call "visual techno." It took some video clips of an actual news show,
then looped and counterpointed them, with an effect sort of like the old
Max Headroom stutters.  I'm going to try to score a copy for SFSU, and
I'll let you know if we get it.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Mon Sep 29 11:14:14 1997

	Mon, 29 Sep 1997 10:49:29 -0700 (PDT)

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Mon, 29 Sep 1997 10:49:07 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from upmajb08 - 204.95.110.71 by msn.com with Microsoft SMTPSVC;
	 Mon, 29 Sep 1997 10:48:32 -0700
Date: Mon, 29 Sep 97 17:52:24 UT
From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@classic.msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL18.199709291747560016@classic.msn.com>
To: "funkateers" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: SRR:  Problem:  To DJ or not to DJ?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, I was vegging out listening to some music and I was having the feeling I 
always get when I listen to something I really like . . . . I always think, 
"Damn, I wish I could spin so I could make everyone feel what I'm feeling."

I don't want to be the next Keoki or anything, and I wouldn't even trip off 
never ever getting paid for spinning at a party as long as I had another 
daytime job that paid enough for me to buy records and equipment.  And I 
wouldn't be out to be the biggest and the best, I realize I'd be just one of a 
million amateurs.  I'd just want to make people feel good, feel like I feel 
when I hear an incredible song . . . the type of music I want to spin is so 
rare out here, people should be hearing it.

Problem:  I'm a student and I don't have a very large income (about $650 a 
month) and I have to save up for when I go off to college.  So I have limited 
time and _very_ limited funds.  It'd be hard for me to get material because I 
want to spin happy hardcore and I'd have to get all my stuff imported from the 
UK, which can't be cheap.

So I thought, "Well, I'll just learn to spin, and when I get out of college 
and get a decent job I can start throwing my own parties and spinning at 
them."  I spoke to a dj friend about this and he said that music will have 
changed so much by then.  And I want to spin the kind of 4-beat that's out 
now, plus some of the classics from the early 90s.  I want to do it now(!) but 
I don't know if I can or should.

So what should I do?

xoxo--Miccaela

	Mon, 29 Sep 1997 11:54:33 PDT
X-Originating-IP: [204.118.88.1]
From: "Mike Robinson" <c64k@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: SRR: Problem: To DJ or not to DJ?
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Mon, 29 Sep 1997 11:54:33 PDT
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>Well, I was vegging out listening to some music and I was having the 
feeling I 
>always get when I listen to something I really like . . . . I always 
think, 
>"Damn, I wish I could spin so I could make everyone feel what I'm 
feeling."
>

That's the best reason to start spinning.

>Problem:  I'm a student and I don't have a very large income (about 
$650 a 
>month) and I have to save up for when I go off to college.  So I have 
limited 
>time and _very_ limited funds.  It'd be hard for me to get material 

Start small, learn off other peoples records if possible, buy 1 or 2 
records a paycheck.  If you don't have a lot of money to spend you'll be 
more likely to find THE best track to spend that money on.  

>So I thought, "Well, I'll just learn to spin, and when I get out of 
college 
>and get a decent job I can start throwing my own parties and spinning 
at 
>them."  I spoke to a dj friend about this and he said that music will 
have 
>changed so much by then.  And I want to spin the kind of 4-beat that's 
out 
>now, plus some of the classics from the early 90s.  I want to do it 
now(!) but 
>I don't know if I can or should.
>
>So what should I do?

Do what you want.  Hardcore's been around for a while now, it's not just 
gonna up and dissapear (tho some people wish it would :( )
And hey, in a few years the early nineties will be "retro" and in and 
all......

So, equipment wise, use friends decks.  Buy stylii(styluses?) so they'll 
be more willing to let you play on their stuff.  

Buy only 1 or 2 records per paycheck, take your time choosing them.

See if DJs you know will let you learn with their records.

If nothing else, give it a try, otherwise, you'll always be wondering 
whether you could/should have done it.

mike 
---64k---

To those who are seeking growth potential (aren't we all?):

CITISCAPE Media Design, LLC is currently looking for the following in an
Interactive Designer....

1) Knows HTML inside and out (and can grasp Cascading Style Sheets and Dynamic
HTML - Understands the differences between Navigator 4.0 and IE 4.0).
1.5) not intimidated by Javascript or Jscript.
2) Preferably has an education outside of web design (i.e. fine arts,
illustration, etc.)
3) has strong graphic design skills
3.5) understands the benefits of an efficient design/production process.
4) has a grasp of Macromedia Director (but does not need to be an expert in
Lingo) and can work within the program successfully.
5) has strong and intelligent sense for what makes great UI's.
6) wants to make a difference in this wacky thing we call NEW MEDIA!
7) wouldn't mind living in Sacramento for about a year (w/ the possibility of
relocating to S.F. after that....)

Please send your resume to me via email or fax at:

rwpointer@citiscape.com

or

(916) 922-3353

If you have an online resume, please refer me to the URL. A portfolio is
required (interactive or otherwise).

Salary right now is between $25k and $40k depending on experience.

CITISCAPE Background:

We have been around for two years. In 1995 we had two employees. Right now we
have 7. Our work on the web has been noted by: Macromedia (Shocked site of the
week, Shocked site of the Day, Macromedia's Vangaurd gallery, RealAudio's
WebActive Site of the week, multiple local site awards (sacto), and nationally
recognized by New Media Magazine's Invision Awards (finalist in two categories
this year: http://www.invisionwards.com).
Our clients include: Hal Riney and Partners, McClatchy Newspapers (via the
Sacramento Bee), Peet's Coffee and Tea, Saturn Cars, Real Audio, Amazon.com,
Pointcast, Leftfield, etc.

We are reviewing applications right now.

Please forward if you think you know someone who may qualify for this job.
Thanks a bunch.

     Troy??? I wish I would have known, I would have said hello.. What were 
     you wearing??? 
     
     Anyhow, this was a cool party... They had said at the map point it had 
     sold out, but at the door, they were still letting in a few select 
     people. 
     
     This location is cool, when it's completely open. It's the same 
     location as Pro-Soy's Light my Fire Party, but this time they only had 
     the downstairs open... Very humid... The walls were sweating, no for 
     real!
     
     Music was cool, some of the mixes were clumsy, but they made up for it 
     with the choice of music... 
     
     Someone walked around with a few gallons of water, and obliged needy 
     partiers, very cool... Didn't see a 12 year old though...
     
     The only misfortunate item was when I went downstairs to get some air. 
     A young girl was having a VERRY INTENSE evening... Acid trip I 
     believe, could be wrong. But the female host at the door, with the 
     feathers in her hair, realized this was getting sorta dangerous with 
     the open door and all. So, she grabbed the girl, and yelled at her 
     "YOU NEED TO MAINTAIN" "BE COOL NOW, FRIENDS ARE HERE"  - All done out 
     of love....  
     
     Cool party, I'm glad Cyberfest didn't break my heart.. Sorry to all 
     the folks that got ripped off. I hope there's a means for a refund, 
     because you did not get the show promised... Keep the Peace!
     
     <JCO>


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: psy harmonics
Author:  Troy Sheets <tsheets@saturn5.com> at Internet_mail
Date:    9/29/97 10:23 AM


     
When we arrived at around midnight, 115 minna was already a complete 
sweatbox.  Within an hour I was completely soaked, head to toe, as if
I had just jumped into a pool.  The heat and humidity was probably due to 
the fact that the music totally rocked... starting with streight-up 
psy-trance (none of which I had heard before), then moving into some
sick breaktrance.  breaktrance is the bomb!  fast breakbeats with 
lush synth lines over it...  around 5-6am they were spinning techstep 
jungle! and then they brought it back around to pure psytrance in the
morning.  It was really fun hearing this sort of variety of music.  Props 
to the crew for letting people freely hang out on the street to cool 
off... I couldn't beleive how loud the music was outside and the cops 
didn't seem to care... Hmmmm... I'm not complaining, though!  
     
-troy

tsheets@schwa.eng.sun.com                  <- Official Use Only 
http://www.saturn5.com/tsheets/            <- Instant Content 
troys-list@schwa.eng.sun.com               <- Inquire Within

>
>Well, I was vegging out listening to some music and I was having the 
feeling I 
>always get when I listen to something I really like . . . . I always 
think, 
>"Damn, I wish I could spin so I could make everyone feel what I'm 
feeling."
>
>I don't want to be the next Keoki or anything, and I wouldn't even trip 
off 
>never ever getting paid for spinning at a party as long as I had 
another 
>daytime job that paid enough for me to buy records and equipment.  And 
I 
>wouldn't be out to be the biggest and the best, I realize I'd be just 
one of a 
>million amateurs.  I'd just want to make people feel good, feel like I 
feel 
>when I hear an incredible song . . . the type of music I want to spin 
is so 
>rare out here, people should be hearing it.
>

It's a good reason to start :). Although it's true, Happy hardcore 
hasn't really caught on out here to say the least, but if your motive to 
start spinning is to play and listen to the kinds of music that make you 
feel good, I say go for it. 

On the other hand....

If your motive is to play out and get people to listen to your music 
selection immediately, beware. Anyone will tell you there are way too 
many DJ's out there right now. I've experienced this personally and it's 
not a pretty scene. You could even practice for months, get really good 
at beat-matching, and still be fighting for spots at little house 
parties ;). Anyway, if you really want to get people to hear your music 
you need to start off by getting a tape recorder and making mix tapes. 
That way people can hear your stuff without being burdened by trying to 
squeeze you into thier line-up. Once enough people have heard the hard 
work you've put into your tapes they should start asking you to play at 
thier gigs without you even asking.


Anywayz...good luck :)

RE:  Hardcore

yeah, you'l prollyhave to pick up a lot of imports, but you can 
mail-order from places that have good Hardcore selections, like Dr. 
Freecloud's Mixing lab (www.drfreeclouds.com) or other soCal places.  
Hardcore is as big as ever down here, so I wouldn't worry too much about 
it drying up over the next 2 or 3 years.  Especially 'Happy' Hardcore.  
People down here seem to be more accepting of that verses Terrorcore and 
some of the 'darker' hardcore stuff.

:)
PUYA

At 12:06 PM 9/28/97 -0700, Megan Haggerty wrote:
>At 10:16 PM -0700 9/27/97, blkadder@value.net wrote:
>>On Sat, 27 Sep 1997, Megan Haggerty wrote:
>>
>>> The dance community should have the option of
>>> attending a massive if they so desire.  Personally, I prefer smaller, more
>>> underground parties/clubs but I respect that others may have different
>>> preferences.  I agree with Vlad that it is sad that this party was
>>> cancelled.
>>
>>I'm not. Then again I have hear tales of near riots at the front gates at
>>past events, sketchy experiences with other attendees, as well as seen the
>>article in the paper last year about all the people(15 or so if memory
>>serves) found wandering the streets after their New Years party in a
>>drug-filled stupor. Wow, sounds like some place I want to go. Think of it
>>this way: perhaps by the cancellation of the event, some lives were
>>saved, literally.
>
>Can an event be held responsible for the actions of it's attendees?  I'm
>torn on this issue, myself.  I beleive each individual is responsible for
>his/her own actions.  But on the other hand, should an organization which
>has repeated problems at its events continue to put on those events?  I am
>not close enough to the situation on either side of the arguement to draw a
>sound conclusion.

Event coordinators should not be responsible for the actions of the
attendees, but they should be responsible for the environment they create.
For example, just over a week ago, I was at a cool little party in the
city, and one of the attendees started flipping out a little.  It was /not/
the party throwers fault that this happened.  It /was/, however, due to
good handling by the people throwing the event that the situation didn't
get out of control.  Having a ton of friendly people there who were all
willing to help calm the person down, was great, and, contributed to the
great vibe that was floating around.  Its hard o have that sort of thing
happen at a massive, its not the same.  

People who don't take responsibility for their parties are not a part of
the underground, they are exploiting it.  The moment it becomes about money
and ego and drugs, and not about music and friendship and everything else,
its lost its meaning.  It still might be a great show, but it probably
won't be a great experience.


Just my long rambling take...

No, this isn't a bsp...more of an rfi. A few times while riding in GG park
on sundays I've run across a particularly interesting group. I don't know
if they're a club or organization or anything, but (when I saw it) it
consisted of about 10-20 people playing drums, and about 150 people, split
into groups, dancing to the drums. It was all really quite cool, but
unfortunately I have been unable to find these folks again.

Does anyone know who/what/when/where this is?

Yes, this is something that happens every sunday in GG park, near the pan
handle, that at a place called Hippy Hill... there are usually 1-2 hundred
people there building up and amazing vibe.  It is another close knit family,
because we see the same people each weekend, and get to know each other thru
it.   It usually begins around 1 or 2 pm, but there are people hanging out
from 10 or so in the morning... it is a nice wind down from saturday night.  
There is not really a name of any organization that does it, it's just
whoever wants to jam or dance or connect goes... and thats what its all
about... :)  
we all should arrange to meet together there sometime,  ...?  anyone?


Passing the Love,
---Maya---

Precedence: bulk

I live across the street from GG park, so I am over there frequently.

I think my favorite thing about the "drum circle" is that it is not *only*
drums, but anything anyone wants to play.  You frequently get saxophonists,
guitarists, harmonicas, whatever.  My favorite is the guy who drops by
occassionally to play the stick-and-coke-bottle.  They are people of all
different ages, backgrounds, and musical skill levels.  People show up if
they want to, which makes each musical creation entirely spontaneous and
unique.

One of my favorite things about GG park in general is the frequent
spontaneous musical that occurs.  It is quite common to run across someone
practicing in one of the subterranean walkways under the streets (great
acoustics!) or sitting in a little grove of trees serenading their
girlfriend.

If you haven't visited GG park from a musical perspective, I highly
recommend it.

Lying around in the sun listening to people make music is also a great way
to spend those lazy sunday afternoons after being up all night at a party.

>No, this isn't a bsp...more of an rfi. A few times while riding in GG park
>on sundays I've run across a particularly interesting group. I don't know
>if they're a club or organization or anything, but (when I saw it) it
>consisted of about 10-20 people playing drums, and about 150 people, split
>into groups, dancing to the drums. It was all really quite cool, but
>unfortunately I have been unable to find these folks again.
>
>Does anyone know who/what/when/where this is?
>
>Thanks,
>
>/justin

  At San Francisco State we have a film called "Little Jesus," shot at
Hippie Hill in 1969. There was drum and weird instrument action even then. 
The amazing highlight (no pun) of the film, though, shows the folks
passing around a gas mask loaded with marijuana. People would put on the
mask, and the smoke would pour out the nozzle in front and around the
sides of the mask -- making the smoker inside look like a barbequed alien
-- then they'd take the mask off and pass it to the next person. You could
almost see the birds flying out of the eyelids of the smokers as they
emerged.  :<)

> Yes, this is something that happens every sunday in GG park, near the pan
> handle, that at a place called Hippy Hill... there are usually 1-2 hundred
> people there building up and amazing vibe.  It is another close knit family,
> because we see the same people each weekend, and get to know each other thru
> it.   It usually begins around 1 or 2 pm, but there are people hanging out
> from 10 or so in the morning... it is a nice wind down from saturday night.

Received: from 208.136.96.250 by db01-fast via web-mailer (2.1) on Mon, 29 Sep 1997 19:15:35

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: San Fran Disco
CC: uk-dance@uk-dance.org
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

It started off in the blistering heat of the Folsom Street fair, the 
kinkiest show on Earth with hundreds and even thousands of leather clad 
fetishists prowling and mincing the streets like a modern-day Sodom and 
Gomorrah to the soundtrack of dirty filthy fucked up house.
>From this surreal scene I head down to the pier, and await embarkation 
of the Sunset boat. Finally, after much waiting, we all pile upon the 
decks and sit out top, watching the sun go down and waiting for the show 
to begin. There must be over 500 people on board, all looking eager to 
get on with the serious business of dancing their way around the bay, and 
the frustration at the late leaving time is rife in the air. Eventually 
we chug off into the sunset with a loud cheer, the music boots up and 
the party kicks off. Right from the start I can tell its going to be 
something beyond a normal party experience - there is a vibe in the air that 
everyone there is going to interact at their best to create something 
really special. We kick off with some funky hip hop on the top deck, and 
killer deep house on the lower deck, people get straight into it - no 
warm up at all, and within 30 seconds the whole place is kicking to the 
sounds of appreciative yells of joy over the deep reverberating bass 
rhythms from deep within the boat. 
Pretty soon we are out in the bay, looking out at the incredible 
palette the sunset is daubing on the horizon beneath the Golden Gate Bridge, 
and the multitude of lights piercing the dark silhouettes of the 
skyscrapers dominating the city skyline. Soon we pass out under the bridge 
itself, everyone crowded on the open-air deck craning their necks at the 
awesome sight of the towering red structure. Back to business down below we 
are treated to more crazy funky Chicago house from Derrick Carter's 
Chicago partner (Who's name escapes me) and as the boat chugs its way along 
the Marin county coastline and past Alcatraz and Treasure Island the 
beat just goes straight on and on, people locked onto one groove, everyone 
on the same wavelength - crazy San Fransiscans exercising their right 
to party hard. 
At one point I look out of the window and see an insane sight - we are 
cruising past the old naval air base at Alameda, and the huge naval 
bunkers and gun turrets and docking stations lit up by sparse halogen light 
create a really freaky atmosphere, a technospherical set through which 
we cruise on our little mobile island of humanity powered by organic 
house beats.
All too soon the boat starts to turn, and we leisurely make our way 
back, the dancefloor blistering with heat as people go for it even harder 
as they realise they haven't much time left, and the music gets harder 
and more evil and techno-like as we all dance ourselves into a rabid 
frenzy of pure hedonism, and all it takes is a quick look out of the window, 
or a brief walk onto the open deck to be transported from this clubbing 
frenzy into the beauty of a warm starlit night, with the sparkling 
lights of the approaching city providing the visual effects.
A close flyby of the downtown San Fransisco coastline while the DJ 
slaps on Gary Newman's "Cars" just for that final bit of insanity, and 
we're back in dock, the trip over, and people stumble off the boat, dazed 
and confused and irreversibly altered for having been a part of the one 
mind trapped aboard a boat that we all became for those all-too brief 
hours.
Sunset boat parties are something else.

C@weasel



Get free e-mail and a permanent address at http://www.netaddress.com

I know this thread is kinda beaten and dead, but I just had to say:

andyhawks said:
>Think back -- if you were 17 years old and just 
>discovering techno, the rave scene, and LSD concurrently -- 

This describes me.  Born 12/8/79.  First got into the music when "Amp" started 
airing.  First rave was in April this year.  First candyflip was in late 
August.

>wouldn't Keoki's music appeal to you and wouldn't his personality >attract 
you if nothing other than for the fact that he makes himself >highly visible?

Nope.  No way, Jose.  Hell naw.  Nuh-uh.  No sir.

Not all of us teenybopper newbies are as predictable as ya'll seem to think.  
I don't even like The Prodigy too much (although I confess to owning and 
enjoying "The Prodigy Experience")

But I have friends who fit the above description who think Keoki is hella 
tight.  The same people who down other djs/musicians for being too commercial 
(e.g. The Prodigy).  Go figure.

Does this sound like bitching?  Sorry, I'm not pissed or anything, just had to 
address that though.  Bugged me a little bit.

xoxo--Miccaela

>>Yes, this is something that happens every sunday in GG park, near the pan
handle, that at a place called Hippy Hill... there are usually 1-2 hundred
people there building up and amazing vibe.  It is another close knit family,
because we see the same people each weekend, and get to know each other thru
it.   It usually begins around 1 or 2 pm, but there are people hanging out
from 10 or so in the morning... it is a nice wind down from saturday night.  
There is not really a name of any organization that does it, it's just
whoever wants to jam or dance or connect goes... and thats what its all
about... :)  
we all should arrange to meet together there sometime,  ...?  anyone?
Passing the Love,
---Maya---<<


Yes yes!  this is great fun, perhaps the most relaxed I ever get is sitting in 
the sun, listening to the rhythms.  I was there on Sat., with my lil bro, 
playing catch.  I know there are other SFR's that go sometimes, (Kerryl?), we 
should all meet at one of these. Ja wohl! Nathan

Vanessa & Miccaela wrote:
> 
> I know this thread is kinda beaten and dead, but I just had to say:
> 

My $.02:

I don't really give a crap about his attitude, but I have heard him
spin, own a bootleg of his stuff that he played w/ DJ Dan coupla years
ago, and one of his CD mixes f*ckin' jump.
I think his selection of music when he mixes is awesome.
However, I do think his own self produced music kinda sucks. It never
really goes anywhere.
Anyway, I am sure that he is completely aware of the concern that y'all
are bringing up due to his new CD being called "ego trip."
If that is what it is, so be it...His karma will take care of the  bad
vibes he spreads wittingly.
otherwise, (a la Donnie Brasco):

Fahgetta 'bout it.

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

p.s. Wow, just getting involved in the scene since Amp started to air?
What was the impetus for you to candyflip? why even bother, i guess,
when the whole atmosphere is already different enough, dontcha think? I
didn't take E at all for a good seven years while I was raving my heart
out. I was so into the music. I tried it on a whim last year to see what
it was all about. It was great, don't get me totally wrong, but I'm glad
that I had a vision of the scene that wasn't tainted by the "drug
gogles" that a lot of people have. Y'know, its the ones that can't
imagine going out unless they are on something I think that totally miss
the amazing effect that the music can have on an even sober person.
Anyway, I guess I just bring it up (being the old fart that I am)
because I would hate to see you get burned out or dependent on
extraneous substances to see how amazing all of this can truly be.
Anyway, i guess that's my 4 cents.

Hey everyone out there where ever you are, whatever you may be doing, 
whomever you may be dreaming about, I figured I would like to say a 
little something motivational and cheerful just because...well, I'd like 
to.
  

   Smiles, ice cream, beaches, sunsets and full moons shinning the light 
on everything that is.
   Love, tranquility, happiness, and those who were meant to be...
   Laughter, work, life, all that has to be done...
   Wind blowing through you fingers while you are admiring your best of 
friends...
   All that used to be, can still be created in your souls, 
   Your first kiss...
   Clear, brisk nights, at a family barbeque with cousins, aunts, and 
uncles who you have never met before...
   Memories, creating and sharing them with those you want to love and 
remembering those times you have hated...laughing at them.
   If darkness comes, so will the light, we must keep our heads high and 
trample through it like a field of knee-high grass.  
   Everything happens for a reason, and everything can be learned from 
and should be.  There are people who care, you may have just not found 
them yet, 
   but they are thinking of you as you are thinking of them...happily, 
embracing the moments...when you will meet...

   I just felt like sharing what was on my brain...sorry if I caused 
anyone any misfortune  :)
   Can anyone tell that I'm in love? :P

  PLUR everyone and good night, for tomorrow is a new experience

"One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by 
making darkness conscious."
                         -C.G. Jung

Happily,
  bAByHueY

P.S.
and when you do find that someone, don't forget to bring your...

Slinky

   0  O  o

     OOOOOoooohh.  I've got something for people who have been in the bay 
     area for awhile...
     
     Do you remember way back when, on TV20-KOFY, when they had 3-D movies, 
     and the greatest,... Scratch n Sniff TV... You'd have to go to 7-11, 
     pickup your very cool 3-D glasses, or your SNUFF sheet, with all the 
     cool smells going on..  Grab a slurpee, turn on the TV and when a 
     number would flash on the TV, you'd scratch n sniff that number on 
     your page.... INTERACTIVE TELEVISION BEGINS PEOPLE!!!

I love hippie hill drum sessions....I used to live around the corner from the
Haight and I would go every Sunday...its fun to bring your dog...if you have
one...I wouldn't call it a candy-raver scene...it's more of a
hippie-kickback-chill spot...yet you still have that cool drum circle beat
going on....it's a good vibe....you do get the occasional tourist photo shoot
moments going on...it's fun....yeah!!!!!!! It sometimes lasts until 4:20 on a
nice day. I'll be there...hope to see you there.....oh wait....I'm going to
San Diego with Rebecca and Janel this weekend...I forgot....does anyone have
any suggestions for San Diego? We are in search of a good party to go
to....underground....any tips will be appreciated...have a beautiful
day!!!!!!     

                                        =oP    Lots of Luv, mushy (melissa)

The drum circle at Hippie Hill is a wonderful part of San Francisco, with a
long history and a great vibe.  I haven't been there for a couple months,
and I miss it.  It happens every week.  Maybe there should be a weekly
meeting place?  (I am being a just little selfish here, as I can not meet
this weekend :>)  ).  A good place to meet is just behind the bench.  

See you all there next week.

Peace food and hug bombs,
Kerry


At 10:21 PM 9/29/97, you wrote:
>>>Yes, this is something that happens every sunday in GG park, near the pan
>handle, that at a place called Hippy Hill... there are usually 1-2 hundred
>people there building up and amazing vibe.  It is another close knit family,
>because we see the same people each weekend, and get to know each other thru
>it.   It usually begins around 1 or 2 pm, but there are people hanging out
>from 10 or so in the morning... it is a nice wind down from saturday night.  
>There is not really a name of any organization that does it, it's just
>whoever wants to jam or dance or connect goes... and thats what its all
>about... :)  
>we all should arrange to meet together there sometime,  ...?  anyone?
>Passing the Love,
>---Maya---<<

My e-mail's a little persnickity today - hope this works.
Sorry to beat this dead horse but this point is one I'm really wondering
about.

A massive certainly isn;t a social event  - its an avenue to see/hear
performers that you wouldn't otherwise be able to see/hear live. That is why
the atmosphere is rock concert-ish. And that is why I don;t go to too  many.
But if someone had been booked that i really wanted to see I probably
would've. But not for any of the reasons I go to sunset. Apples and oranges.

thanks for your input - jd

ps-massives here vs massives in europe are also apples vs. oranges (imo)

Subject: Re: CYBERFEST CANCELED

I agree - I hadn't planned on going but I know a lot of people who have never
had the chance to see Carl Cox or Aphex Twin. Can anyone tell me how you
could manage to see/hear/experience either one of these influential and
talented artists (OK yes they are also popular but that doesn't diminish
their influence or talent) at anything other than a massive type event? 
Unless you were in England back in the day and were lucky enough to see them
before anyone knew their names, or now are so well connected you can get them
to turn up at your house for a go on your decks, there isn't much choice.
Putting a CD in is never close to vibing off Carl Cox's bouncey energy and
big smile while you can feel the bass of the big sound system in your chest.
Even if you have to wade through 5000 16yr old gangsta kids to do it. (That
is what I've been told is the major problem with Cool World - I don't know if
this is true or not or even if it by definition is a bad thing). jd

------- Forwarded Message

>>AROUND THE FIRE is a movie about us, about our music scene and hanging
>>out at shows.  This movie is currently being filmed, and they need
>>EXTRAS, lots of fun and music loving folks to hang out and be in the
>>movie.
>>
>>
>>
>>As an incentive, and to make the movie authentic, the producers are
>>throwing a week-long camping bash at Stafford Lake in Novato, Marin Co.
>>The scene simulates outdoor shows and "vendorville," so vending and
>>camping is encouraged.  Here's the scoop...
>>
>>
>>
>>Monday Sept. 29 through Friday Oct. 3rd
>>
>>
>>
>>FREE CAMPING,  FREE BEER,  FREE MUSIC!!!!!
>>
>>
>>
>>Daily (M-F):  8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.  MOVIE SHOOT.
>>
>>
>>
>>Music at Night (about 8 p.m. to 10 p.m.):
>>
>>        Monday:         ZIGABOO MODELISTE and his AAHKESTRA  (awesome
>>drummer formerly
>>of the New Orleans Meters)
>>
>>        Tuesday:        THE WEBS
>>
>>        Wednesday:  BLEW WILLIE
>>
>>        Thursday:       CRAZY FROM THE HEAT
>>
>>
>>
>>Please try to come early, camp, and take part in the daily shootings.  If
>>you work, try to take one day off to join the fun. TUESDAY is recommended
>>if you can only take off one day.
>>
>>
>>
>>BRING:  colorful hippie and Deadhead clothes and stuff (ANYTHING you
>>might see in Vendorville), camping gear, weird crazy vehicles, money for
>>food, good energy.
>>
>>
>>
>>DOGS:  NOT recommended, but if you MUST bring them, they MUST be on a
>>leash and under strict control at all times.
>>
>>
>>
>>DIRECTIONS TO STAFFORD LAKE:  101 North (of SF) to Novato.  Take the
>>Atherton/San Marin Drive exit, turn WEST (Left) on San Marin Drive.  Go
>>1.5 miles & turn RIGHT on NOVATO Blvd.  Go 3 to 4 miles to the Stafford
>>Lake park entrance (west of Stafford Lake dam).  Look for Around the Fire
>>signs.
>>
>>
>>
>>This message is passed on from the film makers:  Tommy Rosen and John
>>Comerford.  Please contact Brad Lyman at (415) 643-2337 with any
>>questions.  They THANK YOU GRATEFULLY for your support!!
>>
>>
>>
>>C'mon out and have some fun!!!  PLEASE PASS ON THIS MESSAGE ASAP TO
>>EVERYONE WHO WOULD BE INTERESTED!

------- End of Forwarded Message

On Tue, 30 Sep 1997 13:07:34 -0700 Sol <balanced@deepwell.com> writes:
>At 12:32 AM 9/27/97 -0700, you wrote:
>
>>how  many of you Guys had a " My buddy " Doll

>*****
>
>I had a "Dapper Dan" .

I was not allowed to have dolls...cause i was a boy.
But i kept ripping the head off my sisters Ringo doll,
(ringo was one of the beatles for you youngins)
so i was finally given a lucky troll with flourescent hair
so that i would leave my sisters dolls alone.

I also had a stuffed chipmunk that I called chippy.
I carried him everywhere until his fur was worn off
and his head started to come loose. Then my dad
took him out to his workshop and did surgery to replace
his fur and reattach his head. I never went anywhere
without chippy tucked under my arm so i was very upset
while he was undergoing surgery. 

My middle name is alvin ...i was named after alvin
the chipmunk...and have lived up to my name...

	a true fish story brought to you by the 
	
		foolish fish

			><{{{">   <"}}}><

Or how about playing Intellivision through WPIX TV station (NYC) by calling
the station and--if you were lucky enough to be chosen--saying, "Pix" into
the phone to activate the fire button of the controller as you watched the
results in real-time on the TV. It was done during commercial breaks in the
afternoons. The caller was able to play one full game and those who beat the
high score got gift certificates for Toys 'R' Us.

Adam

imaginations. We didn't mind; we liked it. When I was young I had some
Planet of The Apes action figures, and a model of a Wankel rotary engine.

Fer (sp?) Jeans. <toggle Homer Simpson voice> Mmmmm camel toe. Now that's
ancient history. Anyways remembering odd things doesn't make you old, bad
fashion does. As I always say: You're only as old as your fashions are lame.

Although I've been subscribed to SF-Raves for several months now, I've
never found the need to post. So hi, I'm Matt, and I thought you might
find the following interesting:

(My apologies if this fuels a renewal of heated discussions.)

---------------

SACRAMENTO, Sept. 30 (UPI) _ Legislation signed into law by the governor
will outlaw the party drug GHB, sometimes called ``liquid ecstasy'' or
the ``date rape'' drug.

Beginning next Jan. 1, the measure by Assemblyman Larry Bowler, R-Elk
Grove, will make it a felony to possess gamma-hydroxybutyrate, which may
cause respiratory arrest, liver failure, seizures and prolonged
unconsciousness.

Bowler says the bill was requested by law enforcement officers in San
Francisco and Los Angeles who say GHB is out of control among youths who
brew it in bathtubs from engine solvents and lye.

Manufacture and sale of GHB is prohibited in the United States, but
possession isn't illegal in most parts of the country.

Wilson also signed a bill that adds the Internet and electronic mail to
the list of mediums through which it's illegal to distribute harmful
sexual material to a minor.

Also signed was a bill that prohibits rapists from obtaining custody or
having unsupervised visitation of a child who was conceived as a result
of the rape.

Another newly signed measure prohibits the sale, manufacture, possession
and importation of military practice or metal replica hand grenades.
Gangs fill them with explosives and use them as weapons.

_-

Copyright 1997 by United Press International.

All rights reserved.

got this from a friend and thought you might like it...


>   Some food for thought:
>  
>  Imagine there is a bank which credits your account 
>  each morning with $86,000; carries over no balance 
>  from day to day, allows you to keep no cash balance, 
>  and every evening cancels whatever part of the amount
>  you had failed to use during the day.
>  
>  What would you do?
> 
>  Draw out every cent, of course!
>  
>  Well, everyone has such a bank.  Its name is TIME.  
>  
>  Every morning, it credits you with 86,400 seconds.  
>  It carries over no balance.  It allows no overdraft.
>  
>  Each day it opens a new account for you.  
>  Each night it burns the records of the day.  
>  
>  There is no going back.  
>  There is no drawing against the tomorrow. 
>  You must live in the present on today's deposits.  
>  Invest it so as to get from it the utmost in health, 
>  happiness, and success!
>  
>  The clock is running.  Make it the most of your day...
>  
>  To realize the value of ONE YEAR
>  Ask a student who has failed his final exam.
>  
>  To realize the value of ONE MONTH
>  Ask a mother who has given birth to a premature baby.
>  
>  To realize the value of ONE WEEK
>  Ask an editor of a weekly newspaper.
>  
>  To realize the value of ONE DAY
>  Ask a daily wage laborer who has ten kids to feed.
>  
>  To realize the value of ONE HOUR
>  Ask the lovers who are waiting to meet....
>  
>  To realize the value of ONE MINUTE
>  Ask a person who has missed the train.
>  
>  To realize the value of  ONE SECOND
>  Ask a person who has survived an accident.
>  
>  To realize the value of ONE MILLISECOND
>  Ask the person who has won a silver medal in the Olympics.
>  
>  Treasure every moment you have!  
>  And treasure it more because you shared it with someone 
>  special...


. . . . . . .
ben_chun@community.net
ben_chun@technologist.com

www.community.net/~ben_chun/

Hi all!  ]=}

 First off I'm sorry to spam both lists but this is a very relavant 
question or two...

 My housemate just bought a pair of tables and a mixer (Numark, rrrrrr) 
as well as other goodies. (Big happy face here as I get to play as well!) 
As I'm the one who gets to set them up I was looking through the manuals 
and found some needed info missing.

 The tables are Technics SL-1200MK2. Can anyone give me some info on 
these beautiful machines? Are they any different from other 1200s? Also; 
I have the tone arms balanced (set at 0) but I don't know what the 
correct stylus pressure should be (we have the Ortofon Concorde with the 
Night Club S stylus). The Ortofon spec sheet has an "Equivalent stylus 
tip mass" (at 0.5 mg). Is that the number I'm looking for?

 I also have no height for the stylus to adjust the tonearm height. Do I 
have to measure it myself or am I juist missing something here.

 Ever since my unexpected dance set at Burning Man this year I've been 
itching to spin more but too poor to really do it. But now!.....  :)
